HEADLINE: The Dance of the Cranes

 BODY:
Americans have learned to know two Bob Doles. One is the churlish partisan who can belittle as a "Democrat war" the struggle against Hitler in which his own right arm was shattered. Far more attractive is the other Bob Dole: the engaging Kansas Republican with an acerbic distaste for political cant.
Alas, it is Senator Churl who summoned a filibuster to delay or derail the Administration's economic stimulus legislation. President Clinton agreed yesterday to hear out legitimate objections -- but he was right to needle Senate Republicans, "who all have jobs," for blocking a job-creating program. 
 Because Democrats fell short of the 60 votes needed to end debate, the Senate can't act on the $16 billion package until it returns from spring recess on April 19 -- and probably can't act even then without caving in to Republican demands to shrink the already small package.
Mr. Dole as Senate minority leader thus denies a new Administration the chance it deserves to speed recovery and create jobs. Yet it is primarily politics, not principle, that drives this dance of the cranes, in which Republicans are preening for political advantage.
Senator Dole complains of inadequate consultation on a package larded with too much pork. There's something to this; the White House may well have mishandled legitimate questions about the relevance of $1.9 billion to make up shortfalls in college student aid programs and of a film on early Louisiana culture. But when asked what kind of compromise he seeks, Mr. Dole was frank: "Big one."
If anything, the stimulus package is too modest, given the weakness of the recovery. Yet Mr. Dole wants to scale down the package and, even worse, offset much of it by making cuts elsewhere, virtually guaranteeing that it will produce very little stimulus at all. He seems to be asking a Democratic President and a Democratic Congress to scupper the very program they were elected to carry out -- or else risk gridlock. It is the rightful role of the minority to oppose and criticize, but not to paralyze.
Senate rules permit unlimited debate, and on great occasions, dissenting lawmakers have resorted to filibusters, for good and bad causes. But to mount a filibuster so soon comes with particular ill grace from a defeated party in the early days of a new Administration. The American system, if it is to work, requires balance as well as checks; the majority has its rights as well as the minority.
In the hard reckoning that Senator Dole well understands, obstructionism for its own sake is often bad politics. For the most visible Republican in Washington to play a spoiler role can hurt his own cause even more than Mr. Clinton's. If the President's program is not given a reasonable chance to succeed, how can he be blamed for its failure?
Let's hope the other Senator Dole, refreshed by the recess, responds in better spirits to the President's offer to reach a productive compromise.

HEADLINE: Student Work Programs Take Us in the Wrong Direction

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a shocking March 27 editorial, "A Prudent Approach to Student Work," you declare, "There is much to recommend a New York State requirement" that high school students be required to work as a condition of receiving their high school diploma. 
 How wrong can you get? Child labor is a serious blemish on our country today. America stands alone among leading industrial countries in the vast proportion of teen-agers in our work force. In Western Europe, as well as in Japan and other leading industrial countries, there is virtually no child labor. Only in America among advanced countries are high school-age children widely employed. Only in our country are truancy laws so weakly enforced.
Here is a prime reason American kids are failing to keep pace in math and reading with their foreign contemporaries. Here is also a reason American unemployment continues tragically high despite recovery in growth of gross domestic product. Unemployed adults should have the jobs now taken by high schoolers.
On any given day in Milwaukee, 30 percent of high school students are not in school; most have jobs. Many of those who are in school sleep in class because they work nights. Wisconsin students are probably less delinquent in this regard than students in other states, including New York.
Wisconsin studies show that the earnings of this teen-age labor are not spent on the necessities to help families secure food, shelter and utilities. Less than 2 percent goes for such purposes. Where does this income go? It goes for what parents won't buy their kids: cigarettes, booze, garish clothes, videos and, yes, in too many cases, guns.
Instead of a work requirement for high school diplomas, we need to impose stiff fines on employers of high school-age kids.
America provides a brief school year and much too short a school day, along with shamefully weak enforcement of truancy laws. And now you champion a requirement that students must spend more time away from classrooms to earn a diploma.
A Labor Department study estimates that this country can have more than 20 million new high-tech, high-paid jobs in the next generation if our work force can qualify for them. It also finds that less than 2 percent of our young adults have the literacy and math qualifications.
If you persuade the New York State Regents to provide a work requirement, and other states follow, your state and our country's future is in big trouble.
 
WILLIAM PROXMIRE
Washington, March 28, 1993
The writer was Senator from Wisconsin from 1957 to 1988.

HEADLINE: Colleges Increase Student Fees Again, But at Lowest Percentage in Decades

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
The nation's leading colleges and universities have managed to hold next year's fees for tuition, room and board to their smallest average increase in two decades. But even at that, the increase at many institutions will outstrip the rate of inflation.
And Yale University will be the first to break a barrier that symbolizes the upward spiral in college costs. Next fall the university's total fees will come to $25,110 a year, or more than $100,000 for a four-year undergraduate career. 
 Costs will rise 5 percent to a little more than 6 percent at most of several dozen four-year public and private institutions surveyed by The New York Times. The Consumer Price Index rose 2.9 percent in 1992. In the current academic year, the average annual cost at a four-year public institution increased 11 percent from 1991-92, to $2,253, and 7 percent at four-year private colleges, to $8,879.
Public universities cite declining state aid as the principal force behind their tuition increases. Private institutions cite their mounting expenses in variety of areas -- from higher student aid to salaries and benefits for staff and faculty, from higher energy costs to the growing expenses of maintaining top-tier academic programs and libraries.
 
Harder for Students
 "There are some very legitimate reasons to raise tuition," said Kent Halstead, director of Research Associates of Washington, which produces a widely used index of the costs at colleges and universities. "Tuition doesn't cover a student's education in either the public or private sector."
Still, many experts warn that the increases are making it harder and harder for middle-class students to go to college. Students have demonstrated at several campuses to protest rising costs.
And admissions officers say many students are applying to more colleges than ever to find out which ones will offer the most generous financial aid.
"Students realize it's a buyer's market in college admissions, and that means that they are doing more shopping and a better job of shopping than they have done in the past," said Stanley E. Henderson, vice president of the American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers.
In announcing next year's increase in tuition to $18,630 from this year's $17,500 and its increase in room and board to $6,480 from $6,200, Yale noted that the total increase was the smallest in 20 years.
Howard R. Lamar, the university's acting president, spoke of "continuing efforts to restrain the growth of costs," and said Yale would keep moving in that direction while "committing the resources necessary to assure that all students who are admitted to Yale receive the aid they need throughout their undergraduate careers here."
For the next academic year, for example, the university plans to award $25.6 million in financial aid, a 13 percent increase over this year's $22.5 million financial aid budget.
At public institutions, the lingering effects of the recession have depressed contributions from state Legislatures to several universities.
The University of California, for example, expects to receive $1.7 billion for the 1993-94 academic year through state appropriations, down from $1.8 billion this academic year. The decline has prompted the University of California system to increase its tuition next year to $4,049 from $3,044. Room and board are expected to cost $6,103 next year, up from $5,761 this year.
"We have done everything we can do avoid cutting into academic programs," said Rick Malaspina, a spokesman for the University of California system, which has nine campuses. "So far, we have succeeded, but it has been struggle every year."
The story is similar in Texas. Hurt by a moribund economy that has led to smaller or flat appropriations from the State Legislature, the University of Texas system, after charging just four dollars for one credit hour for years, has steadily increased its tuition to its current level of $24 for one hour for in-state residents; next year, the rate goes to $26 under a formula that adds two dollars each year through the 1996-97 academic year.
 
Students Protest
 At public and private institutions alike, the increases have touched off debate, leading to protests from Syracuse University to the City University of New York to San Diego State. Stacey Leyton, president of the United States Students Association, a lobbying group that represents 3.5 million college students, said the institutions could not justify fee increases that were double the rate of inflation. And she noted that not all of the tuition increases went exclusively for a student's education but went instead to help finance construction of football stadiums and research laboratories.
But Lyn Hutton, the vice president and treasurer at Dartmouth College, said institutions were spending much more on labor, a component that accounts for a small part of the Consumer Price Index. A better measure is the Higher Education Price Index, which calculates the cost of salaries and compensation, library books and subscriptions and other expenses.
The index was designed by the Federal Government 30 years ago and is now maintained by the private Research Associates of Washington. Over the last 10 years, according to research by Harvard University, the compounded rate of the Consumer Price Index rose by 4.1 percent compared with 5.2 percent for the Higher Education Price Index, although several university officials say this is unlikely to quiet the criticism.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 10, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about college fee increases for the 1993-94 academic year referred incorrectly to student protests about them. Students at the City University of New York protested college expenses two years ago, not this year.

HEADLINE: Kazakhstan And Chevron Start Venture

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES

 BODY:
The Chevron Corporation and the Republic of Kazakhstan officially established a $20 billion joint oil venture yesterday that industry officials and analysts view as a a bellwether for other American oil companies wanting to do business in the former Soviet Union.
The 50-50 joint venture will generate modest revenues and profits for San Francisco-based Chevron in its first few years, analysts said. "In the long term it will add more than $1 a share in earnings," said Eugene Nowak, a senior oil analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. "This is a mega-venture." Chevron earned $1.57 billion, or $4.63 a share, in 1992. 
 Wall Street gave its blessing to yesterday's formal signing of the deal in Kazakhstan, pushing Chevron stock up $1 to close at $84.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Huge Undeveloped Resources
 The joint venture, which was agreed to last May but delayed twice, is the largest so far between a Western oil company and a former Soviet republic. Other American oil and gas producers have expressed interest in investing in the former Soviet Union, which has some huge but largely undeveloped fields. Many potential investors have, however, been waiting for Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States to open their doors to Western investment, as Kazakhstan apparently now has.
"It's certainly a bellwether deal" in the former Soviet Union, said David O'Reilly, Chevron's vice president of strategic planning. "The reason we were the first to close a big deal is that we started early. It took a lot of patience and perseverance by all parties."
The project is also the largest international deal for San Francisco-based Chevron in the last 20 years, following ventures in Saudi Arabia and Indonesia, Mr. O'Reilly said in a telephone interview from San Francisco.
The joint venture company, called Tengizchevroil, or TCO, will be owned by Tengizneftegaz, a subsidiary of Kazakhstan's national oil company, and the Chevron Overseas Company, a unit of Chevron's international exploration and production subsidiary.
Chevron will receive 20 percent of the income generated over the life of the project, while Kazakhstan will get the rest.
The joint venture will develop the huge Tengiz and Korolev oilfields on the northeastern coast of the Caspian Sea. The Tengiz field, one of the largest discovered in the last decade, is more than twice the size of the Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska.
 
Big Potential Is Seen
 TCO expects the Tengiz field to produce more than 700,000 barrels a day by 2010. The field, located in a barren region with a harsh climate, now produces about 65,000 barrels a day and is estimated to hold about 25 billion barrels of oil. About six billion to nine billion barrels can be recovered, Chevron said.
The venture plans to invest more than $1.5 billion to develop the field over three to five years. It also must build a pipeline to handle the increased production.
Mr. O'Reilly said the oil in the Tengiz field was high quality, but was fairly deep -- more than 10,000 feet underground -- and was under high pressure and contained sulfur. TCO's investment will include adding an unknown number of plants to process the oil and remove the sulfur.
Chevron, Russia and Kazakhstan have agreed that the oil from the Tengiz field can be transported through Russia to ports for export.
 
Payments to Government

 
 Under the financial terms of the 40-year venture, TCO will pay the Government of Kazakhstan bonuses, taxes and royalties and $50 million for regional development.
The agreement comes after more than five years of discussions about the project and could signal the willingness of former Soviet republics to allow Western companies to help develop natural resources and shore up their sagging economies with hard currency, analysts said.
"It's a sign to all parties that something like this can be developed," Mr. Nowak said.

HEADLINE: Big Bills Coming Due at H.U.D., Crimping Expansion of Programs

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Several old bills are coming due at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and the costs are frustrating the Clinton Administration's hopes of rapidly expanding Federal housing aid.
A combination of new laws, old decisions, deferred expenses, poor management, and the quirks of Federal accounting are forcing the department to seek tens of billions of dollars in expanded budget authority over the next few years just to house the families it is now assisting. 
 This reduces its ability to offer rent subsidies to the millions of families that qualify for aid but are forced to wait as long as a decade because of the lack of Government financing.
Only part of the ballooning ledger represents new annual expenses. A larger portion stems from bookkeeping rules that require the department to account in a single year for money that will be spent over several years.
But taken together, the numbers to be released Thursday when President Clinton offers his budget for the fiscal year 1994 present a gloomy fiscal forecast for Secretary Henry G. Cisneros. The bad news comes after 12 years in which Democrats promised to reverse Republican housing policies they blamed for homelessness and urban distress.
"Just to keep the same number of families housed continues to cost more money into the future," said Herb Persil, the department's budget director. "If you want to add additional families, that just adds to the problem."
The General Accounting Office, a Congressional arm not noted for its florid language, recently warned that the financial pressures "will only worsen an already dismal situation." Last summer, a Senate Appropriations subcommittee called the figures "staggering."
The sudden fiscal constraints come after two decades of worsening conditions for low-income renters. Though Federal housing assistance has been expanding, the number of needy renters has been growing even faster.
The department provides aid to about 4.5 million families, either through conventional public housing or programs that subsidize families living in private apartments.
But the department estimates that as many as 13 million more families qualify for housing assistance, which unlike cash welfare or food stamps is limited each year by Congressional appropriations.
And about 5.1 million of those families are considered to have "worst case needs." This means their annual household incomes fall below ceilings that, depending on the city, average about $19,000 for a family of four. In addition, these families live in "severely substandard" conditions or spend more than half their income on rent and utilities.
"The amount we need is far beyond what we're going to be able to get in the foreseeable future," said Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, a housing expert.
 
The Bookkeeping Problem
 Much of the budgetary concern centers on the department's Section 8 program, which provides subsidies to 2.7 million families living in private apartments. The families pay 30 percent of their income on rent, and the Government pays landlords an additional stipend, pegged to local housing costs.
When the program began in the mid-1970's, the Government financed it mostly through 15-year contracts, which have begun to expire in large numbers. Federal budgeting rules require that the entire multi-year cost of a contract be charged against the department's budget in the year it is renewed, although the money is actually spent over several years.
Five years ago, none of the department's budget authority went toward renewing old contracts. Now about $7 billion of H.U.D.'s $25 billion budget in the current fiscal year is allotted to the renewals, and the department expects that figure to grow to more than $15 billion by 1997. To reduce the cost of the contracts, H.U.D. has shortened their length to five years. As a result, the department will soon have to begin renewing its renewals.
Mr. Frank, among others, argues that such numbers are largely an accounting problem that exaggerates the situation. While H.U.D.'s budget authority will have to grow by leaps and bounds over the next few years to renew the contracts, the actual spending in any given year remains steady, rising only in rough step with inflation. "Can we find the budget authority? Yeah," he said.
But some housing experts take a different view, saying the need for budget authority throws H.U.D. into fierce competition with other, more popular agencies. "It's a major problem," said Cushing N. Dolbeare, a housing consultant and longtime advocate for low-income housing.
Under current law, the Government's overall budget authority is capped every year, meaning increases at H.U.D. must come from decreases elsewhere. The law expires in 1995, giving Congress the chance to write in new assumptions that account for the expiring contracts.
 
'Preserving' Cheap Housing
 A second area costing the Government large new sums involves what are called "preservation properties," referring to hundreds of thousands of apartments for low-income families built beginning in the late 1960's with Government-subsidized loans.
The programs gave developers the option of paying off their mortgages after 20 years, leaving them free to displace low-income renters and charge market rates. When it became clear by 1990 that many developers intended to do just that, Congress passed a law that barred owners from raising the rents. But it compensated them with new subsidies.
The result is that H.U.D. must spend hundreds of millions of dollars a year in new payments to landlords, simply to preserve the existing units as low income. H.U.D. forecasters have said the cost could reach $750 million next year; the Congressional Budget Office has said the program could cost the department $4 billion over the next three years.
A third area of concern involves the backlog of renovation needed in the nation's 1.4 million units of conventional public housing. Some of the apartments are now 50 years old, and they need significant repairs. About 100,000 are too decrepit for habitation.
In 1985, a consulting company hired by H.U.D. estimated it would cost $22 billion to bring the apartments into line with housing codes. Last year, the National Commission on Severely Distressed Public Housing, which was appointed by Congress, increased the estimate to $27 billion -- more than H.U.D.'s entire annual budget.
Repairing the units would bring sharp new annual costs. The transition report prepared for Mr. Cisneros emphasized the "significant gap" between the $5 billion a year that the commission said was needed, and the $3.1 billion now being spent. But without adequate repairs, more units are likely to fall vacant.
 
Costs of Foreclosed Property
 H.U.D. faces a fourth area of increased costs in its management of repossessed apartments whose owners have failed to pay insured mortgages. H.U.D. now manages 48,000 such apartments, which it is trying to resell to private owners. The transition report said the department would need to increase subsidies by $2 billion to make the apartments attractive to new investors, and it warned that poor management was "dramatically increasing holding costs."
The increased expenses come after two decades in which the number of needy families grew sharply because the incomes of the poorest workers have fallen while housing costs have risen.
Government assistance has continued to expand in the past decade, when it became a subject of great ideological strife, but the pace of expansion slowed. At the end of the 1970's, the Government was expanding assistance by about 300,000 families a year, a figure which fell to about 55,000 under the first Reagan budgets and grew to about 85,000 in the past several years.
Mr. Cisneros has said he would like to increase that number to about 100,000 families a year. But Ms. Dolbeare notes that at that pace it would take 51 years to house the 5.1 million families on the department's list of the most needy.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:
International A2-12
 
CLINTON SHIFTS GEARS ON BOSNIA
After coming into office proclaiming the need to take action against moral outrages in Bosnia, the Clinton Administration has shifted gears, and is now telling the American people that Bosnia is a quagmire about which very little can be done. A1
 
U.N. GENERAL ON THE MOVE
Resuming what has become a personal battle to save the besieged Muslim enclave of Srebrenica, the French commander of the United Nations force in Bosnia set out by road to return to the town before it is overrun by Serbian troops. A6
 

MACEDONIA APPROVED FOR U.N.
The Security Council finally approved United Nations membership for Macedonia after a compromise ended a yearlong controversy with Greece over its admission. A5

HEADLINE: To Crystal, 12, School Serves No Purpose

SERIES: Children of the Shadows: The third of ten lives of the city.

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Crystal Rossi wears two streaks of bright magenta in her hair. They hang, stains of Kool-Aid, down her loose, long strands of blond like a seventh grader's twist of punk: Don't come too close. Don't mess with me. Don't tell me what to do. I'm not like you.
At her Brooklyn public school, a kaleidoscope of teen-age rage, Crystal's teachers see a young girl with an attitude. They focus on her slouch, her Kool-Aid streaks, her grunge clothes and sullen anger and see all the signs of trouble. But those vivid slashes say the most, communicating a basic paradox of adolescence, the double-edged message: "bug off" and "LOOK AT ME." 
 This is the time, this tender age of 12, when every major decision on the treacherous road to adulthood looms. It is also the time, in the sixth and seventh grades, when some students start a long, slow fall away from school.
 
'The Classes Are Boring'
 On the surface, Crystal hardly seems the sort of child who would stumble.
Her family is stable. Her stepfather works. Her mother takes care of the home. Her father lives just blocks away. Her school is typical, chaotic, underfinanced and overcrowded, but it is clean and relatively safe.
But in a competition between the street and her Bensonhurst school, the street seems to be winning.
"The classes are boring!" Crystal exploded one afternoon. "And the teachers are mean!" Her eyes downcast, she complained that too much class time was spent on discipline. "They are always yelling," she said. "I wish they would all just shut up."
Her face to the world is one of toughness. But in fact she is a child trying to navigate a difficult and often lonely road. In a whisper one day, her head cast down and fingers playing across a desk top, she admitted that she was often nervous.
"Sometimes I can't even sleep," she said. "I stay up all night, and then I'm too tired to get up in the morning."
She rarely allows herself to express such vulnerability. Instead, she tends toward bravado; in a rare moment of exuberance she tells her mother that she is a "leader" who sets the pace in school. Her mother does not buy it. "No," her mother says as she shakes her head. "You are a follower."
Such deflations are consistent. What is absent is a quiet, steady voice of encouragement, a single figure to lead Crystal through the minefields of a childhood in Bensonhurst. Pressures abound, applied by teachers, parents and even friends, but Crystal seems without a touchstone to guide her and give her a sense of her potential.
At home, three other daughters occupy her mother's time and worry. Crystal's sister, Colette, 15, is failing the ninth grade. Her halfsisters, Candice, 5, and Jovan, 2, demand attention and dominate family life, especially when their dad comes home and lifts them in a warm embrace. Crystal, lonely and lackluster, hides in plain sight.
Crystal says she wants to be a lawyer. But she has never actually met a lawyer and is now flunking most of her classes. That career appeals because, she says, "you get to talk back to people" and "you make a lot of money."
Her teachers worry that she might not even make it to her high school graduation. They already see the signs. In class she ducks competition and is losing focus. Outside of school hers is a childhood of temptations and dangers: drugs, alcohol, gangs and older kids who linger on street corners wanting everything from sex to the coat off a 12-year-old's back.
There was a fleeting moment when Crystal's academic future seemed full of promise. Her 34-year-old mother, Colleen Ficalora, said Crystal was once slated for a kindergarten for gifted students, "but she would have had to take a bus." Now, in the seventh grade at the Joseph B. Cavallaro Junior High School in Bensonhurst, Crystal is often restless, angry and tuned out.
Mrs. Ficalora wants Crystal to break a family pattern. Not one of her own 14 brothers and sisters graduated from high school. Neither did she. Nor did Crystal's father or stepfather. If Crystal gets her diploma she will stand apart.
At school, some teachers are trying to help. But sitting in one class, a "resource room" tailored to give troubled students individual attention, Crystal slumped on her desk. "We just sit there," she said later. "They are supposed to help you with stuff you don't understand. But I understand everything so I just sit there."
"Kids who study are all nerds," she said dismissively. "Who'd want to be like that? Everybody makes fun of them."
But the kids make fun of one another for failing, too.
"Stooopid," Crystal taunted a friend in the resource room one morning.
"No, you're stupid, stupid," the girl retorted.
"No. You. You're stupid," Crystal shot back, her head resting on her desk top.
Most days, Crystal says, she is usually happy only at lunch, when she and her friends bend over pizza and sandwiches "just talking." The time brings them together, jostling and punching and trading stories of their day. Sometimes they vanish into a bathroom and plant thick lipstick kisses -- perfect O's -- on one another's foreheads. Their mark of solidarity against a world too often hostile.
 
The School
Clean Halls,
Crowded Classes
Of the 950 or so students at Cavallaro Junior High School on any given day, says Rose P. Molinelli, the principal, 300 or more are at risk of everything from dropping out to doping up to slashing their wrists and watching their lives literally drain right out of them. One of the school's seventh-grade classes last year had five suicide attempts. This year has been quieter, but the threats remain.
"You can walk out this door any afternoon and get hurt," Mrs. Molinelli said as she stooped on a busy stairwell to scoop up a bit of litter. Other pressures are subtler.
"The kids all know who is abused and who is having trouble at home and who is in a gang," Mrs. Molinelli said. "They know who gets high. They know who gets killed. It gets to them. I think all kids today are at risk. And parents are overwhelmed. A lot of kids get lost."
Three years ago Cavallaro, on 24th Avenue and Cropsey Avenue, was a place where gangs lurked in hallways and teachers lived in fear. Then Mrs. Molinelli came, the gangs were banished and a new sense of order was imposed. Today the halls are clean and orderly and, unlike the local high school where a metal detector was recently installed to screen out guns and knives, students can move about with a sense of ease and safety. A guard monitors everyone entering and leaving the building, and Mrs. Molinelli herself quizzes every child she finds wandering the hallways during class time.
Crystal glides through the environment as though untouched. When a fight breaks out in the hall, she slips around the corner. But privately, she whispers about the gangs, the kids who have been robbed or hurt or are threatened by bullies, and of friends with "troubles" at home.
"I know a kid who just got shot," she said starkly. "He got shot and he is dead."
Mrs. Molinelli changed the school hours -- ending the day a half-hour earlier -- to let her students out before the local high school students have a chance to victimize the younger children. Other problems are more intractable.
Classes run at or near their maximum of 30 children each, and teachers have to struggle just to keep order, much less provide individual attention. Budget cuts have whittled resources, and although Mrs. Molinelli says her teachers have come up with creative ways to compensate for the shortages, she knows the children could use more.
"We're on the edge," she said. "We're already on the edge and now they are talking about more funding cuts. Right now, we've only got one guidance counselor for 700 students. That's not enough."
Crystal's schedule includes one-on-one tutoring in a "rap class" where Cathy Searao, a school drug counselor, spends time talking with troubled students partly as a mentor and partly as a friend. Shrugging, embarrassed and monosyllabic, Crystal says she likes the program because there "the teacher really talks to you." One afternoon Ms. Searao taught Crystal and a friend how to develop film. It was the one moment in her school day when Crystal smiled. She shyly admits that she also enjoys science and a dance program she goes to after school.
Mrs. Molinelli would like to see more individualized programs in the school. But in the meantime, she fights cutbacks.
Crystal's mother wants more from the public school as well. "I feel like I try my hardest," she said, "but I still need someone there education-wise who can back me up."
 
The Home
Without a Beacon,
Losing Direction
Early on a wintry afternoon, teachers chatted about the bitter cold and a new problem it had spawned. Some students arrived in class wearing ski masks and it was scaring the staff stiff. A warning went out over the public-address system: Henceforth, ski masks were forbidden. It was too unnerving for the teachers not to be able to identify potential assailants.
In science, as a substitute teacher tried to teach the difference between fact and opinion, Crystal spent her time, lipstick in one hand, a mirror in the other, tracing steaks of red along her lips.
The toll of her inattention is already becoming all too clear. In the first semester, Crystal passed every major class but science. But as the school year progressed, she started drifting. In September Crystal made her way to class on time on every day but one. In January she was late 12 days out of 20.
Her mother says it is a constant battle just to get Crystal up and out. As she and her husband begin the day, the tone is set.
"I start trying to wake her up at 7 A.M.," Mrs. Ficalora said. "By 7:30, I am really screaming."
Crystal's February report card included a 65 in social studies. She failed English, math, science, foreign language and physical education. "We have already sent the family an 'at risk' letter," said Diane Costaglioli, the assistant principal in charge of the seventh grade. "She's on a decline."
At home, her mother tells her to do her homework but rarely checks, and her stepfather, Louie Ficolara, an electrician at ABC, rarely asks about it. But together they provide a raft of high-tech toys that keep Crystal occupied but unmotivated.
The basement room she shares with Colette has all the comforts -- and distractions -- of a fully equipped apartment. "Sometimes my mom punishes me by making me go to my room," Crystal said. "But that's O.K. We've got a television, a VCR, Nintendo, a radio, books, magazines, our own phone line and a bunch of other stuff down there."
Upstairs, there are distractions, too. The television comes on just after Crystal gets home at 3. It stays on well into the night.
Mrs. Ficalora complains that the family is not brought in to the school's daily rhythms. "We don't even have to see the homework," she said. "So we don't know what they're dealing with."
Somehow, though, there has been a breakdown in communication. Last fall, Crystal's school gave each student a homework planner that encouraged parents to be involved in each day's assignment. Crystal says she lost hers and her mother concedes that although she at times helps with homework, she usually is involved only at report-card time.
 
The Streets
A Neighborhood
Of Temptations
For Crystal, though, homework can seem almost quaint in a life that whirls through a landscape full of real and perceived dangers. Outside school, her world stretches from glass-strewn lots where friends drink and smash bottles against brick walls to street corners where gang members pick fights. Her friends are an ethnic stew of Italian-Americans, Puerto Ricans, blacks and immigrants -- a multiracial bond that in coming years may well be tested.
So far, though, they face their fears together. Temptations and highs lurk everywhere. Though Crystal says she has not yet tried marijuana, LSD or crack, she talks about such drugs the way children used to talk of trolls and ice cream cones. Like most of her friends, she has already sampled alcohol and cigarettes. Other temptations await. "Everybody drinks," she said with a knowing shrug. "They drink and do acid in the park."
 
A Poke, a Slap, a Punch
 Crystal knows the varied routes to dropping out. But they do not scare her. "They hang out," she said of the students who leave school. "They do weed. They drink. They do acid. Everybody knows what they are doing."
Sex looms, too. So far, boys don't seem to be her problem. Her mother prohibits her from dating. But Crystal points out coolly, "When I'm out there you don't know where I am." Crystal's mother assumes that her 12-year-old can take care of herself. "I let her know that she has an independence," she said.
Yet just surviving is a constant struggle. Teachers, the police and parents say they are often stunned by the casualness of the violence both inside and outside school. Hallways are full of a steady stream of students who sniffle that a friend has hit or kicked them. Students are called from class for fighting. Friends poke, trip and slap.
On the streets, fights start over nothing. Many boys link up with gangs. Crystal lists their names, neighborhood by neighborhood, including two for girls, Bitches on a Mission, and the Five Million Hoodlums, to which some of her friends belong. "They can protect you," Crystal said somewhat admiringly. "They can keep you safe."
But it is toward her sister Colette that Crystal most often turns for protection. "She watches out for me," she said. "If somebody bothers me, she sends people after them."
Colette may be failing, but she has another quality that Crystal values far more than grades. She is the one older person who always listens -- and never punishes.
Still, anxiety pervades. "I'm always nervous," she said quietly one day at school, her head cast down, her hands clasps tightly between her legs. "I get nervous over nothing. And then I'll get a really big headache."
One moment of ease comes in the minutes between school and life after school. When the last bell rings, Crystal and her friends linger outside the building to remind one another that they care. Linking arms and passing gum and cigarettes around, they laugh and poke and share their secrets, their fears, their triumphs. Then they reach forward, one to the next, to kiss, almost somberly, and wish one another well.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1079 words

HEADLINE: CUOMO ANNOUNCES HE IS NOT SEEKING SEAT ON HIGH COURT

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 7

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he had asked President Clinton to remove him from consideration for an appointment to the United States Supreme Court, saying he wished to continue serving New York while the state was on the cusp of economic recovery.
Many in the Cuomo administration interpreted the Governor's announcement as a virtual declaration that he will run for a fourth four-year term next year. Mr. Cuomo said in an interview today that he was preparing aggressively for a 1994 campaign but was not ready to make a declaration. 
 The Democratic Governor, who declined to run for President in both 1988 and 1992 after long flirtations, released a letter that he wrote to Mr. Clinton today confirming a telephone conversation the two men had Thursday night. The substance of the conversation first was reported in Newsday today.
 
'Public Speculation'
 "I do not know whether you might indeed have nominated me, but because there has been public speculation concerning the possibility, I think I owe it to you to make clear now that I do not wish to be considered," Mr. Cuomo wrote.
White House officials said today that Mr. Cuomo had been under serious consideration for the seat being vacated this summer by Justice Byron R. White. And the 60-year-old Governor said no indications to the contrary had prompted his decision to withdraw.
"I had no sense that it would not be me," Mr. Cuomo said in the interview. "I will not tell you that it was offered. I will tell you I had no sense that I had been eliminated."
 
'Considerable Expectation'
 A senior White House official who requested anonymity said Mr. Cuomo "took himself out of consideration at a time when he had a considerable expectation that he would be chosen, although it wasn't a lay-down hand."
Another senior Clinton Administration official said that "nobody urged him to withdraw."
Many officials in both Washington and Albany said they were mystified by Mr. Cuomo's decision, given his affection for the law, his frequent musings about his desire to be a judge and his long tenure as Governor.
That confusion quickly gave way to speculation that Mr. Cuomo may have withdrawn his name pre-emptively after learning that he was unlikely to receive the nomination. Some also wondered whether the Governor had agreed to withdraw so that Mr. Clinton could name a woman or a minority judge as his first appointee, with the understanding that Mr. Cuomo would receive a later appointment.
Mr. Cuomo declined to rule out the possibility that he would consider a future Supreme Court opening.
"I haven't thought beyond this letter or this conversation," he said.
Mr. Cuomo used his letter today to put in a plug for Judith S. Kaye, who he nominated in February as Chief Judge of the New York Court of Appeals and who apparently remains a contender for the Supreme Court.
White House officials said today that other contenders include Judge Stephen G. Breyer of the United States Court of Appeals in Boston, Judge Jose A. Cabranes of the United States District Court in Connecticut, Judge Amalya L. Kearse of the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan and Judge Patricia Wald of the United States Court of Appeals in Washington.
 
'Down the Road'
 The officials said Mr. Clinton was still two to three weeks away from announcing a selection. They also said he was trying to think in terms of several appointees in case Justice Harry A. Blackmun, who is 84, or Justice John Paul Stevens, who turns 73 this month, decide to retire soon.
"We're trying to think down the road," one White House official said.
Since Justice White announced two weeks ago that he planned to retire, much of the speculation about whom Mr. Clinton would name as his first appointee to the Supreme Court has focused on Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Cuomo was the only person mentioned by the President as a prospective justice during the 1992 campaign, and he has been described as a leading contender in a number of news reports during the last week.
Aides to both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Cuomo said White House officials had held preliminary discussions about the possibility of naming the Governor to the Court with Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son and Mr. Clinton's nominee to be an assistant secretary of Housing and Urban Development. On Monday, March 29, Mr. Clinton tried to contact Mr. Cuomo to discuss the Court, but the Governor missed the call. A number of other missed calls followed over the next two days.
Mr. Cuomo finally reached Mr. Clinton Thursday night, when the President was flying to Oregon for a conference on the Northwest forest.
Neither the Governor nor the President disclosed the content of the conversation today, but aides to both men said Mr. Cuomo removed himself from consideration shortly after the discussion began.
In his letter to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Cuomo wrote, "Although New York is on its way back, it has not yet fully recovered from the punishing national economic decline which you are trying so hard to reverse. I believe I can best serve by working to speed and strengthen that recovery in this state that has been so good to me and my family."
But several Cuomo aides speculated that his decision had more to do with the changes in political and personal life style that he would have to make by moving from from the Governor's office in Albany to the Supreme Court in Washington.
 
Difference in Pay
 The Supreme Court position pays $164,100 a year, more than the $130,000 Mr. Cuomo receives as Governor. But he would have to move from the richly furnished Executive Mansion, where he lives for free, to take a job with no housing allowance.
One friend of Mr. Cuomo who has talked to him about the Supreme Court said the Governor believes his current job is "better than being on the Supreme Court, to be one of nine, to be curtailed in terms of speech.
"He doesn't need the power, and he doesn't need the prestige and he doesn't need the robe."
And a Cuomo aide said the Governor "would look at the Supreme Court as a postscript to a career, and he's not ready for the postscript."
That aide said Mr. Cuomo's decision today "just about" serves as a re-election announcement.
But Mr. Cuomo would not give away his plans. "I would be surprised to hear anybody in my administration say that because that would mean they don't know a whole lot about me," he said today. "If I wanted to make a declaration that I was running in 1994, I would make it."

HEADLINE: Bosnia Reconsidered;
Where Candidate Clinton Saw a Challenge The President Sees an Insoluble Quagmire

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
After coming into office proclaiming the need to take action against moral outrages in Bosnia, the Clinton Administration has shifted gears, and is now telling the American people that Bosnia is a quagmire about which very little can be done.
In effect, the Administration has gone from shaking its fist at the Serbs to throwing up its hands. And it has gone from describing Bosnia as a test case of America's ability to nurture democracy in the post-cold-war world to being the intractable "problem from hell" that no one can be expected to solve. 
 Administration policymakers vigorously deny that they have given up trying to press the Serbs into making concessions to the Bosnian Muslims, and insist that they are now working on lifting the arms embargo to give the Muslims more of a fighting chance.
 
A Revised Perception
 But they also concede that they have begun to talk about Bosnia differently, to cast the problem there less as a moral tragedy -- which would make American inaction immoral -- and more as a tribal feud that no outsider could hope to settle.
The reason for this political redefinition goes back to the Presidential campaign, when Mr. Clinton used the Bosnia issue to differentiate himself from President Bush in foreign policy, and to put Mr. Bush on the defensive. Mr. Clinton lambasted Mr. Bush for passivity toward Bosnia's fate and for dumping the problem in the lap of the Europeans.
 
Little Support for Intervention
 But since coming into office, Clinton Administration officials have learned just how complex the Bosnia issue really is. The Europeans and Russians are woefully divided on what to do there; all polls show that the American public has no desire to send its sons and daughters to fight there, and the Pentagon resists getting involved in military action on the ground there.
At a time when the President's support for homosexuals in the armed services and his own lack of military experience have injured his credibility with some at the Pentagon, he clearly does not want to challenge the generals on Bosnia. And at a time when he is absorbed at home in the difficult effort to build support for his economic and health care programs, he cannot afford to have the nation's attention diverted and divided by debate over intervention in the Balkans.
But Mr. Clinton also does not want to look as though he is going back on another campaign pledge. Hence, the Administration is setting out to redefine for Americans the nature of the Bosnian problem in a way that makes its limited involvement there look like understandable prudence rather than moral indifference.
When the President's aides are asked what Mr. Clinton really thinks about the Bosnian situation, they say that no foreign issue troubles and frustrates him more, but he is adamant about not letting his emotions dictate policy.
The first sign of the Administration's new tone on Bosnia came on March 28, when Secretary of State Warren Christopher, appearing on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," was asked what Washington would do if the Serbs did not sign the peace agreement.
In a remark that aides said Mr. Christopher rehearsed in advance, he depicted the conflict as the re-emergence of ancient European tribal feuds. "Let me put that situation in Bosnia in just a little broader framework," he said. "It's really a tragic problem. The hatred between all three groups -- the Bosnians and the Serbs and the Croatians -- is almost unbelievable. It's almost terrifying, and it's centuries old. That really is a problem from hell. And I think that the United States is doing all we can to try to deal with that problem."
But he added, "The United States simply doesn't have the means to make people in that region of the world like each other."
Contrast that with Mr. Christopher's statement on Feb. 10, when he first unveiled the Clinton Administration's Bosnia policy by describing the conflict as the destruction of one people by another. "Serbian ethnic cleansing has been pursued through mass murders, systematic beatings, and the rapes of Muslims and others, prolonged shellings of innocents in Sarajevo and elsewhere, forced displacement of entire villages, inhumane treatment of prisoners in detention camps," he said.
Mr. Christopher added at the time that how Washington responded to the crisis in Bosnia "tests our commitment to nurturing of democracy and the support of environments in which democracy can grow and take root."
"And it tests what wisdom we have gathered from this bloody century, and it measures our resolve to take early concerted action against systematic ethnic persecution," he added.
By altering the definition of what was happening in Bosnia, Mr. Christopher was trying to change the stakes. What had been an outrage that was immoral to stand by and watch became a Balkan feud that was simply "terrifying" to watch.
President Clinton himself reinforced this view on Tuesday during his joint news conference with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. He declared, in effect, that the United States was not ready to act with force on its own in Bosnia, that the Europeans were ready to do even less and that therefore it was quite possible that the Serbs would get away with their aggression.
Asked what more could be done by the United States and Europeans on Bosnia, Mr. Clinton said: "It is a difficult situation. It is the most difficult and most frustrating problem in the world today. The only point I was trying to make is I have proceeded all along on the assumption that whatever we did and whatever we could do, we would and should act through the United Nations in a multilateral way."
The President insisted that he had done his "best to continue to stiffen the sanctions, to continue to push for more action, to push for enforcement of the no-fly zone, to push all the countries involved to do what we could to try to bring this to a successful conclusion, so that the principle of ethnic cleansing is not rewarded in Bosnia and therefore encouraged in other countries."
But he added: "The United States is not capable of solving the problem alone. I don't think anyone expects us to do that. We have been in many cases more aggressive in what we were willing to do than the European neighbors of the former Yugoslavia."
If the Europeans will not follow, Mr. Clinton suggested, then it is impossible for Washington to lead. He then cited the Persian Gulf war coalition as an example of the cooperation that is required. But it was precisely the Bush Administration's willingness to draw a line in the sand, and commit its own manpower first, that brought the Europeans along behind it in the gulf war. In Bosnia, Mr. Clinton is suggesting that if the Europeans will not follow, America cannot lead.
Asked if this gridlock might not allow the Serbs to get their way, as long as they can withstand economic sanctions, Mr. Clinton answered: "That is what I am concerned about. You got it. That's about as good a statement as I could have made myself."
 
Balkan Update
 The United Nations commander in BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA, Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon of France, led a convoy of armored vehicles yesterday to the besieged Muslim enclave of SREBRENICA, carrying needed food and medical supplies. General Morillon told aides he would remain there to insure the survival of the town and its 60,000 residents. Some 150 Canadian troops are also enroute to Srebrenica, and a convoy was planned today to evacuate wounded, sick and needy people.
In BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, the Russian envoy, Vitaly Churkin met with President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia on what the Yugoslav news agency Tanyug called "a new Russian initiative toward resolving the conflict" in Bosnia. He also met with the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic.
The United States and its NATO allies meeting in BRUSSELS delayed giving the final go-ahead to military plans for enforcing a United Nations-authorized ban on flights over Bosnia because of last-minute French concerns. But ambassadors of the 16 nations of NATO said the alliance's warplanes would start the operation by the middle of next week. European warplanes began arriving in ITALY in preparation for enforcing the ban.
At the UNITED NATIONS in New York, MACEDONIA was approved for membership by the Security Council after months of haggling with Greece over the symbolism of the former Yugoslav republic's name.
Moving with unusual speed, the World Court in THE HAGUE said it would rule today on the Bosnian Muslims' request for emergency protection from what they say is Serbian genocide.

HEADLINE: U.S. Oil Loan for Russia Faces Dispute and Delay

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
A White House plan to assemble $2 billion in Federal loans to the Russian oil and gas industry by next Wednesday is unrealistic, American and international financial officials said today.
For a year and a half, the deal has been mired in divisions within the Russian Government and in a squabble pitting the United States against the World Bank. Some of the difficulties have been resolved, but Russia will not receive any money until later this year, a World Bank official said today. 
 An American official said that while an agreement for the loans might be signed soon for symbolic purposes, it would be "the icing on the cake, without the cake." Both officials insisted on anonymity.
A White House summary of the assistance program, released after the meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia, last weekend between President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, included a "push for completion by April 14" of the loan arrangement. But the loan was not included in a $1.6 billion assistance package for Russia announced on Sunday because of uncertainty that the loan's major details could be arranged quickly.
The Export-Import Bank of the United States, a Federal agency that finances some American exports, has been trying to lend the money since September 1991.
On Dec. 18, Eugene K. Lawson, who was the bank's acting chairman until January, held a news conference and announced that an agreement to make the loans was imminent. This never happened.
 
An Elusive Commitment
 "Having announced it about 15 dozen times that we were about to have this, it keeps seeming to elude us," Mr. Lawson said.
The loans would pay for the purchase of American oil- and gas-production equipment and parts. A lack of spare parts has idled 36,000 oil wells in Russia, a fifth of the country's total, and eroded its ability to earn convertible foreign currency to pay for imports and for some of the costs of economic change.
The loans would be repaid with the proceeds from the Russian oil and gas exports. To assure repayment and to limit the chances for corruption, the proceeds would go into a special offshore account that Moscow would not be able to tap for any other purpose.
But the arrangement encountered two obstacles. First, the World Bank has barred its debtors from setting up offshore accounts because the bank insists on being the senior creditor in exchange for its not requiring any collateral for its loans. Also, some factions in the Russian Government oppose the accounts as an insult to the nation's sovereignty.
"They didn't want to be treated like Nigeria; they wanted to be treated like a great power." said Mr. Lawson, who is now the president of the United States-Russia Business Council, a Washington trade association for companies trading with Russia.
Last week, the World Bank's executive board decided to allow waivers for offshore accounts, provided that countries being granted waivers demonstrated clear need, and had an acceptable economic recovery program in place or nearly so.
But the World Bank has not yet decided what constitutes an acceptable economic program. Its own loan provisions require that a country meet stiff targets for reducing budget deficits and curbing growth in the money supply.
 
Bureaucracy Sets In
 Russia has not been meeting these goals and on top of that, suffers from extremely high inflation.
The Russians have not yet applied for a waiver, which, though a formality, would take a few weeks to review, a World Bank official said. "Nothing here happens in a few days," the official added, emphasizing that the April 14 deadline was unrealistic as a result.
Once a waiver is granted, the bank still extensively reviews each sale by producers of American drilling equipment before actually lending money. This can take several months.
In a separate matter, the Ex-Im Bank announced on Monday that it had approved an $82 million loan to Gazprom, Russia's natural gas production and distribution enterprise. The deal, which does not rely on an offshore account, calls for Gazprom to buy pipeline-construction equipment from Caterpillar Inc. The transaction was set up last year, before Moscow began defaulting on grain-purchase loans guaranteed by the Agriculture Department.

HEADLINE: White House Trying to Trim Blocked Jobs Bill, Aides Say

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Acknowledging that it has failed to win over any of the Senate Republicans who are blocking President Clinton's $19.5 billion economic stimulus plan, the White House is working on significantly scaling it back, senior Administration officials said today.
While no decision has been made on how much the plan could be cut, several proposals have been recommended to the White House, from a Republican suggestion to halve the plan and eliminate spending on community development, to a Democratic plan to delay putting it into effect. 
 Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, one of a group of conservative Democrats whose support is crucial to the President's budget, sent a compromise to the White House today that would trim the spending package by 25 percent and delay the implementation of another part of it.
The Administration aides conceded that Mr. Clinton's chances of peeling off the three Republican votes he needs to end a nine-day filibuster in the Senate grew dimmer today. They said the White House had concluded that the plan Mr. Clinton presented to the Senate would have to be significantly changed if it was to survive.
"We are having direct discussions with the Republican senators who have a particular interest in this jobs program that has a direct impact on their state," said Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff.
 
Clinton Strategy Defended
 George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said it was not necessarily inconsistent for the President to step up his attacks on the Republicans blocking the plan while backing away from the package he originally proposed.
"He's going to fight for as much of this program as he can get," Mr. Stephanopoulos said of the President's actions. "At the same time, if adjustments are needed to allow for a debate and vote on the President's package, he is willing to consider those adjustments."
The White House has targeted three Republican Senators -- Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, James M. Jeffords of Vermont and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania -- for special wooing after the Senate's two-week recess, which began Monday. But there was no sign that any were willing to give ground.
"I will listen to anything," Senator D'Amato said today. But he added, "I certainly can't go along with the package, nor will I, as it is."
 
'Genuine Stimulus' Needed
 Senator Jeffords, a moderate, saidthe White House would have to demonstrate its interest in "genuine stimulus and job creation" before he considers breaking ranks.
But he also said his standards for what can be defined as genuine remains high. He said he would support spending for unemployment compensation, highway construction, summer jobs and child immunization, but not at the level Mr. Clinton recommended.
The $19.5 billion job stimulus bill is made up of about $4 billion for the extension of unemployment benefits, $2 billion for education grants, $6 billion in spending for highways and public improvements and $2 billion for summer jobs. The Republicans have been especially critical of $2.5 billion in proposed community development block grant spending, which they say would pay for some pork barrel projects.
An additional $3.2 billion of the package is money that has been authorized -- but never spent -- for improving roads and airports.
"We may not get 100 percent of everything we're trying to do in every area," Mr. Clinton said today, "but I do think the American people will see that the focus of all of this is to guarantee a healthy economy and a growing jobs market to try to turn this around."
Even as work began on cutting back the program, the President stepped up his attacks on the Republicans who are blocking it. He used a routine bill-signing ceremony to liken the economic recovery to "a fire starving for oxygen," and emphasized those parts of the package that would provide summer jobs and promote highway construction.
 
'We Know What Works'
 "In my view, the message of the last election was to break the gridlock and grow the economy because Americans are tired of a system that doesn't work and a recovery that doesn't produce new jobs," Mr. Clinton said at the ceremony. "We know what works. We'll only be able to reduce the deficit and increase investment in the long term if we guarantee the strength of the recovery by building jobs in the short run."
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that he had been distracted by international concerns in recent weeks and had to refocus his attention on the task of justifying the new spending he proposes as a strategy to create new jobs. He has clearly decided to take primary responsibility for selling the rest of his economic program.
Members of the President's own party have been critical, however, signaling that he cannot afford to sell his program on oratory alone. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York said in an interview that the Administration badly misjudged both the mood of the Senate and the mood of the country when it tried to push the job-stimulus package intact. "They sent up a bill filled with dogs," he said.
But Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, who has been managing the bill on the Senate floor, chastised his colleagues for pre-empting Mr. Clinton's negotiating opportunities.
"I don't think we ought to be rushing out with options of our own and taking away from the President his flexibility, his running room, his options," Senator Byrd said in an interview. "I think he ought to be allowed to decide what about his package ought to be negotiated, what should be negotiated."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Private Mortgage Insurers Are Facing New Competitor

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Private mortgage insurers are facing competition from a new company, the Amerin Guaranty Corporation, which has pared costs sharply on policies that protect mortgage lenders if homeowners default, and charges premiums that are tax deductible to homeowners.
Amerin officials contend that their product is priced about 20 percent below similar policies offered by the four companies that now dominate the private mortgage-insurance market. Norwest Mortgage, one of the nation's largest mortgage lenders, signaled its approval yesterday and began offering Amerin insurance along with other kinds of policies through its 467 offices around the country.
 
 
Low-Income Borrowers
 Mortgage insurance is required by government agencies and most investors when a mortgage is 80 percent or more of a home's purchase price. Such policies were written for more than a million of the 7.4 million mortgages issued last year. The insurance and its cost are particularly important to banks that are trying to increase their lending to low-income families, which tend to make small down payments. 
 By offering lower-cost insurance, Gerald L. Friedman, founder and chairman of Amerin, which is based in Chicago, said it was "inevitable that part of the savings will eventually be passed on" to home buyers. Rather than holding all of the larger profit margin, he expects lenders to share some of it with home buyers in order to attract more business.
Because lenders can fatten their profit margins with Amerin mortgage insurance, Mr. Friedman expects to garner 10 percent to 15 percent of the market within thee years.
To create the savings that might be passed on, Mr. Friedman and Stuart Brafman, Amerin's president, have created a company with fewer than 35 employees; the number is not expected to rise much above 60, even if Amerin grows rapidly in coming years.
Rather than build a network of 20 or 30 branch offices and a thousand or more sales representatives, Amerin makes its sales pitch at the headquarters of mortgage lenders, not their branch offices. It also economizes by leaving the underwriting, or credit-checking part of the mortgage lending process, to the lenders.
For lenders whose record and procedures meet Amerin's standards, it agrees to insure the loans they issue without conducting its own review. To encourage lenders to keep their standards high, Amerin will lower premiums for those lenders whose loans result in fewer than normal claims and increase premiums for those whose claims are high.
"The mortgage origination system is the largest capital market in America," Mr. Friedman said, "and the last part of that delivery system to change has been private mortgage insurance."
 
 
Tax Considerations
 For home buyers, the Amerin insurance is attractive because the annual insurance premiums -- roughly four-tenths of 1 percent of the mortgage amount -- are part of the monthly mortgage payment, the interest of which is deductible from a taxpayer's income. The premiums are part of the mortgage because the insurance policy is bought by the lender, who adds the cost to the interest rate on the mortgage. Amerin says its tax advisers have assured it that mortgage interest payments that include the insurance are deductible.
With other companies, premiums are paid by the homeowner to an escrow account and are not deductible.
Amerin's business plan was promising enough to attract several blue-chip investors, who have agreed to invest an initial $200 million. Morgan Stanley & Company, which started as an adviser to Mr. Friedman, decided to sign on as an investor, and was joined by J. P. Morgan, Aetna Insurance and the pension funds of A.T.& T. and General Motors.

HEADLINE: Shuttles Profit Despite Fewer Fares

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Like the aerial acrobatics of hummingbirds, which seem to defy the laws of aerodynamics, the shuttle operations of Delta Air Lines and USAir seem to fly in the face of airline economics. Despite falling ridership, the hourly flights between New York and Boston and New York and Washington continue to make money for the otherwise money-losing carriers, leading some industry analysts to nickname them Anomalous Air.
Their profitability stems in large part from the seeming immunity of the shuttles to the fare wars that have ruined margins in most other parts of the airlines' domestic service. The ability of the shuttles to continue raising prices -- one-way fares from New York to Washington are now $138 -- was probably a consideration in Delta's promise last week to upgrade planes on these flights even while curtailing service elsewhere in the country as part of a sweeping cutback.
 
A 32-Year Run May Be Ending
 But some analysts suggest the shuttles' days of coining money may be coming to an end, 32 years after Eastern Airlines started the service in the busy Northeast Corridor. Even airline executives foresee an end to what has been the shuttle's defining characteristics -- namely, hourly service throughout the day and a seat for everyone who shows up at the gate. 
 The various gloomy assessments assume the continued fragmentation of air traffic within the corridor. Other airlines have offered flights in the corridor to take advantage of its heavy flow of business travelers, who are less sensitive to fare increases than leisure travelers. That eroded shuttle traffic to fewer than 3 million last year, from almost 4.4 million passengers in 1987.
Amtrak is also expected to continue to siphon passengers from the shuttle, as it has between New York and Washington. The fare on the 17 daily Metroliners on that route, advertised as the Civilized Shuttle, is $90 one way. Amtrak fares have been 30 to 40 percent lower than air fares "since time immemorial," according to a spokesman for the railroad.
"And if they ever get the high-speed train from Boston to New York, one day the shuttle as people know it may go bye-bye," said Gordon Linkon, president and chief executive of USAir Shuttle. "It won't pay to fly those routes every hour or half-hour."
Amtrak, it turns out, is experimenting with just such a train, the X2000, and is also in the process of extending electrified rails from New Haven to Boston.
"We anticipate completion in 1997," said Clifford Black, an Amtrak spokesman, "and then the run between New York and Boston will fall from four hours to less than three, and our current fastest New York-to-Washington train will fall from 2 hours 35 minutes to 2:15. We've been slowly taking customers from planes for 15 years, but then we'll take even more of them."
 
Amtrak Share Gaining
 Last year Amtrak carried 42.8 percent of the 3.5 million total air and rail passengers between New York and Washington -- up from 37.2 percent in 1990, according to the Department of Transportation. While Amtrak's share between New York and Boston was only 20.9 percent, even that was up from 17.3 percent in 1990.
The shuttle has also suffered at the hands of other carriers. For example, while Delta and USAir fly a total of 31 daily shuttle flights between Washington National Airport and La Guardia Airport, Trans World Airlines and American Eagle, the subsidiary of American Airlines, fly a total of 21 daily nonstops between Washington National and Kennedy International Airport. In addition, Continental flies 12 daily nonstops between Washington and Newark International Airport.
Similarly, Delta and USAir fly 33 daily nonstops between Boston and La Guardia, while T.W.A. and American Eagle fly 22 between Boston and Kennedy. Continental flies 17 daily nonstops between Boston and Newark.
While fares for those flights are about the same as for the shuttle, for an unrestricted coach seat, an array of promotional fares can lower a one-way ticket to below $80.
 
Stimulating Air Traffic
 With so many promotional fares and airports to choose from, the nonshuttle flights probably help stimulate air traffic in the corridor, analysts say, or at least keep it from eroding further. But some of that traffic appears to be derived from would-be shuttle passengers who find Kennedy or Newark more convenient, or who prefer nonshuttle flights for other reasons.
For example, at Delta's shuttle gate at La Guardia one recent evening, two Washington-bound passengers, Stephanie Brzozowski and Allyson Deane, who sell advertising for PC magazine, said some co-workers flew American Eagle to Washington partly because they preferred American Airlines for its frequent flier program.
Nevertheless, "The shuttle has been very successful since we began operating it in 1991," said Neil Monroe, a spokesman for Delta, which bought it from Pan Am during that carrier's death throes.
The shuttle had been consistently profitable for Pan Am, even when that carrier's other routes were losing millions. "We started it in October 1986 and from Day 1 we had 24 percent of the market," said Jeff Kriendler, a former Pan Am official. "We become profitable within the first year of operation."
Pan Am's market share eventually averaged between between 56 and 60 percent, while Delta's share currently is about 52 percent.
 
The Old Days
 Eastern enjoyed a 100 percent market share for 20 years, until New York Air started a competing shuttle in 1981. It operated until 1986, when New York Air's corporate parent, the Texas Air Corporation, bought Eastern. After the Justice Department announced that it would begin investigating the merger's effect on competition, Pan Am bought New York Air's slots and gates for $65 million.
When Eastern subsequently fell on hard financial times, Donald J. Trump bought its shuttle for $350 million in 1989. But ownership of the renamed Trump Shuttle had to be transferred to a group of banks when the Trump Organization stopped paying interest on the debt. USAir paid $16.2 million to manage and operate the shuttle for four and a half years, with an option to buy.
Mr. Linkon of USAir acknowledges that "it's tough, very tough to make money in this market," because "what was once a single-carrier money tree has been divided between two carriers." But speaking of the owners of the USAir Shuttle, he said, "They're getting more than their money's worth."
The shuttle operation remains profitable, analysts say, because despite occasional price wars, Delta and USAir are careful not to try filling seats by offering money-losing fares, as most of the industry did last summer. While both carriers offer discounted advance purchase fares, as well as cheaper weekend and child fares, the usual one-way walk-up fare ranges from $138 to $150.
 
Price Not a Factor
 The current shuttle operators believe, as did the shuttle operators before them, that most business travelers -- who make up 80 percent of their passengers -- are relatively unconcerned about prices. "I wish I could tell you that at $99 fares our traffic was a little better," Mr. Linkon said, "but when it went up to $119 two weeks later there was no difference. And it was about the same when it went to $150." If the fare went up to $200 it might be a different story, he said, "But I'm not planning to find out."
Where lower fares do make a big difference, Mr. Linkon said, is with leisure travelers. Fares are as low as $39 for children accompanied by an adult. "By lowering those fares," Mr. Linkon said, "we have in essence doubled the number of minor children on our flights."
The competition between Delta and USAir has been through enhancements and services, although each usually quickly matches the other. At various times, they have both offered as many as 6,000 frequent flier miles for a 400-mile round trip. For a nominal price Delta offers helicopter service from Manhattan while USAir offers limousine service. USAir offers assigned seats, and last year it removed up to nine seats in each of its planes to give passengers the same leg room as Delta's. Delta recently said it would replace its shuttle fleet with newer renovated planes.
One notable amenity, allowing passengers to pay on board the hourlong flights, fell victim to the time constraints on flight attendants, who have time only to serve snacks or modest meals.
An improving economy is likely to put more business travelers on shuttle flights, at least initially, but some analysts are pessimistic about the long-range outlook. George Pearson, president of Avitas, an airline consulting firm in Reston, Va., acknowledged that the shuttles were probably making money with their current fares and load factors (that is, percentage of seats filled) in the low 50 percent range.
"But what happens," he asked, "if load factors continue to deteriorate or the carriers have to lower fares to remain competitive?"
