HEADLINE: A Volley of Airline News Raises Industry Stocks

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Bulls woke to the sound of planes booming overhead yesterday, and apparently liked what they heard.
Companies in the long-sputtering airline industry issued a number of announcements that spurred a broad rally in stocks. The Standard & Poor's airline index reached a 52-week high, while the Dow Jones transportation average surged to a record. [Page D8.] 
 Most noteworthy was an unexpectedly large jump in domestic passenger traffic in March, which is seen by many as suggesting a healthy economic rebound and possible profits for the beleaguered industry this summer. Some airline executives said that bookings for the coming months were very strong.
So after roughly five years of virtually no growth in the industry, "we now have a classic cyclical recovery in traffic," said Julius Maldutis, airline analyst at Salomon Brothers. He estimated March domestic traffic up 4.2 percent, and 6 percent when adjusted for the effects of the Northeastern blizzard that canceled thousands of flights.
The airlines still face fundamental problems to be addressed by a commission that was formally authorized yesterday by President Clinton. The panel is to develop a plan for revitalizing the industry. Mr. Clinton said that answers might "lie in a more aggressive trade policy, others may come from keeping the global marketplace freer from unfair competition, more may stem from the supporting role of aviation in preserving our national security."
 
A Convergence of Hopes
 Like the President's signature, many of yesterday's events were not unexpected. But the din of positive announcements seems to have impressed airline watchers. Most of the fragmented news items pointed to greater efficiency. "We're seeing the beginning of a lot of restructuring that will force inefficient capacity out," said Kevin Murphy, airline analyst at Morgan Stanley.
For example, United Airlines said it had converted firm orders into options for 49 Boeing planes as part of plan to slash capital spending by $5.5 billion through 1996. The move by United, the nation's second-largest carrier, pushed up the price of its stock by $9.875, to $137.
Stephen M. Wolf, chairman of the parent UAL Corporation, said that "as painful as these decisions are, Boeing and United recognize that the immense economic problems the industry is facing have forced us to scale back our capital spending plans significantly."
Southwest Airlines said it would begin service from San Jose, Calif., to Burbank, north of Los Angeles, and to Las Vegas. The move solidified the low-cost carrier's strength in California, pushing up its stock price $2.75 to close at $38.875.
As Southwest moved into San Jose, American Airlines announced that it was dropping nearly half its flights from its money-losing hub operation there. Investors cheered the action and bid up the stock of the parent AMR Corporation by $3.25 to $69.
Delta Air Lines started the latest round of cost-cutting last week, when it abandoned a 36-year-old policy of no layoffs and said it would eliminate 600 pilots' jobs by the fall. Investors cheered the cuts then and seemed swept up in optimism again yesterday, raising Delta stock $3.50, to $57.
America West, operating under bankruptcy protection since June 1991, said Tuesday that it would probably be unable to make a payment on a $100 million loan that had been made in the first place to keep it operating. But this bad news from America West gave analysts further confidence that excess seat capacity might be removed from the system.
USAir Group was also swept up in the bullish airline market, rising $3.125, to a 52-week high of $24.75.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Continental Optimistic
WILMINGTON, Del., April 8 (Reuters) -- Continental Airlines, which is operating under Chapter 11, said today that it foresaw profits this year and through 1996.
John Luth, the company's chief financial officer, told a United States Bankruptcy Court hearing that there would be an operating loss of $181 million and a net profit of $567 million in the period from January to April. He forecast an operating profit of $168.3 million and a net profit of $26.9 million for May through December.
Continental filed for bankruptcy in December 1990. Mr. Luth testified on the final day of hearings on the company's reorganization plan. A decision by Bankruptcy Judge Helen Balick is expected on the plan within a few days. Under it, Air Canada and Air Partners of Dallas would invest $450 million in Continental.

HEADLINE: France Wants 'Trade Peace'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PARIS, April 7

 BODY:
France's new conservative Government, which took a hard line on trade during last month's general election campaign, is sending out peace signals now that it has taken power.
Foreign Minister Alain Juppe said today that the Government was adopting a more constructive approach to the issue than the previous Socialist Government. "On GATT, we have moved from a diplomacy of blockage to a diplomacy of movement," Mr. Juppe told Europe 1 radio. 
 Prime Minister Edouard Balladur, appointed a week ago, told French farm leaders on Tuesday that his Government opposed a draft farm accord reached in Washington last November. But, according to aides, Mr. Balladur does not want to cause a crisis by threatening to veto the pact, and he wants "trade peace" with Washington.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, welcomed the French shift while cautioning that the United States had not heard directly from the French Government. "We are hopeful that they, like we, see trade and trade expansion as key to restoring economic growth," he said in a statement in Washington.
The center-right used farm trade as a political sledgehammer, saying the Socialists had failed to stand up for French farmers in talks with Washington. Now it is asking for time to shape policy.

HEADLINE: Tobacco Price Reductions Could Help the Bond Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Philip Morris's 40-cent-a-pack cut in the price of its Marlboro cigarettes was bad news for the stock market, other cigarette companies and the idea of brand-name attraction. But the news could turn out to be a help for the bond market.
Tobacco price increases over the last year have been a major factor in the increases in both the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index. In the 12 months through February, tobacco prices were the fastest-rising component of the consumer index, rising 10.4 percent. For the producer index for the 12 months, the rise in tobacco prices has accounted for about three-tenths of a percentage point of the 1.8 percent increase. 
 The cut in Marlboro prices, if it spreads, could take some pressure off inflation at a time when price jitters seem to have capped the bond market rally that began just after the Presidential election. That rally sent the yield on the 30-year bond down to a 16-year low of 6.72 percent on March 8. It was the expectation of many investors that inflation would decline this year that gave the rally much of its momentum.
Joel Popkin, the head of his own research firm in Washington, said that he expected a broad cut in tobacco prices could trim one- to two-tenths of a percentage point off the Producer Price Index. The impact on the Consumer Price Index will be less because this price index covers goods and services while the producer index covers just the cost of goods.
Mr. Popkin also thinks the reductions may come as other prices are slowing in the middle of the year, aiding in inflation's moderation.
 
 
'Better Prices'
 "It will come at a time when there will be better prices in general so inflation will look even better and some bond market participants may choose to interpret it as a sign that prices are starting to recede," he said.
The lower prices could begin to show up in the April inflation data, which is released in May, and through the summer. If tobacco helps, along with other factors, including possible restrictions on health-care prices as part of President Clinton's health-care plan, then the signs of slowing inflation could be very reassuring to the bond market.
None of the easing of inflationary pressures is expected to have a major impact in the reports on the March Producer Price Index and Consumer Price Index, however, which will be released this morning and tomorrow, respectively. The bond market is officially closed for the Good Friday holiday.
It was the unexpectedly strong economic data for the first two months of the year -- and the fear that the trend will continue in the March reports -- that helped spook bond traders and investors in the last month. For the first two months of this year, the consumer index rose at an annual rate of 5.2 percent, while the producer index was up 3.4 percent.
Another reason slowing inflation could help the market is that many investors apparently had been buying bonds on the belief -- supported by some prominent forecasters -- that the rate of inflation would decline this year to below the 2.9 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index in 1992.
 
 
A Lot of Doubts
 While the increases in the two inflation indexes this year have raised a lot of doubts, there are still forecasters who expect that a slowly growing economy and price breaks on tobacco and other goods will help to moderate inflation enough during the rest of the year to bring it below 3 percent.
But this forecast is losing adherents. "A couple of months ago, the world was moving in my direction and thinking that inflation was moving lower," said Edward Yaredeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "But now they are thinking it will be the same or maybe even higher."
Mr. Popkin thinks it is not possible for the consumer index to be lower this year, in part because of the surge at the beginning of the year. With the consumer index rising at a 4.6 percent annual rate for the first three months of the year -- including an expected increase of three-tenths of 1 percent for March -- the rest of the year will have to average less than a two-tenths of 1 percent increase a month, or an annual rate of 2.2 percent for the next nine months, to get below last year's rate.
Mr. Popkin forecasts a rise of around 3.5 percent in the Consumer Price Index. He expects that the rates of increase will slow in the middle of the year, compared to the spurt in the first three months of the year. But then he thinks that the pace will pick up a little at the end of the year.
Raymond McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., is forecasting that the pace of inflation will be slower in the rest of the year because of lower tobacco prices and because the huge jump in clothing prices in the beginning of the year will subside.
But he still expects the monthly Producer Price Index increases to be two- to three-tenths of 1 percent, which is higher than last year, and a rate for the year of 2.5 percent to 3 percent. For the Consumer Price Index, he expects monthly increases of three-tenths of 1 percent, with an annual rate of around 3.5 percent.
 
 
Treasury Market
 Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed yesterday ahead of the release of the Producer Price Index today and the Consumer Price Index tomorrow, when the bond market is officially closed for the Good Friday holiday.
Bond prices got a lift early in the day after the second report in two days -- yesterday's from Goldman, Sachs & Company -- said the Treasury would cut the size of the 30-year bond auction and switch to two auctions a year instead of four.
But most of the gains were lost in later thin trading. The price of the 30-year bond was up 5/32 with the yield down to 6.95 percent, from 6.96 percent Tuesday. Treasury note prices were up less or unchanged.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction yesterday of three-month and six-month bills. The auction was delayed from Monday because Congress had not approved an increase in the Government's borrowing limit.

HEADLINE: CLINTON PRESSING UKRAINE ON A-ARMS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
In an effort to put pressure on Ukraine to give up the nuclear weapons left on its soil by the Soviet Union, the Clinton Administration has rebuffed Ukraine's request for a meeting between the Prime Minister and President Clinton or Vice President Al Gore, senior Administration officials say.
The officials say the rebuff is part of an effort to get the Ukrainians to fulfill their promises to ratify the arms-reduction treaty and give up the nuclear weapons. 
But some specialists fear the move may send a signal that the Kiev Government is important to Washington only to the extent that it is a nuclear power.
Ukraine's position is crucial because Moscow and Washington have said they will not begin to carry out the arms-reduction treaty until Kiev ratifies the accord and joins the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, which is intended to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.
 
The Request From Kiev
 Ukrainian legislators said recently that Kiev may ratify the arms-reduction treaty but refrain from joining the non-proliferation treaty, thus keeping its option to develop a nuclear arsenal.
The new attempt to put pressure on Ukraine began when Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, a Texas Democrat and chairman of the Agriculture Committee, invited Prime Minister Leonid Kuchma to meet with his committee. The former director of an SS-18 missile factory, Mr. Kuchma has become an advocate of change, particularly on economic matters.
In March, after the committee's invitation was received, Foreign Minister Anatoly Zlenko came to Washington and met with Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher. Mr. Zlenko informed the Administration that Mr. Kuchma wanted to meet with Mr. Clinton or Mr. Gore.
The request was taken up by a committee led by Strobe Talbott, the ambassador at large for the nations spawned from the former Soviet Union. Mr. Christopher was also consulted.
 
The Response by Washington
 The Administration decided to inform Kiev that such a meeting could not be guaranteed in advance, effectively rebuffing the Ukrainian request.
Prime Minister Kuchma was also told that a visit to Washington would be more "opportune" if Ukraine first ratified the arms-reduction treaty and acceded to the non-proliferation treaty, one senior Administration official said. But Mr. Kuchma was also told that if he was determined to press ahead with his visit, meetings could be arranged with lower-ranking officials.
The rebuff reflected a calculation that the Administration should not "reward" Ukrainians with high-level meetings until they ratified the two treaties. Top Administration officials believe Kiev is trying to squeeze new concessions from Washington.
 
The Skeptics
 Some experts, however, said the rebuff was a mistake and would strengthen the hand of those Ukrainians who argue that Kiev should hold on to the nuclear weapons.
Paul A. Goble, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and a former State Department expert on non-Russian ethnic groups in the Soviet Union, said the Administration's policy "will have the opposite effect of what is intended."
"If they want to send a signal to the Ukrainians that they are isolated and nobody loves then," he said, "and therefore they might want to think about how to defend themselves, this is a good way to do it."

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Race Sees Democrats Vote for Basics

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENOSHA, Wis., April 7

 BODY:
Congressional primary voters looking for a successor to Secretary of Defense Les Aspin gave an easy victory on Tuesday to a conventional Democrat, who had pushed jobs and health care, over a rival who had run against Congress as hard as he had run for it.
The Democratic winner, Peter Barca, a state legislator for eight years, will now face the Republican victor, Mark Neumann, a wealthy homebuilder who said today that the general election, on May 4, would focus on President Clinton's economic plans. 
 "Bill Clinton the man is very popular here, but the increase in taxes on working people isn't," said Mr. Neumann, who ran against Mr. Aspin last fall and threw a scare into him before the Democrat rallied to win his 12th term in the House, with 58 percent of the vote.
Mr. Barca, 37, said today that although he hoped deeper cuts in Federal spending could be found, "the spirit of Clinton's economic program is right." And he said his Republican opponent failed to understand the urgency of the health-care problem and what he described as the need for "radical surgery" to provide full access to care.
 
Stressing the Traditional
 Mr. Barca defeated Jeff Neubauer, also 37, by stressing traditional Democratic themes -- jobs, health care and improved education and job training -- along with his call for "meaningful action on the deficit," including a law that would give the President authority to veto individual items in spending bills.
He also emphasized his experience in the Legislature, where he is chairman of the Democratic caucus, and relied on strong labor support to gain a big edge here in Kenosha, his hometown, and cut into Mr. Neubauer's vote in his own hometown, Racine. Those two old industrial cities along Lake Michigan cast more than two-thirds of the Democratic votes in this southeastern Wisconsin district.
With 98 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Barca had 32,744 votes, or 50 percent, to 21,306, or 33 percent, for Mr. Neubauer, with the rest scattered. In the Republican contest, Mr. Neumann had 27,569 votes, or 79 percent, to 7,378, or 21 percent, for Charles Coleman, a state legislator.
Mr. Neubauer, a former legislator and Democratic state chairman, had sought to tie himself to Mr. Clinton, whom he backed early in the 1992 Presidential race. But his main emphasis was to challenge Congress itself. In television advertisements, he called boldly for a "pay cut for Congress," although when questioned about it he urged only a modest trim: a cancellation of the lawmakers' last cost-of-living raise.
Campaigning at bowling alleys and at free-meal lines in church halls until the polls closed Tuesday night, Mr. Neubauer said he hoped to work with newer members of Congress, both Democrats and Republicans, to develop a "governing coalition of people who want reform."
He also called for a constitutional amendment to balance the budget, promised not to "send costly political junk mail at taxpayer expense" and demanded that Congress abandon its "lavish perks and privileges." But against Mr. Barca's basic Democratic message, the Neubauer appeal failed.
The general election, one of this spring's four House special elections caused by resignations, appears to favor the Democrats slightly. Mr. Barca and Mr. Neubauer helped by avoiding attacks on each other during the primary campaign. And while last fall Mr. Neumann could make incumbency and the flaws of Congress the issues against Mr. Aspin, Mr. Barca carries no such baggage.
So Mr. Neumann, 38, will be stressing the taxes in the Clinton program. He will call for spending cuts and argue, as he did today, that "I've balanced budgets in the real world." He can expect considerable outside help from his party.
But making the distinction Mr. Neumann promised today, of attacking Mr. Clinton's programs but not Mr. Clinton personally, may prove difficult. Mr. Clinton carried this district last November with 41 percent of the vote, to 35 percent for President George Bush and 23 percent for Ross Perot.

HEADLINE: Stock Option Rule Change Is Planned

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
The Financial Accounting Standards Board put corporations and their top executives on notice yesterday that starting in 1997 it plans to require companies to take a charge against earnings when they grant stock options.
But it left the door wide open for companies to continue issuing gargantuan option awards without harming earnings for three more years. Through 1996, companies would only be expected to estimate in their footnotes what profits would look like if the charge was immediately taken. 
 "That is a downside of it," said Ralph V. Whitworth, president of the United Shareholders Association in Washington, noting that many companies were already accelerating their option grants in anticipation of the rule change. "I'm sure there will be those that try to get in under the wire, and it's a pretty clear wire."
 
Time to Press Case
 For the F.A.S.B., whose pronouncements never attracted the likes of CNN television camera crews until yesterday, the long lead time also means that the controversy surrounding stock options, which typically give employees the right to buy their companies' stock at a fixed price any time over 10 years, will not ebb for some time.
Many top executives who are following the debate say flat out that they have no intention of spending the next three years experimenting with various option pricing models (one reason the F.A.S.B. cited for not making the effective date more immediate as some had wanted).
On the contrary, top executives say they intend to use the time to lobby, cajole and otherwise try to persuade the accounting board to back off.
"It is somewhat gratifying that the F.A.S.B. has at least delayed the implementation of a charge to earnings for a lengthy period," said Brian Borders, president of the Association of Publicly Traded Companies in Washington. He said his group of 400 small and midsize companies would "continue to work with the F.A.S.B., the Securities and Exchange Commission and, if necessary, the Congress to avoid the ultimate implementation of that charge to earnings."
The business community will have plenty of opportunities to make its influence felt; four seats -- and perhaps all seven -- on the accounting board will turn over by the end of 1997, and all appointments are made by the Financial Accounting Foundation, a not-for-profit group on which big business is well represented.
At least one small investor yesterday complained that the length of the delay put the final outcome in too much doubt. "It's going to be three years until the rule takes effect, and business is going to lobby like crazy to derail it," said Leonard Susseles, a 66-year-old Brooklyn resident who once owned a leather goods factory and now lives from his investments.
Timothy S. Lucas, the F.A.S.B.'s research director, indicated that the board would be happy to reconsider the issue, but was not likely to budge on the larger principle. "Several board members said there is value in these plans and when you give an employee something of value in return for working there that is compensation and should be charged to expense," he said.
 
Changes in Compensation Plans
 The board plans to give companies some leeway in how they comply. It is not, for instance, insisting that companies use any particular model for pricing options, as long as their choice satisfies certain criteria. And once companies compute the value, they can spread the cost over as many years as it takes for the awards to become vested.
Companies are likely to consider revamping their compensation programs as a result.
Stock options have become the most popular form of executive compensation because of their favorable tax and accounting treatment. They are the only major form of compensation that does not reduce earnings. Yet companies get a tax deduction when executives exercise the options.
One critic of the current accounting rules was happy yesterday that the double standard was about to end. "The F.A.S.B.'s proposal, if it becomes final, would place a reasonable check on executive pay packages which contain options, a check which until now has been missing," Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said in a statement.
But George H. Sollman, chief executive of the Centigram Communications Corporation of San Jose, Calif., vowed to continue fighting the charge. He is one of many chief executives who can recite from memory the exact number of Senator Levin's bill (S259), which some say prodded the F.A.S.B. into action.
Mr. Sollman is a spokesman for the 20 high-technology companies that have banded under the banner of the Coalition for American Equity Expansion. They feel the charge will throttle the nation's high-tech sector.
Centigram, for instance, would be facing a 40 percent reduction in earnings because it makes stock options available to all of its employees. "And we are not abnormal," Mr. Sollman said. "In Silicon Valley, it's one of the currencies you use to attract, keep and motivate employees, and it's made a difference in terms of our competitiveness."
 
Performance Options
 One wrinkle sure to please people on all sides of the issue is a proposed change in how companies account for options that have some strings attached. Advocates for shareholders would like companies to make their option grants contingent on performance, either by requiring management to outperform the market, or at least inflation.
Under current accounting rules, performance options are highly disadvantaged because they alone must be booked. So few companies issue them.
Now that performance options and plain-vanilla options would enjoy the same accounting treatment, companies will probably take a second look at issuing performance options.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Drop While Taxables Advance

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The average yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were mixed in the latest week because of shifting investor interests, according to the most recent survey by IBC's Money Fund Report.
In the tax-exempt category, yields were down moderately in the week ended Tuesday. Analysts noted that the volume of municipal issues, though down somewhat, remained heavy. Strong investor demand pushed prices higher and yields lower in the latest week. 
 The assets of the tax-exempt money funds increased $1.7 billion in the latest period, pushing total assets to $103.9 billion. Walter S. Frank, chief economist at the Money Fund Report, said, "You're not seeing the rush by tax-exempt issuers to refinance older debt as you did in the earlier part of the year, and we're now seeing a noticeable amount of money coming out of the once-attractive long end of the market to the short end."
Money managers appeared to sit tight this week, with the average number of days left until maturity of securities in portfolios unchanged at 50.
The IBC/Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt fund fell 4 basis points, to 1.98 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield also down 4 basis points, to 1.96 percent. Over a 30-day period, the compounded yield is averaging 1.92 percent, and the simple yield 1.90 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Less state and local taxes, the taxable bond equivalent for the average seven-day yield is 2.75 percent for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket, and 2.78 percent for those in a 31 percent bracket.
Among the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million, the Money Fund Report said the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market again outperformed all other funds in its group with a yield of 2.64 percent, or 11 basis points lower than its top yield last week.
 
Taxable Funds
 Aided by a selloff in the stock and bond markets, assets of taxable money market funds increased by $15.8 billion, to a total $485.9 billion, in the week ended yesterday. Institutional fund assets rose $13.2 billion, to $169.6 billion, while retail assets gained $2.6 billion, to $316.3 billion. Some new funds contributed $2.4 billion.
"As expected, the bulk of the money flowing into the funds was from large institutional investors," Mr. Frank said. "The money funds are the natural place for institutionals when there is turmoil in the markets."
Analysts said the average number of days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios remained at 60.
IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield on a taxable fund rose a basis point, to 2.71 percent, with the seven-day simple yield also up a basis point, to 2.67 percent.
The Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund had the highest return among general-purpose taxable money funds, with a yield of 3.50 percent.
For comparative purposes, banks, which compete directly for investors' cash, are offering an average 2.60 percent. The yield is down a basis point from a week ago.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, Up Against Mark, Falls Again in Yen Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Traders broadened their selloff of German marks yesterday, propelling the dollar mostly higher on world markets. But the Japanese yen benefited even more from the mark-selling and touched another record high against the dollar.
The mark's decline was mostly traced to further speculation that Germany was preparing to cut interest rates after more gloomy economic news this week. 
 Gold edged higher in New York after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose 50 cents a troy ounce to close at $338.40. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $337.75, up 25 cents from late Tuesday.
The rush to sell marks began Tuesday on a report of higher unemployment in West Germany and news that Daimler-Benz, Germany's biggest industrial group, planned 14,700 job cuts.
 
Lower Rates Expected
 Afraid of aggravating inflation, Germany's central bank has been hesistant to lower interest rates too fast. But more and more traders believe the Bundesbank may begin to favor swifter easings as a way to stimulate the economy.
Reinforcing that view on Wednesday, the Dutch and Belgium Governments cut their key short-term interest rates, seeming to help pave the way for lower rates in other European countries.
Many traders sold their marks for Japanese yen, one of the few major currencies viewed as fundamentally strong.
The dollar closed in Tokyo at 114.02 yen, down 0.26 yen from Tuesday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 113.65 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was quoted at 113.50 yen, down from late Tuesday's 113.85 yen and a new postwar low.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5150 from $1.5140 late Tuesday. At late afternoon in New York, a pound traded at $1.5135, less than late Tuesday's $1.5150.

HEADLINE: Installment Debt Rises $1.2 Billion

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Consumers increased their installment debt by $1.2 billion in February, to $728.8 billion, the sixth straight monthly advance following an extended decline, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Credit card and other revolving debt jumped by $2.4 billion, or 11.4 percent at an annual rate, while loans to buy automobiles rose $1 billion, a 4.8 percent pace. 
 However, much of this rise was offset by a $2.2 billion drop in "other" credit, which includes loans to finance mobile homes, education, boats and vacations.
"The consumer is still operating in a fairly conservative fashion," commented Edward F. McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs. He called "overstated" the assertions that consumers have significantly liberalized spending after a period of repaying debt. The debt decline was concentrated in automobile credit, Mr. McKelvey noted, a category affected by the expansion of leasing.
The decline in other credit over the last two months, analysts suggested, may reflect debt consolidation on the part of those who have taken advantage of falling interest rates to refinance homes. The higher revolving debt could reflect bills from the Christmas holidays.
January's rise in overall installment credit was revised to $1 billion from an initial estimate of $900 million, today's report also showed.
Over the latest 12 months, overall installment debt is up a very modest $400 million, with a rise in revolving accounts almost entirely offset by a decline in other debt, the same pattern as prevailed in February.
The Fed's consumer credit report includes all household debt not secured by real estate. It does not include home equity loans or mortgages.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Selling pollution rights isn't popular; neither are alternatives.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
SHOULD polluters be allowed to buy their way out of cleaning up? The idea of selling pollution indulgences does not go down easily among those steeped in the Puritan ethic. Once understood, though, the concept of converting environmental sin into a commodity that can be traded like heating oil futures or I.B.M. stock looks like the cheapest way to solve some expensive problems.
But a first major test, a national auction of rights to emit sulfur from power plant smokestacks, was received with something less than enthusiasm last month. And by no coincidence, the state regulators who can make or break the trading system are viewing its birth with deep suspicion. Champions of "marketable emissions allowances" are now worried that their baby will be smothered in the crib. 
 Since pollution is bad for children, trees and other living things, it would be nice -- and might be crucial -- to have less of it. But how to get from here to there? The traditional approach is command-and-control: Tell polluters what standard they must meet, and perhaps even dictate the technology.
Brute force works. America's air and water are far cleaner than they were two decades ago. But brute force is expensive -- well in excess of $100 billion a year, by the Environmental Protection Agency's reckoning, and rising far more rapidly than the G.N.P. That is why an unlikely coalition of environmentalists and conservatives fought for a more flexible system for halving the sulfur emissions dumped on forests and lakes downwind.
Power plants can cut emissions by encouraging energy conservation, by switching to low-sulfur fuels or by snatching sulfur particles from exhaust gases with chemical "scrubbers." But the cost varies greatly according to the location and age of the plants. So the logical approach is to let the utilities choose their own strategies. And the logical extension of the logical approach is to let utilities pool their efforts by creating free markets in emission rights.
Under the Clean Air Act of 1990, utilities may meet the sulfur standard on their own, or buy allowances to emit sulfur by the ton from utilities that exceed the standard. Polluters are even allowed to squirrel away unused allowances for future use or sale.
A half-dozen trades have already been privately consummated between consenting utilities. However, the first public auction came only on March 30, when the Chicago Board of Trade offered a big block of allowances controlled by the Environmental Protection Agency.
The auction was not a failure: Washington sold out its inventory. But it was hardly a smashing success. Prices were a small fraction of the estimated cost of meeting the standard with scrubbers, evidence that utilities are not focusing on least-cost approaches to meeting the standard. Moreover, virtually none of the allowances offered privately were sold, suggesting that everyone is wary of playing the new game.
Lester Lave, an economist at Carnegie Mellon University, partly blames the arcane auction rules thoughtlessly dictated by Congress. But Mr. Lave and just about everyone else rooting for the system agree that state regulators are also undermining its chances.
Utility commissions in Midwestern states that produce high-sulfur coal are pressuring local utilities to install expensive scrubbers, presumably to keep miners employed and mines profitable. As disturbing, most commissions have failed to spell out who bears the risk in utility compliance strategies.
If a company buys allowances now for $500 a ton, will its stockholders be forced to eat part of the cost if prices later fall to $300? By the same token, if a utility decides to scrub, will it be penalized if it cannot sell the allowances generated for a high enough price to have justified the decision? "Nobody knows," laments Mr. Lave, and thus no utility is sticking its neck out.
A more direct challenge to sulfur emissions trading is coming from Thomas C. Jorling, New York's State's environment commissioner. Mr. Jorling fears utilities in the Ohio Valley will pay up rather than clean up, leaving the Adirondacks to cope with more sulfuric rain. He wants to inhibit interregional trading and, in particular, to stop the sale of allowances to plants upwind of New York.
The Environmental Defense Fund challenges his premise. There simply are not enough allowances out there to make it practical for Midwestern utilities to avoid a major cleanup, argues Joseph Goffman, a lawyer for the fund. And he thinks that the Jorling ploy could boomerang, inhibiting these same utilities from pursuing aggressive cleanup strategies in the 1990's to ease their burden in the next century.
But the deeper objection to Mr. Jorling's crusade is that he is trying to wriggle out of a hard-won deal that balanced the interests of region against region and environmentalism against economic growth.
"The Midwest is taking it in the neck to save the Adirondacks," Mr. Goffman said. It is a wretched precedent, he suggests, to stop the region's utilities from using the law to minimize the cost.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
New Public Housing, French Vintage 1922

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
YOUNG architects are supposed to make a splash. It's a letdown when their first building doesn't herald a new voice. But Jean Dubus, 41, and Jean Pierre Lott, 31, have done something truly original. Their first work, an apartment building in Paris, reverberates with the shock of the old.
They've dusted off an unbuilt 1922 design for public housing by Le Corbusier, one of the most influential voices in 20th-century architecture, and brought it startlingly to life. What makes their debut even more stunning is that, after 70 years, the design still looks fresh. Not a dim echo, it's the bold refrain of an idea whose time has come again. 
 This building should be of special interest to Americans, in part because Le Corbusier was a prophet more honored in the United States than in France. Twenty-five years ago, before the Federal Government had withdrawn its support for subsidized housing, Le Corbusier was the major influence on the design of public housing in the United States. That influence was not altogether benign.
Le Corbusier's proposals to rebuild cities as complexes of tall "towers in a park" was alluring in theory. But in practice it was a bomb dropped on traditional urban form. While the concept produced some successes, like New York University's housing complex at Bleecker Street and La Guardia Place, designed in 1966 by I. M. Pei & Partners, more often it resulted in bleak public housing projects that disfigured many American cities and became warehouses for the poor.
It's time to take another look. Social housing is on its way back in the United States. In his confirmation hearings, Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, pledged that his agency would resume housing construction. Architects are calling once again for socially responsible work. Architecture schools, like those at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Parsons School of Design, are devoting conferences to public housing issues.
Those issues are not limited to design. Public housing depends on public policy. But design has a role to play, and so does architectural history. Mr. Dubus and Mr. Lott have looked to the tradition of social housing as an inspiration for the present. They've taken a flawed design and made it work.
I came upon this remarkable building at the end of a long day spent trekking through government-sponsored housing projects. The day was long because looking at social housing can bring on a tiring mix of emotions. Envy for a city that recognizes the importance of providing housing for the middle class. Admiration for the high quality of the designs, which are usually chosen in juried competitions. And not least, a heavy dose of guilt for wishing one were elsewhere, for any tourist with only a few days to spend in Paris would gladly trade in the city's entire stock of a social housing for an afternoon at the Louvre.
Sure, it's great to see all the terrific things young architects are doing with windows these days. But it's only 20 minutes to closing time at Ste.-Chappelle. Taxi!
"Patience," advised my guide, a young French architect named Jean Mas. "There's one more building I'd like to show you."
We zipped down to south Paris, to a neighborhood not far from the site where the horrible new Grande Bibliotheque, now under construction, is poking a quartet of towers into the sky. We pulled into a side street off Porte d'Italie and screeched to a halt beside the architectural apparition that arose before us. "See?" Mr. Mas asked. "It looks familiar?"
Mais oui. To the student of modern architecture, Le Corbusier's "Villa Immeubles" is as familiar as the Eiffel Tower. Designed in 1922, this was Le Corbusier's most ambitious project to date. With it, he applied the principles of modern architecture to the task of city planning, enlarging to urban scale his concept of the house as a "machine for living."
First sketched out on the back of a restaurant menu, the design was exhibited later that year at the Salon d'Automne, where the public got its first look at Le Corbusier's ambition to transform his adopted city of Paris into a machine-age utopia.
The concept was simple. Duplex maisonettes, each with its own outdoor garden, were arranged in rows of 24, then stacked atop one another in long blocks five double-stories tall. In one version of the plan, the blocks were arranged in quadrangles around a central garden.
The private "hanging gardens," which alternated with two-story living rooms enclosed by large glass walls, faced onto this public space. On the rear side of the block, open corridors (Le Corbusier called them "streets in the air") provided access to the units. City traffic was routed underground. Laundry and meal services would be provided, as in a grand hotel.
The Villas Immeubles project preceded by a few years Le Corbusier's radical proposal to rebuild Paris as a city of "towers in a park," and was actually quite traditional in scale and organization. Inspired by the architect's visit to a Carthusian monastery outside Florence, this "park inside a square" resembled a stripped-down version of the Palais Royale.
Mr. Dubus and Mr. Lott's explicit homage to a dead modernist is not quite the polemical act it may seem. It was the French housing authority's idea to call on architects to submit designs in the spirit of Le Corbusier, for a competition held in 1987, the centennial of the architect's birth.
But Mr. Dubus and Mr. Lott were delighted to get into the spirit. Like many young architects today, they believe that the paths opened up by the pioneer modernists have not reached a dead end. Nor, like some of their American counterparts, do they believe that it is desirable or even possible to detach modern forms from progressive social goals. The notion that one can have modernism without utopianism would strike them as absurd, indeed unnecessary, since they are fortunate to live in a nation that has not allowed privatization to dissolve the public realm.
Their building is not a shelter for the homeless. Like most social housing in central Paris, the project is designed for lower-middle-class families. A mix of government subsidies -- for land acquisition, construction costs and rent supports -- enables the housing authority to rent the units for about 30 percent below market value. Eligibility is based on income and family size. Of the building's 95 apartments, 11 are reserved for artists, who also receive subsidies.
Completed a year ago and now fully occupied, the Villa Immeubles is a homage but not a copy. Mr. Dubus and Mr. Lott have modified Le Corbusier's design and, in fact, substantially improved it.
Their block is only a quarter of the quadrangle Le Corbusier envisioned. There are no hotel services, and in place of sunken roadways, there is an underground garage for about 300 cars. These alterations help to integrate the building comfortably into the existing context of streets and small local shops. It does not stand alone like a walled compound.
Mr. Dubus and Mr. Lott have also modified the internal organization of the apartments and the garden facade on which that organization is expressed. Instead of alternating stiffly between an open terrace and an enclosed living room, the design doubles the rhythm. The living rooms are joined in pairs horizontally within glazed vertical shafts, while the gardens are carried (again in pairs) on concrete bridges that stretch between the shafts. This arrangement leaves room for a wide, open well behind the terraces, through which air and natural light flow into the building's interior.
But the most radical change from the original is the building's circulation. Instead of arranging the "streets in the air" along the exterior rear wall, the architects have run them straight through the building's heart. But they have not fully enclosed them. One side, planted with greenery, opens onto the air well and the terraces. And instead of placing these corridors even with the terraces, the architects have set them on a level halfway between them.
This organization creates a spectacularly rich spatial and social composition. The apartments are entered through a small vestibule that leads to a bedroom in the rear. Depending on the layout, a Le Corbusier-style spiral staircase either ascends or descends from the vestibule to a main floor with more than double the floor area.
The master bedroom and bath are here, next to a small sitting area that can be used as an extra bedroom. A kitchen and dining area occupy the central core of the apartment, and in half of the apartments these are placed on a balcony overlooking the living room with its atelier-style window. A door leads off from the living room to the terrace. The openness of these interiors is a striking contrast to the warren of mazes common in American housing projects.
The prospect outside the "villas" is even more extraordinary. Walking along the streets in the air, one passes through a rhythmic sequence of enclosing walls and open air, gazing past the private terraces toward a public garden below. The result is a masterful weaving of form and sociology, supremely urban in its clear articulation of private, semi-private and public space. It is thrilling to reflect on the difference such a design can make in the lives of families and communities.
Heavy balcony railings mar the fluid space inside the apartments, and the stairs would have benefited from having open risers. Traditional furniture looks surprisingly at home inside these classically white modern rooms. In several living rooms, the airy delicacy of old-fashioned lace curtains makes the perfect foil for the broad expanse of glass.
In the building's public areas, the palette of white and gray is relieved with patches of dusty green and rose. At dusk, in a gem of a detail, the corridors are suffused with mellow light from small halogen lamps set into the floor. Then, the entire building takes on the glow of a dream rekindled.

HEADLINE: In North Korea, Try Diplomacy First

 BODY:
North Korea's abrupt refusal to allow inspections of its nuclear sites has now led the International Atomic Energy Agency to take the unprecedented step of asking the United Nations Security Council to impose sanctions.
But diplomacy may still be the best way to keep North Korea from getting The Bomb. The task is to persuade Pyongyang to reverse its rash renunciation of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and open all its nuclear sites to inspections. 
 Inspections would enable the I.A.E.A. to tell whether Pyongyang has produced enough plutonium to make a bomb. They could also assure that its nuclear reactors are not diverted to bomb-making.
The I.A.E.A.'s call for sanctions is understandable. But whatever economic leverage the U.N. has with autarkic North Korea depends on China's willingness to enforce an embargo and deny it oil. China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, favors "patient consultations" instead, though he does not rule out sanctions if diplomacy fails.
Some in Washington are urging more forceful steps. But attacking Iraq's nuclear facilities failed to put it out of the bomb-making business. And bombing the North's reactors would invite retaliation against nuclear power plants in South Korea, if not all-out war. That understandably frightens Seoul, which prefers to try diplomacy. And it feels North Korea may be amenable to compromise.
Pyongyang's double-dealing doesn't help. But the North's conditions for continued adherence to the Nonproliferation Treaty do not seem impossible to satisfy. Pyongyang wants an end to the Team Spirit exercises conducted by the U.S. and South Korea. It wants to inspect bases in the South to assure that no U.S. nuclear arms remain. It seeks assurances that Washington will not use nuclear arms first. And it wants high-level talks with Washington to resolve the nuclear issue.
Before resorting to sanctions or force, Washington should exhaust diplomacy. It has until at least mid-June to try; that's when the North's withdrawal from the treaty would take effect. Pyongyang can do little to advance its nuclear ambition by then. If diplomacy fails, sterner measures may then be easier to sell to Beijing and Seoul.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (94%); UNITED STATES (94%); CHINA (92%); KOREA, REPUBLIC OF (92%); IRAQ (79%);

HEADLINE: Essay;
Not 'Ready to Go'

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Bob Dole, the Republican leader in the Senate, chose Oregon's Mark Hatfield, a soft-spoken moderate, to talk to Pennsylvania's Arlen Specter about signing the filibuster letter.
Comes April 30, it will be seen as a critical moment in the first hundred days of the Clinton Administration. To stop the Democratic legislative locomotive, solidarity on the part of the Republican minority was vital, and Hatfield and Specter have long been mavericks. 
 The Pennsylvania Senator listened to the argument against Mr. Clinton's bill to stimulate the economy by increasing the deficit by $19.5 billion in new Federal spending. He asked to read the final draft of the letter, and signed on -- not as a party regular but as a Senator profoundly offended by the steamroller tactics of the Democratic leadership.
Senator Robert Byrd, the Appropriations chairman, had been eager to reassert his power after failing last year to move the C.I.A. to his native West Virginia. Against Senate tradition, he used parliamentary tricks to make it impossible for any senator to amend the President's spending bill.
But the Senate was created to protect the minority against majority tyranny. That's why small states have the same two votes as large states and why it takes much more than a majority to cut off debate. Senator Byrd, who burdens us all with taxpayer-subsidized books about Senate traditions, forgot about that respect for dissent and compromise in his zeal to ram through the whole Democratic "stimulus" without examination of each of its components.
The Republicans were driven into unaccustomed unity. As a result of the all-or-nothing demand of Bobby Byrd and the hubris of the Clinton White House, the addition to the deficit of billions in political payoffs to mayors who delivered for Democratic candidates is a dead duck.
Liberal media are apoplectic. "It is the rightful role of the minority to oppose and criticize," huffs a New York Times editorialist, "but not to paralyze." In other words, it's O.K. for the minority to complain, but to insist on a role in making national decisions -- why, that's causing the dreaded "gridlock."
Now we'll have a much-needed debate. On the surface, it will be about the pork permeating this particular bill, which is based on the "Ready to Go" wish list supplied by the Conference of Mayors. We will see if the taxpayer wants to shell out $1 million for the casino in West Haven, Conn., $500,000 for a bike path in Minneapolis, $80,000 for tennis courts in Perth Amboy, N.J., and similar goodies for loyal pols and their contractor contributors.
In the glare of publicity, many of these costly political favors will be deleted from the bill when it is reconsidered. So will billions in grants to students, which have nothing to do with the quick creation of new jobs, supposedly Mr. Clinton's purpose in submitting this legislation.
But under the surface is the greater debate: What did the voters say in the 1992 election?
Did we change parties to stimulate the economy by providing government jobs, thereby -- claim the Clintonites -- enlarging the deficit today in the hope of reducing it someday? Or did the majority vote to reduce the crushing deficit that had quadrupled in the past 12 years?
I think the voters' villain was the deficit. Add the Perot protesters to the Republican die-hards and you have a mandate to reduce the deficit -- to cut it in half in four years, as candidate Clinton promised. To that 57 percent of the electorate, add those of us who voted to oust the hapless Bushies after being assured that Clinton would be a "new kind of Democrat."
Clinton's post-election leftward lunge has led to a political paradox: the great majority who wanted to get off the spend-and-tax treadmill is not being represented by the majority party.
We don't need to go deeper into deficit to pump up the economy. That will continue to come back by itself, unless heavy new taxes and all the Clinton hints of price control spook the current recovery.
The filibuster that stopped the "Ready to Go" payoff reminds Clinton and the rubber-stamping-ground that has become the Congress: The American majority will rule, even if it has to be represented for the time being by a Senate minority.

HEADLINE: Tough Talk Won't Help Trade With Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"For Clinton, 'Managed Trade' Is Emerging as Policy Option" (front page, March 30) exposes the faulty thinking and naivete of "strategic trade" and "aggressive unilateralism." United States trade deficits are made by chronic budget deficits and low savings in the United States, not by Japan or other Asian countries.
United States trade deficits with Japan consist mainly of products Americans want eagerly but that are not made here -- fax machines, flat liquid-crystal panels, compact disk players, even quality cars, to name a few. This situation is the same as Japan's unabated imports of Hollywood films and American pop music. Can such imbalances be corrected by ill-conceived managed trade? 
 The Clinton Administration has mistakenly embraced the United States-Japan semiconductor agreement of the Bush-Reagan era as the way to reduce trade deficits with Japan. All that you have to do, managed-trade advocates say, is demand, under threat of unilateral retaliation, that Japan set aside a dictated portion of the target market, like 20 percent of the microchips market. This magic number was recently reached. But a simple analysis of it would show the opposite conclusion.
Only because Japan's deepening recession shrank the total market size of microchips, and only because this market shrinkage did not deter the rising popularity of Intel's central processing unit chips in Japan, was the target of 20 percent passed. Intel's chips would have continued to sell well without political protection. The successes of Intel, Texas Instruments and other American companies in Japan point up the simple truth of international trade in high-tech-related products.
If you back technically superior products with marketing and manufacturing investments in targeted foreign markets, you can sell them there. Unfortunately, the cheapening of the dollar has made investment by American companies in Japan prohibitively expensive. The cheaper dollar has helped United States trade with Europe only because American manufacturers have long had manufacturing and marketing operations for European customers. America's trade deficits with Japan do not prove closure of markets by Japan.
Furthermore, the school of "aggressive unilateralism" assumes Japan cannot retaliate. Japan has plenty to retaliate with. American steel companies have discovered that their operations in the United States have been seriously hurt by the withdrawal of massive technical and financial aids from their Japanese steel partners. One Japanese steel company after another was hurt by the harassment of "dumping" suits from American steel companies last year. Japanese companies seem to have concluded they can use their technology and money more safely elsewhere.
If Detroit's Big Three mimic steel industry harassment of Japanese companies, they would find themselves hurt in the United States and in Japan. President Clinton's managed trade advocates should go back to the drawing board.
 
YOSHI TSURUMI
Professor of Intl. Business
Baruch College, CUNY
New York, March 31, 1993

HEADLINE: Trade Center Blast Providing Economic Lift, Experts Find

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
In the first attempt at a comprehensive analysis of the economic damage caused by the bombing of the World Trade Center, Port Authority economists and consultants have concluded that the explosion has actually provided a lift to the local economy.
The attack -- which killed six people and injured 1,000 others -- wreaked havoc on the fabric of the city and authority officials did not suggest that news of economic benefit would undo the tragedy of it. 
 But in a report issued yesterday, the authority said that because of insurance claims, the reconstruction and cleanup effort was largely being financed from outside the region, supplying jobs to people who lived nearby.
 
Discomfort Shows
 They estimated that the economic activity generated by the terrorist attack would bring more than $200 million into the regional economy.
Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey made no secret of their discomfort with the interpretation that the bombing was good for the economy. And, they were quick to point out that their analysis does not account for the intangible losses associated with the bombing deaths and injuries, or for the emotional trauma to tens of thousands of other New Yorkers affected by the blast. And in any case, they said, the estimated lift is small compared with the region's $470 billion economy.
In addition, they said the long-term impact is hard to measure. The costs of higher insurance premiums and increased security for the trade center should not be onerous, they said. But it is not yet clear whether the perceived risks of doing business in the area will make the trade center complex less competitive in the crowded national market for commercial real estate.
In their report, Port Authority officials place the cost of business disruption and reconstruction at just under $600 million. That figure is in the same range as a March 1 estimate issued by the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman.
But the Port Authority expects that all but $50 million to $100 million of out-of-pocket costs to business, local government and the authority will be reimbursed from private insurance and Federal emergency assistance. And the loss of employment, notably some 900 jobs at the shuttered Vista Hotel and the Windows on the World restaurant, will be more than offset by added construction and cleanup payrolls.
Reconstruction and cleanup costs, by the Port Authority's reckoning, will exceed $300 million. And just after the bombing, there was speculation that dislocation of businesses and the 50,000-plus people who work in the trade center would cost several times that much. The Port Authority now estimates that this loss will come to less than $200 million -- good news that Port Authority Chairman Richard Leone attributes to planning, much effort and good luck.
Both public agencies and private contractors, he noted, "worked at supersonic speeds" with the cleanup and emergency repairs. Government permits that routinely take months were issued on the spot. With a green light from insurers, cleanup crews were set to work 24 hours a day to prepare the buildings for reopening.
Perhaps as important, the current glut in city office space made it possible for some 350 businesses to relocate within days. "If this had happened in 1985 or 1986," in the midst of the real-estate boom, Mr. Leone pointed out, the recovery would have been drawn out and far more costly.
Unlike most natural disasters, the great bulk of the damage was done to business property. Thus almost all of the loss, including the disruption of businesses, was insured.
Of the estimated $132 million to $160 million in financial damage to trade center tenants, all but $7 million to $25 million is likely to be reimbursed. Of the Port Authority's own estimated $376 million to $380 million loss, just $20 million to $22 million will come out of the authority's resources -- a trivial sum in the context of the authority's $2 billion-plus annual budgets. While an exact comparison is not possible, these numbers seem consistent with the total $510 million private insurance liability estimated last week by the American Insurance Services Group, an industry-financed association.
Government outlays for emergency services, of course, were not insured. But now that President Clinton has declared New York eligible for disaster relief, a good chunk of the $22 million to $39 million borne in large part by states and localities should be underwritten by Washington.
 
50,000 Workers Displaced
 The Port Authority's more challenging task was to estimate the broader economic impact on the region. And here the authority relied on plausible assumptions -- in particular, that the insurance reimbursement largely came from pockets outside the region and that the bulk of the reconstruction and cleanup went to local contractors and workers.
Some 50,000 to 55,000 workers were displaced by the trade center closing. In most cases, though, they were quickly back at work. And while there are some serious losers -- in particular, employees of the Windows on the World restaurant and the Vista Hotel who will be laid off for many months -- their wage losses are overwhelmed by the earnings of thousands employed in the fast-track reconstruction effort. What is more, Matthew Drennen, an economist at Cornell and consultant to the Port Authority, estimates that a good portion of this net earnings gain will be spent within the region, creating more jobs.
But the net stimulus is short-lived. A chunk of the benefit will certainly be offset by higher property insurance premiums and higher building security costs in the future. And if access to the trade center garage is restricted, the loss of parking revenues could be considerable. Last, but hardly least, some analysts worry that the bombing will make downtown Manhattan in general, and the World Trade Center in particular, a less prestigious place to work.
That apparently explains why Port Authority officials are determined to restore the buildings to better-than-new condition, emphasizing the agency's optimistic stance and minimizing reminders of the bombing.

HEADLINE: Richard B. Stearns Jr., 54, Dies; Managed Real-Estate Investments

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Richard B. Stearns Jr. a real-estate investment executive, died on Tuesday night at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 54 and lived on the East Side of Manhattan.
The cause was cancer of the bladder, said his brother-in-law Cecil Wray. 
 Mr. Stearns managed a portfolio of real estate valued at more than $15 billion when he was chairman, from 1989 to 1991, of Prudential Real Estate Investors, which is based in Newark. It is part of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, also based in Newark.
Of the total, $10 billion worth of real estate was owned by the Prudential, and more than $5 billion was owned by other institutional investors, mostly pension funds.
He joined the insurance company, which is the country's largest, in 1981 and became chairman or chief executive of three other Newark-based Prudential real-estate and mortgage units.
 
Involved in Schools
 Over the years, Mr. Stearns was also a director or trustee of the Brearley School, an independent school for girls, and the Diller-Quaile School of Music, both in Manhattan; the New York School for the Deaf, in White Plains; the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity, and the National Association of Real Estate Investment Managers.
He was born in Stamford, Conn., grew up in New Hampshire, and graduated from Kimball Union Academy in Meriden, N.H. He earned a bachelor's degree in economics from Colgate University in 1960 and a master's degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1961.
After serving as a vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank and of Gulf & Western Industries and as treasurer of Schlumberger Ltd., he joined the Prudential, as a vice president.
He founded Prudential Home Mortgage Company in 1984 and oversaw its burgeoning operations in its first five years. The company, which was a joint venture with Salomon Brothers from 1984 to 1988, is now the second-largest originator of home mortgages in the United States. From several offices across the country, it issues mortgages to individual home buyers. In 1992 it originated more than $28 billion worth of mortgages.
 
Director of Several Companies
 In early 1992, after a reorganization of the Prudential Realty Group, Mr. Stearns was the chief executive officer of Institutional Investment Management -- a Newark-based division of the Realty Group -- which manages commercial real-estate investments, mostly for pension funds.
Last year, Mr. Stearns left Prudential and became a managing director of Security Capital Group, a closely held corporation that invests in real estate, using pools of capital provided by investors, and also manages investments in real estate. In addition he was a managing director of several affiliated companies.
He is survived by his mother, Barbara Stearns, of New London, N.H.; his wife, the former Sharon Gates, to whom he was married in 1968; a son, Owen Johnson Stearns, and two daughters, Hope Gates Stearns and Leigh Asher Stearns, all of Manhattan, and a sister, Ruth Santos, of Larchmont.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1694 words

HEADLINE: RUSSIA REBUFFS U.S. ON TOUGHER MOVES AGAINST BELGRADE

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 8

 BODY:
Underscoring the international community's problems in pushing through even modest measures to punish the Serbs for resisting a peace accord for Bosnia and Herzegovina, Russia refused today to accept a toughened set of American-sponsored sanctions against Belgrade.
In a threat to Washington's hopes for a positive vote on the new sanctions at the United Nations on Monday, Russia told the Security Council that it cannot agree to their main points: seizing Yugoslav transport equipment, banning all ships entering Yugoslav waters and more strictly enforcing an existing trade embargo. 
 Russia's representative at the United Nations, Yuli M. Voronstov, said he would consult with Moscow over the weekend and report its decision before the Council votes on Monday morning. It was unclear whether Russia would merely abstain or break with the United States for the first time since the end of the cold war by using its veto to block the resolution for new sanctions.
 
No Military Sentiment
 There is no sentiment at the Council for military action to punish Serbia, beyond the measures already approved to enforce a no-flight rule over Bosnia that has no military importance.
Perhaps trying to take advantage of the Russian move, and also to forestall a Council vote, the Bosnian Serbs sent a letter to the United Nations mediators contending that their position had been "misrepresented" and saying that they wanted to reopen negotiations on the peace plan in Geneva.
After the Bosnian Serb decision last Friday and Saturday not to sign the United Nations-sponsored peace plan, the Clinton Administration said it wanted to get a prompt Security Council resolution further tightening the economic sanctions on Serbia and Montenegro, the two remaining republics that make up Yugoslavia. That vote was put off until Monday to accommodate a Russian request.
The Russian position appeared to reflect the quandary posed for President Boris N. Yeltsin by the drive to strengthen the trade blockade of Yugoslavia. The effort by Washington to get sanctions is based on the hope that the move would force Belgrade to end the fighting in Bosnia by pressing its Serbian allies there to reverse themselves and accept the peace plan.
 
Sensitive Issue in Moscow
 For Russia to vote in favor of such additional sanctions would infuriate President Yeltsin's opponents in the Russian Parliament and elsewhere who contend that Russia has an obligation to back its Serbian "brothers," who share the Orthodox religion. The issue is particularly sensitive because of the April 25 referendum testing Mr. Yeltsin's political power. If Mr. Yeltsin holds firm against the additional sanctions, it could produce a Russian veto. That would annoy his Western backers and jeopardize billions of dollars of aid he hopes to receive in coming months. But an abstention might lead the Serbs to believe that they have stronger Russian backing than they actually have and encourage their defiance.
The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, wrote today to the two Balkan mediators, Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, saying he wants to reopen direct peace negotiators with them and Bosnia's Muslim and Croat leaders in Geneva as soon as possible. Mr. Vance, the former Secretary of State, is due to step down soon and be replaced by Thorvald Stoltenberg, Norway's former Foreign Minister.
Contending that the Bosnian Serb refusal to accept the peace plan has been "widely misrepresented," Dr. Karadzic said, "We should like you to know we are ready for the resumption of the Geneva talks as soon as possible. The time has come for direct talks among the sides to the conflict on the basis of the positive achievements so far."
But the United States, Britain, France and other countries supporting tighter trade controls on Yugoslavia say they still want to press ahead with a vote on the new resolution next Monday unless Russia threatens to block it by using its veto as a permanent Council member.
Russia's United Nations representative, Yuli M. Vorontsov, told the Security Council this morning that speedy adoption of a new sanctions resolution is not necessary because the cease-fire in Bosnia is holding and because Vitaly I. Churkin, Russia's special envoy dealing with the Yugoslavian crisis, has reported progress in the talks he held with the Yugoslav leadership in Belgrade on Wednesday.
Mr. Churkin, the Deputy Foreign Minister, is expected here later this week to discuss his Belgrade talks with Council members and the mediators.
America's United Nations representative, Madeleine K. Albright, with support from Britain and France, expressed surprise and irritation at the abrupt change in the Russian attitude. The change came after extensive consultations on Wednesday, when Mr. Vorontsov made no mention of the reservations he suddenly raised today.
Russia also submitted a list of amendments to the new draft resolution that are designed to reverse the tightening of the trade embargo proposed by the United States, Britain and France. Most other members now favor tightening the embargo, following the Bosnian Serbs' rejection last week of the Vance-Owen peace plan, which the Croats and Muslims have accepted.
 
Sticking Point on Imports
 Mr. Vorontsov expressed opposition to new plans to ban all shipping from the Yugoslavian Federation's territorial waters and to tighten controls over cargo boats sailing the Danube through its territory. He suggested that Yugoslavia be allowed to import essential humanitarian goods more easily.
At first Britain and France wanted the new resolution to give strong endorsement to the Vance-Owen plan. And they hoped the Council would adopt it last Friday or Saturday just before the Bosnian Serbs' parliament met to decide whether to follow the Muslims' example and agree to the peace proposals.
But the Clinton Administration refused to support an unqualified endorsement of the Vance-Owen proposal, which it once criticized as rewarding Serbian "ethnic cleansing," although it offered no alternative. In the end it would only agree to say that the Council "commends" the plan and "calls on" the Serbs to accept it too.
 
Sought Postponement
 The American Administration then called for the vote to be postponed a second time, until after President Clinton's Vancouver summit meeting with President Yeltsin, saying that it also wanted time to strengthen the sanctions.
The original text sought a ban on all shipments of goods through Yugoslavia; new restrictions on freighters moving down the Danube; impoundment of all Yugoslavian ships, planes and trains in foreign countries, and a freeze on Belgrade's overseas financial assets.
In addition, the United States suggested banning all ships from entering Yugoslavian territorial waters, imposing even tighter control over ships moving on the Danube through Yugoslavia and freezing Yugoslavian-owned buildings and land in foreign countries as well as financial assets. It also proposed that the sanctions take effect as soon as they are voted instead of 15 days later.
But Britain, France and Russia succeeded in retaining the 15-day grace period and watering down the plan to take over Yugoslavian real estate and land. Only Russia objected to declaring a naval exclusion zone in Yugoslavia's territorial waters.

NATO READY ON FLIGHT BAN

 PARIS, April 8 (Special to The New York Times) -- NATO gave the go-ahead today for warplanes from the United States, France and the Netherlands to start enforcing the United Nations ban on flights over Bosnia and Herzegovina beginning on Monday.
The 16-nation alliance, which agreed to carry out the enforcement last week, approved a detailed operational plan at a meeting today in its Brussels headquarters. "Everything is in place," said NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Woerner. "We have already started to deploy."
NATO sources said 24 fighters from the United States, 14 from France and 18 from the Netherlands, would participate initially. Their pilots will have authority to shoot down aircraft that violate the zone over which flights have been banned if they ignore warnings to leave the area and return to their bases.
 
 
 
BALKAN UPDATE
 The commander of the United Nations military force in BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA abandoned his effort yesterday to reach the besieged Muslim enclave at SREBRENICA after hundreds of Serbs blocked his convoy on the road between ZVORNIK and BRATUNAC. The commander, Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon of France, was to be accompanied by 150 Canadian troops from VISOKO who were to reinforce the small United Nations garrison in the enclave.
In another setback to United Nations relief efforts in Bosnia, Serbian soldiers searching a truck carrying flour to a Muslim suburb of SARAJEVO discovered 5,000 rounds of ammunition hidden in 48 boxes beneath the flour sacks. The United Nations said the ammunition had been placed aboard the vehicle by unknown people in an attempt to discredit the relief operations.
Suggesting that Yugoslavia had been supporting Serbian forces in Bosnia, the World Court, in THE HAGUE, urged the Belgrade Government to insure that any forces it controls in Bosnia do not violate the 1948 convention banning genocide. Although Bosnia won an implicit condemnation of Yugoslavia, it failed to persuade the Court to take immediate compensatory action.
In BONN, a court ruled that German military personnel could remain on NATO air surveillance planes that will help enforce a United Nations ban on Serbian military flights over Bosnia.
At the UNITED NATIONS, Russia refused to accept a toughened set of American-sponsored sanctions against the Yugoslav Government in BELGRADE, telling the Security Council that it cannot agree to the main points of a plan that calls for seizing of Yugoslav transport equipment, a ban on all ships entering Yugoslav waters, and stricter enforcement of an exisiting trade embargo.
And in WASHINGTON, a senior Defense Department official insisted that the use of limited force to stop Serbian attacks in Bosnia had not yet been ruled out.
