HEADLINE: Dinkins Proposes a 2-Year Freeze On New York City's Water Rates

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Responding to fierce complaints of higher water bills in New York City, the Dinkins administration proposed a two-year freeze on water and sewer rates yesterday and a ceiling on those rates in the two years after that.
The Mayor said his proposal would cut water bills by $188 million during the next two years, or more than $100 for the average homeowner. The city had forecast that water rates would increase by 7 percent in the next fiscal year and 10 percent in the following year. 
 New York will be able to afford the freeze, city officials said, by using water-bill surpluses from the 1992 fiscal year and from another surplus it expects this year, which ends June 30. The city also expects to save through conservation measures and cost-cutting steps that the administration announced yesterday.
Although money from such surpluses must be spent on water and sewage operations under city bond rules, Mr. Dinkins could have chosen to use the money to upgrade sewage plants or on other capital projects. But in this election year, the Mayor has decided instead to use the money to prevent increases in water bills, thus producing savings where they are likely to have a big impact on middle-class residents and building owners.
 
Sharp Jump in Rates
 The sharp jump in water and sewage rates has been a problem for the Dinkins administration, which has been wrestling with ways to curb the increases during the last few years. Five years ago, during the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, the city began installing meters in every house and apartment building to encourage conservation by making consumers pay for the water they actually used. Previously, owners had paid fixed rates. The meter-installation project, coupled with the cost of refurbishing treatment plants, helped to push water rates higher.
In the last two years, the average water bill increased 30 percent. Some housing advocates have complained that low-income residents, who often live where pipes are old or faulty and leaks are prevalent, were particularly hard hit.
Mr. Dinkins has been under pressure from housing advocates, homeowners and building owners to reverse the trend. And there has been concern at City Hall that the increasing cost of water would help to paint New York as an undesirable place for businesses.
The average single-family home in New York City now pays $350 in water and sewage charges, up from $220 in the 1990 fiscal year. The city had forecast that bills would have increased to $420 in fiscal 1994 and $593 by fiscal 1997.
The Mayor's proposal would freeze water rates at their present level for next year and 1995 and establish a ceiling of $750 a year for single-family homes in the two fiscal years beginning in 1996. Two-family homes would pay no more than $1,250 a year; six-family homes would be limited to $3,250 a year.
The Mayor's proposal is subject to the approval of the New York City Water Board, an independent seven-member group responsible for setting water rates. The Dinkins administration will present the plan to the board next week and hearings will take place during the next few weeks. Mayoral aides say they expect the proposal to be approved at the water board's May 11 meeting.
 
Proposal for Spring
 In a news conference at City Hall to announce the proposal yesterday, Barbara J. Fife, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, said the timing of the announcement was a result of the requirement that the Mayor propose a water rate to the board each spring.
Responding to questions on whether the announcement was politically motivated, Ms. Fife said: "This is a move to provide some relief to the people of the City of New York. If it were political, we wouldn't have taken an action that would affect the next few years. We would have done a one-shot deal."
The Mayor also announced cost-saving moves to help pay for the rate freeze. They include a rebate program for bill payers who undertake various water-saving measures and another for customers who fit their bathrooms with water-conserving fixtures. The program, which will begin in the Bronx in September, will provide a rebate of as much as $240 for each bathroom fitted with the new fixtures.
 
Extending Flat Rates
 In addition, the Mayor announced that the city would extend a program allowing recently metered buildings to continue to pay flat-rate charges for an interim period and that it would eliminate a surcharge on industrial waste paid by businesses.
Albert F. Appleton, Commissioner of the City Department of Environmental Protection, said that his department had been able to save money in several areas. He said, for example, that the recession had kept the cost of capital projects far lower than original estimates and that interest payments had been lower than previously anticipated because of the refinancing of long-term debt.

HEADLINE: Future Doctors Unsettled By Health-Care Changes

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 8

 BODY:
In the library, at home, even between cuts in the operating room, the prospect of dramatic change in the health-care system is the talk among medical students in this city known as a mecca for future doctors because of its concentration of teaching hospitals and medical schools.
"We'll be in the O.R. taking out an extra pair of gloves, and someone will say, 'You're wasting those gloves, Hillary wouldn't like that,' " said Mark Brown, a fourth-year student at Tufts University School of Medicine.
 
Expecting Less Freedom
 Mr. Brown and his fellow students say they know they will have less freedom in their practices than their predecessors in the profession, who earned an average of $170,600 in 1991, and they expect to earn less money, particularly if they go into specialties like ophthalmology, radiology or cardiac surgery, which have traditionally been among the highest paid. They seem resigned to the end of what many refer to as the golden age of medicine. 
 But in interviews, two dozen medical students at Tufts were unanimous in saying that major change in the health-care system is long overdue.
They are worried that the national health-care plan, which is being developed by a task force headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton and is to be unveiled in May, will not fix what is wrong, or that it will only add to the bureaucracy that provokes some older doctors into warning them that they have picked the wrong career. Mostly a group of people who have been carefully planning their futures since childhood, the students are worried about the unknown.
 
'Like I'm in Limbo'
 "What kind of office am I going to have?" Monica Lumpkin, a third-year student who wants to go into family practice, asked over dinner with two classmates. "I feel like I'm in limbo. I don't like the sound of managed competition. It sounds too detached from public health. The doctor would be even more powerless."
Across the table was John Rhee, who has known since childhood that he would be a doctor, like his father and his grandfather. "Suddenly, there are all these restrictions being placed on doctors," Mr. Rhee said. "What about restrictions on lawyers? We have two lawyers in the White House."
 
Easing of Burden
 While the details have not been announced, President Clinton has said he favors managed competition, in which more doctors and patients join prepaid plans, like health maintenance organizations, that compete over price and quality. Administration officials have also spoken of price controls for doctors.
Ms. Lumpkin says she worries that H.M.O.'s might not offer patients the best care, or enough autonomy for doctors. But she also says that since she spends nearly every waking hour studying medicine she has not had time to learn much about H.M.O.'s.
Other students say that H.M.O.'s, or other group practices, might actually be a blessing, helping them balance career and family. One, Holly Gallivan, was inspired to become a doctor by her father, a thoracic surgeon, but says she does not want to be on call 24 hours, like her father. "I want to have time for my family," she said. "If I could have time, I'd sacrifice the big bucks. I don't expect to make a lot of money."
Many of the students have been spilling out their anxieties to professors like Dr. Sherwood L. Gorbach, who graduated from Tufts in 1962, when medical students had a nearly universal vision of their futures in private practice. For all their concerns, Dr. Gorbach said, he believes that today's students may ultimately be more satisfied with their profession than his former classmates who, at their 30th class reunion last year, were awash in bitterness over the Government's intrusions.
 
Money vs. Idealism
 "Today's students are entering without this expectation of free enterprise," he said. "They are being told that while their profession will always be well compensated, they are not going to make these fabulous salaries. When we interview students, we find they're coming for idealistic reasons."
Still, with skyrocketing medical school costs -- tuition at Tufts is $27,000 a year -- money is a central concern of students here, who will graduate with an average debt of $70,000. And while they may support reforms to extend care to all and limit costs, they do not necessarily want the changes to come at their expense.
"Everyone deserves health care," said Seth Linker, a fourth-year student who is planning to be an ear, nose and throat surgeon. "But I think I deserve to get back exactly that I put in: up to half a million dollars."
 
'Deserve to Be Compensated'
 If the experience of older doctors is a guide, Mr. Linker, who is also training as a plastic surgeon, could eventually earn well over $300,000 a year. "I think it's wrong to become wealthy off someone else's misery," he said. "On the other hand a part of me says: 'I worked hard. I'm six years behind my friends economically and socially. I deserve to be compensated.' "
But he added: "If the Government says I can't make over $100,000, I'm not going to scream." He also said he planned to provide free care to patients who could not pay.
David Goldberg, a fourth-year student who plans to pursue a career in invasive cardiology, was still in a state of disbelief last week over his exit interview with his financial aid adviser. "I owe $150,000," he said. "Depending on what Bill Clinton does, I could crash and burn. I've worked very hard, but I'm just a little scared."
Ahead for Mr. Goldberg is a residency at Yale-New Haven Hospital: three years of 100-hour weeks, with a $29,000 starting salary. Eventually, he expects to earn at least $200,000. "After putting in all this training and earning minimum wage for a long time," he said, "I deserve to be comfortable."
His comments, made in an informal discussion of health-care reform with 15 other students, provoked enormous dissent. "What does the world owe you?" demanded Peter C. Park, a second-year student, who intends to work as a family practitioner in the inner city, earning about $80,000 a year. "There are people living on the street."
When the students talk of the urgency of reform, their experiences shape the discussion. "I was working in an eye and ear infirmary, and this woman who was working a minimum-wage job came in needing an audiogram that costs $200," said Tim Pawlik, a second-year student who says he wants to practice in the inner city. "The secretary said, 'She doesn't have health insurance.' So she couldn't get the test."
Another second-year student, Karen Tarbell, said she had seen 9-year-olds at homeless shelters who have not received any immunizations.
Mark Brown frets about the waste he sees in hospitals. "We'll order a chest X-ray, and we can't find it," he said. "So what do we do? We order another one for another $60."
The students have plenty of ideas for Mrs. Clinton's task force. Sarah deFerranti thinks money could be saved by cutting back on high technology. "They should only have two M.R.I.'s per city," she said, referring to costly magnetic resonance imaging scanners, which many experts say are overused and which most hospitals in Boston have. "Let's put all our money into prevention, not technology."
Her classmate, Ms. Gallivan, agreed. But Boston, she said, is a city where it is hard not to become enthralled by technology. "Oh, boy, the toys they have in Boston," she said. "I went to the ophthalmologist the other day. He had a laser in his office, and all kinds of gadgets. I know that's very expensive, but still it was exciting."
President Clinton has talked about the need for more primary care doctors, such as those in family practice or pediatrics, who can provide more care at lower cost than specialists. So has Dr. Morton A. Madoff, the dean of the Tufts' medical school.
While a lot of first- and second-year students may talk about going into primary care, only 27 percent of each graduating class actually does. "They hear primary care getting denigrated," Dr. Madoff said. "They recognize the tremendous income disparity. They look at their debt rising."
Ms. Gallivan said primary care seems to violate the ethic that motivates so many Boston doctors and medical students. "You're always supposed to be doing the next-hardest thing," she said. And, this surgeon's daughter said, becoming a surgeon is the next-hardest thing.
Mr. Rhee, who is in his third year, is leaning toward one of the higher paid specialties, radiology -- a choice he says was influenced by his projected debt of more than $100,000.
All the uncertainty about incomes has apparently not helped the atmosphere in the operating room. Mark Brown was scrubbing up for a hernia repair when the chief resident asked him what specialty he had chosen. Ophthalmology, Mr. Brown replied.
The chief resident expressed resentment that ophthalmologists could make as much for a 30-minute cataract procedure as some surgeons do for three-hour operations, Mr. Brown said.
But the resident was aware that cataract surgery fees were likely to be cut. "He was very satisfied that I was going to make less money," Mr. Brown said. "Every specialty hates the others. We're about to be assaulted, and all we can do is pick on each other."

DOCTORS SEE NEED FOR REFORM
 BOSTON, April 8 (AP) -- A survey of doctors in the United States, Canada and the former West Germany found that a majority of them believe their health-care systems need reform.
The survey, directed by Dr. Robert J. Blendon of the Harvard School of Public Health, was published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.
The survey found that 23 percent of doctors in the United States, 33 percent in Canada and 48 in Germany thought their health-care systems worked well.
The telephone survey was conducted in early 1991 and had responses from 602 Americans, 507 in Canadians and 519 in Germans. The margin of error was plus or minus 4 percentage points.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET;
CLINTON OUTLINES SPENDING PACKAGE OF $1.52 TRILLION

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
President Clinton today sent Congress a $1.52 trillion budget full of new details showing how he wants to reduce the Government's deficit while spending more money on public works, education and retraining jobless workers.
In presenting its 1994 budget, the Administration acknowledged that domestic spending under Mr. Clinton's plan would exceed the limits that Congress set in 1990 and reaffirmed this year. But Mr. Clinton and his budget director, Leon E. Panetta, vowed to fight for their proposals. 
 Mr. Clinton's budget closely follows the blueprint he sketched in a speech to Congress on Feb. 17. But his appeal to Congress for deficit reduction was so effective that lawmakers, in their initial deliberations on the budget, outdid the President.
 
Some Proposals Jeopardized
 Their apparent zeal to control Government spending now jeopardizes some of Mr. Clinton's proposals to spend more on public works, education, job training and other domestic programs.
Like Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, Mr. Clinton predicts that the budget deficit will decline -- in both absolute terms and as a share of the nation's total economic output -- if Congress follows his prescription. But Mr. Clinton's minutely detailed plan for the next five years takes no account of his ambitious proposals to overhaul the nation's health-care system.
Mr. Panetta asserted that those proposals, scheduled for submission to Congress this spring, would control health costs, slow the growth of the Medicare and Medicaid programs and further reduce the Federal budget deficit.
 
Republican Criticism
 But many people in and out of Government say the President's plan to guarantee health care for all Americans is just as likely to create big new demands on the Federal Treasury, which could drive the deficit far above the record $290 billion posted in 1992.
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said of Mr. Clinton's budget, "It's pretty much what they promised -- more taxes, more spending."
Mr. Panetta said: "It's a courageous budget. It asks every American -- senior citizens, Federal workers, doctors, hospitals, farmers, the wealthy, everyone -- to contribute to this effort to put this country back on the right track."
But Senator Dole, who helped organize a Republican filibuster against parts of Mr. Clinton's economic recovery plan, said, "People out there in the real world just don't understand how record-setting tax increases and a taxpayer-financed spending spree by Congress will solve the deficit or put Americans back to work."
 
1994 Deficit: $264 Billion
 Mr. Clinton's budget predicts a deficit of $322 billion for the current fiscal year. For the 1994 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, he proposes spending of $1.52 trillion and expects receipts of $1.25 trillion, for a deficit of $264 billion.
Tax collections and Government spending are acutely sensitive to changes in economic conditions. In formulating his budget, Mr. Clinton adopted the economic assumptions of the Congressional Budget Office, widely regarded by private economists as realistic. Democrats often charged that Mr. Reagan's economic assumptions were unduly optimistic.
In just seven weeks as budget officials recalculated Mr. Clinton's proposals, the budget blueprint has changed in ways that underline the difficulty of cutting the deficit:
*Five-year savings in Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, shrank to $46 billion, from the $63 billion assumed by the Clinton Administration in February.
*Revenue from increased taxation of Social Security benefits, originally put at $29 billion over five years, are now estimated at $23 billion.
*The projected total of budget deficits over the next five years has grown by $31 billion, to $1.2 trillion, since Mr. Clinton outlined his proposals in February.
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, explained that with today's budget document, the President is "filling in the detail of proposals that were made in February, providing committees of Congress with more specific guidance."
 
Steps in Complex Process
 Mr. Clinton's budget is one step in a complex process by which Washington decides how to extract money from taxpayers and redistribute it for purposes it considers likely, in the words of the Constitution, to "promote the general welfare." The precise contours of Government spending and taxes depend on hundreds of decisions to be made by Congress over the next six months.
On March 31 and April 1, Congress approved a general plan, the budget resolution. To execute that plan, the committees of Congress -- 26 Appropriations subcommittees and 23 authorizing committees -- will make specific decisions, which may or may not conform to the President's wishes, depending in part on the effectiveness of White House lobbyists.
In his formal budget request today, Mr. Clinton refined some of his tax proposals, to make the energy tax more acceptable on Capitol Hill and to allow corporations to take tax deductions for executive pay over $1 million a year, provided the pay is tied to performance.
A panoramic view of Mr. Clinton's budget suggests that the Pentagon and farmers are among the big losers. Military spending, which began to decline under President Bush with the dissolution of the Soviet bloc, would decline 14 percent in the next five years, to $239 billion in 1998, from $277 billion this year.
Spending for agriculture would fall 42 percent, to $12.6 billion in 1998, from $21.9 billion this year. The Agriculture Department said that a return to more normal crop yields and weather would reduce the need for farm price supports and other Government subsidies.
By contrast, Mr. Clinton shows Medicare spending up 62 percent and Medicaid up 84 percent over the next five years. The cost of Medicare, $132.7 billion this year, would rise to $215.5 billion in 1998. The Federal share of Medicaid, the health program for low-income people, would rise to $148.3 billion in 1998, from $80.5 billion this year.
 
$296 Billion in New Revenue
 Over the five-year period covered by Mr. Clinton's budget, outlays for job training and employment programs would rise 41 percent, to $10.9 billion from the current $7.7 billion. Housing assistance would rise 39 percent, to $29.6 billion from $21.3 billion. Food stamps and other nutrition programs would grow 28 percent, to $45.4 billion from $35.4 billion.
The cost of the earned-income tax credit, for low-income workers with children, would more than double, to $22.9 billion in 1998, from the current $8.4 billion. Mr. Clinton and antipoverty groups say the tax credit is a way to reward work.
President Clinton said his tax proposals would generate additional revenue of $296 billion over the next five years. That figure does not include the $23 billion that he wants to raise by increasing the taxation of Social Security benefits for people with incomes above certain levels: $25,000 a year for individuals, $32,000 for couples.
The Administration classifies the Social Security proposal as a cut in spending rather than a tax increase. Either way, beneficiaries say, they lose money.
Even with Mr. Clinton's attempt at fiscal austerity, the White House acknowledges that the Federal debt, the accumulated total of all Federal borrowing, will continue its relentless rise, from $3 trillion last year to $4.6 trillion in 1998. (The numbers show debt held by the public and do not include Government securities held by Government trust funds.)
Representative John R. Kasich, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, said: "While the Clinton budget will not be dead on arrival, there's no question that it's debt on arrival. It saddles Americans with $1.2 trillion in additional national debt over the next five years."
The Clinton budget drew a tepid reaction from environmental groups. Peter A. A. Berle, president of the National Audubon Society, called it "a mixed bag and, in some instances, a missed opportunity." He welcomed proposals for increased spending on waste water treatment, but said he was "very disappointed" with cuts in the land and water conservation fund, used to acquire land for future generations.
Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club, praised the Administration for proposing a new tax on "wasteful and polluting energy use." But he said the budget for the Environmental Protection Agency suggested that it was "still suffering from the abuse it received during the 1980's."
All told, spending for natural resources and the environment would decline under Mr. Clinton's budget, to $20.8 billion next year, from $21.9 billion this year. It would rise slowly, to $21.6 billion in 1998, but would not keep pace with inflation.
In his campaign last year, Mr. Clinton said he would "expand efforts to acquire new park lands and recreational sites." But in the new budget, spending for conservation and land management would decline from $4.7 billion this year to $3.8 billion next year and $3.4 billion in 1998.
 
Transportation Spending
 As expected, Mr. Clinton asked Congress to repeal certain restrictions on the use of Federal money for abortions. Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League, hailed the proposal, saying it would help poor women and Federal employees who depend on the Government to help finance their health care.
Mr. Clinton proposed major increases in Federal spending for mass transit, and much of the money would go to New York and New Jersey. Nationwide, the total would rise 37 percent, to $5.1 billion in 1998, from $3.7 billion this year.
Jack Gilstrap, executive vice president of the American Public Transit Association, said he was pleased with the proposal, "the biggest increase any Administration has offered in 13 years."
The deficits shown in Mr. Clinton's budget would be much bigger but for a growing surplus in the Social Security trust fund, which tends to mask the shortages in other parts of the budget. The Administration estimates that the trust fund surplus, $318.5 billion at the end of 1992, will reach $736 billion in 1998.
Mr. Clinton's budget would carry out his commitment to reduce the number of people working in the executive branch of the Government. The number of civilian employees, now 2.1 million, would decline by 102,000 in the next two years. Sixty percent of the reduction would occur in the Defense Department.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Acts to Sweeten Pot for Voters

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 8

 BODY:
Despite a new round of appeals and incentives from abroad to push for economic reform, President Boris N. Yeltsin is raising wages, increasing spending and issuing low-cost credits for bankrupt industries as part of a campaign to win a crucial referendum this month.
The steps being carried out by Mr. Yeltsin include linking interest on savings to inflation, raising benefits for the military and maintaining price controls -- all of which economists say swell the Government deficit and aggravate inflation. 
 Mr. Yeltsin's actions come as Russia is being pressed by the Clinton Administration and leaders of the other industrial nations to impose many painful austerity measures in order to get inflation under control by curbing Government subsidies and credits.
Inflation is now running at nearly 30 percent a month , which economists say has devastated Russia's chances for increased trade and investment.
 
Meeting in Tokyo
 The major industrial countries, known as the Group of Seven, plan to ease the terms for Moscow to repay $80 billion in debts and to offer another $30 billion in grants and loans at a meeting of foreign and finance ministers in Tokyo on April 14 and 15.
In Washington, Administration officials are also proposing that the International Monetary Fund and other creditors loosen some of their requirements for fiscal probity in Moscow, but only if the Russian Government shows good faith by carrying out some economic reforms.
Because much of the aid being proposed is contingent on seeing Russia carry out further reforms, Mr. Yeltsin's actions are raising questions about whether the new aid will ever be fully distributed.
In the last year, only a little more than half the $24 billion in aid that was promised ever found its way to Russia because of a failure to control inflation and rein in the money supply.
 
'I Really Am Very Skeptical'
 "I really am very skeptical," a Western envoy said. "I don't see what you can do with the money supply out of control. It all could take longer and be more painful than people realize."
Western officials nonetheless indicate that they seem to understand that Mr. Yeltsin must first renew his political mandate.
Mr. Yeltsin faces an important plebiscite on his presidency and his reforms on April 25, and aid from abroad is being organized and timed to help him then.
A senior Western diplomat said that unless Mr. Yeltsin can win handily, restoring his mandate and giving him new leverage over the legislature and the Central Bank, which the legislature controls, economic reform in Russia "will continue to go nowhere slowly."
 
Economics and Politics
 Boris G. Fyodorov, Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Finance and Yeltsin ally who is the main proponent of economic reform, says, "Everything depends on April 25."
But the campaign for the referendum shows that in Russia no less than anywhere else, good economics are often bad politics. Even after President Clinton and others have proclaimed their support for reform in Russia, there remains deep skepticism about the kinds of medicine prescribed.
As defined by foreign creditors, for example, good economics mean much tighter money, less Government spending, better tax collection, higher interest rates, broader property rights, stricter interpretation of bankruptcy law and the readiness to accept significantly higher unemployment.
One critic of such steps, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, is instead promising new credits for the energy industry and for farmers as the spring sowing season starts. He is also criticizing the sale of Government-owned businesses to the private sector and talking of the need to preserve a large state sector and create price controls.
 
May Not Be Decisive
 Many foreign and Russian analysts also caution that April 25 may very well not be decisive, and that it may actually perpetuate the political and economic stalemate until elections can be held for president and legislature.
Referring to some of Mr. Yeltsin's deficit-swelling steps, Mr. Fyodorov said in an interview Wednesday with the newspaper Rossiskaya Gazeta that the Government would simply have to find a way to finance these new political commitments.
"The budget as such is already all but nonexistent," he added, disclosing that the deficit this year was actually about $23 billion, based on revenues of about $14.9 billion.
He said it was essential to bring inflation down to less than 100 percent a year, from a current rate that is perhaps 40 times higher than that. "Otherwise everthing we do falls apart," he said. "It's impossible to fund anything and any planning or investment becomes absurd."
 
Attack on Central Bank
 Mr. Fyodorov also continued his strong attack on the Central Bank and its chairman, Viktor Gerashchenko, who, he said, "displays astonishing ignorance." He cited a statement from Mr. Gerashchenko to the effect that with high inflation, the bank needed to issue even more rubles.
Foreign economists pushing for reforms also say that the Central Bank has not established a system in which money can be transferred easily among accounts in Russia. Many say they believe that the bank must eventually become answerable to the President of Russia, and not the legislature.
Deputy Prime Minister Aleksandr N. Shokhin, a Fyodorov ally, said everyone in the West "is turning to us at every corner to ask: 'Well, how is it? When will you come to terms with the Central Bank?' "
The prospects for a clear mandate for Mr. Yeltsin have also been clouded by confusion over the regulations governing the referendum. The Congress of People's Deputies, which dominated by Mr. Yeltsin's political foes, has ruled that Mr. Yeltsin must win the votes of half of all registered voters, an almost impossible task.
 
Taking Account of the Problems
 It is now expected that, no matter what the actual vote is, Mr. Yeltsin will claim a renewed popular mandate if he wins the majority of the votes cast. If the results are disappointing, his advisers suggest, he may resign to force new elections.
Foreign Governments seem to be trying hard to take account of the real political problems Mr. Yeltsin faces.
"You have to set them macroeconomic standards, but ones they can reach in the current political and financial situation," a Western envoy said.
In recent appearances and interviews, Prime Minister Chernomyrdin has called for "corrections" in the reforms and sharply attacked the privatization program and its director, Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais. The Prime Minister added that many mistakes were being made in the crucial effort to turn state property over to private hands.
 
Compared to Collectivization
 In an especially inflammatory analogy, Mr. Chernomyrdin compared privatization to the Soviet collectivization of farmland -- implying the process was brutal, ideological and arbitrary.
Mr. Chubais, reacting angrily, said there could be no comparison to collectivization, under which "the Bolsheviks physically annihilated three million people" and sent another seven million to Siberia.
Mr. Chernomyrdin also said that destroying the Soviet planning and distribution ministries, Gosplan and Gossnab, was a mistake, and that they were still needed "in a slightly different form.
Mikhail Berger, the economics editor of Izvestia, said Mr. Chernomyrdin's recent remarks had badly shaken Mr. Fyodorov and other reformers.
"If you take half the economy away from the market and revise the basic principles of privatization, then what is left of the reforms?" he asked.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy
President Clinton sent Congress a $1.52 trillion budget that provides details of how he wants to reduce the deficit while spending more on public works, education and retraining jobless workers. But his detailed five-year spending and taxing plan takes no account of the overhaul of the health-care system. [Page A1.]
The Clinton Administration proposed that companies could continue to deduct seven-figure compensation packages as a business expense as long as they were tied to corporate financial performance and approved by shareholders. [D1.] 
 Producer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, but the core inflation rate, which excludes figures for the erratic energy and food sectors, rose only one-tenth of 1 percent. The report calmed fears of resurgent inflation. [D1.]
Weak March sales were reported by almost all of the nation's large retail chains, which were hurt by bad weather and economic uncertainty. The drop continued a deceleration that began in January and is expected to continue. [D2.]
 
International
A Japanese company's purchase of the only American maker of some computer components used in the Patriot and Trident missiles contained key national security problems missed by the Federal Government when it approved the deal, according to a study by the Commerce Department. [D1.]

Synergen's chief executive resigned over management differences and a top research officer will become a consultant. [D3.]
The president of Staples resigned and the office supply retailer reorganized its top management, promoting two executives. [D3.]

Stocks lurched downward for most of the session but ended barely changed. The Dow closed down 0.54 point. [D4.]

Crude oil tumbled amid reports of weaker-than-expected demand and concern that Kuwait will flood the market. [D13.]

HEADLINE: Federal Judges Blame Money Woes for Slowdown

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
Facing what they say is a severe budget shortfall, most Federal judges around the nation have stopped scheduling new civil jury trials.
While there is disagreement about whether the postponements are prompted by brinkmanship or depleted budgets, there is no question that thousands of civil trials are being delayed. Most are commercial disputes, but the backlog also includes civil rights and copyright cases and other lawsuits filed under Federal law. 
 A recent memorandum to the district courts from a committee of the Judicial Conference, the policy-making arm of the courts, said that because of budget problems, no new civil jury trials could begin after May 12.
"The executive committee very much regrets that this extreme action is necessary, but I trust all of you understand the severe fiscal situation in which we find ourselves," L. Ralph Mecham, the director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, wrote in the memo.
 
Indigents' Trials Delayed
 Court administrators also say that the budget for many lawyers for indigent defendants in Federal criminal cases will run out as early as the end of this month. That will make it impossible for the trials to begin until Congress provides more money, which is not expected until September at the earliest.
About half of the 90,000 indigent defendants that pass through the Federal courts each year are represented by private lawyers appointed and paid by the court under the Criminal Justice Act. The other half are represented by Public Defender offices, which are not affected by the courts' budget problems. More than four of every five Federal defendants are poor enough to qualify for Government-paid lawyers.
By law, criminal defendants in Federal cases must generally be tried within 10 weeks after they have been charged. Cases delayed because the Government can not pay a lawyer might be dismissed.
Even if there is no money to pay indigents' lawyers, administrators say they are trying to save money to pay for juries in criminal trials by putting off civil trials.
The increase in criminal cases during the Reagan and Bush years has overloaded many Federal dockets and dramatically increased the interval between filings and trials in civil cases. Even before the latest budget problems, civil trials in many Federal jurisdictions had been delayed because of enormous increases in Federal narcotics cases.
This year, court administrators say, the problem for civil litigants worsened because Congress provided the judiciary with $130 million less than judges said they needed. The problem could be resolved if Congress were to give the judges more money or, according to some judges, if court administrators took funds from other judicial programs.
Privately, a handful of judges and Congressional aides say that there is some money left from other criminal programs to pay for jurors and defense lawyers until Congress can act in the fall, and that the judges are simply pushing for more money.
The judges have asked for another $92 million on top of the $2.46 billion already provided. Nearly $2 billion of the budget is for the salaries and expenses of staff and judges. The budget also includes $68.8 million to pay for jurors and $215.1 million for lawyers' services.
The jurors are paid $40 a day plus expenses, like food and parking, and hotel charges when they are sequestered. Administrators say that another $7.5 million should be enough to pay for criminal and civil jurors until the next fiscal year begins in October.
 
Not 'Crying Wolf'
 "There's no doubt in my mind that this is a ploy," said a Federal judge who insisted on not being identified."They could still save millions of dollars if they were less extravagant with a lot of their expenses."
But court administrators and many judges disagree. They also say they cannot shift money from one program to another without Congressional permission, and that they have already taken pains to reduce unnecessary expenses.
"Far from crying wolf, the courts have worked very hard to reduce the costs," said Federal Judge William W. Schwarzer, the director of the Federal Judicial Center.
Whatever the causes of the slowdown, litigants from around the nation have begun to feel the pinch. By postponing cases, the courts are effectively making them more difficult to settle, since many are not resolved until the eve of trial. That, in turn, could increase the backlog of cases.
A few of the cases being delayed have enormous ramifications. For instance, one patent case that was set to begin in Federal district court in New Bern, N.C. in June between two drug makers, Barr Laboratories and Burroughs-Wellcome, may have to be postponed. The outcome of the case will determine the price and availability of the drug AZT, which is used to treat AIDS patients.
 
'Appalling Problem'
 Judges from around the nation expressed frustration and anger at the budget problems, but have already begun notifying lawyers that they cannot schedule new trials.
"It's an appalling problem," said Federal District Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. in Manhattan. "What just makes me sick at heart is that we are simply not able to do the nation's business."
He added: "This is not choosing between one aspect of spending or another; this is saying one of the branches of Government is out of business. This is about litigants being disenfranchised."
A handful of other judges say they will ignore the notice and proceed anyway by offering the jurors i.o.u.'s to be redeemed when the money comes in.
"I will tell the jurors they'll have to wait to get paid," said Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein of District Court in Brooklyn. "I don't imagine that it will be a big problem."
Shortfalls in the Federal judiciary's budget have become a perennial problem, although this year seems to be the worst in a long time. Seven years ago, Federal courts postponed civil cases for two weeks.
Last year court administrators narrowly averted an empty budget for indigent criminal defendants by getting permission from Congress to shift money from other criminal justice programs. Congress then provided more money in September. But this year, with Congress working on President Clinton's economic package, administrators and lawmakers say it will probably be months before more money for the judiciary is approved.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Inflation News Heartens the Bond Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
After several weeks of nervousness and a heavy selloff in the bond market, traders and investors got some reassuring news on inflation yesterday and drove the yields on Treasury bonds and notes sharply lower.
Prices of bonds and notes spiked higher in the morning after the Labor Department reported that the core producer inflation rate, which excludes food and energy prices, rose just a tenth of 1 percent in March, well below the rate in February and January and below market expectations. 
The negligible increase in the core inflation rate allowed the market to ignore what probably would have been a very disturbing four-tenths of 1 percent increase in the overall Producer Price Index for finished goods.
Prices surged again later in the day when the the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, offered reassuring comments on inflation, saying that the economy was nearing price stability.
By the end of a shortened trading day ahead of the Good Friday holiday today, the price of the 30-year bond was up 110/32 , while its yield plunged to 6.85 percent, down from 6.95 on Wednesday.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note, another longer-term issue that is sensitive to inflation, was up 24/32 as its yield fell to 5.96 percent, from 6.06 percent the day before.
The selloff in the market since early March had been sparked by sharp jumps in the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price index in January and February and a surprisingly large jump in jobs over the first quarter of the year. The data did not portend a surge in inflation but indicated that if the pace continued, inflation would not decline below last year's level, which some forecasters and investors were betting on, and that it would likely be a little higher.
Given how far the bond market had rallied, that was enough of a reason to sell until the outlook was clearer.
But while yesterday's inflation report was positive, the course of the market from here is still uncertain. The Consumer Price Index for March will be released today, when the market is closed. If the consumer price increase is not in line with the small rise in producer prices, much of the market's good feeling of yesterday would be lost.
Traders said part of yesterday's bond market surge came from buyers who had previously sold Treasury securities short because they expected the core inflation rate to be higher. When their speculative bet proved wrong, they had to buy back the securities quickly to limit their losses. That added to the sharp rise in prices and the steep decline in yields, said Andrew S. Brenner, a trader at Nomura Securities International.
Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, said the report on March producer prices -- combined with the recent declines in the prices of commodities like lumber and copper -- provides a signal that inflation will decline this year.
Yesterday, Mr. Yardeni reaffirmed his forecast of a 2 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index, compared with 2.9 percent in 1992. He said such a small increase would mean that the yield on the 30-year bond should move toward 6.5 percent or lower, which is below the 16-year closing low of 6.72 percent reached on March 8.
But other analysts are not as sanguine. While the March producer price data provided a signal that inflation is not rising as fast as it was in the first two months of the year, they still forecast that prices will rise at the same or a slightly faster pace this year. And that means bond yields will remain around their current levels, but in a trading range that will preclude a breakthrough to new lows.
 
Yields Are Locked
 "I think people understand that inflation is not going to be horrible," said Nancy Kimelman, the chief economist for Technical Data in Boston. "But they understand that it is not going to be 2.5 percent either and that keeps us confined in a trading range."
Robert Giordano, the director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he expected data later in the year to show the inflation rate slowing to around last year's level. He said such data would send bond yields to new lows.
"But whether or not this is the start of that is another question," he added, saying that for now he believes that yields are locked in a trading range.
The bond market's rally yesterday was also aided by other data, including a small decline in initial jobless benefits claims and weak March store sales, which indicate that the economy is growing at a slower pace than at the nearly 5 percent clip at the end of last year. The slower growth means there is little chance that prices will be pushed higher by the demand of consumers or the exhausting of production capacity.

HEADLINE: Limited U.S. Force Held Still an Option in Bosnia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
As senior Administration officials prepared to meet on Friday to discuss American options in the face of the apparent collapse of peace talks in Bosnia, a senior Defense official insisted today that the use of limited force to stop Serbian attacks has not yet been ruled out.
In recent public remarks, President Clinton has backed away from his campaign position that air strikes could be used to curb Serb aggression. And the weight of opinion within the Clinton Administration appears to be to rely on economic sanctions to try to slow the fighting. 
 But, reflecting divisions within the Administration, the senior Defense official said it was possible Washington might yet decide to use force if it became clear that the talks could not be revived.
"I do not think we are giving up on it," the official said. "We are going to look at it."
The "principals committee," a body of top Administration officials dealing with national security matters, is scheduled to meet Friday to review the situation in Bosnia.
Among the issues the Clinton Administration has yet to resolve is when to declare the peace negotiations conducted by former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen dead and what to do if the talks cannot be restarted.
The meeting comes as there are divisions within the Clinton Administration over its Bosnia policy. Citing objections by the United States' European allies and Russia to the use of limited force, the State Department has dropped any talk of military action to quell the fighting and has instead stressed the need to tighten economic sanctions on Serbia.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher has also said that Washington is consulting with its allies over exempting the Bosnian Government from the United Nations arms embargo, which has locked in the Serbian advantage. But Mr. Christopher has also gone out of his way to underscore that such a move could have serious drawbacks if the British and French responded by withdrawing the forces they have sent to Bosnia to guard aid convoys.
The American military, eager to avoid sliding into a quagmire, has argued that limited air strikes and arms shipments to the Bosnians would not be decisive.
But Defense Secretary Les Aspin continues to believe that air strikes should be considered and is sympathetic to the notion of lifting the arms embargo on the Bosnian Muslims, senior Administration officials have said in recent weeks.
In comments on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton appeared to side with the State Department by backing away from his campaign statements about using limited force. President Clinton stressed that the United States could not take any steps without the approval of its allies on the United Nations Security Council and suggested that the Serbs might be able to get their way if they could weather the economic embargo.
But Mr. Aspin has yet to press hard for using limited military force, officials say. And a senior Defense official said Mr. Clinton might yet opt for force.
"You have to ask yourself not what is going on now, but what it going to happen if it is clear that the Vance-Owen thing is not going to happen," the senior official said, asserting that the United States allies might drop their opposition to limited force if the killing continues.
The allied reluctance to use force also raises questions about the Clinton Administration's support of the peace negotiations.
Senior Defense officials have said in recent days that the Clinton Administration has been unable to muster sufficient support within the NATO alliance for dispatching a sizable peacekeeping force to Bosnia should the Clinton Administration succeed in persuading the Serbs to sign an accord.
The difficulties in using force appear to overshadow the West's willingness to enforce a no-flight zone over Bosnia. In Washington, the Pentagon said the United States had committed 12 Air Force jets and 12 Navy fighters from the aircraft carrier Roosevelt.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plan Adds Money For New York

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
The New York metropolitan region stands to benefit substantially from President Clinton's proposed increase in financing for mass-transit and social-welfare programs, according to analyses by state and city budget officials.
Mayor David N. Dinkins welcomed the budget proposal as a major change from the fiscal programs advanced by Republican administrations during the last 12 years, which eliminated many urban programs and reduced spending on others. 
 "For the first time in a dozen years, the proposals made by the President are good news for New York City and its residents," the Mayor said.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, which requires approval by Congress, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut would receive nearly half of the $1.4 billion proposed for mass-transit capital assistance, a testament to the political clout of the three-state Congressional delegation. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, is chairman of the Finance Committee and sponsor of the legislation that authorized the financing, while Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, New Jersey Democrat, is chairman of the transportation subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee.
 
'Good News for America'
 The mass-transit capital program would increase current spending by $640 million. Of that, New York would receive $318 million, New Jersey $226 million and Connecticut, $78 million. Under current law, New York receives $177 million, New Jersey, $207 million, and Connecticut, $57 million.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called the budget "good news for America," while Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, another Democrat, said that "President Clinton's priorities match those of the people of New Jersey."
However, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, who was elected as an independent, declined to comment, leaving Terry L. Muilenburg, director of the state's office in Washington, to sound a cautious note. "Our preliminary analysis looks favorable," she said, "but we're reserving final judgment."
Under the proposal, New York City would receive $300 million in mass-transit capital funds, an increase of $30 million; Buffalo would receive $5.4 million, a rise of $4 million; Rochester would get $3.3 million, up $1.5 million, and Syracuse, $3 million, up $1.6 million.
But New York would suffer a slight decrease in mass-transit operating expenses, to $120 million from $121.4 million.
The three states would also benefit from a $3 billion national increase in spending on highway programs, to $18.3 billion. New York would receive an increase of $159 million, to $918 million; New Jersey would get an increase of $55 million, to $529 million, and Connecticut would receive an increase of $56 million, to $335 million.
The New York metropolitan region also stands to benefit from a $137 million increase in funds for Amtrak, to $633 million. The railroad serves the northeast corridor, among other routes. None of the funds have been earmarked for specific areas.
The area's low-income population would benefit from Mr. Clinton's proposed increases in many social-welfare programs. New York State would receive a $49 million increase in child-nutrition funds, to $595 million; a $97 million increase for Head Start programs, to $292 million, and smaller increases in special supplemental food programs for women, infants and children, as well as refugee assistance programs.
 
Praise From Dinkins
 Mayor Dinkins cited $400 million proposed nationwide for programs for undocumented aliens as "one of the most important new initiatives in the President's budget." He said the program "would be a great benefit not only to those workers in this city but also to the city health facilities, which are the safety net of our health-care system."
New York State would also benefit from a proposed $600 million nationwide increase in grants used to rebuild low-income neighborhoods. The state would receive a $78 million increase, to $208 million. But funds for housing rental subsidies to the elderly and disabled would decrease by $65 million, to $118 million, and rent subisidies for the poor would decrease $18 million, to $9 million.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, noting the austere aspects of the President's budget, said: "While we would like to do better, the Clinton Administration definitely has the city's priorities at heart. For a change, urban programs are not being arbitrarily cut."
Mayor Dinkins expressed disappointment that the budget failed to provide $70 million for construction of sewage-treatment plants in New York City. "I will make every effort to get this program resurrected as the budget process moves forward," the Mayor said.
 
Gain for Housing Authority
 But he was pleased that funds for public housing operating assistance would rise nationwide to $2.52 billion from $2.28 billion, providing the New York City Housing Authority with an increase of $38 million, to $402 million.
Lyle Dennis, director of New Jersey's office in Washington, compared President Clinton's budget favorably with that of former President George Bush, which would have eliminated the Economic Development Administration, abolished community services block grants and killed several other programs that have helped the state.
"On balance, the state of New Jersey is treated fairly by the proposals which President Clinton has made," Mr. Dennis said.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Defends Big Stimulus Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 8

 BODY:
The Government has begun a vigorous defense of a huge new spending package to jump-start the economy and ease political pressure from Washington, even though details of the plan will not be announced for another week.
No figures have been disclosed, but it has been widely reported that the Government will announce from 12 trillion to 13 trillion yen in supplemental public works spending this year, or $105 billion to $115 billion. That follows a similar 10.7 trillion yen program begun last summer, which appears to have had little impact. 
 Critics of the plan say it has been shaped more by politics than economics and that the figures may have been massaged to make them seem larger. The real spending increases included in the budget, excluding sums that have no net impact on economic growth, are called ma mizu, or fresh water, by the Japanese.
Many Japanese and foreign economists contend that only a third to two-thirds of the new plan is ma mizu. Susumu Kato, the economist here with CS First Boston (Japan), said he expected only about 60 percent of the reported figure to represent a real increase. Jesper Koll, an economist here with S. G. Warburg Securities, put the figure at 40 percent because of what he said was double-counting and the use of Government money instead of private investment.
Finance Ministry officials, who called in foreign journalists today to discuss the matter, admitted that the previous stimulus plan was less than 100 percent ma mizu. But they insisted that there would be as much as 80 percent ma mizu in the new plan and that it would lift the economy to more than 3 percent growth this year from only about 1 percent growth in the fiscal year ended March 31.
Some officials warned that too much stimulus could ignite inflation, particularly in the property market.
"Of course, this kind of exercise is not a purely scientific exercise or a purely economic exercise," said one Finance Ministry official, who insisted that he not be identified. "It is a matter of politics as well."
The issue is important because the United States has urged Japan to stimulate its anemic economy to reduce its huge trade surplus, which hit a record $132.6 billion last year. A stronger domestic economy would mean that Japan would import more and that manufacturers would be able to sell more products at home rather than export them.
Next week, the finance and foreign ministers from the leading industrial nations, the so-called Group of Seven, will meet here, and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa is said to be eager to offer the spending package as evidence of Japan's sincerity in reducing its surplus.
More important, Mr. Miyazawa is scheduled to leave for Washington late next week, where he will meet with President Clinton, who has harshly criticized Japan's trade imbalance. The economic stimulus plan is expected to be part of a huge new financial program that Mr. Miyazawa will bring to Washington as an omiyage, the traditional souvenir that a Japanese traveler brings as a gift to his host.

HEADLINE: Chicago's Mile of Retailing Magic

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 8

 BODY:
In an era when staying alive is a major feat for a downtown shopping district, North Michigan Avenue's "Magnificent Mile" of department stores and boutiques is a standout in that it has continued to live up to its name.
"I don't think there's another street like it in the country," said Robert Middlemas, general manager of Midwest operations for Nordstrom Inc., a high-end department store chain that has been unable, to its dismay, to find a store site on the broad stretch of the avenue north of the Chicago River. "It's a Mecca for shopping." 
 A recent survey by Northern Realty Group Ltd., a commercial real estate broker and consultant based here, showed retail vacancy rates in the corridor at 4.9 percent overall and 1 percent for street-level sites. The survey also found that rental rates, which have been falling sharply in many urban areas, have been stable on the avenue in the last year.
"Vacancy rate is a very good barometer," said Robert W. Buckner, president of Thompson Associates, a retail consulting firm in Ann Arbor, Mich. "Five percent or less is an incredible downtown vacancy rate."
Total sales at the approximately 420 stores along the avenue and in the neighboring Oak Street and North Pier areas increased at a modest clip right through the recession and topped $1 billion for the first time last year, according to figures compiled by the Greater North Michigan Avenue Association, whose members include hoteliers and office managers as well as store owners.
Such figures have local realtors and Chicago boosters crowing that the Magnificent Mile, which is not quite a mile long, is otherwise well-named. It is far healthier, they assert, than more famous urban shopping destinations like Fifth Avenue in New York and Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, Calif.
Still, a Michigan Avenue address is no guarantee of success. Page Jewelry, a chain with 22 jewelry stores in large malls around the Midwest, including 7 in the Chicago area, closed its store in Chicago Place, an eight-story vertical mall anchored by Saks Fifth Avenue in 1991. Bonwit Teller and I. Magnin both shut struggling department stores, and realtors say that both Neiman Marcus and Bloomingdale's have been disappointed at various times with the performance of their stores. Gucci, which had a shop on two floors in the shopping center anchored by Bloomingdale's, gave up one of them to J. Crew.
Stores that appear to be faring better are nonetheless coy. "All I can say is it depends on what time of year and what product lines," said Jaqui Lividini, a spokesman in New York for Saks Fifth Avenue, when asked to characterize the performance of the Michigan Avenue store. She declined to compare it in any way with other large downtown Saks stores or the far larger New York flagship.
A key reason for Michigan Avenue's bustle is that the Chicago area and much of the rest of the Midwest escaped the brunt of the recent recession. But Michigan Avenue has other advantages for retailing.
The neighborhood includes a mixture of modern, high-rise office buildings and a large number of hotels catering to business travelers, conventioneers and tourists. It is also surrounded by the town houses and penthouse homes of some of Chicago's wealthiest residents. The parade of storefronts is broken by trees and the city's historic water tower, as well as three vertical shopping centers that feature 50 or more stores each and views of nearby Lake Michigan.
Its reputation for catering to wealthy shoppers dates back to the early decades of the century when it began attracting the carriage trade that had previously patronized the "Splendid Mile" of stores on State Street in Chicago's downtown Loop, located just to the south..
In addition, companies like the Sony Corporation, F.A.O. Schwarz, and Nike Inc. have recently opened high-energy stores on the avenue that are as much entertainment centers as sales outlets.
 
Nike's Own Basketball Court
 At Sony, visitors play with language translation devices, pads for sketching designs that appear on television screens, and other electronic novelties while viewing the company's wares. Nike Town's attractions include mementos of Michael Jordan, Bo Jackson and other athletes the company features in its advertising. Another feature is a basketball court where customers can take Nike shoes through their paces.
"This was No. 1 on the agenda," said Cindy Thurman, a recent Nike Town shopper who drove three and a half hours from Champaign, Ill., with her sons, ages 10 and 14, for "a couple of days of hitting some of the shops."
Not everyone is thrilled with the changes. To 80-year-old Stuart Brent, who has sold books on Michigan Avenue for 49 years and recalls long chats over coffee with writers like Gore Vidal in a long-gone cafe, the avenue is gripped in "spiritual boredom."
Specialty stores like Mr. Brent's book shop, just across the street from Nike and Sony, have long attracted out-of-towners searching for items that cannot be found in smaller retail centers. But the flashier newcomers have nevertheless broadened the street's appeal.
Surveys show that more than half of the spending on the street comes from people who live more than 50 miles away. At the F.A.O. Schwarz store, which opened in September, shoppers come regularly from Grosse Pointe and other wealthy suburbs of Detroit, from Minneapolis and from other cities in the Midwest. They have helped build sales volumes to a level second only to the 26-store chain's flagship New York store, according to Shannon Shaffer, the store manager.
"We knew it would be a home run," said Ms. Shaffer.
 
No Room for a Discounter
 One retailer that is having trouble going to bat on the street is the Filene's Basement Corporation, the clothing discounter. Filene's Basement tried to acquire I. Magnin's lease from R.H. Macy & Co. last year in a deal approved by the bankruptcy court but has been stymied by Prudential Insurance Company, the owner of the land. Prudential says that the lease strictly bars a discounter from using the site, a restriction it wrote in to protect property values. The dispute is in court, with the Greater North Michigan Avenue Association strongly backing Prudential.
Nordstrom's and other large retailers that would like big spaces on the avenue could be out of luck until the turn of the century or beyond. Developers say it would be far too risky to construct the 250,000 to 300,000 square feet of retail space a Nordstrom's would want because the only way to keep rents reasonable would be to develop a hotel, offices or luxury residences above the store.
The extra development would be a problem, because the market in these nonretail sectors is discouraging. The limited residential development near the downtown area is concentrated on relatively cheap abandoned industrial land just south of the city center, and both the hotel and office markets are glutted.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Urges Product-Liability Revisions

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 8

 BODY:
In an effort to protect manufacturers from exorbitant legal judgments, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed significant changes in the state's laws on product liability that would make it harder for people who have been injured to establish fault and recover damages.
The Governor's proposal would also limit contingency fees that lawyers may charge in cases of product liability, as well as personal injury and wrongful death. 
 In proposing the legislation, Mr. Cuomo cited the burdens he said the state's liability laws had put on manufacturers. After a grinding recession and slow recovery, Mr. Cuomo has now sided with Republicans in the Senate who have long complained that the strict laws have overly burdened the state's businesses.
The most sweeping of the new laws would limit the time in which manufacturers can be sued to the "useful life" of a product and would give them the presumption of innocence if a product is made with the most advanced technology at the time.
 
'More Inviting' for Industries
 It would also block using as evidence the fact that manufacturers later improved a product's design. It would protect them from lawsuits based on inadequate warnings of products' possible dangers unless negligence can be proven.
"This measure," he said in a statement, "will make New York a more inviting place for manufacturers to locate."
While business groups hailed the legislation, public advocacy groups and lawyers denounced it as "anti-consumer," saying it would undo the state's reputation as a leader in protecting people from faulty products.
"This bill shifts responsibility away from manufacturers and onto consumers," said Blair Horner, executive director of the New York Public Interest Research Group. "It makes it even more difficult for consumers to receive damages when they are victimized."
 
Fierce Challenge Is Likely
 The Governor's proposal will almost certainly face a fierce challenge in the Legislature. A similar, although stronger bill has stalled in the Senate and Assembly for years. But if Mr. Cuomo's is seen as a compromise, it could stand a chance.
The state's product liability laws have gradually evolved in court cases over much of the century rather than in legislation. The Governor's proposal would for the first time create statutes specifying the circumstances in which manufacturers could be held liable for injury or death caused by their products.
Calling the system "inordinate the way it is now," Mr. Cuomo said his proposal would create a clearer and fairer one that would protect customers and manufacturers.
"The challenge before us is: How do you reduce the exposure of the business community without being unfair to the injured consumer?" he said in an interview. "I believe the changes we are proposing will deprive no single injured person of a fair opportunity to recover damages."
 
Shield for Most Stores
 In addition to the protections for manufacturers, the legislation would also shield from liability almost all stores that sell defective products made by other companies.
Two other changes would apply not only to product liability, but also to lawsuits in all personal injury or wrongful-death cases.
One would limit lawyers' fees by using a schedule created for medical malpractice cases in 1986. Under the schedule, lawyers could charge 30 percent if the award is less than $250,000 and incrementally less as the award rises, to 10 percent for awards more than $1.25 million.
Also, in cases with several defendants, successful plaintiffs would not be able to seek all damages from manufacturers found only partly liable -- the so-called "deep pockets" rule. Under the law now, a company assigned only some of the liability can be forced to pay the entire award simply because it has the money.
Daniel B. Walsh, the president of the Business Council of New York State, praised the legislation as "a significant step forward that will help improve our economy."
Others, though, sharply criticized the proposal as reversing a legacy of court protection for consumers.

HEADLINE: Investments For Industry

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
Low interest rates and high profits are prompting American businesses to increase their estimates of how much they will invest in buildings and new equipment this year.
Companies surveyed in the first quarter said they would spend $582 billion in 1993, up 6.6 percent from last year, and if realized, the biggest increase in four years, the Commerce Department said today. 
 A 1993 increase of 6.6 percent, if carried through, would be the largest since investment spending rose 11.4 percent in 1989. The estimate is an improvement over three months ago, when companies said they planned a 5.3 percent increase.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said the survey was "encouraging and provides us with the hope that U.S. firms will contribute to economic growth this year."
But he noted with concern a planned 20.8 percent decline in investment by airlines, which would hurt an aerospace industry already reeling from cuts in military spending.
On Wednesday, stock prices of major airlines rose significantly in response to a spate of news items seen as indications of improving efficiency in what has been a largely unprofitable industry.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
After Cuomo's Court Withdrawal, Time to Work on a Legacy

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 8

 BODY:
This time there was no plane left waiting on the tarmac.
Unlike Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's last trip to the precipice, when he made preparations to fly to New Hampshire to file for the 1992 Presidential primary, there was no symbol of angst today about the Governor's decision to withdraw his name from consideration for the United States Supreme Court. 
 In fact, Mr. Cuomo's aides and friends said, the Governor showed a surprising ambivalence about the court from the very beginning. And he seemed uncommonly at peace today with his decision.
While his staff almost universally encouraged him to take the job if it was offered, Mr. Cuomo focused immediately on what he considered its shortcomings, his aides said.
 
'Hard to Accept'
 It was too confining. It was too passive. You could not speak your mind on radio and television. It was high on intellectual stimulation but low on instant gratification of either the ego or the soul.
"People find it hard to accept -- it's such an exalted position and all that -- but he just didn't want to be a judge," said Vincent Tese, the state's director of economic development and a Cuomo confidante. "It's not where his experience and talents lie."
Another Cuomo aide said: "Unlike the Presidency, everyone on the staff wanted him to do it. He just never got there."
Mr. Cuomo never got there at least in part because of a singular desire for political closure.
After a glorious first term, when he invigorated state government, shot to national stardom with a memorable speech and won re-election by a record margin, Mr. Cuomo's last six years have been increasingly difficult. His critics place part of the blame on the state's flagging economy and part on the Governor's style, which can be long on proposals and short on the grittier business of effecting change.
 
Strengthening His Grip
 Having endured hard times, Mr. Cuomo sees an opportunity for a fiscal revival for his state and a political rejuvenation for himself, his closest friends and aides said. He envisions a chance to create the legacy that has eluded him, to set a mark for endurance, to finish the way he started.
While other politicians instinctively reach for the next rung, Mr. Cuomo prefers to solidify his grip on the rung before him.
He once mused disdainfully that it was a distinctively American failing that politicians always strive for higher office rather than making a difference where they are. And even though it was his mother, an Italian immigrant named Immaculata, who asked him after his first gubernatorial election when he was going to become a judge, Mr. Cuomo has always had one foot in the old country and one in the new.
"There's a natural assumption that this is such a grand and important position that everything should fall before it," Mr. Cuomo said in an interview. "But that's a judgment individuals have to make and I made mine and that's it."
 
Even Young Children
 The reason, of course, that people find it hard to accept that Mr. Cuomo did not want to sit on the Supreme Court is that he seems so intellectually and temperamentally suited to the job. He remains fascinated by the law and thrives on spirited debate and the dissection of belief.
As he explained in a radio interview this week, Mr. Cuomo regularly even challenges young children about the foundations of their world.
"I'll say, 'How old are you?' and they'll say, 'Nine.' " he began. "And then to just give a small, and I hope inoffensive, presentation of the Talmudic process, I say, 'How do you know?' "
"They say, 'Because I'm 9.' "
"Well how do you know?"
" 'Well, because my mother told me.' "
"Well, do you believe everything your mother told you? Maybe you're 17, and she doesn't want you to know because she doesn't want you to drive yet. Did you believe her when she told you there was a Santa Claus?"
Is it farfetched to think that, with Mr. Cuomo on the Court, a debate over Roe v. Wade would have begun with the question, "Justice Scalia, what color is your robe?"
 
Another New York No
 Mr. Cuomo, by the way, is not the only New Yorker who does not want to be considered by President Clinton for the Supreme Court.
Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye of the New York Court of Appeals, whom Mr. Cuomo promoted for the job after withdrawing his own name, said today that she also preferred to stay in New York.
Mr. Cuomo has said in interviews over the last two days that he simply believes he can be of more service in New York than in Washington. He has been energized in recent months by a series of crises he has helped manage, ranging from the World Trade Center bombing to the bankruptcy of The New York Post.
And he clearly has been buoyed by the gradual improvement in the state's economy and the relative ease of putting together this year's state budget. While he said today that he does not expect New York's fiscal condition to improve to the level of the mid-1980's, he is hopeful that the days of heavy deficits are behind him. That would allow him to focus on the issues that one Cuomo aide characterized today as "legacy pieces:" health care, changes in the public schools and environmental protection.
 
Baloney and Garbage
 If Mr. Cuomo runs for, wins and completes a fourth four-year term, he would surpass the 14-year mark set by Nelson Rockefeller, a record second only to the 25 years served by New York's first Governor, George Clinton.
Some in Albany, including members of the Governor's staff, have questioned why anybody would want the job for that long. They have hypothesized that Mr. Cuomo must take some psychic pleasure in the petty disputes with the Legislature that occupy so much of his time.
"That's a lot of baloney, that's a lot of garbage," Mr. Cuomo said today. "You think I enjoy being in there for hours disagreeing with Marino and Weprin. What am I, perverted? I'd rather be reading a book or writing poetry.
"You can't enjoy it. A lot of it is unnecessary. The whole system stinks. You don't do it because it's fun. You do it because you feel you're making a contribution toward improving things."
Then Mr. Cuomo noted that it has been a season for comebacks in New York -- for the economy, for the trade center, for The Post, metaphors all perhaps for the political comeback he may envision for himself.
