HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET;
A Budget With a Chance

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
For years, Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush sent Congress budgets that were, it was commonly said at the time, dead on arrival. Since no one expected the Democrats who controlled Congress to approve the proposals of the Republican Presidents, the budget documents were more election manifestoes than operational plans, dependent more on stirring words than on sound fiscal analysis.
By contrast, the detailed budget President Clinton submitted today is clearly alive and kicking. The President and the majority in Congress are not only from the same party but on the same wavelength. This budget serves the conventional purpose: It is a road map for the course the country will be traveling. 
 Cutting through the spare language and detailed accounts, what the budget shows, for better or worse, is that taxes will go up, the military will face deep cuts and spending will be increased for several Government programs that languished in the Republican years.
"This budget basically reflects the policies of a new Administration," said Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton's budget director, "trying to change the priorities for this country and set a new direction."
While political obstacles lie along the course, they stand to block only details of the Clinton budget, not the themes. Snags will doubtless continue to develop, like the current impasse in the Senate over the President's jobs and economic stimulus bill. But Congress has already voted to put into effect tax increases and spending cuts in the neighborhood of what Mr. Clinton wants.
Furthermore, the main elements of the Clinton budget are on a fast track in the Capitol. All the tax proposals and many of the biggest spending programs like Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid will be packaged in one bill under the jurisdiction of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the Ways and Means panel , said his committee would begin drafting the legislation, called a reconciliation bill, the first week in May and would finish in no more than two weeks. The measure will then go to the full House, which plans to vote by the end of May.
The Senate panel, headed by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, has promised to finish its work and send the measure to the floor by the middle of June.
This legislation will be debated under procedures that guarantee quick action. In the House, amendments on the floor will be limited if not completely barred. In the Senate, the rules will prohibit a filibuster like the one by Republicans that has tied up the jobs bill.
Under Democratic control, the Senate and House are most likely to approve easily the proposals to raise the taxes of corporations and wealthy individuals and to expand significantly the earned-income tax credit, a measure that helps poor working families rise above the poverty level.
The biggest disputes in the reconciliation bill are likely to develop over two tax proposals that together would raise about $75 billion over the next five years, much of it borne by middle-income taxpayers.
 
Disputable Tax Proposals
 One, a new tax on nearly all fuels, would result in most families paying a few hundred dollars a year more than they do now for gasoline, electricity and consumer products and services.
The other would increase the income taxes some retirees pay on their Social Security benefits. It would affect less than a quarter of the nation's Social Security recipients -- single retirees with incomes above $25,000 and couples with incomes over $32,000. But a retired couple getting $50,000 a year from a combination of Social Security, private pensions and investment income -- hardly a family anyone would consider wealthy -- would pay more than $500 in additional income taxes.
Both Republicans and many Democrats will balk at these measures, but the best bet is that the legislation will be adopted. No one has come up with other tax proposals that raise the same amount of revenue and are more politically digestible.
"We simply have to do it," said Senator Moynihan. "It's a problem if you're a political speech writer. But if you've got to raise $272 billion you have to do it."
The figure Mr. Moynihan cited is the amount of deficit reduction that the budget resolution approved by Congress last week orders his Finance Committee to achieve over five years.
But even if Congress approves Mr. Clinton's budget more or less as he offered it, that does not guarantee it will meet his goal of reducing the Federal deficit from the current 5.2 percent of the nation's total production of goods and services to 2.8 percent in the 1997 fiscal year, the last of Mr. Clinton's term.
 
Tiny Shifts Mean a Lot
 First, unexpected expenditures could arise, ranging from wars to natural disasters.
Second, no one can be sure the proposed taxes would raise as much revenue as the Clinton Administration and Congressional authorities estimate. Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ronald Reagan and now president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, argues that wealthy taxpayers will rearrange their finances to cut their tax bills and that as a consequence, the total receipts by the Government will be much lower than the budget projects.
Finally, forecasts of economic growth, inflation and interest rates are highly speculative. Unlike the Republicans, who often based their budgets on optimistic forecasts, the Clinton Administration is using forecasts that are decidedly more pessimistic than even those favored by their own economists.
Yet if the projections are off by only a small amount, the deficit down the road could change significantly. For example, if the economy grows by one percentage point less each year than the estimates being used, the deficit in the 1997 fiscal year, expected to be just under $200 billion, would be nearly $100 billion larger. If inflation runs one point higher, the deficit would be nearly $50 billion larger.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Investors Flee Metals After Aloca Report

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Investors battered aluminum stocks yesterday, and analysts said the issues were likely to remain under pressure until huge inventories of the metal have been pared.
The selling was prompted by an unexpectedly poor first-quarter-earnings report from the Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer. Late Wednesday Alcoa said its first-quarter earnings fell by 50 percent from year-earlier levels, citing the aluminum glut and record-low prices for aluminum ingot. 
 Alcoa's news, which came after the stock market closed on Wednesday, was dealt with harshly yesterday. The stock fell by $2 a share in heavy trading, to a new 52-week low of $60.375 a share.
Reynolds Metals, which is expected to announce its earnings next week, fell by $1.25, to $44.25, also a new 52-week low. And prices of other metals companies declined slightly.
Since most aluminum makers are expected to post first-quarter losses, Alcoa's poor earnings report was a sobering reminder that even strong performers are finding it difficult to buck fundamental trends that plague the entire industry.
Overproduction, which has pushed prices to about 51 cents a pound, their lowest level in nearly a decade, is only one of the problems, analysts said.
 
Fighting Softening Demand
 The metals business is also fighting softening demand in Europe and Japan, which last year consumed an estimated 48 percent of all aluminum used in the industrialized West. The on-going depression in the former Soviet Union, traditionally a big consumer, and weakness in Eastern European economies, have not helped either.
Despite these weak spots, analysts said that basic, underlying demand for the metal remains good. The supply problem is what bedevils the industry. "Aluminum consumption has gone up every year for the last eleven years, to a new record each time," said Daniel Roling, a non-ferrous metals analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "There is not a demand problem."
At an estimated 5.1 million metric tons, "the inventory overhang is so overwhelming that we will be living with low metal prices and low aluminum prices for quite some time," said Thomas Van Leeuwen, senior metals analyst at Lehman Brothers. The industry has not yet cut back sufficiently to bring supply down. It is difficult to imagine that any rapid recovery will occur anytime soon over the next year to 18 months."
Despite poor fundamentals, many analysts said they are advising clients to hang on to aluminum stocks. "We have holds on most of the stocks, and are a bit more optimistic about Reynolds," said Charles Bradford, an industry analyst at UBS Securities. "At the bottom of the last recession in the early 1980s, the industry was operating at 70 percent of capacity. This time it is operating in the 90s. That means when the turn in prices comes it could be more violent on the upside."

HEADLINE: Security Issue Overlooked In Computer Concern's Sale

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
A review by the Commerce Department has found that the Federal Government missed key national security problems when it allowed a Japanese company to buy the only American manufacturer of some computer components used in the Patriot and Trident missiles.
The transaction, involving a unit of the Applied Magnetics Corporation of Goleta, Calif., was approved by the Bush Administration in January. The sale was the first foreign investment issue taken up by the Clinton Administration, which theoretically could still cancel it. 
 Foreign embassies and many American and foreign corporations have followed the case as a bellwether of the new Administration's attitudes toward the sale of companies with militarily strategic technologies. Federal law requires extensive review of such sales, but the Bush Administration routinely approved the deals at the end of the reviews.
The Defense Department has tried to avoid depending on Japanese companies for key military equipment, partly to avoid the risk of losing supplies in any political confrontation and partly because the employees of American defense companies vote in this country while Japanese defense company workers do not.
After being told today of the Commerce Department's findings, Senator J. James Exon, the Nebraska Democrat who wrote the nation's foreign investment review laws, said, "The transaction never should have been approved." Senator Exon criticized the Bush Administration's original decision after it was revealed in news reports on Jan. 25.
The Commerce Department's findings, contained in a confidential memo to the Treasury Department, come at an awkward time. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan is to arrive here next week for his first meeting with President Clinton. The Administration is trying to balance its concern about Japan's trade surplus with the need for Japanese participation in aid to the former Soviet Union.
According to the memo, the interagency committee that approved the sale on Jan. 19 was unaware that the Applied Magnetics unit was the only American company producing parts for sophisticated computer laser-disk drives. The eight-agency Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States was also unaware of the extent to which the Navy's Trident missiles and the Army's Patriot missiles depend on these components, the memo said.
A Treasury Department official said tonight that the details of the Commerce Department memo were being actively investigated by the Treasury and Defense Departments. An American official who insisted on anonymity said that some of the information in the memo was not new, but the official declined to be more specific.
A copy of the memo was mailed to The New York Times in an envelope with no return address. Federal officials confirmed the authenticity of the document.
 
Degree of Misrepresentation
 Federal law allows the Treasury to reopen the case and cancel the sale if it determines that there were "material" misrepresentations made by the participants. The memo avoids any characterization of whether any misrepresentation was material. The memo said that if information provided by Applied Magnetics was intended to indicate that there were alternate sources among American companies for the components, "then that was possibly a misrepresentation."
William R. Anderson, the chief executive of Applied Magnetics, denied in a telephone interview today that any misrepresentations had been made. "You could make that point on the basis that our OMA's were designed for specific applications," he said. "That's really splitting hairs." The component in question is known as an OPD OMA subassembly.
Mr. Anderson said that other companies, mainly in Japan, were producing similar products, and that any national security concerns about the deal were unfounded.
 
Promises No Disruption
 The memo said that an Army program to improve the reliability of the Patriot missile, which was used to shoot down Iraqi Scud missiles in the Persian Gulf war, could be delayed by a year or two if the supply of the components is interrupted for any reason, the memo added. But Kim Frank, a spokeswoman for the American operations of the Tokyo-based Nakamichi Corporation, the company that bought the American concern, said today that the supply will not be interrupted and production will remain in the United States.
Laser-disk drives are like the compact disk players that many Americans have in their homes. A tiny laser is used in both to read the disk as it spins, much like a stylus in a phonograph.
But while a compact disk player might break if it falls off a bookcase, laser-disk drives for missiles are built to withstand the tremendous acceleration of a rocket launching, along with all the bumps and jostling that may be required to deploy a missile.
Most laser-disk drives move the entire laser around the disk. Applied Magnetics developed a technique in which the laser is mounted at the edge of the disk and shines a beam into a tiny lens that moves back and forth quickly across the disk and reflects the beam downward, reading the information.
Mr. Anderson said that his company's technology compensated for the acceleration of the lens and for the acceleration of the missile at the same time. But he said that a few Japanese companies had also developed similar technologies recently using stationary lasers.
 
Faced Deadline
 Shortly after President Clinton took office, the White House's National Economic Council and the Treasury Department began an immediate review of the last-minute decision by the Bush Administration. The Bush Administration was forced to make a decision on Jan. 19 because of a rule setting time limits for Government deliberations on such cases.
According to the Commerce Department memo, Applied Magnetics told the review committee on Jan. 14 that the Eastman Kodak Company, Honeywell Inc. and I.B.M. all made similar laser-disk drive components. But when the department later contacted these companies, it found that Kodak and Honeywell made components that were incompatible with current military hardware, while International Business Machines makes a similar but not interchangeable component in Japan, the memo said.
Ronald C. Roberts, a spokesman for Kodak, said that the memo was accurate. Kodak's technology is incompatible with Applied Magnetics' equipment and cannot be adapted to it, he said.
Honeywell and I.B.M. had no immediate information.

HEADLINE: Weather and Tax Fears Stall March Retail Sales

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Cold, wet weather and the prospect of higher taxes put the brakes on retail sales in March.
And although the sun has finally decided to make more than a passing appearance, retailers say less ephemeral issues like job instability, taxes and consumers' doubts about their future prosperity will continue to inhibit sales. 
 "There's no question the weather had an impact on the whole country last month," said Stephen A. Watson, the president of the Dayton Hudson Corporation. "But business would not be this difficult if there were not underlying issues out there. We're not out of the woods yet."
Almost all of the nation's large store chains reported weak March sales yesterday, continuing the deceleration that began in January. The Salomon Brothers Same-Store Sales Growth Index, which tracks the sales of 22 major retail chains, increased only 1 percent. A similar index compiled by Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. rose just nine-tenths of a percent.
Dayton Hudson, which operates Target stores, Mervyn's and several department store chains, reported a 3.9 percent increase in comparable-store sales over the five weeks that ended on April 3. Comparable-store sales are the sales in stores that are open at least a year, which analysts consider a better indicator than total sales because new stores typically have erratic sales patterns.
 
Apparel Sales Decline
 Wal-Mart Stores Inc., had a 3 percent increase in same-store sales in March, far below its usual double-digit growth pattern. The May Department Stores Company, which operates several regional department store chains like Foley's and Famous Barr, posted a 5 percent gain in same-store sales. But analysts noted that last year the company had a 4.7 percent decline in same-store store sales in March, inflating the comparison.
Apparel retailers had difficulties. The Gap Inc. reported a 6 percent decline in same-store sales, and The Limited Inc.'s comparable-store sales slipped 3 percent.
"In the fourth quarter, we saw a return to the mall, which came about with the post-election enthusiasm and was clearly credit-driven," said Thomas Tashjian, a retail analyst at the First Manhattan Company. "Since then, shoppers have received their credit card bills and a lot less of a tax refund than they got last year."
Retailers cautioned against reading too much into one week's worth of sales. Mr. Watson of Dayton Hudson attributed some of the acceleration to the fact that Easter is earlier this year than last. Spending usually picks up two or three weeks before the holiday.
"The outlook is for a slow spending environment, maybe 1 to 2 percent growth in real spending adjusted for inflation," said Robert F. Buchanan, a retail analyst at Alex. Brown.
 
Some Analysts Optimistic
 Mr. Buchanan and other analysts said they expect retailers to become more promotional in April, since the slow sales rate had inflated inventories. Retailers like Lord & Taylor and Macy's have already started sales, which they usually hold after Easter.
"They've taken early markdowns trying to clear the shelves," said Walter F. Loeb, president of Loeb Associates Inc., a retail consulting company. "Retailers are very conscious of being lean and mean."
That does not bode well for first-quarter profits, however, since price-off sales cut into margins. Still, some analysts seemed optimistic about retailers' prospects for the next six months. They said warmer weather and the emergence of clearer fashion trends like bell-bottom pants, platform shoes and peasant blouses would help sales for apparel retailers like the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, which closed 90 of its 218 stores for at least one day over a recent snowy weekend.
"Better weather and a better apparel offering in April should lead to improvements, although it's not going to make up for what they've already lost in the first quarter, said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst at Salomon Brothers.
Following are the details of major retailers' sales for March compared with sales for March last year:

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rose 0.4% in March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
In a report that calmed fears of resurgent inflation, prices received by American producers rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, but scarcely at all when figures for the erratic energy and food sectors are removed.
So-called core inflation edged up just a tenth of 1 percent, according to the Labor Department, the best performance since December. 
 "Today's producer price figures throw cold water at the notion that inflation is roaring back in the midst of a tepid economic expansion," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade group representing businesses that buy from producers.
Separate reports today showed a modest 9,000 decline in claims for first-time jobless benefits last week and a 6.6 percent advance, to $582.3 billion, in projected 1993 corporate spending for new plant and equipment.
 
 
Interest Rates
 The reassuring inflation report followed two months of somewhat unsettling figures at both the wholesale and retail levels, which had led to what many viewed as negative developments. These included a rise in interest rates that could damage an uneven economic expansion already marked by meager job growth.
But today's report -- the department is to publish the Consumer Price Index for March on Friday -- was widely seen as a return to the subdued inflation levels of most of 1992 after aberrational increases in the first two months of this year. Overall inflation last year, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, was 2.9 percent. Most expectations for consumer inflation in 1993 remain in the range of 3 to 3.4 percent.
Donald E. Maude, bond strategist at Scotia McLeod, said he found "all aspects" of the P.P.I. report "highly encouraging for the inflation outlook." He cited, among others, the unsustainability of a 1.3 percent burst in energy prices resulting mainly from the mid-month blizzard and continued moderation in prices at earlier stages of production.
Intermediate goods prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month while crude goods rose four-tenths of 1 percent. They rose two-tenths and three-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, when energy was excluded.
Finished goods, like summer dresses, are those that are ready for sale to the final business or individual user. A bolt of cloth would be the comparable intermediate product; raw cotton would be the comparable crude product.
Other analysts noted that some key industrial commodities had been slumping severely recently, with copper futures tumbling to a five-year low and prices of aluminum dragged down by sluggish demand amid abundant supplies. Tobacco prices, which have buoyed the indexes for a year or more, have turned soft as reflected in this week's announcement by Philip Morris of a big cut for Marlboro cigarettes.
 
 
Some Skeptics
 Some analysts, however, remained skeptical. Michael P. Daly, an economist for the Cigna Corporation, the Hartford-based insurer, said it might be "inappropriate" to exclude energy since oil demand had firmed. Mr. Daly, who characterized his view as a minority one, said he was a bit surprised that the bond market rallied so strongly today after the report was released.
The four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the P.P.I. for finished goods was the second consecutive one of this size, advances not matched since the report for May 1992 that was subsequently revised downward.
Energy prices jumped 1.3 percent in March, midway between the January and February increases, with heating oil soaring 8.5 percent. Consumer foods rose five-tenths of 1 percent following a slight February decline as red meats, eggs, soft drinks, cheese and dry milk products rose, and the index for fish was raised substantially by a correction of earlier figures.
Prices of tobacco products, passenger cars, light trucks and household appliances advanced less than in February, while prices turned down for sanitary papers and health products, over-the-counter drugs and periodicals. Capital equipment rose two-tenths of 1 percent, about the same as in most other recent months, the department said.
 
 
Materials for Durable Goods
 Among intermediate goods, prices for materials for making durable goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent, far less than in February, as copper and brass mill shapes dropped 5.6 percent, hot rolled steel sheet and strip also turned down and the drop in primary copper accelerated. Hardwood lumber and plywood, subject to tight supply due partly to environmental disputes in the Northwest, gained less than in February.
Materials for nondurable manufacturing rose three-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month as increases for paperboard, alkalies, chlorine, synthetic fibers and paint materials turned up, while basic organic chemicals turned down.
Construction goods rose 1.2 percent, a bit more than in February, on higher prices for millwork, plastic products, plumbing fixtures and brass fittings and gypsum products. The first-quarter increase for construction materials was at an annual rate of 13.8 percent, the biggest quarterly leap in 13 years.
The March upturn in crude goods mainly reflected higher costs of energy -- up eight-tenths of 1 percent following a 2.5 percent February decline -- as basic industrial materials rose much less than in February, while foods and feeds edged up slightly. Natural gas eased another 1.5 percent, following a February drop of almost 13 percent.
For the quarter, finished goods rose at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in contrast to a slight decline during the final three months of last year, the report also showed.

HEADLINE: Stocks Little Changed Despite Positive Data

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In the last day of a trading week shortened by Good Friday, the stock market lurched downward for most of the session yesterday but ended with overall prices barely changed. Good news from the Government on inflation did not seem to command many traders' attention.
There were some forceful exceptions. Alcoa dropped 2 points, to 60 3/8, after its announcement Wednesday -- made after the markets closed -- that first-quarter earnings fell 50 percent. 
 And U. S. Surgical plummeted another 15 1/4, to 31 3/8, after the company said, also late Wednesday, that it expected poor second-quarter results. The medical-instrument maker, whose stock had been falling for months, was the most actively traded stock on the Big Board at 8.44 million shares.
 
 
Searching for Stocks
 Otherwise, some investors, their wallets fattened by cash from the sell-off of consumer-product and retailing stocks earlier in the week, seemed to be searching for stocks to buy, accounting for the many share prices that traded in a narrow range.
Airline stocks like AMR, parent of American Airlines, proved to be one-day wonders. The stocks vaulted Wednesday on a variety of positive news, but drifted to earth yesterday in light trading in the absence of more cheering developments.
"There is plenty of confusion in the marketplace," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago. "The only thing stopping the market from falling is the excess cash that is all dressed up and looking for some place to go."
Mr. Chalasani said, for example, that when oil stock prices rise, airline and auto stocks usually fall because high petroleum prices raise the operating costs of planes and cars. But all three groups of stocks have generally risen recently, partly because of investors looking for good stocks to buy, he said.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down 0.54 point, to 3,396.48. For the last five sessions, the Dow has pulsed between about 3,320 and 3,420. The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index was down 0.48 point, to 243.84. The Standard & Poor's 500 was down 0.89 point, to 441.84. The Nasdaq composite index declined 2.55 points, to 666.33.
But like Wednesday's trading, advancing stocks led decliners by about 10 to 9. A total of 284.7 million shares were traded, lower than earlier sessions in the week.
 
 
Producer Prices
 The Labor Department reported an hour before the Big Board's opening bell at 9:30 A.M. that producer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts were impressed, however, that "core" inflation, which excludes food and energy, rose a lower-than-expected one-tenth of 1 percent.
Although the bond market rallied at the news, because low inflation makes existing bonds more valuable, the stock market slumped a little in the morning, then dropped more than 12 points in the early afternoon.
The selloff of consumer and retailing stocks leveled off, but trading of these issues was still at volumes that landed the companies on the Big Board's most-active list. Philip Morris was the second-most-active stock, closing down 1 point, to 46 1/4. Philip Morris's volume was 8.25 million shares, up from 7.5 million shares Wednesday but below Tuesday's 10.2 million shares.
Wal-Mart Stores closed up 1 1/8, to 28 7/8, on volume of 7.55 million shares, lower than Wednesday's 11.4 million shares and about half of Tuesday's 14.6 million shares.
Coca-Cola was up 1/4, to 39 3/4, on volume of 5.42 million shares, up from Wednesday's 3.6 million and Tuesday's 4 million.

HEADLINE: Stone Container Holds Off On Stock and Debt Offering

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The Stone Container Corporation, its stock pummeled since it disclosed plans last week to raise $500 million by selling stock, said yesterday that it would postpone any attempt to raise capital.
Roger Stone, chairman of the pulp and paper company, said investors had misunderstood the company's financial condition. 
 "It was perceived we had liquidity problems, that the banks were imposing a solution on us," Mr. Stone said. "That was wrong."
Mr. Stone said the company decided late last year to raise capital to reduce its high level of debt and had presented that plan to its banks. He said the deadline of May 31 in Stone's credit amendments, which was disclosed in the company's annual report last week, was not really an important date.
 
Loss Forecast
 Mr. Stone added that the company would report a loss for the first quarter but added that the loss would be well within expectations, which he said were for a range of 80 cents to $1.25 a share. That contrasts with a loss of 15 cents a share in the similar quarter a year ago.
Stone's stock fell to $6 a share in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday -- amid speculation that the stock offering would not be made -- when it was halted for the announcement. It did not reopen, but there were two later trades, one at $6.50 on the Pacific Stock Exchange and one over-the-counter at $7.50, which became the closing price. That was down $1.25 for the day. Before the disclosure of the financing plans, the stock was trading for $12.50.
Mr. Stone said Bankers Trust, its lead bank, was supportive and said he was highly confident that the banks would approve necessary amendments to its credit agreement to enable it to defer raising more capital until a more opportune moment.
Stone went deeply into debt in the 1980's as it embarked on an acquisition binge, leaving it vulnerable to the recent recession, which is still affecting many of its markets. Mr. Stone said that when the company was planning the possible stock offering, its shares were trading in a range of $15 to $19. At current prices, he said, the offering did not make sense. He said that a related $300 million debt offering, also disclosed in the annual report, had also been postponed.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Bit of Hartford's Past Yields to Change and Chains

BYLINE: By Kirk Johnson

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
FOR 158 years, through the days of whale oil lamps and the brief flowering of a local literary culture around such luminaries as Mark Twain and Harriet Beecher Stowe, Huntington's Book Store knew Hartford well enough to survive just about anything.
Like Hartford, it was a little stuffy, perhaps, and unquestionably highbrow, but in a town of insurance actuaries and banking burghers, it was the right stuffy: the same endearing rectitude and seriousness, leavened at surprising times by a streak of prickly, assertive, even oddball independence of mind. 
 And now it, too, will slip away into memory, a victim of recession, high-volume chain bookstores and suburbanites who won't go downtown anymore. The store, which has done business under eight different names and at least as many owners since it opened in 1835 as Packard & Brown booksellers, will close next month.
One can still take the pulse of Hartford from the books sold here. Nonfiction sells better than fiction, literary fiction sells better than commercial fiction, and where commerce is dominated by corporate mainframes, books about I.B.M. computers sell better than books about the more freewheeling Macintosh.
Pulp romance and science fiction? Thank you, no. They molder on the shelves. Sidney Sheldon and Danielle Steele? "The cusp of literature," sniffs the owner, David Epstein.
But this is no hoary museum of unread Henry Adams novels and fixed-income annuity journals. This was the store that displayed, almost exuberantly in its windows, Salman Rushdie's novel "Satanic Verses" a few years ago, if only to make a point. In the 1960's, the former owner, Trumbull Huntington, was arrested on indecency charges for a similar exuberance in selling Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer." (He was cleared, and Mr. Epstein keeps the court transcript in the back, for inspiration.)
Harriet Beecher Stowe, according to store legend, used to come here and sit in dignified repose, insisting that she be waited upon. Mark Twain, by contrast, reputedly held a more raucous court in the back room. One imagines his thick cigar smoke and his wet whisky glass rings staining the high-minded tomes in gleeful spite of their pomposities.
There are two spots in Huntington's that should be recorded for posterity. One is the far corner on the right side as you enter. That is where a clerk, Vinny Fuerst, plays his viola every morning for two and a half hours before the store opens. Facing the language and travel books, eyes closed, his mournful midrange notes filling the store, he seems transported to some faraway place. His music, whether Mozart or Mendelssohn, sets the tone: However crazed a day may be outside, a calm sense of sophistication and friendly intelligence invariably reigns here.
The other spot is just behind the biography shelves, where a person could stand openly and blatantly reading magazines all through his lunch hour without the slightest intention of buying a one. That such a person could then look the clerk in the eye next time and not feel even the slightest trace of opprobrium says much about the level of tolerance and the pace.
If this were a bar, it would be the sort where you could nurse a single beer all night. They knew you'd develop a real thirst sooner or later, probably for some obscure, expensive book that they would gladly order for you. And if everybody doesn't quite know your name, well, then you haven't been there enough.
Is it a stab in the back to this troubled, stumbling city for Huntington's to close? Is this a betrayal of the sort that Hartford's last big department store, G. Fox, perpetrated last year after a 145-year history.
There is clearly a tension in the air, and in the way of any broken relationship, the unspoken questions are often the loudest. Mr. Epstein said some customers have burst into tears. "How can you can do this us?" they ask.
And sometimes Mr. Epstein wants to ask back: Where were you all these sad months when the store really needed you? Who betrayed whom?
"I've been playing to an empty house," he said.
Still one should not mourn the death of book buying in Hartford. Two chain bookstores have opened in the last year. An Encore Books is now only a half-block away, and Barnes & Noble opened a 60,000-volume superstore just over the city line in West Hartford, stocking almost twice as many books as Huntington's had before it began its liquidation sale.
Going to a chain bookstore, of course, is like going to McDonald's. The menu will be about the same, and you could be just about anywhere. Huntington's was a personality that grew on you, or it didn't.
"In Huntington's you would find a distinctive taste," said one former lunchtime browser, Scott Bushnell, who now lives in chain-store purgatory in Fort Wayne, Ind. "It's the only thing I really miss."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits New Low vs. Yen And Gold Slips in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar sank against most leading currencies yesterday, tumbling to another postwar low against the Japanese yen in a selloff tied to falling American interest rates.
Gold edged lower in New York after a mixed showing overseas. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fell 80 cents, to $337.60 an ounce. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $337.00 an ounce, 75 cents lower than on Wednesday.
 
Favorable Price Data
 Dealers sold dollars after the bond market rallied in response to the Government's latest inflation report. The enthusiasm in the bond market drove the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.85 percent from 6.95 percent on Wednesday. 
Lower American interest rates reduce returns on dollar-denominated investments and tend to lower the demand for dollars.
Currency dealers detected a change in the mood of the bond market, where inflation fears were eased by the Labor Department report on producer prices for March. It showed prices charged by producers rose four-tenths of a percent in March. But excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, prices edged up just a tenth of a percent, the smallest increase in three months.
Trading in the dollar began in Tokyo on a weak note, and the currency finished the Tokyo session at 113.65 yen, down 0.37 yen from Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar fell to 113.40 yen. The selling continued in New York, where the dollar also ended at 113.40 yen, down from 113.50 late Wednesday. It was another postwar low for the dollar.
The dollar briefly dipped below 113 yen in New York, and several dealers said they suspected that central banks intervened to halt the slide. There was no confirmation of any central bank activity.
John McCarthy, chief dealer at ABN-Amro Bank in New York, said the selloff was exaggerated because it came as traders were adjusting their positions ahead of the Easter weekend.
The British pound rose to $1.5251 in London from $1.5150 late Wednesday. A pound fetched $1.5275 late in New York, compared with $1.5135 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.6065 German marks, down from 1.6190; 1.4785 Swiss francs, down from 1.4910; 5.4395 French francs, down from 5.4770; 1,573.50 Italian lire, down from 1,591.00, and 1.2571 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2631.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Whither 12 Warhols?
Andy Warhol was an artist who liked to think in multiples. But what might he say if he knew that 12 of his works are being offered for sale at once at Sotheby's in New York on May 3?
Ten of the works are from the private collection of Fred W. Hughes, Warhol's business manager for 25 years and now the executor of the Warhol estate and chairman emeritus of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts. Mr. Hughes has amassed an extraordinary collection of Warhols from the early 1960's, which experts consider the cream of the crop for serious Pop Art collectors. Mr. Hughes said he was selling his Warhols because "I need the money." 
 The other two Warhol works in the sale are being offered by unidentified private collectors.
Sotheby's made the deal with Mr. Hughes quite recently and did not include the Warhol works on the international tour that usually precedes a sale of important Impressionist, modern or contemporary art. Nor has Sotheby's cited the Warhols in its advertising for the May 3 sale.
"The tour was arranged far in advance, and this was fairly late business-getting," said Lucy Mitchell-Innes, who heads the global division of Sotheby's department of contemporary art. The negotiations were not final until February, she added.
 
A Roller-Coaster Ride
 Some art-world experts think the auction is just too much of a good thing, and predicted that putting 12 top Warhols up for sale on the same night will flood the market and drive prices down. But others say they believe the sale will create an excitement that could give the market a boost.
Since Warhol's death in 1987, prices for his work have taken a roller-coaster ride. During the late 1980's, prices for Warhols, as for so much art on the market, shot up; in 1989, the record price for a Warhol was set when "Shot Red Marilyn," a 40-inch-square painting from 1964, sold for $4.03 million at Christie's in New York. By 1990, when the market took a downturn, Warhol's prices were taking a beating, too.
But over the last year, buyers have paid high prices for work they considered extraordinary. Last May, for example, "210 Coca-Cola Bottles," from 1962, sold for $2.09 million at Christie's in New York. In November, "Marilyn X 100," also from 1962, sold at Sotheby's in New York for $3.7 million. And in December, at Sotheby's in London, "Four Marilyns," from 1962, fetched almost double its pre-sale estimate, selling for $946,000.
"Warhol has always had universal appeal," said Ms. Mitchell-Innes. "And it's helped sustain the market."
 
'No Two Are Alike'
 Most of the works in next month's sale are from 1961 to 1963. The two being sold by private collectors are "The Tuna Fish Disaster," from 1963, which Sotheby's is estimating to bring $500,000 to $600,000, and "Self-Portrait (Green Camouflage)," from 1986, estimated to bring $400,000 to $500,000. Among the works from Mr. Hughes's collection are "Double Elvis," from 1963, estimated to bring between $700,000 and $900,000; "Old Telephone," from 1961 ($600,000 to $800,000); "Schlitz Cans," from 1961 ($500,000 to $700,000), and "A Boy for Meg," from 1961 ($600,000 to $800,000).
"Our objective was to price works conservatively, without being disrespectful to the market, so that everyone would want to come buy," said Ms. Mitchell-Innes. "No two images are alike, both in terms of subject and price range."
The 10 Warhols being sold by Mr. Hughes will have a catalogue of their own, and Mr. Hughes said he believed the market was right for the sale. The Manhattan art dealer Leo Castelli agrees. "There are still about a half a dozen collectors from the United States, Germany and France who are looking for serious Warhols," Mr. Castelli said. "I don't think this is a bad idea; it might create some healthy competition among buyers."
Other dealers were more skeptical, but none would talk negatively for attribution. Several contemporary-art dealers said they believed the market could not absorb so many Warhols at one time.
But one potential buyer is the Warhol Museum, which is to open in Pittsburgh next spring with an extraordinary collection it inherited from the artist's estate. Asked if there was any basis for such pessimistic speculation about the market for Warhols, the museum's director, Thomas Armstrong, would say only, "I decline to comment." Mr. Armstrong also declined to discuss whether the museum was interested in buying any of the Warhols in the sale.
 
Changes for Curators
 Last spring the news was about artists going gallery hopping; this season, it's museum curators who are on the move.
At the Museum of Modern Art, John Elderfield, who was the curator of the spectacular Matisse retrospective and has headed the Modern's drawing department for the last 13 years, has just been named chief curator at large. The new title is the first in a series of changes in the top curatorial titles.
"Chief curator is more descriptive than department director," said Richard E. Oldenburg, the museum's director. "The curators felt it is a better description of their true responsibilities." A search committee is being formed to look for a new head for the drawings department.
Saying he was delighted by his new appointment, Mr. Elderfield added, "I felt it was time for a change." In his new position, he will devote more time to writing catalogues, like the second volume on Matisse, and to organizing exhibitions, while assisting Mr. Oldenburg with shows and publications. "There is always a sense that with seniority comes more administrative work," said Mr. Elderfield.
Mr. Oldenburg was quick to point out that Mr. Elderfield's position is considered to be on the same level as the museum department heads, and that the change will not affect the duties that make up the museum president's job, a paid position for which candidates are being interviewed. "John can help me with the curatorial side of the museum without becoming involved in the day-to-day administrative process," he said. "The job of the president will be purely business and fund-raising."
 
Coast-to-Coast Moves
 In Washington, the National Gallery of Art made two major appointments this week. Mark Rosenthal, a freelance curator who has been a consultant at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan, where he organized "Abstraction in the 20th Century," a show scheduled to open next year, will become the National Gallery's curator of 20th-century art. He replaces Jack Cowart, who left last fall to become chief curator and deputy director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.
And Philip Conisbee, who is leaving the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, where he headed the department of European painting and sculpture for the last five years, will become the National Gallery's curator of French paintings. He will once again be working with Earl A. Powell 3d, who was the director of the Los Angeles County Museum before becoming director of the National Gallery last fall.
"It's definitely an important step for me," said Mr. Conisbee. "I have been working on the gallery's catalogue of 17th- and 18th-century paintings, and it hasn't been easy being across the country."
The Los Angeles County Museum is now looking for a replacement, but "the difficult economic situation in Los Angeles has not been encouraging," Mr. Conisbee said.
Not encouraging, indeed. Just as Michael E. Shapiro replaced Mr. Powell as director of the Los Angeles County Museum, the Los Angeles Board of Supervisors cut $2 million from the museum's operating budget. The museum is also facing a decline in membership funds and in donations. It has cut its staff drastically the last few months and is being sued by Maurice Tuchman, the senior curator for 20th-century drawings. Mr. Tuchman, who was the chief curator of 20th-century art for 27 years, alleges that he was unfairly demoted and is seeking damages and reinstatement to his former job.
Mr. Conisbee isn't the only curator to flee. Judi Freeman, a curator of 20th-century art at the Los Angeles County Museum, is leaving, too. She is becoming the Joan Whitney Payson senior curator at the Portland Museum of Art in Portland, Me. "It's a small museum where I will be given the opportunity to work on acquisitions and exhibition programs in both 19th- and 20th-century art, in all media," said Ms. Freeman. "I feel very strongly that more women at museums need to start taking the initiative in senior curatorial positions. I will be able to put a mark on this institution."
 
 
Growing Again
 As museums expanded in the 1970's and 80's, many began to resemble small campuses. One that continues to grow is the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston.
This month, ground-breaking takes place for the first phase of its ambitious master plan: a $7.5 million building designed by the Carlos Jimenez Architectural Design Studio in Houston. The three-story building is to house the museum's administrative offices and classrooms for the Junior School of the Glasell School of Art, the museum's teaching wing. "This will centralize all of our administration," said Peter C. Marzio, the museum's director. "Long-term, it means the museum building will remain entirely public."
This isn't the institution's first major expansion. In 1986, the sculptor Isamu Noguchi designed its Cullen Sculpture Garden. Two other additions, Cullinan Hall and the Brown Pavilion, completed in 1958 and 1974, respectively, were designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. And just a year ago, the museum announced plans for a $50 million complex to be built east of the museum's main building. The Spanish architect Rafael Moneo was selected to design the addition.
Mr. Marzio said that half the money for the latest addition has been raised, all of it from the private sector, and that he was confident of raising the rest privately, too.

HEADLINE: The President's Budget Priorities

 BODY:
The budget presented yesterday by the Clinton Administration contained no big surprises. The line-by-line details in its 1,300 pages mirrored the economic plan Mr. Clinton outlined in February. Still, the budget's release provides a good occasion to measure the progress and implications of President Clinton's assault on Reagan-Bush economics.
The basic numbers are familiar. Mr. Clinton proposes to cut the deficit over the next four years by about $450 billion, while increasing public investments in infrastructure, training and education by about $150 billion. Spending in Commerce, Justice and many other departments is barely touched. The big hits are few: cuts in spending on defense and agriculture, increases in energy taxes and income taxes on upper-income families. 
 Despite the cuts, annual deficits will remain large and over the next five years are expected to add more than $1 trillion to the national debt. Still, by 1997, the Clinton plan would bring the annual deficit down to about $200 billion -- a reasonable target. But it would rise steeply thereafter unless health care spending for Medicaid and Medicare are brought under control.
Although the broad aggregates show only modest gains, there is an important tale in the line-by-line particulars. Mr. Clinton proposes tilting spending away from the military and away from consumption, both public and private. It's an important turnaround for an economy that has seen its savings rate evaporate. A generation from now, Americans should enjoy better living standards.
A few numbers in next year's budget capture Mr. Clinton's priorities. Defense Department spending will fall by $10 billion, while spending by Health and Human Services will rise by almost $50 billion. The increases will go for early education for poor children, childhood immunization, women's health and drug abuse treatment.
Spending by the Labor Department will fall, but the remaining money will be targeted on job training and retraining -- especially for workers who lose their jobs because of military cuts and plant closings.
Congress has already approved Mr. Clinton's targets for overall spending, revenue and the deficit -- except for the short-term $16 billion stimulus package that is tied up in the Senate. But the approval settled virtually no specifics. It's the all-important details in the new budget that Congress will take up after Easter break.
America's economic future depends more on what the Government buys than on how much it borrows. Spending billions on unnecessary military bases, even if paid for with taxes, undermines growth; and borrowing to invest in 21st-century technology can propel growth. Priorities matter -- and that's where Mr. Clinton's plan sparkles.

HEADLINE: On Terming Proposed U.S. Attorneys a 'Woman and a Black'

 BODY:
To the Editors:
"Woman and a Black," a March 31 headline states, have been proposed as United States Attorneys in New York. By identifying Mary Jo White and Zachary W. Carter exclusively by race and gender, you perpetuate problems that you condemn in your editorials. Moreover, you reinforce the marginalization of both women and blacks, and indirectly help to marginalize black women doubly. 
 These were the thoughts that three virtual strangers discovered they held in common March 31. And the questions that arose during our conversation were these:
If race and gender are the key criteria in the nomination of these two people, as your headline suggests, are we to assume that all "women" are white and all "blacks" are men?
Are "blacks" somehow exempt from gender classification, and are "women" somehow exempt from distinction by race?
Could you ever dream of a headline that read "Male and a Jew Proposed as United States Attorneys in New York"? Or even, "A White and a Heterosexual"?
This is certainly an exciting time for women and minorities in this country. But as the Clinton Administration has repeatedly tried to stress, the point is not to put heretofore marginalized groups into office simply because they are so-called minorities, but rather to fill offices with people who have always been qualified to fill these positions and who, as a group, reflect the larger group that is the public. An Administration that looks like us has not been the case in any of our lifetimes.
The appointment of women and minorities is important to the betterment of our sociopolitical environment and is indeed newsworthy. But why not reflect that real progress is being made by rejecting categories that only reinforce marginalization?
As we three -- differing in age, occupation, economic status and sexual orientation -- immediately realized, headlines like this ultimately work against achievement of equality between races and genders. The labels you choose to give your subjects can help or hinder, accelerate or freeze progress in this area. Race and gender are closely allied categories, and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream applies here -- to judge one by the "content of one's character" -- to resist the tendency to label.
 
K. M. HOBBS, G. RUSSELL JUELG, BERNARD SEEMAN
New Brunswick, N.J., April 1, 1993

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Here We Go Again

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Time after time in the past half-century the Western democracies strengthened dictatorships economically and militarily. Then of course the dictatorships made war against the democracies. Heaven help us, the West is at it again.
Before World War II, the West permitted Hitler to rearm. It handed him Czechoslovakia. Hitler and Mussolini were allowed to take Spain into the Fascist orbit. After World War II, Central and Eastern Europe were delivered hogtied to Stalin. 
 In Asia and the Pacific, the West absolutely knew Japan would be a threat only to Asians, nothing for the likes of us to worry about. After Tokyo surrendered, half of Korea, brutalized by Japan for decades, was turned over by the U.S. to the Red Army.
In the Middle East Iraq was armed by the West up to the invasion of Kuwait. During and since the gulf war, Iran moved to nuclear capacity while the West stood by -- that part of the West that was not selling Teheran some of the right stuff. And we told ourselves Mideast terrorism was a threat only to Middle Easterners.
And now -- now we press money and space equipment on Communist China. In 5 to 10 years, the surge of China will turn out to be either acceptable or terrifying. But that will depend on what happens beginning now -- whether the U.S. pushes for freedom within China, at sorrowfully long last.
Under a democratic government, China's growth would be no more fearful, and just as welcome, as growth in a democratic Russia.
The danger of rising power lies only in those countries where it is overseen, commanded and used by governments whose rulers can make war by fiat -- the dictatorships, whether Fascist, Communist, military, terrorist or theological.
The world adores all those stories about how the Chinese are each and every one making money hand over fist. But the Communist dictators of China still rule by police terror. The burgeoning Chinese Army still is totally controlled by the Communists. They can use it at their will, as all Asia never forgets.
During Bushbaker, the U.S. did nothing to slow the growth of Chinese Communist power by backing the freedom fighters -- not while Beijing jacked up its military budget every year, not while Beijing sold nuclear and missile hardware and technology to other dictatorships.
And meanwhile, in case anybody still cares, thousands of political prisoners are tied to boards, tortured and starved in Communist jails. Millions of Chinese sweated at slave labor in the prison camp -- a built-in part of Beijing's economic planning.
Congressional attempts to use economic pressure on Beijing were vetoed by the White House. Instead, Bushbaker sold Beijing space satellites and military jet engines, and something even more valuable: respectability.
Why, Communist China is so respectable that Olympic representatives traipse around Beijing from banquet to banquet. Beijing is the number one prospect for the Olympic games in 2000. That will be a real fine way to ring in the new century, with an Olympic site politically unmatched since Nazi Berlin in 1936.
Now it is Bill Clinton's chance. He can stop military sales to China's Communist lords. And, under legislation that Senator George Mitchell, the majority leader, and Representative Nancy Pelosi of San Francisco will again submit, he can cancel China's low tariff privileges unless by next year political prisoners are freed and Beijing stops peddling missiles to dictatorships.
President Clinton will be under pressure to waffle. Export-import lobbies will tell him, hell, it's a fool's game to give up business with China.
And even if he lifts tariff privileges, millions will still be enslaved and Tibet occupied. China's people will still live under despotism and the Communist army still will grow.
So what's the use? How about this:
"China cannot withstand forever the forces of democratic change. One day it will go the way of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. The United States must do what it can to encourage that process."
Mr. Clinton said that on Sept. 14, 1992, when he was running for President. It was true then and it is true now, and more important to peace and human dignity with every Communist-made rocket, every scream from the cells.

HEADLINE: Korean Shop Owners Fearful Of Outcome of Beating Trial

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 9

 BODY:
When customers at Elizabeth Hwang's tiny, graffiti-covered convenience store get angry, they know how to frighten her. They say, "We're going to burn down your store."
They tried once before, during the riots a year ago, and now Miss Hwang and her family are preparing for new attacks on Korean businesses if the city erupts again in violence when a verdict is reached in the new trial of the four officers accused of beating Rodney G. King. 
 "We are scared again, same as last year," said Miss Hwang, a 24-year-old college student who quit her studies after the riot to help out full time at her aging parents' market in South-Central Los Angeles, one of the toughest parts of town.
This fear runs throughout the city as people await the verdicts. Gun sales have risen, and schools have prepared to keep children inside their classrooms. National guardsmen have moved into staging areas and county hospitals have readied their emergency rooms to handle riot victims.
Last year, Korean businesses were the primary target of looters and arsonists, suffering more than $350 million in damage, or nearly half the city's total, a recent survey found. The Hwang store suffered $28,000 in damage and stolen goods, but the Hwangs can count themselves lucky simply to be open.
Of 2,100 Korean businesses burned or looted last year, fewer than one in four have reopened, according to the survey conducted by the Korean American Inter-Agency Council, a coalition of nine groups and agencies.
The economic blow suffered by the nation's largest Korean-American community was so severe that for some residents the classic immigrant pattern has been reversed: people in the homeland have taken up collections and sent them aid.
As the Federal civil rights trial of the four officers approaches its conclusion close to the anniversary of the riot that followed their acquittals on state assault charges last April 29, many of the 145,000 Koreans who live here are making grim preparations.
Some merchants at flea markets have begun removing their merchandise from their shelves. Storefronts are being fortified with extra Plexiglas and bars. Churches are holding special prayer services. Throughout the community, shop owners are getting ready to defend themselves as if on the eve of a war.
Like many others, Miss Hwang's family is armed now -- with a Glock 17 pistol, a Beretta and a shotgun -- and they plan to barricade themselves in their store to fight off looters. Last year, she said, she slept in the store for a month after the riot.
"In our family all we have is this store," said Miss Hwang as she served her mostly black and Hispanic customers in a nonstop stream -- a packet of cookies, a bottle of fortified wine, two cans of beer. "This is our life. If we have no store, we don't eat."
Her sales for the most part were accompanied with smiles and friendly chatter. She said most of her customers were regulars who would do her no harm.
About a third of Korean businesses in Los Angeles are, like Miss Hwang's, scattered around South-Central. Another third are clustered just to the north in the bustling immigrant enclave of Koreatown, where David Joo was also serving customers nonstop at the Western Gun Shop.
"Best business since just after the riots," he said, pausing for just a moment between the sale of a Luger and a shotgun. "Two times better than normal. Maybe three times."
Gun buyers, virtually all of them of Korean descent, crowded his shop, some in business suits, some carrying leather briefcases. One walked out with his suit jacket slung over an assault rifle.
"These days we are selling almost everything," Mr. Joo said. "But the big difference since the riot is that we are selling a lot of long guns, like shotguns and rifles, including high-powered military rifles like the commercial model of the M-16."
The gun sales have been fueled as well by what community leaders say is a rising level of violent crimes against Korean merchants. At a recent candlelight demonstration at City Hall, organizers said that in the six weeks from Feb. 5 to March 21, five Korean merchants had been killed in 13 violent attacks.
Keun Kim, a grocer who owns 11 guns, said shoplifters have become more brazen, walking out of his store without trying to conceal their stolen 12-packs of beer.
 
Shoplifters at Ease
 "They know the police don't respond to shoplifting calls any more," Mr. Kim said. "They tell me to go ahead, call the police."
But like some other merchants, Mr. Kim has decided to leave his weapons at home, reasoning that some robbers might consider an armed shopkeeper a challenge and that firearms can be more of a danger than a protection.
During the riot last year, many Korean residents were horrified at a lack of response from an overwhelmed Los Angeles Police Department. For the most part, the police failed to respond to their calls for help.
Mr. Joo was one of those who took matters into his own hands, firing his own pistol outside a Korean-owned jewelry shop after he said a large number of looters had begun shooting. "The L.A.P.D. ran away in half a second," he said in an interview two days afterwards. "I never saw such a fast escape. I was pretty disappointed."
Since then, the merchants have formed several self-defense patrols, equipped with vehicles, weapons and communications equipment.
Among Mr. Joo's customers this week were representatives of one of the largest of these groups, the Korea Young Adult Team of Los Angeles, who bought five AK-47 assault rifles.
"We made a mistake last year," said Yong Kim, the group's leader. "This time we won't. I don't know why Koreans are always a special target for African-Americans, but if they are going to attack our community then we are going to pay them back."
This is not the life Miss Hwang's family anticipated when they immigrated five years ago. "We never thought there was going to be this much danger," she said.
"It's scary," Miss Hwang said. "They can kill you. It's scary all the time. They've robbed the store three times since last year. They put the gun up to my head."
Now this young immigrant has scaled back her American dream.Asked what she hoped for in her life, she said, "I would like to be where there is not so much danger."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Lithuanians Lean on Ex-Marxists Amid Free Market's Uncertainties

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania

 BODY:
He describes himself as a construction engineer and a Lithuanian patriot, although he has not worked as an engineer for three months now. In January, Rimantas Pirmaitis was laid off, the sort of thing that would never have happened when the Communists were in charge.
He now sells flowers from a street stand in central Vilnius, earning what he can to support two small children and his wife, who is pregnant. 
 "Of course I still believe in a free Lithuania," said Mr. Pirmaitis, 43, who joined the protests of 1989 and 1990 that forced the first cracks in Soviet rule, and led a year later to Lithuania's independence. "But we are past the time for marches and anthems. What we need now is something real, something we can eat and touch."
 
Inflation Above 600 Percent
 With inflation running at more than 600 percent over the last 12 months, and imports of Russian fuel oil so erratic that few buildings had heat or hot water over the winter, Mr. Pirmaitis and other Lithuanian voters exercised their new democratic option in the hope of improving their economic lot.
In a presidential election in February and in parliamentary balloting last fall, they voted out Vytautas Landsbergis, the musician-turned-politician who led the Lithuanian Government for nearly three years during its confrontation with Moscow, and other liberal reformers of Sajudis, the independence movement that faced down Soviet Army tanks and troops outside the republic's Parliament in early 1991.
In their place, voters turned to a group of reform-minded former Communists turned Social Democrats, including Algirdas Brazauskas, the 60-year-old bearlike former head of Lithuania's Communist Party, who is now the republic's President.
The election results, in which Mr. Brazauskas took more than 60 percent of the votes, easily defeating Stasys Lozoraitus, the Sajudis candidate and Lithuania's current Ambassador to the United States, represented a measure of the degree to which a disintegrating economy has tilted the political debate in this Baltic republic of 3.7 million.
Of the former Soviet satellites and republics, Lithuania is the first in which voters voluntarily agreed to restore power to elements of a political elite from the old Communist system.
Yet there is no evidence to suggest that Lithuanians -- historically among the least compliant members of the old Soviet empire -- are yearning for a return to the good old days of socialist central planning and a rigid command economy. For one thing, Mr. Brazauskas, a longtime Communist maverick who in 1989 was the first provincial party boss to break with Moscow, vowed in the campaign to press forward with Western-style economic reforms, albeit at a more measured pace.
"I'm no miracle maker," Mr. Brazauskas said in a recent interview. "This is the worst situation the Lithuanian economy has been in in this century. All I can say, if we fail to improve the situation here, and someone replaces me who can, then I shall be the first to shake his hand."
 
Value of Knowing The Names of Cows
 In choosing Mr. Brazauskas, Lithuanians opted for a more personal brand of leadership. Mr. Brazauskas, one Western diplomat here said, is as different from Mr. Landsbergis as Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago was from Adlai E. Stevenson.
"One is an intellectual and the other the consummate streetwise politician," the diplomat said. "When Brazauskas goes to a village, he not only remembers the names of the farmers but the names of their cows."
In an economic plan announced in March, Mr. Brazauskas and his new Prime Minister, Adolfas Slezevicius, said they wanted to open doors wider to Western investors, with measures including more liberal banking laws intended to draw foreign capital and legislation to change the Constitution so foreigners could own land in Lithuania.
The Government is also urging major changes in agricultural policy, including slowing the pace of privatization and enforcing a prohibition on breaking up large farms into smaller, unprofitable units.
Interviews with farmers, workers, students and pensioners here underscore that the election returns reflected more a sense of distress and frustration over the nation's economic decline than any second thoughts over their new political freedom. Given a chance to exercise their choice democratically, in a self-satisfied demonstration of their new, post-Soviet political freedom, voters unhesitatingly picked the old-fashioned political pros over the young idealists and nationalist intellectuals of Sajudis.
 
High Hopes Dashed By Unemployment
 "I marched in all the marches and attended all the rallies and believed intensely in Sajudis and Mr. Landsbergis," said Lidija Cesniene, 62, a retired linguist. "But now I am frustrated and disappointed. Sajudis tore down everything, and put nothing up in its place."
Nearby, in the central park where the statue of Lenin once stood, Lina Vaitiekuniene, 34, said the high hopes she had felt when Lithuania had become independent had been dashed. In March she lost her job in an electronics factory near Vilnius.
"I am sorry to say I've become a pessimist," she said. "I hope Brazauskas can make things better; that's why I voted for him. But economically, right now I am worse off than in the old times."
Like that other reformed Communist populist, Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow, Mr. Brazauskas is facing a formidable challenge, and the Baltics are already edgy as they watch political events unfold uncertainly in Russia.
As in the rest of the old empire, the dismantling of the old Soviet system has loosened a riptide of expectations and dizzying possibilities.
Politically and culturally, Lithuania and the rest of the Baltic republics are in full bloom. Shops are filled with Western goods, cafes buzz with conversations between local entreprenuers and foreign investors, and there is a rich exchange of political views in a myriad of publications and broadcasts.
But the demise of the central command economy has also wreaked havoc in the small republic. "These days, you can get anything you want in Lithuania," Joana Snieganiene, 58, said as she shopped in the Kalvarija farm market. "But who can afford the prices?"
Factories that made Soviet-style radios and computers for which there is no longer a market have cut back or stopped production entirely, contributing to unemployment among people who never before had to worry about job security.
The official Government figures show the number of unemployed at 29,100. Unofficially, even ranking members of the Government do not dispute that the real number is probably closer to 200,000.
 
Reform Politicians Were Out of Touch
 As a result of sharp declines in industrial and agricultural production, the Government itself estimates that gross domestic product in 1992 was only 39 percent of what it was the year before.
That Sajudis fell from power was not wholly unexpected. Other broad coalitions that also came to power in Eastern Europe on the strength of their single-minded opposition to the Communists -- including Solidarity in Poland and Civic Forum in Czechoslavakia -- also lost popularity in the face of the economic hardships of post-Soviet reconstruction.
Many people complained that Sajudis was out of touch with the people, particularly in the countryside, where the Sajudis leadership moved quickly to dismantle collective farms and restore private property seized by the Communists without reckoning the consequences it would have on agricultural production.
Vytautas Kazlauskas, 60, a pig farmer from Moletai, about 40 miles from Vilnius, said the Government had given land back to people who did not care to farm it, and provided little help for those who did. "The people in Sajudis just didn't understand the countryside," Mr. Kazlauskas said.
Among other things, new private farmers discovered that they could neither sell the land, if they did not want to farm, nor borrow money for tractors, fertilizers or seed, if they did. Moreover, the Government made no provision to share or lease equipment still in the hands of the old collectives.
With the cost of production rising, output of everything from eggs to milk has fallen sharply, prodding a parallel increase in food prices, which have climbed about 700 percent in the last 12 months. With meat supplies declining too, producers nearly doubled their prices in early April, and the Government, which once supplied meat products throughout the old Soviet Union, now says it must import them from Germany just to satisfy local demand.
While Mr. Brazauskas and his political supporters in Parliament so far have been able to lay the blame at the door of their predecessors, the challenge in the coming months will be to satisfy the growing expectations of Lithuanians that the new Governmnent can get things back on track.
 
Popular Pressure To Raise Spending
 For one thing, Lithuania, the poorest and most rural of the Baltic republics, so far has not attracted anywhere near the same degree of Western investment as Latvia or Estonia.
Western analysts here say the biggest danger is that the Brazauskas Government may react to domestic political pressure by increasing wages, pensions and other benefits at a time when Government revenues are declining and inflation is already rampant. The Government recently said it intended to double pensions if it could find the revenue.
In public appearances since his election, Mr. Brazauskas has gone out of his way to appear as a conciliator and a healer, and to emphasize that he prefers now to be known as a now as a reborn Social Democrat rather than a old-time Communist.
"Let's agree on one thing," he said. "Nobody would vote for a Communist today in Lithuania. People voted for us because we promised to find a less painful way to carry on with reform."
Viktor Petkus, who spent 25 years in Soviet prison camps and now serves as an adviser on human rights to the Lithuanian Parliament, is among those who argue that it is wrong to hound Mr. Brazauskas or other former members of the old Communist Government because of their past.
"Some of those who talk about rooting out the Communists are more Bolshevik than the ones they blame," said Mr. Petkus, who is 62. "I think even the Communists now agree that no river can flow backwards."
Still, the scars of 50 years of Communist domination heal slowly, and many here are determined not to forget. Flowers are still placed regularly alongside the memorial outside the old K.G.B. headquarters in central Vilnius, in memory of those killed in 1991 when Soviet Army troops opened fire on demonstrators.
"They have only changed their name," complained Bronislava Bundziene, 54, a teacher who joined a recent Sajudis demonstration against the Government. "The way they work, the way they think, their goals have not changed. In their hearts, they are still Communists."
Mr. Landsbergis, who now sits in Parliament as the leader of the opposition, warns darkly that Mr. Brazauskas is still surrounded by former servants of the Soviet state, including K.G.B. informers, who may be less willing to stand up to Russia should conservatives or hard-line nationalists gain the upper hand there.
In Vilnius, as in the neighboring Baltic capitals of Riga and Tallinn, the events unfolding in Moscow, in which President Yeltsin is being challenged by former Communists in the Russian Congress, are watched with apprehension.
While Lithuania was the first of the Soviet republics to break with the Soviet leadership, it has moved faster than its Baltic neighbors in repairing relations with Moscow. Lithuania, for example, is the only Baltic state to have negotiated an agreement with Russia on the withdrawal of former Soviet Army units.
 
Defeated President Ponders Situation
 Mr. Landsbergis acknowledges that his leadership was found wanting. "We achieved independence," he said. "But our achievement was not reflected in the living standards of people, and it was not enough to explain that some difficulties were necessary in making the transition to a Western economy."
With the next elections four years off, and the economy still struggling, he says he fears that Mr. Brazauskas will fall back on what he knows best. "Their experience as leaders of a socialist economy is not what we need today," he said of the former Communists back in power. "Either they will be successful, or they will turn back the economy to their own competence."
