HEADLINE: IRAQI GUNNERS FIRE ON AMERICAN JETS IN NORTH, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
American fighter jets today bombed Iraqi antiaircraft batteries that fired at the aircraft as they flew a routine surveillance mission over the no-flight zone in northern Iraq, Administration officials said.
But Baghdad denied shooting at the American F-16 and F-4G fighters and said the United States attack had been unprovoked. 
 The incident marked the first challenge to allied aircraft in Iraq since Iraqi gunners fired at French reconnaissance planes on Feb. 3 and the first against American planes since the days immediately after President Clinton's inauguration.
If Iraqi gunners did shoot at the American planes, which the Pentagon said were not hit, it would end a two-month charm offensive Baghdad had waged to persuade the United Nations to lift economic sanctions imposed during the Persian Gulf crisis. The United Nations Security Council agreed Monday to maintain the restrictions, saying that Baghdad had not fulfilled its obligations under the Persian Gulf war cease-fire.
 
New Test of U.S. Resolve?
 Administration officials expressed concern that if Iraq's hostilities were deliberate and are repeated this weekend, it could signal a renewal of Baghdad's efforts to test United States resolve.
"If they start shooting again, it tells me they're starting back toward confrontation, and things could ratchet up very quickly," said one senior Defense Department official who watches the Persian Gulf region closely.
The incident today also coincided with the arrival of the latest group of international inspectors in Baghdad to pursue the United Nations goal of eliminating Iraq's major weapons programs.
In January, during the final days of the Bush Administration, United States warplanes launched two attacks in southern Iraq in retaliation for Baghdad's refusal to abide by United Nations resolutions, including its ban of visits by United Nations weapons inspection teams.
President Saddam Hussein responded by allowing entry for the teams and announcing a unilateral cease-fire in honor of President Clinton's inauguration. But within days after Mr. Clinton took office, the attacks resumed with American fighters firing on Iraqi artillery sites after the Iraqis took what American pilots said were threatening actions.
In late February, Iraqi forces aimed their guns at the helicopters of two inspectors who had mounted a major air-and-ground search west of Baghdad for hidden missiles and missile parts or launchers.
The United States mission to the United Nations said today that it did not plan to summon the Iraqi Ambassador or issue any demands over the attacks, unless such incidents are repeated and become a pattern, The Associated Press reported.
"Iraq understands clearly what its obligations are in regard to the no-fly zone and will be held solely responsible for the serious consequences of failure to comply with these obligations," said the State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher. The United States and its allies have barred Iraqi planes from two areas, in northern Iraq to stop aerial attacks against Kurds and and in southern Iraq to stop attacks against Shiite Muslims.
 
Four Cluster Bombs
 The military's European Command said that at 1:05 P.M. local time, Iraqi antiaircraft batteries two miles east of the Saddam Dam, near Mosul, fired at three American F-16's and one F-4G. Allied aircraft have patrolled the area north of the 36th parallel since the end of the gulf war two years ago.
The sites attacked were about 20 miles inside the northern zone, Pentagon officials said today.
In response, the military said, two of the F-16's dropped a total of four cluster bombs on the batteries, but it was not clear what damage they did. The Pentagon said the fire-control radars of the the artillery batteries were being used at the time. The American planes then returned to Incirlik Air Base in Turkey.
Baghdad, however, immediately denied shooting at the American aircraft.
"The soldiers were having lunch at the time," Gen. Abdeljawad Dhanoun, the governor of Nineveh province, told Iraqi state television. "There was no state of preparedness or firing by the air defense forces in the region of Saddam Dam in northern Iraq."
Administration officials, in turn, discounted the Iraqi denials, but acknowledged that it was unclear whether the incident was ordered by the authorities in Baghdad or were actions taken by local commanders.
"We'll have to see what happens over the weekend," one Defense Department official said. "Maybe it was a localized incident."
Allied air patrols generally fly at altitudes that are out of range of most Iraqi guns. But firing the antiaircraft batteries is viewed as a challenge to the coalition's enforcement of the no-flight zone.
In addition to the antiaircraft guns, American officials also contended that the Iraqis directed radar at the American planes. The United States considers the use of such radars as a threatening act and a possible prelude to firing missiles from surface-to-air batteries.
Pentagon officials said there were no incidents south of the 32d parallel in the no-flight zone intended to protect the Shiites.

HEADLINE: REJECTION IS SEEN FOR A TAX CREDIT AIMED AT BUSINESS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
The tax break to encourage business investment that President Clinton has proposed as a central element in his plan to stimulate the economy and create jobs is not likely to be enacted, leading lawmakers in both parties say.
That means Mr. Clinton may get almost none of the measures he has sought to give the economy a quick jolt. The other half of the stimulus program, a spending bill, has been blocked in the Senate by a Republican filibuster and stands no chance of passage in its current form. 
 The proposed investment tax credit, meant to induce businesses to buy new machinery and equipment, has won little support in Congress or in business circles.
 
Congressional Leaders Opposed
 Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said in an interview recently that the tax credit, which would cost the Government more than $21 billion in lost revenue over five years, was an integral part of the President's economic package and that the Administration would fight to preserve it.
It was supposed to be part of the tax bill that Congressional committees will begin drafting next month, with the idea that the credit would be retroactive so it could be applied to purchases made after last Dec. 3.
But the chairmen of the Congressional tax committees -- Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, and Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee -- said they were opposed to the proposal because it would open an unnecessary tax loophole and did not know of much support in either party on their committees.
Even the National Association of Manufacturers, which represents the kinds of businesses that are among the heaviest buyers of machinery and equipment, is opposed to the Clinton proposal.
 
Criticism From Industry
 "It is a bad idea that will simply shift investment from the future forward," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, the association's president.
Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economics consulting company, said of Administration officials, "They can't find a friend for it in Congress or in industry."
Mr. Clinton and his spokesmen have maintained that the stimulus program is needed because the economy is recovering so slowly from the recession and relatively few new jobs are being created. Some economists favor the proposals and some do not, but the prevailing view is that the effect of a $30 billion stimulus over two years in a $6 trillion economy would be marginal.
As for the political consequences, the rejection of a large portion of the President's stimulus package will probably be forgotten if Mr. Clinton succeeds in winning approval of the basic elements of the budget he submitted to Congress on Thursday.
The opposition to the investment tax credit proposal comes from several directions:
*Some opponents believe it will be a waste of money.
*Others are philosophically opposed to skewing the marketplace with tax incentives.
*Others note that while the President was giving with one hand he would take away with another, by raising the tax rate on corporate profits to 36 percent from 34 percent; they say they would rather keep the lower rate than have an investment credit.
*Still others say they favor an investment tax credit in a different form.
Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Rostenkowski, who were interviewed separately in their offices, said they expected the fight in Congress to be over what else to do with the $21 billion, not over whether to approve an investment tax credit.
"That's our cushion," Mr. Moynihan said. "It's going to be used in place of revenue from some other tax."
 
Other Proposals for Money
 Mr. Rostenkowski said it was even possible that the money saved by not approving the tax credit would be used to lower the Federal deficit further.
An investment tax credit was first put on the books in the Kennedy Administration. It expired and was reinstated several times until it was finally repealed, supposedly for good, by the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The main theme of the 1986 law, which Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Rostenkowski strongly supported, was lower tax rates and the elimination of tax breaks.
"I have spent a lot of effort getting mischief out of the tax code," Mr. Rostenkowski said.
But Mr. Clinton has a different philosophy. He believes that businesses and individuals should sometimes be given tax incentives to accomplish economic and social goals.
In his election campaign last year, Mr. Clinton offered an investment tax credit as one of the main aspects of his effort to generate more private investment. "Putting People First," the Clinton campaign manifesto, observed that the Japanese invested twice as much per person as Americans and he promised "a targeted investment tax credit to encourage investment in new plants and productive equipment here at home that we need to compete in the global economy."
 
Plan Smaller Than Expected
 The actual proposal sent to Congress in February proved to be much more modest than many business executives and economists had expected based on the campaign oratory.
First, the credit would be only 7 percent rather than 10 percent as some had anticipated. Second, it would be what is known as an incremental credit, meaning it could be claimed only on the amount of investments above the average investments in previous years. Third, it would last only for two years for companies with sales of more than $5 million a year. For smaller companies, the credit would be permanent, but it would drop to 5 percent after two years. (As an illustration, a successful automobile dealership or a machine shop with 50 employees might have annual sales of $5 million.)
Administration officials said they favored an incremental credit so businesses would get no tax break for investments that would have been made anyway. The officials said they wanted the credit for big businesses to expire after two years to hold down the cost and to get the benefit of the new investment as quickly as possible.
"What the President is looking for is the most bang for the buck," Mr. Bentsen said.
As a matter of theory, economists are divided on the wisdom of an investment tax credit generally, but few support an incremental, temporary credit.
Laurence H. Meyer, a prominent economic forecaster based in St. Louis who was commissioned by the Clinton campaign to do a pre-election study of investment tax credits, is a strong believer that a permanent credit would generate new investment, create hundreds of thousands of new jobs and lead to significant improvement in the economy.
But in an interview this week, Mr. Meyer said that a temporary tax break would simply be a disruption, causing companies "to shift investments to 1994 that would have taken place anyway in 1995."
Mr. Meyer said he was intrigued by the notion of allowing the credit only for investments above a certain level. But he said he doubted that an incremental credit would be workable on a permanent basis because companies would master the rules and find ways to get around the law.
Jane G. Gravelle, a senior specialist in tax and economic policy at the Library of Congress, said the Clinton proposal would be an administrative nightmare and would punish companies that invested during the recession while rewarding those that did not.
The Administration hoped that the announcement that the credit would be retroactive would induce companies to step up their purchases of machinery and equipment early this year. Economists and representatives of trade associations who follow such matters said they saw no indications that many companies had done so.
Executives of companies like those in the airline and computer industries who might be expected to support an investment tax credit said the Clinton proposal was too small to make much differences in their businesses.
"The carrot is so small, I find very few people if any in favor," said Mark A. Bloomfield, president of the American Council for Capital Formation, an association here that lobbies for measures to make business investment more attractive.

The Economy
The business investment tax credit that President Clinton has proposed as a central element in his plan to stimulate the economy is not likely to be enacted, leading Congressional Democrats say. That means Mr. Clinton may get almost none of the measures he has sought to jolt the economy. The other half of the stimulus program, a spending bill, is stalled in the Senate. [Page 1.]
Medical-cost inflation continued to decelerate in March, according to the consumer price report, which showed an overall rise in consumer prices of only one-tenth of 1 percent. [33.] 
 The travel industry and consumer groups object to a price-fixing suit filed by the Government against major airlines, saying the proposed settlement will hurt travelers. [33.]
 
Companies
General Motors was asked by the Government to voluntarily recall millions of pickup trucks that critics charge are fire hazards. The request, which G.M. turned down, came after a Federal finding that the gasoline tanks in 4.7 million vehicles of all makes built from 1973 through 1987 were dangerous. [1.]
I.B.M.'s new chief executive loves the company's electronic mail network. On Tuesday, Louis V. Gerstner Jr. distributed a seven-paragraph message to all employees, which was a departure from the more formal style of his predecessor. [33.]
The Washington Public Power Supply System will move to abandon two partly built nuclear plants rather than spend $10.5 million a year on the paperwork needed to keep them alive. [35.]

International
Japan's Export-Import Bank will spend $12 million in the construction of a coal export terminal in Los Angeles, its first investment in a project in an industrialized country. [33.]
President Clinton will ask Congress to renew special authority to complete negotiations on a sweeping overhaul of the rules governing world trade, which are snarled over farm subsidies. [34.]

Markets

Foreign stock markets are attracting an increasing amount of money from American institutions and individuals. The primary reason: the potential for high returns. [31.]
Utility stocks have become a remarkable investment for some because they are paying dividends almost double the interest available from bank certificates and money market accounts. [31.]

HEADLINE: U.S. to Send General to Vietnam, Hinting a Thaw

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
In its first policy decision on Vietnam, the Clinton Administration will send John W. Vessey Jr., a retired Army general, to Hanoi on a fact-finding mission on missing American servicemen, a move that could lead the United States to withdraw its opposition to international bank lending to Vietnam, senior Administration officials said today.
The officials stressed that President Clinton will make no decision on easing any American pressure on Vietnam until he is convinced that Hanoi is doing all it can to cooperate with the American authorities on the contentious and emotional issue of Americans missing since the Vietnam War. 
 But the Administration is trying to work out the broad outlines of a Vietnam policy before late April, when the International Monetary Fund will decide whether to take steps toward resuming lending to Hanoi. France, Germany, Japan and a number of Asian nations are poised to lend Vietnam enough money to repay its longstanding I.M.F. debts, which could allow Vietnam to qualify for new loans.
The new Administration is caught between its isolation on the loan issue and its desire to increase Vietnam's commercial dealings with the rest of the world on the one hand, and the reluctance of Mr. Clinton, who opposed the Vietnam War and did not serve in the military, to take any step that would expose him to criticism that he is soft on Vietnam.
Mr. Clinton cannot afford another bruising battle, given the controversy over his own military record and the furor over the issue of whether to lift the ban on allowing declared homosexuals to serve in the military.
For his part, Secretary of State Warren Christopher is keenly aware that Vietnam, a country of 70 million people, is a great untapped business opportunity, one he does not want American businesses to lose to foreign competitors. Liberal and even some conservative lawmakers have begun calling for more liberalized relations with Hanoi.
But senior Administration officials stress that even if the United States were to end its opposition to international loans to Vietnam, lifting the 18-year-old American trade embargo is another matter, and would happen only slowly and in stages. Some senior officials speak of the possibility of an eventual economic relationship with Vietnam but no full-scale normalization of diplomatic relations.
 
General's New Mission
 In a question-and-answer session after a speech on American foreign policy, Mr. Christopher raised expectations that the United States might lift the embargo. Asked about the American approach to the embargo, he repeated the Administration's conditions, but said, "It's unfortunate that many other countries around the world are getting ahead of us in their commercial endeavors in Vietnam and I hope that we can enable our businesses and industries to catch up by moving more rapidly down the road."
General Vessey, a former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who was the Bush Administration's special envoy to Hanoi, will seek detailed information on a range of issues, including full American access to Vietnam's archives, the resolution of outstanding cases where there are discrepancies in reports, and the return of the remains of American soldiers. The Administration acknowledges Vietnam's increased cooperation in the last 18 months, but there are differences between senior officials over the lending issue.
When asked on Thursday about the pending vote at the I.M.F., one senior Administration official said, "I think the United States Government hopes very much to be in a position to join the group that is positive about the situation in Vietnam." But he added that Mr. Clinton is firmly committed to insuring that the United States gets all the available information on the missing Americans.
 
Vietnam's Burden of Proof
 Other senior officials involved in the decision said that they were not yet satisfied that Vietnam had fully cooperated on the issue and that the burden of proof was on the Vietnamese.
Even some of the most conservative members of Congress have urged the new Administration to make a concrete gesture toward the Hanoi Government.
"I've been a hard-liner in a lot of ways," Senator Larry Pressler, a South Dakota Republican, said last month during the Senate confirmation hearing of Winston Lord as Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. "I'm a Vietnam veteran and served two tours there," he said. But he added that the time has come for President Clinton to "recognize Vietnam."
Senator John F. Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat, who recently issued a comprehensive report on the fate of several hundred American servicemen missing since the Vietnam war, asked Mr. Lord to explain why the new Administration was so willing to engage with China as a way to push for change there, but took a "don't be involved" approach toward Vietnam.
Last fall, the Bush Administration made conciliatory gestures toward Vietnam after receiving what officials considered extraordinary assistance in identifying missing Americans. Mr. Bush allowed American companies to open offices in Vietnam and to sign agreements that would take effect as soon as the United States lifted the embargo, but he left the White House without doing so.

HEADLINE: Travel Industry Protests U.S. Stance on Fares

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Late last month, the nation's airlines cut fares about 30 percent on certain coach tickets purchased at least 14 days in advance. While all carriers tell passengers of the various restrictions, Northwest and USAir do not add that the tickets must be purchased by April 21, because that would tip the public to a possible fare change the following day.
Why the big secret? Both airlines fear that the disclosure would run afoul of Justice Department recommendations made as part of a civil antitrust suit against eight leading airlines, accusing them of price fixing and restraining price competition. 
 The department's proposed remedy, which came in the form of a consent decree that it unsuccessfully tried to compel all eight airlines to sign, prevents airlines from discussing their fare changes until they advertise them publicly.
That provision has much of the travel industry up in arms, worried that such a proposed remedy could itself restrain price competition.
Delta Air Lines, one of the six carriers that have not signed the decree, contends that the airlines would become the only American industry barred from discussing sales and price increases in advance of public notice. The computer reservation system was assembled to give travel agents -- and therefore passengers -- an idea of future prices.
"This is a bullying misuse of power that will work to the detriment of travelers," said John Noble, chief executive of Northwestern Business Travel in Minneapolis.
Even consumer organizations, which might have been expected to applaud the suit, have misgivings. The proposed solution is opposed by at least a dozen organizations, including those representing corporate travel executives and restaurants, and even the Congressional Travel and Tourism Caucus, a group of lawmakers that examines ways to promote tourism in the United States. Many of the opponents contend that denying consumers information about fare reductions and increases means they will end up paying more.
Cornish F. Hitchcock, a lawyer and aviation specialist for Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group, said, "As strange as it is to be criticizing an antitrust initiative, I'm not sure the public will be better off if the Government wins."
Linda Golodner, president of the National Consumers League, said the department's proposed remedy "has not been well thought out" and "would do far more harm than good."
 Several weeks ago, executives of 14 large associations -- including several representing travel agents -- asked President Clinton to advise Attorney General Janet Reno to seek a voluntary stay of the Justice Department proceedings so the new Administration could review the action taken in the final days of the Bush Administration.
Not all of those associations categorically reject the charge that the carriers colluded to fix prices. But they say the Government should seek different remedies.
The object of so much wrath began with the suit filed by the Justice Department's antitrust division on Dec. 21 against American, United, Delta, Northwest, USAir, Continental, Trans World and Alaska Airlines.
Also named as a defendant was the Airline Tariff Publishing Company, a fare-data collection and dissemination service owned by a group of airlines, including those eight.
 
 
Signals on Prices
 The complaint contended that since at least April 1988 and continuing through at least May 1990, the airlines at various times agreed among themselves to raise particular fares and eliminate particular discounts for travel between specific cities.
In January, J. Mark Gidley, the acting assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, said that the airlines used the tariff publishing company to communicate proposed prices to competitors and reach agreements on fare increases. The process of posting proposed increases and counterproposals with the publisher, he said, enabled the carriers to agree on fares before they were offered to the public.
To remedy the supposed violations, the Government asked the eight carriers to sign a decree agreeing to stop providing the publisher with the starting and ending dates for future fares, unless they publicly advertise the ending date of a new promotional fare. The suit seeks no penalties, but the decree would require the airlines to change procedures for 10 years.
All eight airlines denied breaking the law, noting that the same system that they used to announce fare increases is also used to announce reductions -- including last summer's record-breaking half-price sale.
 Nevertheless, two airlines signed the consent decree: USAir, which at the time was seeking Government approval for what became a $300 million investment by British Airways, and United, whose motivation mystified its competitors.
"We were not guilty of any offense," said Stephen M. Wolf, United's chief executive. "But it became a case of how much it would cost us in legal fees."
Since signing the decree, United announced plans in March to buy USAir's operating authority between Philadelphia and Gatwick Airport near London. United wants to transform that flight into a flight serving O'Hare Airport in Chicago and the more desirable Heathrow in London, and it would need Government approval to make the change.
American and Northwest, while insisting that they have done nothing wrong, are informally complying with the decree, figuring that this will protect them against private triple-damage lawsuits from consumers.
Neither carrier provides advance notice of fare changes anymore, or uses a final ticketing date on promotional fares unless that date is included in advertising. In addition, American no longer responds to questions from the press about whether it is matching a rival's fare, or the dates a new fare begins or ends, unless it has advertised that information.
 Travel agents, who book more than 80 percent of domestic air travel, have been particularly upset by the Justice Department suit. If successful, it would mean that the carriers -- and by extension, the agents -- could guarantee a fare only if a ticket was purchased the same day the quote was made. And, they added, a successful suit would in effect give a Federal judge authority to regulate prices.
"The Government does not sue Chevrolet for announcing what next year's models will cost," the American Society of Travel Agents said, "even though it is understood that the price may be adjusted upward or downward depending upon how their competitors price their own new line. The fact that this information exchange goes on more rapidly due to computers does not change the principle."
Delta has not agreed to sign or abide by the Government decree.
The United States District Court in Washington, meanwhile, has given the carriers until Oct. 1 to file motions for summary judgment, and if they fail to win a summary dismissal the trial is set for next Feb. 14.
Opponents of the Government suit say they cannot understand why it was brought by the Bush Administration's Justice Department. But some of them speculate privately that Mr. Gidley had wanted to increase his visibility to land a job with a prominent Washington law firm.
Indeed, Mr. Gidley recently followed William P. Barr, the former Attorney General, to the high-powered firm of Shaw, Pittman, Potts & Trowbridge. But Mr. Gidley denies having had ulterior motives.
 
 
Decision Is Defended
 "It was a complex investigation, begun under one of my predecessors and prosecuted with intensity over a three-year period," he said. He added that the case was supported by the Justice Department's career staff; by its chief economist, Barry Harris, and by his superior, Wayne Budd, the Associate Attorney General.
 As for the timing of the case and the opposition of a variety of organizations, Mr. Gidley said: "We don't shut down the Justice Department after an election. We bring cases as we're able to decide them. And we decide the cases based on the facts and the law. You don't conduct head counts."
Moreover, Mr. Gidley said he had no second thoughts about bringing the case. "I'd be stunned if anybody at the Justice Department disagreed that I'm a conservative antitrust lawyer," he said. "So the fact that I brought this case should show you something about the strength of the case."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Easing Rules for Moscow Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
Under heavy pressure from the Clinton Administration and other Western governments, the International Monetary Fund is moving to ease restrictions on aid to Russia with the aim of freeing several billion dollars in assistance.
The much-needed burst of new assistance to the suffering Russian economy would follow a year when the monetary fund gave Moscow far less money than anticipated because Russia failed to take the strict austerity measures the fund demanded. 
 In the face of criticism that the fund has done too little for Russia, fund officials said a program they hope to set up by late April could provide about $4.5 billion in loans in the next few months, without the usual tough requirements for slashing inflation and budget deficits.
 
Urgent Aid for Imports
 The fund's 24-member board on Thursday informally endorsed the new program to provide urgent aid to countries whose tattered economies are making the transition from Communism. Officials from the fund said their new aid program would help finance desperately needed imports.
In a news briefing today, a senior Treasury Department official, who spoke under condition of anonymity, praised the plans, but signaled impatience with the amount of aid the fund has provided at a time when President Boris N. Yeltsin is fighting with conservatives for survival.
"This is not a situation where aid can be delayed until every 'i' is dotted and every 't' is crossed," the official said. The official noted that the fund's loans are expected to be part of the package that the finance and foreign ministers of the Group of Seven major industrialized nations are expected to unveil in Tokyo on April 14 and 15.
Anticipating similar pressures, World Bank officials have proposed to their board of directors that $4 billion in loans, more than double the amount they were considering just last month, be provided to Russia over the next 12 to 18 months.
At a time when most industrial nations are plagued by anemic growth and budget deficits, the Clinton Administration and Group of Seven Governments are looking increasingly to the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to help Russia.
Speaking about these international lending institutions, the Treasury official said, "They're certainly going to be very important players in any ongoing efforts to support Russia."
In today's briefing, the official called on Japan, as host of next week's meeting, to make a substantial new aid commitment to Russia.
 
Expansion Considered
 Monetary fund officials said the new program may also provide aid to the 14 other former Soviet republics as well as to Mongolia, Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos.
But the creation of this more generous program was obviously a response to the desire to help keep Russia from falling into chaos as it adopts measures to bring its economy under control.
"This is probably the greatest economic reform task that the world has ever faced," the senior Treasury officials said. "The design of policy needs to be very sensitive to that."
Officials from the International Monetary Fund denied that they were reacting to American pressures in creating this program. But one American official said it was no coincidence that the fund was acting with such urgency soon after American officials had indicated in private that they thought the fund was being too cautious with Russia.
 
Broke Vow on Inflation
 The monetary fund was supposed to provide Russia with $3.5 billion in loans last year, but it ended up providing only $1 billion. Russian officials had pledged to reduce inflation to less than 10 percent a month, but the central bank printed so many rubles to plug its budget deficit and to keep teetering enterprises afloat that inflation soared to 25 percent a month.
American and monetary fund officials said they hoped this new program would lead to Russia's signing a stricter aid agreement with the fund by October. Under such an accord, known as a standby agreement, not only would Russia qualify for another $4 billion in loans, but it could also receive an additional $6 billion supervised by the fund to stabilize the ruble.
The fund hopes to win full approval for the plan by its spring meeting on April 30.
Some fund officials said one proposal would be to let Russia receive two $2 billion loans, one for 1992 and one for 1993. Another $500 million might also be made available as a supplement under a temporary aid agreement signed last year.
 
Germany Cites Its Burdens
 German officials have also called on the fund and the World Bank to carry more of the aid burden, asserting that Germany not only has a huge budget deficit and the burden of rebuilding eastern Germany, but that it has also provided far more aid to Russia than any other country.
Under the World Bank proposals, its $4 billion in possible loans would include $250 million to help develop a private banking system, $100 million for management training, and $100 million to develop a social safety net.
There would also be $600 million to modernize farming and $500 million for the oil industry. The plan also suggests $300 million for highway rehabilitation and $400 million for emergency housing construction, especially to help house soldiers returning from postings outside Russia. There would also be a new $600 million loan to finance critical imports, in addition to a $600 million loan already committed for that purpose.

HEADLINE: Slowing Health Costs Help To Hold Down Price Index

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
The deceleration in medical inflation intensified in March, the Government's consumer price report showed today, with health-care costs rising by the smallest amount in nine years.
The rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in medical costs last month magnified a slowdown that has been under way since early 1991. Medical inflation for the first quarter of the year fell to an annual rate of 5.6 percent, down from 6.6 percent in 1992, 7.9 percent in 1991 and 9.6 percent in 1990. 
 The slim rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in the overall Consumer Price Index banished fears that hefty increases in January and February in the so-called core inflation rate might have signaled revived inflation. In March, the core rate, which excludes volatile energy and food prices, rose just one-tenth of 1 percent, the same as the overall rate. The core rate rose by five-tenths of 1 percent in January and in February.
Analysts warned against concluding that health costs were no longer a serious national problem, and there seemed no likelihood that the Clinton Administration would act less urgently in drafting its plan for health-care overhaul, now due in mid-May.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chief economic adviser to President Clinton, said that while she was "edified" by the latest price results, the cost of health care was only one of the factors driving the effort for change.
She cited the intensity of health-care usage, which sometimes leads to unnecessary tests or procedures, and the need to expand insurance coverage to some 35 million people who now lack it. Dr. Tyson noted that those without insurance now resort to some of the most costly treatment, in hospital emergency rooms.
Still, the latest figures did seem to confirm that medical costs have been increasingly restrained for some time and that the attention given by the Clinton Administration has already had an effect.
Analysts said that while there was no way to quantify these forces, it was clear that the recession and the lagging job and income growth that followed had been a big factor.
"The medical sector is not immune to what goes on in the economy," Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said. "It's not as out of touch as many people seem to think."
More recently, there has been a move among drug companies to limit price increases to no more than the general rate of inflation, an effort intended to head off more drastic action by the Government. At the same time, there seems to have been no rush by companies to put price increases into effect quickly in advance of possible controls.
 
Drug and Doctor Fees Restrained

 
 Although figures for short periods are often suspect, it appears that much of the recent medical price restraint has been concentrated in prescription drugs and in the services of physicians.
Drug prices rose at a 4.4 percent pace in the first three months of the year, compared with 5.7 percent in 1992 and 9.4 percent in 1991. For doctors' fees, the first-quarter rate of increase was 3.9 percent, far below the 6.3 percent that prevailed last year.
The direction of costs for hospital and related services, by contrast, seems less clear. At an 8.6 percent annual rate of increase in the first quarter, these costs were rising only slightly slower than in 1992 and 1991, when they rose by 8.8 percent and 8.9 percent, respectively. But the first-quarter rate of increase represented an improvement from 1990's 11.3 percent jump.
Medical costs, which account for 7 percent of the Consumer Price Index, actually posted their biggest increases in the 1970's and early 1980's. Still, after the expiration of general price controls, they tended to be roughly in line with the general level of inflation.
For the past 10 years, though, medical inflation has averaged 7.2 percent, nearly double the 3.8 percent average for consumer prices as a whole.
For the latest 12 months, medical inflation ran at a 6 percent pace, with successive quarterly increases of 6.4, 6.0, 6.2 and 5.6 percent, today's report showed. March's rise of three-tenths of 1 percent was the lowest since a rise of two-tenths in March 1984.
Elsewhere in the Consumer Price Index, the major changes were in clothing and in transportation.
Apparel prices, which rose sharply during the first two months of the year, fell five-tenths of 1 percent, accounting for more than two-thirds of the deceleration from February's C.P.I. increase of three-tenths of 1 percent.
The rise in transportation eased to one-tenth of 1 percent from five-tenths of 1 percent on downturns for fuels and airline fares that outweighed a 1.3 percent jump in the price of used cars and a small rise for new cars.

HEADLINE: In New Jersey Campaign, It's the Consultants, Stupid

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 9

 BODY:
Ask Ed Rollins what the big issue in the New Jersey governor's race is and he will tell you without hesitation: "It's the economy, stupid."
Mr. Rollins, who managed Ronald Reagan's 1984 "Morning in America" campaign, knows a good line when he hears it, and he does not mind the sweeping bow in the direction of James Carville, whom, if all goes as Mr. Rollins plans, he will confront in the fall in a clash of consulting titans. 
 Mr. Carville, "the Ragin' Cajun," will be handling the re-election campaign of Gov. Jim Florio, and Mr. Rollins is in the corner of Christine Todd Whitman, who is both a leading candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor and a personal friend.
"Actually, Carville is more interesting than Florio," said Mr. Rollins, who, like the Governor, was an accomplished amateur boxer who cannot resist throwing a jab or two when the opportunity arises.
The prospect of having a front-row seat as two nationally known advisers exchange blows has tantalized those in New Jersey political circles, although both men are quick to offer metaphors designed to put their roles in perspective: "She runs the race; I'm just the jockey," says Mr. Rollins. "I'm the tail; he's the dog," says Mr. Carville.
The Governor is unopposed in the June 8 Democratic primary. To get a chance at him in the fall, Mrs. Whitman, with Mr. Rollins's help, must first get past the other major Republican candidates, former Attorney General Cary Edwards and former State Senator James H. Wallwork.
 
A Third Heavy Hitter
 Mr. Edwards's chief campaign consultant is Jay Smith, also a Washington-based consultant, who, while not so well known as Mr. Rollins and Mr. Carville, also has a solid record. Since 1976, his firm, Smith & Haroff, has won 82 of the 98 races it has handled, mostly for the House, Senate and governorships. One of Mr. Smith's better-known clients was John H. Sununu, the three-time governor of New Hampshire who went on to become George Bush's White House chief of staff.
Mr. Wallwork, beginning an energetic campaign as a conservative alternative to Mr. Edwards and Mrs. Whitman, has signed up a formidable political pollster and media consultant, Arthur Finkelstein of New York City, who has assisted scores of Republican candidates, most recently Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York in a tough race last year.
Nobody is giving away blueprints of their strategies, but some clues have emerged.
Mr. Carville, for example, tipped his hand a bit in a recent speech to a group of Democratic women in Washington that dealt primarily with President Clinton, for whom he is still working as a consultant.
"I look at my client, Governor Florio in New Jersey, as a great Democrat who stood up to and backed down the National Rifle Association," he said. "There is more backbone and courage in the Democratic Party than there has been in a long time, and we ought to reward that kind of courage."
 
Portrait Is Painted
 In an interview, Mr. Carville said he would like to portray Jim Florio as a man who did what was necessary without regard to special interests.
Discussing Mr. Florio's long-running fight with the National Rifle Association over assault weapons, he said: "I certainly think we should talk about the way the Governor stood up to the gun lobby and how the good guys won. But I don't think we are going to win just running against the N.R.A.
"The big issue is the Governor," he said, "what he has done, what he has done. Match him against his opponents and what they have done and what they want to do. It's going to be a tough election, but I signed on a year ago, and if we continue on the path we are on, we have got a good chance."
Mr. Carville is paying close attention to Mrs. Whitman and her wealth.
"Here is someone with wealth, a person of privilege," Mr. Carville said.
Like Mr. Clinton's first nominee for Attorney General, Zoe Baird, Mrs. Whitman ran into criticism for hiring a couple as domestic help and failing to pay their taxes. She subsequently paid the back taxes and fines. Mr. Edwards also admitted hiring a housekeeper and not paying her taxes until recently.
Mrs. Whitman has had further problems. Despite a net worth in excess of $1 million dollars, she gets a tax break on two family properties totaling some 300 acres because she and her family raise livestock for sale, allowing the properties to be classified as agricultural lands and reducing their taxable value by more than $5 million.
She was also accused of using workers from the Board of Public Utilities, of which she was president, to advise her on buying a satellite dish at one of the properties.
"She's like the comic-strip character Pigpen," Mr. Smith said in a telephone interview. "She walks down the street and gets dirty."
Mrs. Whitman has denied the allegation by Mr. Edwards regarding the satellite dish and termed it "desperation scorched-earth politics" on his part. Mr. Edwards trails her substantially in polls.
 
'Outsider' Is the Word
 For his part, Mr. Rollins seeks to hone Mrs. WHitman's image as a political outsider. Although she was born swaddled in political bunting, daughter of a Republican Party state chairman, Webster Todd, and once presented Dwight D. Eisenhower with a leather golf-tee bag she made at camp, she has held office only as a county freeholder and president of the utilities board, appointed by Gov. Thomas H. Kean.
She soared to political prominence in 1990 by coming within 1 percentage point of defeating Bill Bradley for the United States Senate.
Mr. Rollins agrees that she has "great instincts" for politics, but he said: "She is an outsider. What I want to say is that she is not part of the old-boy network of Trenton."
And what of Mr. Carville?
"He is one of the hottest political consultants in the country," said Mr. Rollins. "He has never failed to keep his thumb on the pulse; he understands blue-collar people and values.
"But now he is the Establishment; he now has to defend the record of an incumbent. Christie gets to be like Bill Clinton, attack the record."
In the presidential race, Mr. Rollins said, "Voters wanted an alternative to George Bush," just as a majority, according to polls, now wants an alternative to Mr. Florio. "George Bush couldn't convince the voters the second term would be different," and neither, Mr. Rollins believes, will Mr. Florio.
"The message will be very much like the Clinton message," he said. "The message is change." Mrs. Whitman will also emphasize job losses in New Jersey during the Florio years, he said, emphasizing the approach "The economy, stupid."
 
'Nasty Campaign' Is Expected
 But before she can directly take on Mr. Florio, Mrs. Whitman has to get by her Republican opponents in what Mr. Rollins predicts will be "a dirty, nasty campaign."
Noting that Mr. Edwards is trailing Mrs. Whitman in the polls, Mr. Rollins said, "He has no avenue except to go extremely negative." He said Mrs. Whitman will reply in kind only if attacked.
In radio commercials already being broadcast, Mrs. Whitman is emphasizing the positives with six spots laying out her program for economic renewal. Each one ends with the slogan, "Common sense, uncommon leadership."
As for Mr. Edwards, an early commercial, as predicted, assails Mrs. Whitman as soft on crime and out of touch with common folk. "Can you believe Christine Todd Whitman?" the commercial begins.
The commercial, produced by Mr. Smith, attempts to capitalize on a statement by Mrs. Whitman a week ago in response to Mr. Edwards's anti-crime proposals, which he has made a keystone of his campaign.
"It's all well and good that the former Attorney General wants to talk about an issue with which he's most comfortable, but the real issue is Jim Florio and taxes," she said.
"If he thinks we are going to sit by and let him distort her record without dealing with his own," Mr. Rollins said, "he should remember I can play hardball with the best of them."

HEADLINE: Dollar Lower in Japan; Holiday Slows Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell against major currencies in light trading yesterday, hitting a new low in Japan.
The American markets for Treasury securities, stocks, commodities and gold were closed for Good Friday; most European stock and precious metals markets were also closed. 
 The dollar finished slightly lower in quiet trading, pressured by the news that United States consumer prices rose just a tenth of a percent in March. Lower inflation suggests that interest rates will not rise, making the dollar less competitive than the high-yielding German mark.
 
Hostilities in Iraq
 New fighting involving American warplanes and Iraqi ground artillery in northern Iraq failed to encourage the usual buying of the dollar that occurs in times of global turmoil.
"If the Iraq crisis were to become protracted over the weekend, we could get a reaction in the foreign exchange market Monday, but not today," Richard Pontius of Standard Chartered Bank in Los Angeles said yesterday.
The dollar finished in New York at 1.6047 German marks, from 1.6075 on Thursday. The British pound settled at $1.5280, up from $1.5265 late on Thursday, and the dollar held steady against the yen in New York, ending at 113.12 yen, down slightly from 113.40 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday, included: 1.4760 Swiss francs, down from 1.4792; 5.4295 French francs, down from 5.4375; 1,568 Italian lire, down from 1,574, and Canadian 1.2571 dollars, unchanged.
Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates on Thursday, included: 1.6079 German marks, up from 1.6075; 1.4770 Swiss francs, down from 1.4795; 5.4410 French francs, up from 5.4370; 1.8050 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8063; 1,570.00 Italian lire, down from 1,571.50, and 1.2570 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2578.
 
New Low in Tokyo
 In Tokyo, the dollar ended at 113.15 Japanese yen, a new closing low, down from 113.65 at Thursday's close.
Speculators sold as they detected no signs of intervention by the Bank of Japan, which repeatedly acted earlier this week to slow the yen's surge. Traders eager to square their books ahead of the holiday accelerated the dollar's fall.
"Many people expected intervention, but as there was no sign of its appearance or even a rumor of it, some people took advantage to sell dollars," a dealer said.
Tokyo stocks closed slightly lower in seesaw trading, with prices depressed by profit taking and dealers' squaring their positions ahead of the Easter weekend.
The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 75.09 points, or nearly four-tenths of a percent, to 19,892.18, with an estimated 750 million shares traded.
Exchanges in Australia, Hong Kong and Singapore were closed for Good Friday. In Taiwan, stocks closed lower.
 
Gold and Oil
 Gold was quoted at a bid of $337.20 an ounce in late Tokyo trading on Friday, against $337 in New York late on Thursday.
Brent crude oil for May delivery was at $18.80 a barrel in afternoon trading in Asia, compared with $20.22 overnight in New York.

HEADLINE: Japan's Export-Import Bank To Invest in a U.S. Coal Port

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 9

 BODY:
A week before Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's scheduled visit to Washington, Japan's Export-Import Bank has announced that for the first time it is investing in a project in an industrialized country -- the United States.
The bank, which until now has devoted most of its resources to helping debt-laden developing countries, announced that it was investing $12 million in a new coal export terminal to replace the current one in the Port of Los Angeles. The deal is scheduled to be signed in Los Angeles on Monday. 
 The deal involves an equity investment, not a loan, and accounts for 10 percent of the total of $120 million being contributed by American and Japanese companies and the Port of Los Angeles. The project will involve building a terminal that will handle nine million tons of coal a year for export, much of it to Japan. When it is ready, the present one will be closed.
 
Pointed Symbolism
 Export-Import Bank officials made it clear that the unusual investment was for both economic and political purposes, which only underscored the pointed symbolism behind the announcement. The officials said that it was the bank's first equity investment and that it was not part of a regular program, but a one-time transaction.
"We think extra Japanese savings should be used for the welfare and the revitalization of the world economy," said Yuichi Ezawa, executive director of the bank. "We hope to continue this kind of cooperation with the United States and perhaps other developed countries later."
The announcement appears to have been part of the preparation for Mr. Miyazawa's visit to the United States late next week. President Clinton and Administration officials have been tough in their criticism of Japan's trade practices and its huge trade surpluses.
Mr. Miyazawa is planning a series of what it is hoped will be impressive economic announcements to counter those criticisms and to demonstrate that Japan is sincere about reducing the surpluses.
 
Public Works Spending
 As has been reported, the Prime Minister is expected to bring a new program of as much as $115 billion in public works spending to stimulate the Japanese economy, which should increase imports from America and reduce the surplus.
In addition, he will reportedly bring a five-year, $120 billion recycling plan to redistribute some of Japan's surpluses to developing countries as official loans and foreign aid. Included in that reportedly will be several billion dollars in low-cost loans to the United States to support some of the public works projects President Clinton has proposed.
The Los Angeles project appears to fall into this latter category. It benefits a city that is still recovering from race riots and should improve American exports to Japan, at least of coal.
The Export-Import Bank said that Japan had been trying to diversify its sources for coal away from Australia, currently the source of 70 percent of its coal imports.
 
Loans to States Contemplated
 This is not the first time the Export-Import Bank has been used to try to improve Japan's image in the United States, along with economic cooperation.
Three years ago, for instance, the bank contemplated offering the sort of loans it gives to developing countries to three poor American states -- Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi -- for projects like industrial parks. The deals never happened, however, in part because of political resistance in the United States.
The bank also began a program to make loans to American companies to improve their ability to export products to Japan. Only one loan, $250,000 to an electronics company in Tampa, Fla., was approved, however. Bank officials have said they hope to revitalize the program by easing the conditions for the loans.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A coal terminal at the Port of Los Angeles will be closed when a $120 million new one, built in part with a $12 million investment from Japan's Export-Import Bank, is ready. Tom Fresquez, a heavy-equipment operator, helped yesterday in preparing rail cars for an incoming shipment. (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times) (pg. 34)

HEADLINE: Law School at Columbia Weighs Aid Program Cut

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Nine years after starting a loan-assistance program to help steer lawyers to low-paying public-interest jobs, Columbia Law School officials are considering cutting it back, saying it may be too generous in fiscally troubled times.
The move is causing a stir on campus and among graduates who say they were counting on the program when they made a commitment to public-interest law. 
 The program would not only affect incoming and current students but also graduates who are working in public-interest jobs and face the prospect of less help in meeting huge debts they incurred to attend the law school.
"To be honest with you, I wouldn't have gone to a school that cost as much as Columbia if I had known they were going to do this," said Melinda Dutton, a 1992 graduate who earns $29,400 a year as a lawyer with the South Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation and borrowed $75,000 to help pay for law school tuition.
Columbia officials, who insist their program is still generous compared with similar ones at Yale, Harvard and New York University law schools, say the reduction in the loan-assistance program is only one measure they must impose to balance the budget next year.
The school, with an operating budget of $25.9 million this year, has already reduced health and pension benefits for faculty and administrators and it is considering a tuition increase next year.
 
Most-Opposed Change
 But it is the proposed change in the loan-assistance program that is causing the most anguish among students, who say their ability to attend the school is in peril, and others like them will be discouraged from taking jobs in low-paying public-service law.
A law degree from Columbia can leave a graduate with loans totaling more than $80,000. Under the assistance program, if a graduate's debt is billed at, say, $1,200 a month, he or she would pay only $175 of that amount, and the program would pay the rest. If the program is scaled back, the monthly amount the graduate would pay could double to $350.
Officials said that without any changes, the program would cost the law school $746,000 next year, about a third more than the cost of the program this year.
"The program cost is getting out of hand, out of control," said Edward J. Moroni, associate dean for finance at the law school. "The number of people taking advantage of the program is greater than we expected, and their debt is growing faster than we had expected."
When the program began, only a handful of students participated. Today, about 30 students a year sign up for the loan-assistance program, Mr. Moroni said. There are 190 people in the program now.
The dean of the law school faculty, Lance Liebman, is expected to make the final decision on the changes proposed by a committee he appointed to study the matter.
He said yesterday that students who had complained about the proposed changes had "made very good arguments, and I'm reviewing this in light of our financial situation, and I'll make a decision in the next few weeks."
Officials say they are committed to the program because they understand that without it, many students saddled with big debts after they graduate might not be able to afford going into public service. Tuition at the law school is now $18,522 a year, a 7 percent increase from the year before. But the officials say they believe the changes are fair.
"Adjustments of precise annual formulas by a few percentage points reflect harsh economic realities, not diminished commitment," Mr. Liebman wrote to one graduate concerned about the changes.
 
Problems at Other Schools
 Columbia is not the only law school that offers such incentives for students headed to public-service careers, and it is not the only school facing fiscal problems, said Carl C. Monk, executive director of the Association of American Law Schools in Washington.
He said that the number of law school graduates going into public service now is much lower than it was during the 1970's, and law school students in general are incurring larger debts to help finance the cost of their education. To help, about 30 law schools throughout the country, both private and public, have set up some sort of loan-assistance program.
Under the current program at Columbia, a graduate who borrowed $60,000 could receive abort $40,000 toward his or her school loans, paid out over 10 years, as long as the graduate stayed in public-service work, as defined by a committee at the school. The graduate would still write checks to the Federal agency or bank that lent the money, but twice a year the law school would reimburse the graduate for part of what he or she paid. The amount is based on a complicated formula tied to the graduate's income.
Under the new program, graduates would be reimbursed for all but an amount equal to 6 percent of their annual income during their first year in the job market. But under the current program, they are reimbursed for all but 3 percent.
For Melinda Dutton, the change would mean she would have to pay $150 a month, double what she now pays. Another graduate, Julie A. Caskey, said she never expected that the program would change.
"They told us, 'If you take out these loans, you will have this program to help you pay for these loans, and you don't have to worry about it,' " said Ms. Caskey, who is $80,000 in debt from law school and works for a small labor-law firm whose clients are mostly union members. "Now we've accepted these jobs and foregone other opportunities that were more lucrative, and we can't go back and remake these decisions, but the university says they can change their program any time they want."
Like Ms. Caskey, Ms. Dutton said she intended from the start to go into public service law, and she shopped around for a university that offered the best incentives to help people with goals like hers.
"I knew I wasn't going to be one of the people making $80,000 a year when I graduated," she said. "I was very serious about comparison shopping when looking at law schools."
Ms. Dutton said that if the proposal is approved, she and many other graduates will feel betrayed.
"It's really terrifying, is what it is," she said. "I think I was naive when I was looking at law school. I thought, 'These are large, well-respected institutions. If they tell me that's the way it is, then that's the way it is.' "

HEADLINE: Clinton to Ask Renewal Of Trade 'Fast Track'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
President Clinton will ask Congress to renew special authority to complete negotiations on a sweeping overhaul of the rules governing world trade, the White House announced today.
Trade talks among 108 countries are now in their seventh year but are snarled in a dispute with Europe over a phaseout of farm subsidies. 
 "The failure to complete the round has been a source of disappointment and frustration to the United States and many of our trading partners," said Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, in announcing the effort to get the talks moving again.
Under the legislation to be submitted, the talks would have to be wrapped up by Dec. 15, with Congress then given until April 15, 1994, to act on the completed agreement.
 
Authority Has Expired
 The previous "fast track" authority expired on March 2. "Fast track" means that Congress is given a deadline for considering trade agreements, and there would be limits on amending the agreements.
A similar fast-track procedure is in place for the free trade agreement planned by the United States, Mexico and Canada.
The global talks, under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, hold out the promise of creating as much as $200 billion in new global commerce a year.
But the talks, which began in Uruguay in 1986, have been deadlocked for the last three years, largely in a dispute between the United States and the 12-nation European Community, particularly France. Basically, the United States wants to eliminate more farm subsidies and to act more quickly than its European trading partners wish.
In Brussels, the European Community's Commissioner for External Economic Affairs, Sir Leon Brittan, called the move "excellent news for the Uruguay Round."
"The time allowed is sufficiently long for the remaining negotiations to take place, but sufficiently short for it to put the necessary pressure on all concerned," Sir Leon said in a statement.
 
Meeting Is Scheduled
 Sir Leon is expected to meet on April 19 with Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, in an effort to get the talks moving.
"A successful round would lower tariffs around the world and establish new multilateral rules for world trade," Ms. Myers said at a White House briefing.
"President Clinton and Ambassador Kantor have spoken with leaders from the E.C., Japan and other nations and emphasized our strong desire to complete an ambitious Uruguay Round this year," she said.
In November, the Bush Administration reached a tentative agreement with the European Community on easing farm subsidies. But France has threatened to veto that agreement.

HEADLINE: HOW THEY DO IT;
A Refinanced Mortgage: Long-Term Interest Savings Offset Short-Term Pain

 BODY:
Last winter, when interest rates fell below 8 percent, William and Gabriela Aynat of Milford, Conn., agreed it was time to refinance their mortgage. A $100,000 loan would cover the $91,000 balance on the original mortgage, and provide extra cash for home improvements. They found a bank offering a 15-year, fixed-rate loan at 7.75 percent, and set a date for an appraisal fo the house. The appraisal was a shock: The house was worth $21,000 less than the $121,000 the Aynats paid for it in 1986. Because their mortgage balance was now 90 percent of the market value of the house, the Aynats would need mortgage insurance, even for a loan of $90,000. And their new monthly payment of about $1,100, which includes mortgage insurance, would be nearly identical to their old one. Even so, the Aynats decided to refinance. Here's how the new loan will save them about $100,000 in the long run.

HEADLINE: Real Earnings Hold Steady

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
The average weekly earnings of United States workers, after adjusting for inflation, were essentially unchanged in March after falling four-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Labor Department said today.
The department originally reported that February real earnings fell two-tenths of 1 percent. The March change in real earnings was less than five-hundredths of 1 percent, it said, without giving a specific figure. 
 Average hourly earnings rose five-tenths of a percent in March, but that was offset by a drop of three-tenths of a percent in average weekly hours and an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in consumer prices for urban wage earners.
March real earnings were 1 percent lower than year-earlier levels, the department said.
In current dollars, weekly earnings of nonsupervisory private workers outside the farm sector averaged $370.44 last month, compared with $369.80 in February and $363.98 in March 1992.
In constant 1982 dollars, weekly earnings averaged $254.07 in March, compared with $254.16 in February and $257.23 in March 1992.

HEADLINE: Clinton Medical Plan Calls For 'Health Security' Cards

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
Under President Clinton's health plan, the Government would issue "health security cards" to all Americans certifying their right to medical care, Administration officials said today.
The card would be a tangible symbol of a person's enrollment in a new universal health insurance program, just as a Social Security card shows that a person has a lifetime account used to calculate Social Security benefits. 
 Three Administration officials involved in health policy, speaking on condition of anonymity at a White House briefing, began their effort to sell the President's plan by emphasizing what they believe will be its most popular features.
"Regardless of whether you lose your job, move, change your job or have a pre-existing medical condition, you'll keep that card," an official said. Insurance plans will have to take anyone presenting such a card, he said.
 
Concern Over Privacy
 The officials did not say how they would prevent fraudulent use of the cards or how they would protect the privacy of patients and their medical records. Members of Congress have expressed concern about such questions in the past.
The officials sought to dispel concern that Mr. Clinton wants to force everybody to join a health maintenance organization, or H.M.O. The officials insisted that people could choose their own doctors and continue customary arrangements under which patients pay a separate fee for each service.
An H.M.O., by contrast, provides a wide range of services in return for a fixed monthly premium. The premium does not vary with the amount of care.
In addition, the officials said, consumers will have access to some sort of "report card" evaluating the quality of care of various health plans. In this way, they said, people can learn how many complaints have been filed against a particular group of doctors and hospitals. The Administration officials reported on the work of the Task Force on National Health Care Reform, coordinated by Ira C. Magaziner, a senior adviser to President Clinton.
 
20 Taxes Considered
 The officials refused to say how Mr. Clinton would pay for his plan, estimated to cost $30 billion to $90 billion a year. One official said the White House was considering a list of 20 taxes and other ways of raising money.
"You name it, we've got it on the table," he said. When asked about the idea of a Federal sales tax, or value-added tax, another official said, "Nothing is off the table."
The officials abandoned the terminology they had been using to describe the President's plan. For months, officials had said that millions of consumers would band together in "health insurance purchasing cooperatives" to buy coverage. The purchasing groups will now be called "health alliances."
Likewise, Clinton Administration officials today scorned the term "managed competition," on the ground that it refers to an academic theory. Their scorn is remarkable because health policy analysts who popularized the term, like Walter A. Zelman, a California insurance official, are now working at the White House.
One White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, "You may call it managed competition, but we call it an American system that works for every state."
The officials also made these points:
*Under Mr. Clinton's plan, consumers would have a right to change health plans, probably once a year.
*Insurers could not reject consumers because of prior illness or other medical problems. Nor could they charge higher premiums to people who were sick. The Administration has not decided whether to allow companies to charge different rates for people of different ages.
*State officials would define the boundaries of each health insurance purchasing group. They would decide whether to have one such group or several in the state.
An Administration official said it would take "some number of years" to carry out Mr. Clinton's commitment to provide coverage for the 37 million Americans with no health insurance.
"This is a major change we're envisioning for one-seventh of the economy," the official said. "You can't turn that on a dime, even if you want to."
Dr. Mark R. Chassin, the New York State Health Commissioner, expressed impatience with the Administration.
"Managed competition poses some real risks that have not been adequately discussed, particularly with respect to quality," Dr. Chassin said today in an interview. "We have missed the coequal goal of health-care reform: assured quality to go along with universal access and affordable cost."
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, the Government would set a national limit on all health spending, public and private, as well as a health budget for each state. But Dr. Chassin said: "If you established a global budget for health-care expenditures in New York State, I wouldn't have any clue how to administer it. I don't think we have sufficient mechanisms. We have no control over spending for private physician services."
Clinton Administration officials confirmed that Medicaid, the Federal-state program for low-income people, would eventually end under the President's plan. Poor people would ultimately get private health insurance coverage through the same purchasing alliances as other people, with help from Government subsidies.
On Thursday, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said: "We expect to fold the Medicaid budget into health-care reform. So at the end of health-care reform, one should anticipate that there will not be something called Medicaid as such."
Governors have repeatedly complained that Congress was imposing costly new Medicaid requirements on the states. Noting such complaints, a Clinton Administration official said today, "The death of a program that people are unhappy with is to be applauded."

HEADLINE: LAW;
Patents and Copyrights: Do It Yourself and Save

BYLINE: By Laura Mansnerus

 BODY:
An economic crunch apparently makes people more defensive about protecting their property, including words, names and inventions. Patents, copyrights and trademarks, known collectively as intellectual property, have become a growing business for lawyers.
The work comes from corporations, kitchen-table inventors and entrepreneurs naming new businesses, and on the copyright side, from artists, developers of software programs and people who write just about anything. All aim to file applications with the United States Patent and Trademark Office or the Copyright Office. 
 But much of the work can be accomplished without a lawyer, said David Pressman, a San Francisco lawyer and author of "Patent It Yourself" (Nolo Press, 1992). The patent and copyright offices assist applicants, and self-help books can guide the motivated. At the least, consumers who do their homework can monitor their lawyers -- "no trivial consideration," in Mr. Pressman's view.
With plenty of business, the lawyers themselves sometimes urge clients to do much of the work -- which would cost at least $150 an hour.
"There's a lot you can do to help your attorney," said Eric Marzluf, a partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Caesar, Rivise, Bernstein, Cohen & Pokotilow.
Patents, which cover new products, manufacturing processes and designs, are the trickiest and costliest of intellectual property rights.
The patent office advises applicants to retain a lawyer. So does the Intellectual Property Owners Association, a lobbying organization in Washington. "The lawyer has tried to foresee knockoffs," said the group's executive director, Herbert C. Wamsley. "Also, patent and trademark office procedures are complicated."
But Mr. Pressman maintains that anyone who can write a detailed description and follow directions can complete an application, whether for a potato peeler or a genetically altered microorganism. As to whether to hire a lawyer, which he estimated would cost $3,000 to $6,000 for the simplest patent application. Mr. Pressman said, "It's a balance of money, competence and time."
Applications can also be handled by patent agents, nonlawyers with technical training who, like lawyers, must register with the Patent and Trademark Office.
Copyright registration is comparatively simple, requiring a short application and a $20 fee. Registration is not even necessary to establish a copyright, which is actually created the moment words are set to paper, but registration can make it easier to prove authorship in court.
A simple, single-author registration can be done without a lawyer, although most will handle it for a modest fee. Mr. Marzluf, for example, says his firm charges about $300.
One of Mr. Marzluf's artist clients, Frank Bender, sought legal help when several museums expressed interest in his model of a proposed memorial to Holocaust victims. In 30 years as a photographer and sculptor, he had never before considered registering a copyright. "But I wanted to make sure no one could take this one away from me," Mr. Bender said.
He filled out the application, wrote descriptions of the sculpture and gathered slides and photocopies. Mr. Marzluf reviewed the paperwork.
On the complexity scale, trademarks fall between patents and copyrights. As with a patent, registering a business name or logo requires a search for any that look similar; this can be done on computer data bases by the applicant, though a lawyer may do it more efficiently. As with a copyright, the application is simple.
Kate McGrath, author of "Trademark: How to Name a Business and Product" (Nolo Press, 1992), generally advises people to pursue their own applications unless and until they find a conflict with an existing trademark.
Lawyers' fees for a trademark begin at about $1,000, including the filing fee, Ms. McGrath said. For a patent or trademark search, an individual or small business can also go directly to the same services that law firms use. Some of them "can be a real deal," Ms. McGrath said, although they cannot give any legal advice.
Lawyer or no, she said, it pays to anticipate trademark conflicts. Compared with the cost of litigation, the initial expenditure looks cheap.

HEADLINE: Another Barely Balanced Budget

 BODY:
"New York State is on the way back," boasts Gov. Mario Cuomo in a confident commentary on the new state budget. But back to what? Negotiating in secret, he and the leaders of the Legislature patched together another year of precariously balanced books, but no long-term solution for the state's fiscal squeeze.
The new budget includes substantial pluses, notably a nudge in the right direction for urban school aid, a critical commitment to long-term planning for mass transit, and state funding to freeze New York City bus and subway fares at $1.25 for at least two years. 
 But the budget also relies too heavily on uncertain revenues, borrowed billions and yet another trick sale of state property; this time, the state will "sell" roads to the Thruway Authority.
The Governor and the Legislature might still be haggling were it not for a late calculation that tax collections will be $800 million higher than had been forecast. It was no stretch for the Governor and the Legislature to find ways to spend the extra money. But that just means they will face a tighter squeeze next year when the windfall doesn't repeat itself.
The only real boost in revenue this year will come from a 17-cent increase in the tax on a pack of cigarettes, making New York's tax the highest in the nation. That's a ten-strike for health, but little gain for fiscal prudence. Cigarette taxes, after their first year, yield less and less instead of the more and more that New York will need to wipe out its structural deficit.
Revenue from the sale of roads to the Thruway Authority just prolongs Albany's addiction to back-door financing. Unable to win voter approval for new state bond issues, the Governor and the Legislature have now authorized billions more in Thruway borrowing -- at higher interest rates than the state would pay. And on the very same weekend, they approved a proposal to ban such fiscal folderol forever, by constitutional amendment. They legislate with forked tongue.
New York State still has the worst credit rating of all 50 states. New York State's budget process is still the most secretive. New York State is on the way back, the Governor says. When?
