HEADLINE: South Korea Steps Forth

 BODY:
South Koreans have a lot more to think about this spring than North Korea's defiance of the world over nuclear inspections. Their own new President, Kim Young Sam, has set a stunning course of democratic reform that could, in the long run, prove far more significant than the shenanigans of the faltering Communist regime.
Mr. Kim, the first civilian democrat elected to Korea's presidency in more than 30 years, had a lifelong reputation as a moderate reformer. But in his first six weeks in office, he has moved boldly. He has brought talented newcomers into his Cabinet, forced corrupt politicians out of office with tough new financial disclosure rules and reaffirmed civilian political supremacy over the armed forces. 
 By American standards, Korea's present economic growth rate, in excess of 4 percent, looks healthy enough. But that's only half the pace of a few years ago, and Mr. Kim realistically aims much higher. The trick is to complete the transition from a low-wage economy with limited competition to a more open one with higher productivity.
Beyond the delicate problem of coaxing North Korea back into nuclear compliance, so far handled by Seoul with subtlety and skill, Mr. Kim faces the challenge of redefining Korea's place in an East Asia no longer shaped by the cold war and massive forward deployment of United States military forces.
Korea is ideally placed to become America's closest partner in this dynamic region. Its rapid economic development, and now equally rapid political strides, have made it one of modern Asia's greatest success stories. And unlike, say, Japan or China, South Korea has never given any nation cause to fear its regional ambitions.
Americans, who stood by South Korea through decades of cold war peril, can feel proud of their ally's growing success. Koreans can feel prouder still.

HEADLINE: The Versatile City That Film Makers Like to Film

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 9

 BODY:
To those who make movies, this city, like Hollywood itself, is a chameleon that can be Anywhere, U.S.A. For that matter, it can be Anywhere, period.
Film makers have found the physical landscape to be highly adaptable. The corner of Lansdowne and Dundas Streets, with a few camels, donkeys and sheep became an impressionistic Tangier in "Naked Lunch." The sprawling Kensington Market doubled as Teheran's souk in a potboiler called "Escape From Iran: The Canadian Caper." Other neighborhoods have posed as parts of London, Paris, Budapest and Beijing, as well as Chicago, Cleveland, Detroit and, of course, New York City. 
 The Brooklyn cheese store for which Cher did some of the accounts in "Moonstruck" is actually Il Centro del Fromaggio on St. Clair Avenue West. (The shop's owner, Francesco Celebre, says he's seen the movie "10 or 12 times.") In "Used People," the Manhattan street where Marcello Mastroianni and Shirley MacLaine were married is Toronto's Gerard Street. And in "Married to It," Casa Loma, the 98-room stone mansion built by an eccentric financier 80 years ago on a hilltop overlooking downtown, substitutes for Gracie Mansion, the New York mayoral residence. One of the bit actors is the former Mayor Edward I. Koch.
"This city is general enough to capture Cleveland easily, New York quite easily and a little bit of Chicago," said Alastair Reid, the British-born director of a new HBO film "Teamster Boss: The Jackie Presser Story," In it, Toronto stands in for all of those cities.
Toronto's mix of architectural styles as well as its ethnic diversity, its significant population of actors and a relatively untroubled union environment have all contributed to making it the third-ranking North American city in film production, behind Los Angeles and New York.
But the biggest advantage is a cheaper Canadian dollar. David Plant, Toronto's acting film liaison officer, said that at the present exchange rate, by which about 80 United States cents buys one Canadian dollar, it is about 30 percent cheaper to shoot here than in comparable locations in the United States.
Some American producers think that percentage may be on the high side. But there is no doubt that there are significant economies, not just from a favorable exchange rate but also from the reimbursement to foreign companies of indirect taxes like the federal Goods and Services Tax and the Ontario sales tax, which together add as much as 15 percent to the cost of just about everything.
John Kemeny, who produced "Teamster Boss: The Jackie Presser Story," estimated that shooting in Toronto rather than in the United States saved at least $200,000 in the $5 million movie.
American television companies also rely heavily on Toronto. Twenty-seven series did filming in Toronto last year. They include "Top Cops" (CBS), "Kung Fu" (Warner Brothers Television), "Secret Service" (NBC) and "Class of '96" (Fox Television). Mr. Plant said that the networks form partnerships with Toronto-based entrepreneurs, who obtain local financing and package deals in ways that yield tax advantages.
 
Millions to the Local Economy
 Last year was Toronto's best ever for film production. The city's Film Liaison Office issued permits for 88 productions that required 2,000 location shootings and pumped $ C305 million (about $244 million) into the city in performers' and technicians' pay, rental fees, hotel and restaurant charges and other revenue. The previous high was $ C289 million (about $231 million) in 1989.
Unlike New York, where so many Toronto-made films are set and which is still feeling the wounds of a bitter 1991 boycott by the major studios, this city offers compliant unions. In New York, relations between producers and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees have long been been prickly. In Toronto, Iatse is only one of three competing unions, each eager to make a deal.
"Like everyone else, we look at a basic contract and try to accommodate particular needs and deal with any obstacles," said Jamie Wood, the business agent of Iatse Local 873. "Sometimes problems come up that a contract couldn't have foreseen, so we look at the spirit of the original contract and do our best to come to a mutual agreement."
Even Sidney Lumet, a film maker who is identified with New York City as much as Woody Allen is, shot his most recent movie, a New York thriller called "Beyond Innocence," in Toronto last fall.
Competition is keen among cities, states and even countries for film productions, which pump billions of dollars into local economies. The Association of Film Commissions, the international professional association for government film offices, counts 275 members, representing major American cities, European countries and even the republics of the former Soviet Union.
To make certain it keeps pace, the Ontario government has just announced a $28.6 million subsidy for its film industry, and last summer Toronto opened an office in Hollywood. The city appointed a former movie public relations agent, Alison Emilio, to run it. Her job, said The Toronto Star, is "to schmooze, to go to all the right parties, meet all the right people."
Among the qualities that Ms. Emilio tries to sell to film producers are Toronto's talent pool (the city, says its publicity machine, has 10,000 actors and extensive technical support) and its multicultural character. According to one Unesco survey, Toronto is the most ethnically diverse city in the world. By one count, more than 140 languages are spoken here, and existing almost back to back are any number of ethnic neighborhoods, with names like Corso Italia, Ukrainian Bloorwest Village, Little Poland, Downtown Chinatown (the oldest of several Chinese neighborhoods in the greater Toronto area), Greektown and Koreatown.
Also helping make it one of the most photographed but unrecognized cities are its widely diverse architectural styles, which range from steel-and-glass skyscrapers to Victorian and Georgian homes, neo-Gothic churches, Greek Revival post offices, Beaux-Arts bank buildings and even a block of Italianate warehouses.
David Cronenberg, the Toronto-born director of "Naked Lunch," recently finished filming a movie version of "M. Butterfly." The movie, based on David Henry Hwang's play about a French diplomat who falls in love with a Chinese opera star, is an international story and was shot in various locations, including Beijing, Budapest, Paris -- and Toronto.
"I found I could intermix the shooting," Mr. Cronenberg said, "finding a little Budapest, some French and some Chinese things, all in Toronto."
For all the benefits derived from the film-production industry, there is an inevitably rueful edge to a city that must always pretend to be somewhere else. Toronto is still waiting to be the star of its own movie.

HEADLINE: May Justice Come to Overcut National Forests

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For more than 30 years the board feet of Federal timber cut each year has improvidently and illegally exceeded the amount grown. 
 In the Willamette National Forest in Oregon, the largest of the Federal forests, in the years 1990-92, timber cut was 18 percent greater than the timber sold. In that forest and other federally owned forests this has been the rule, not the exception, for years.
It's no wonder we have a "crisis" that requires that the Federal forests sell no more timber, except for ecological reasons, until the forests are restored to the sustained-yield basis long mandated by Federal statute.
Out here in the Pacific Northwest Federal forest managers in Region 6 (Oregon and Washington) permitted 10 percent more timber to be cut than was grown in 1952, a percentage that went up to 57 percent in 1987, 25 years later. No one seems to know what the accumulated debt is in board feet, but it has to be staggering.
That the Federal forest is required to grow every year an amount of board feet at least equal to what was cut was in effect long before the Multiple Use Sustained Yield Act of 1960 and before the Federal Land Management Act of 1976, which also required maintaining an even volume of board feet in our publicly owned forests.
Although the Renewable Resource Assessment Act charges the Secretary of Agriculture to prepare a report based on information supplied by the Forest Service and other Federal agencies and on present and anticipated uses of America's renewable resources of the forest, range and other associated lands, those reports, if they exist, are elusive.
The first such report was to be ready by Dec. 31, 1975, then updated in 1979 and each 10th year thereafter. As far as I can determine, the reports were never made or, if they were, they were filed and forgotten.
The problem is not in the laws, but rather in the consciences of Federal forest managers and Department of Justice attorneys.
They turned their backs on the gross overcutting of our Federal forests, a disgraceful state of affairs that President Clinton is remedying.
Now the Clinton Administration can identify and prosecute those responsible for this brazenly corrupt pandering to the politically savvy timber moguls, who on cue shed crocodile tears for unemployed loggers while they are castigating environmentalists for the Federal forest timber shortage that they themselves have caused.
 
CHARLES O. PORTER
Eugene, Ore., March 31, 1993
 
The writer represented Oregon's Fourth District in Congress, 1957-60.

HEADLINE: Representative Is Acquitted In Fraud and Bribery Case

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, April 9

 BODY:
A Federal District Court jury acquitted Representative Harold E. Ford of 18 fraud and conspiracy charges today, ending a long, racially charged legal process.
Mr. Ford, 47 years old, Tennessee's only black member of Congress and head of a powerful political dynasty, was acquitted by a jury of 11 whites and 1 black on charges of accepting bribes disguised as $1.5 million in loans. The trial had prompted fears a conviction could result in violence. The jury also returned not-guilty verdicts against Mr. Ford's two white co-defendants, Karl Schledwitz, 41, and Douglas Beaty, 44, who are both lawyers accused of helping to make the money look like legitimate loans. 
 Before the trail began, Mr. Ford bitterly protested the court's decision to select jurors from largely white and rural Jackson, Tenn., 80 miles east of here. A trial on the same charges ended in a hung jury in 1990 after jurors deadlocked along racial lines.
After the verdict was read, Mr. Ford rose and bowed toward the jurors and said, "I'd just like to thank the jurors very much." Later he called for an end to the racial tensions the trial intensified and again thanked the jurors for the verdict before heading out to a celebration.
 
Time of Healing Urged
 "I call upon all citizens of Memphis now to -- let's go through a process of healing in this city," he told supporters who packed his Congressional office. "We've had 10 years of division."
Judge Jerome Turner of Federal District Court, who rebuffed efforts by Mr. Ford and the Justice Department to throw out the jury and select a new one from the Memphis area, which is almost half black, delivered a stinging rebuke to some of Mr. Ford's supporters, who had threatened economic reprisals because of the trial.
"I was astounded at the willingness of some people to cripple this city and its economic welfare," he said from the bench after the jury returned its verdict. "Our justice system works. Black people and white people can judge each other fairly if just given a chance."
At his celebration, Mr. Ford fired back at the judge, accusing him of presiding over a biased trial. "I have no respect for Judge Turner," he said. "I may call him up and tell him that."
As recently as last weekend during activities commemorating the 25th anniversary of the assassination here of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Ford had likened Judge Turner to the late Mayor Henry Loeb, whose intransigence in a Memphis sanitation worker's strike had been a factor in the events that preceded Dr. King's death.
At a news conference this afternoon, Mayor Willie H. Herenton of Memphis confirmed that "extensive and comprehensive" security measures had been planned in the event of possible disturbances after the trial. "I am extremely elated that Congressman Ford and his co-defendants have been exonerated," he said. "This goes to show that justice can prevail." He is the city's first black mayor.
Jurors deliberated for 15 hours before reaching the verdict.
The trial turned largely on dry, complicated financial transactions that the prosecutor said constituted almost $1.5 million in political payoffs. The defense lawyers contended that they were loans Mr. Ford intended to pay off.
But the often technical and abstruse financial aspects of the case were overshadowed by emotionally charged legal, political and racial issues. Mr. Ford, a popular and powerful figure who served as a Representative from Memphis for 18 years, has said from the start of the 10-year-old case that the prosecution was the result of bias.
The selection of out-of-town jurors was mandated last year by the former presiding judge, Odell Horton, who declared the 1990 mistrial because of inflamed local publicity and the deadlocked jury. In his first trial, the jury selected in Memphis consisted of eight blacks and four whites.
The move by the Justice Department elicited criticism that it had injected politics into the legal system and prompted Ed Bryant, the United States Attorney for the western district of Tennessee, to quit in protest.
In the end, Federal Judge Jerome Turner ruled against Mr. Ford and the Justice Department, denying the motion to select a new jury, and criticized the Justice Department for caving in to political pressures.
In a decision that spoke to an issue raised more and more often throughout the country, the judge said a defendant does not have the right to be tried by jurors of his own race.
"If we are truly to become one nation, to be integrated in a society where the laws are color-blind and all men are equal under the law, then we cannot allow the demands of racially fixed juries to invade our jury system of random selection," he wrote. "It is a sad day, in my view, when the acting Attorney General and a representative of the White House give in to a demand that a jury of the United States must be selected by race."
Mr. Ford's supporters argued that moving the trial to Jackson County had the same effect, by guaranteeing an overwhelmingly white panel.
The key issue in the trial was whether the money Mr. Ford accepted from two Knoxville bankers, Jacob F. Butcher and C. H. Butcher Jr., from 1976 through 1982 were bogus loans.
In his closing argument on Tuesday, Dan Clancy, the chief prosecutor, asked the jurors to disregard personalities and stick to the facts. If they did, he said, common sense would tell them that Mr. Ford had received in payoffs disguised as loans from the Butchers.
William McDaniels, Mr. Ford's lead lawyer, asked the jurors for "a healing verdict for Memphis." And he said the testimony had demolished the prosecution's contention that the loans were payoffs for political favors.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Elegant Retailer Tries Delaying Extinction

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
"What about a museum?" a saleswoman in handbags suggests, gesturing inside the historic Art Deco-style I. Magnin department store on Wilshire Boulevard, which closed last month -- one of six to be shut by the bankrupt retailer R. H. Macy & Company by the end of the year. "Can't you see a brontosaurus here?" she asked.
Some retail industry executives think the metaphor is particularly apt for money-losing I. Magnin, the venerable, San Francisco-based retailer known for high-priced, sophisticated fashions and an elegant ambiance. 
 In what is considered a last-ditch effort to save the specialty chain, Macy and I. Magnin's new chairman, Joseph Cicio, are paring its size to 12 stores and trying to broaden its clientele by offering merchandise that reflects a West Coast style. Of the remaining stores, only one is outside California -- in Phoenix.
 
'A Name of Magic'
 Industry executives and analysts say debt-laden Macy had little choice but to stanch the hemorrhaging from I. Magnin, which has not turned a profit since it was acquired from Federated Department Stores in 1988 as part of the $1.1 billion takeover of Bullock's. But they are skeptical that the retailer's declining fortunes can be reversed while California remains in recession and unemployment stands above 9 percent.
"I. Magnin is a name of magic in California," said Kurt Barnard of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report. "Unfortunately, the magic name has lost its adherents. They must carve out a new customer base."
Macy, however, is giving Mr. Cicio only a year to turn an operating profit. If not, "then we have to make a tough decision," said Myron E. Ullman 3d, Macy's co-chairman. Analysts say the depressed market for retail properties, particularly these kinds of chains, has kept Macy from selling I. Magnin.
I. Magnin's cachet, which proved a measure of protection under previous owners, "isn't enough of a reason to run a business that doesn't work," Mr. Ullman said.
 
Once Had 31 Stores
 The plan to reorient I. Magnin, announced by Macy last month, will save the chain a reported $10 million by closing six stores. That would leave a chain with revenue of $275 million, down from a peak of 31 sites in five states in 1990 and revenue of $440 million.
And after decades of catering to affluent and older customers, those who can afford the $800 Valentino shirts, I. Magnin is trying to broaden its appeal with an advertising and remerchandising effort begun last month called "new attitude." It aims to draw a younger crowd by stocking contemporary designer sportswear priced under $500 for an ensemble.
"I'd always thought it projected too mature, an intimidating feeling of too expensive," said Mr. Cicio, who has been with Macy 16 years and is known for his merchandise displays and store design. "I want that perception to change."
The campaign's unlikely cornerstone is the Edge, which opened earlier last month after a $300,000 remodeling of the sixth floor at I. Magnin's Union Square flagship store in San Francisco. It features hip fashions from a dozen designers new to I. Magnin, like Claude Montana.
Instead of the hushed, aristocratic fine-apparel salons on the lower floors, the sixth floor has a nightclub's energy but the look of a boutique. The music is hip-hop. An espresso bar beckons. So do hand- painted jeans, recycled-paper stationery, natural cosmetics and platform shoes. A floor remake at the Beverly Hills branch is next.
 
Inconspicuous Consumption
 Larger competitors like Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue have grabbed market share by stocking a higher percentage of lower priced, private-label goods that appeal to career women.
I. Magnin was founded in 1876 by Mary Ann Magnin and named for her husband, Isaac. In 1944, it became part of Bullock's, which had its own high-end unit, Bullocks-Wilshire, and all were acquired by Federated in 1964. Macy's changed the three Bullocks-Wilshire stores to I. Magnin stores.
I. Magnin misspent its strength as an urban, fashion leader in poorly planned suburban and out-of-state sites. And its core customers, who still spend more on Chanel than on any other label, have begun a shift to more affordable stores.
"The market isn't supporting the extremes it used to," said Walter Levy, a retail consultant. "There's social pressure against conspicuous consumption."
Industrywide, Mr. Ullman said the specialty store segment remains viable, if sales average $300 a square foot. (Industry leader Nordstrom rings up $388 a square foot.) After the latest round of store closings, I. Magnin's sales per square foot will rise to $260 from $200.
 
Changing the Image

 
 Mr. Cicio, 47, was named chairman and chief executive in September after Rose Marie Bravo left to become president of Saks Fifth Avenue. Previously a senior vice president for fashion direction for Macy, Mr. Cicio moved fast to change I. Magnin's image.
Interiors are being brightened with fresh paint and more powerful lighting. Mr. Cicio would like to add more men's apparel, accessories and private labels. Arie L. Kopelman, president and chief operating officer of Chanel, is confident I. Magnin can woo contemporary customers without hurting its Chanel business. "It takes a real touch," he said. "It's a question of how to broaden it, without losing the luster on the high-end."
Yet Alan Millstein, publisher of Fashion Network Report, gave I. Magnin's repositioning little chance. "It's like trying to turn an ocean liner in a bathtub," he said. "They had attitude for years."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Power Unit Acts to Drop 2 A-Plants

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, April 9

 BODY:
The Washington Public Power Supply System said today that it would move to abandon two partly built nuclear plants on which it halted work 10 years ago rather than continue to spend $10.5 million a year on the paperwork needed to keep them alive.
The executive board of the power system has resolved "to investigate all the ramifications" of closing the two plants, an action that could occur by early 1994, said Carl M. Halvorson, chairman of the board. 
 He said the board had conveyed its intentions to Randall Hardy, administrator of the Bonneville Power Administration, the Federal power marketer that has guaranteed repayment of $4.6 billion in revenue bonds that were sold to finance the construction of the two plants, which were begun in the mid-1970's.
The $10.5 million a year needed to keep the plants alive is collected by Bonneville from more than 100 Pacific Northwest utility companies that have shares in the plants. The bottom-line payers of that cost are the utilities' customers.

 
No Power Produced
 One plant, Unit 1, is in Hanford, Wash., and is 75 percent completed; the other, Unit 3, in Satsop, Wash., is 65 percent finished. Neither has produced any power. The board will also study whether one of the units can be converted to a fossil-fuel plant.
Several utilities with shares in the plants have rebelled against paying for them. In March, the Snohomish County Public Utility District said it would not make further yearly payments of $1.8 million. And Clark Public Utilities said it would sue to force termination if the Washington Public Power Supply System boards did not act today.
The question of when to decommission the plants and restore their sites to farmland would have to be resolved. Costs could run to $150 million for each plant, but Unit 1 has only $100 million in cash remaining in a construction fund from the bond issue and Unit 3 has no cash. Unit 1 could sell its stored nuclear fuel, which was worth about $120 million five years ago but now is worth about $80 million because the price of uraminum has dropped.
 
Hydro Power Output Down
 Bonneville is trying to stave off a financial crisis of its own caused by a drought, which has reduced its hydroelectric output and power sales from Federal dams on the Columbia River.
Mr. Hardy said today that he was trying to hold a rate increase scheduled for Oct. 1 to below 20 percent -- a level that many industrial customers and utilities say would be a blow. He said Bonneville's reserves had plummeted by a quarter of a billion dollars in the last three months "and we've got to take extraordinary measures to deal with this."
Mr. Hardy said he believed the two unfinished nuclear plants were no longer cost competitive. If completed, at a cost of $3.4 billion, they would produce energy for 4 cents a kilowatt hour, he said, while power from gas-fired plants and cogeneration could be had for about 3 cents a kilowatt hour.
 
$2.25 Billion Default
 In the early 1980's, the power system had five nuclear power plants under construction. Only Unit 2 now operates commercially. In 1983, the agency defaulted on $2.25 billion in revenue bonds for Units 4 and 5 after it abandoned the two units, which were about 25 percent completed, because demand for power fell. It was the largest municipal bond default in the nation's history.
Construction on Units 1 and 3 was halted because further financing dried up.
Mr. Hardy does not expect a similar default on Units 1 and 3 because contracts among Bonneville, the power system and the utility participants are valid even if the plants are abandoned and never produce power.
He said he had promised Morgan Guaranty Trust of New York, the bond fund trustee for Unit 1, and the Seafirst Bank of Seattle, trustee for Unit 3, that he would ask the Federal courts to rule on the plan's validity before assets were sold. That will take about nine months.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Washington Public Power Supply System said yesterday that it would move to abandon two partly built nuclear plants. Unit 3, right, in Satsop, Wash., is one of the plants that might close as early as 1994. (Washington Public Power Supply System)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 11; Column 5; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 899 words

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Women: Swap 'Em Or Sell 'Em

BYLINE: By Caryn James

 BODY:
Mom always said that it's just as easy to fall in love with a rich man as a poor man. "Indecent Proposal" proves that it's easier. To reveal the film's premise gives away nothing important. Demi Moore and Woody Harrelson are Diana and David Murphy, a married couple passionately in love and seriously in debt, who go to Las Vegas to try to beat the odds. There, a billionaire named John Gage offers them a million dollars for one night with the wife.
It says everything about the film, though, that Gage is played by Robert Redford. Here is Diana torn between one of America's genuine sex symbols, looking better than he has in years, and the bar guy from "Cheers," whose movie character behaves like a dweeb. What would you do?
The first thing the Murphys do, proving they are true children of the 80's, is call in their lawyer (the superbly unctuous Oliver Platt) to draw up a contract. He provides the story's one touch of humor and goes to the heart of the film's complexity when he says, "For a million bucks I'd sleep with him. It's not like it's hard duty or anything. He's a great-looking guy." 
 Lines like this make "Indecent Proposal" the most adult and intriguing of the recent films in which women are objects to be bought, sold and used to pay off gambling debts. "Honeymoon in Vegas" and "Mad Dog and Glory" engage in verbal acrobatics and labyrinthine plot twists to justify this antediluvian attitude and get on with their comic stories.
The grown-up "Indecent Proposal" is front and center about the nexis of money, power and sex (which no one, let's face it, has ever figured out). When Diana says, "You can't to buy people," the megabucks businessman Gage replies with suave certainty: "That's a bit naive, Diana. I buy people all the time." You can argue with him, but you'll have a hard case to make.
The casting, as much as the script, determines how effectively the film toys with viewers' reactions and defies simple responses. No offense to Mr. Harrelson, but his David is likely to have viewers resisting the obvious sympathies the triangular affair is designed to evoke. When the Murphys' Faustian bargain breaks the marriage apart, Diana pines over her unemployed architect, a man who puts his sneakers on the kitchen table (meant to be an endearingly annoying habit). While the film is coaxing viewers to remember that David is Diana's one true love, he comes off like a self-pitying nerd.
Meanwhile, the handsome billionaire, though manipulative to a fault, is turning on the charm for her and revealing his sensitive side in a mansion on his estate. He hasn't simply bought her; he loves her, too. This is the point at which Mom gets to say, "I told you so."
Imagine how different the film would have been if an actor with typical leading-man looks and a more dynamic screen presence -- someone like Peter Gallagher -- had played David. The attractiveness factor would have been neutralized. The only issue left would have been money, and the film would have been infinitely less provocative. It is impossible to say whether the director, Adrian Lyne (Mr. "Fatal Attraction" himself), intended to make David quite so unappealing. Intentional or not, the trick works.
At first gage seems merely condescending; he makes his million-dollar offer to David when Diana is standing right there. But this approach turns out to be one of Gage's more masterly power plays, allowing him to drive a wedge between the couple, who must share responsibility for the decision. It allows Gage to tell Diana later, "If you were mine, I wouldn't share you with anyone." There is still the rankling sense that she is treated as her husband's property, but the choice and its consequences are evenly shared.
"Indecent Proposal" doesn't want viewers to be comfortable or complacent about this choice, though an easy conscience is precisely what the other women-as-object films aim for.
The recent "Honeymoon in Vegas" is a comic version of a similar story, with Sarah Jessica Parker agreeing to spend a platonic weekend with James Caan to pay off her fiance's $65,000 gambling debt. (The question of whether Demi Moore is worth that much more than Sarah Jessica Parker is a whole other story.) The film is so smart and funny that you would have to be humorless to take the deal seriously in this Vegas filled with Elvis impersonators.
"Mad Dog and Glory" has to work harder to justify itself and glides too easily past its disturbing premise. Uma Thurman labors to convince the audience that it was her idea to work off her brother's gambling debt by giving herself to Bill Murray. She's selfless but not too bright. In both these films, the woman's nominal choice is contrived to allow viewers to sigh with relief, sit back and enjoy the movie.
There is even a man gambled away in a poker game in "Benny and Joon," opening on Friday. It is significant that he is a weak man, barely able to care for himself but with a genius for impersonating silent screen comedians. This mime savant has none of the power society confers on men.
While other films dance around the issue of buying and bartering people, "Indecent Proposal" embraces it. It isn't aways a good film; it employs lazy voice-overs to express sappy sentiments about the Murphys' eternal love. But it turns an inflammatory plot into a surprisingly honest and entertaining movie.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Miami to L.A. On Amtrak

 BODY:
Last Sunday, Amtrak began operating the first regularly scheduled transcontinental train service in United States rail history. The Sunset Limited, which runs triweekly, traverses eight states (Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California) during its 68-hour, 3,066-mile trip between Miami and Los Angeles.
The bilevel coach cars have reclining seats and there is a sightseeing car with chairs facing large windows that curve up into the ceiling of the car's upper deck. A full-service dining car features china, white linen and regional meals from the Southern states. 
 In all, there are 52 stops, including Fort Lauderdale and Orlando, Fla.; Mobile, Ala.;, Biloxi, Miss.; New Orleans, Houston, and Tucson and Phoenix, Ariz. Round-trip coach fares start at $246. On May 28, the fares will start at $287. The All Aboard America Fare, which allows for three stops of variable length (as long as the trip is concluded within 45 days of departure) costs $259, round-trip coach. On May 28, that price will go up to $339. The additional charge for one-way sleeping accommodations, ranges from $284 for an economy bedroom that sleeps two to $533 for a deluxe two-person bedroom with private bathroom and shower, sofa and easy chair. Beginning May 1, the one-way bedroom rates will range from $346 to $650.
The train departs from Miami on Sunday, Tuesday and Friday at 1:30 P.M. Los Angeles departures are on Sunday, Tuesday and Friday at 10:50 P.M. For information and reservations, call (800) 872-7245.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Vacancies Add to Westchester Glut

BYLINE: By MARY VIZARD

 BODY:
A RECENT announcement by I.B.M. that it would vacate 845,000 square feet of office space in two Westchester County buildings has sent the already beleaguered office market in the county reeling.
For one thing, it caused this year's first-quarter office vacancy rate to shoot up 4 points, to 26.4 percent, from three months ago, according to Rostenberg Doern, a Stamford, Conn., brokerage firm that specializes in commercial real estate. 
 The hardest hit area is downtown White Plains, with a record vacancy rate of 35.8 percent, up from 28.9 percent at the end of last year, according to Rostenberg Doern.
This was caused, in large part, by I.B.M.'s decision to vacate 373,000 square feet in Westchester One, the largest building in White Plains, where the company leases 820,540 square feet. And the company is likely to continue reducing its office space, according to an I.B.M. spokesman, Ken Sayers.
"Our strategy is to gradually move out of leased space as contracts expire and into I.B.M.-owned space," Mr. Sayers said. "Regrettably, the company finds it also needs less company-owned space."
As a result, I.B.M. has placed one of its premiere properties on the market: The 472,639-square-foot, I. M. Pei-designed building at 2000 Purchase Street. Employees will begin vacating the building in May and move to company-owned headquarters in Armonk and to a company-owned property in White Plains.
"Just by shutting the building down we can cut our costs by 50 percent," Mr. Sayers said.
The property was designed as a single-tenant building and will probably be bought by a major corporation.
"It's a true corporate building," said John Rostenberg, a principal at Rostenberg Doern. "Architecturally, I think it's the finest building in Westchester. It will take time and effort, but it will sell."
The Purchase building is now one of three buildings on the market with over 250,000 square feet. "Unfortunately, there are also fewer companies looking for that much space," said Michael Siegel, executive director of the Westchester/Fairfield office of the Edward S. Gordon Company, a real-estate brokerage firm.
I.B.M. now leases over 2 million square feet of office space in Westchester and owns an additional 3.5 million, according to Mr. Sayers. At one time, it occupied as much as 7 million square feet, which it began vacating in the late 1980's.
"Most of the space growth took place in the 1970's and the early 80's," said Michael Dailey, executive director for Cushman & Wakefield, which is marketing vacant space in Westchester One. "The company provided the underpinning for the growth and prosperity of the county, so naturally the negative effect is going to be equally as noteworthy."
I.B.M. is not the county's only problem. In the past, Westchester had been an attractive location for expanding companies from New York City, but that no longer seems to be so.
"In part, it's the economy, in that companies are no longer looking for a place to expand," Mr. Dailey said. "And maybe the ones that wanted to go have already gone. And some may have decided there's an advantage to being in New York City."
MASTERCARD INTERNATIONAL was recently considering leaving Manhattan and moving to White Plains. But the company decided to stay put when the city offered it a $2 million tax incentive package.
In the last few years, Westchester has also lost companies to Connecticut, which has a variety of state incentive packages to help businesses expand or relocate.
Last year, the Purdue Frederick Company, an international pharmaceutical concern, announced plans to move its research and development division from Yonkers to a 156,000-square-foot building in Norwalk, Conn. Connecticut and Norwalk offered the company an incentive package worth more than $2 million, including $1 million in relocation costs.
In contrast, Westchester has no official incentive program. Yet it has developed a good record in retaining businesses.
Last year, 52 percent of all leasing activity was from intracounty relocations, according to the Gordon company. Some 33 percent was from company expansions in their current locations and the rest by companies from outside the county.
LAST year, when J.W.P., a multinational technology company based in Purchase, was offered $3 million to move to Connecticut, the county Office of Commerce and Economic Development contacted Alfred B. DelBello, former Lieutenant Governor and Westchester County Executive, who worked for a time as an unpaid "development czar" for the county.
When Mr. DelBello could find no state program that would induce the company to stay, he improvised a deal that involved a reduction in property taxes for an office building in Rye Brook and provided relocation assistance for the company's employees.
A similar deal was struck for TransAmerica Leasing Inc., which just signed a long-term lease for 120,000 square feet at a building owned by the Nestle Foods Corporation.
Some brokers are beginning to wonder if all the time and effort to keep companies would be better spent elsewhere.
Scott H. Benson, president of Benson Commercial Realty in Tarrytown, maintains that "continued lateral movement, which in most cases represents a decrease in gross absorption, continues to erode the marketplace."
He cites the case of TransAmerica, where the company's move from one building to another represented a total net absorption of less than 4,000 square feet.
At a recent talk before a group of real estate executives, Mr. DelBello called for an end to the "cannibalistic" regional competition for large companies. More effort should be expended, he said, in trying to attract and nurture small entrepreneurial companies that can grow in the county.
"Last year, 80 small companies moved into the county, and the same level should be reached this year," said Noreen Preston, an economic development specialist for the county.
As a result of the space glut, rents have been steadily decreasing, allowing small companies to expand in more prestigious locations. The Gordon company reports average rents at $19.61 a square foot, down from $20.21 three months ago.
TWO high-technology companies were recently able to relocate from tertiary to class A space. Securities Applications Inc., which develops computerized security systems, moved from Hawthorne to 4,000 square feet at the Summit of Westchester, in Mount Pleasant. And Reference Systems Inc., which provides integrated business, factory and office automation systems, left White Plains for 6,000 square feet at the Sutton Park Building, also in Mount Pleasant.
"We are witnessing an ever-increasing number of small to mid-size privately held firms taking advantage of the current soft market to upgrade their image," said Edward Stutz, director of commercial leasing for Benson Commercial Realty.
The vast majority of leasing deals in the county are for under 5,000 feet, said Mr. Siegel of the Gordon company, adding: "We're no longer seeing activity in large blocks of square footage."
To help companies grow, the county's development office ran a seminar for small business in January, offering technical assistance, financing and help with legal problems. "It was an incredible success," Ms. Preston said. "We had to turn people away."
Brokers are reporting other positive signs in the marketplace.
"Consolidations, like I.B.M.'s, are starting to abate," said Mr. Dailey of Cushman & Wakefield. "Lately there's been a groundswell of tenants asking for surveys so they can expand. I think we're going to see a turnaround. It might not happen soon. But the signs are out there that it will happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: I.B.M. seeks to sell 2000 Purchase Street building, above, and will vacate space in Westchester One office building in White Plains. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
Forest Protection vs. Property Rights

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
TWO years ago a developer took an option on the Birch Lane Restaurant in New Hartford and 130 acres of timberland off Route 44. He planned to build a mixed residential-commercial complex, but, said the owner, Kenneth Kohner, "the deal fell through because of the poor economy."
Today, still unable to sell the property, Mr. Kohner has begun to harvest the trees. He is one of many woodlot owners, foresters and loggers in the state who make part or all of their living from trees. In the next year or two they will be faced with controversial new state regulations aimed at protecting landowners from unscrupulous loggers, protecting forests from decimation and preserving wildlife habitats. 
 "Previous to 1972 the forests had been increasing," said Donald H. Smith, acting forester for the state's Department of Environmental Protection in Hartford, "but in 1985 when the department conducted its last survey, 29,000 acres had been lost since 1972, when there were 1.8 million acres of forest, or 59 percent of the state.
"There has been little change since 1985 because development slacked off, but as the economy improves and pressure for development rises again we will see more forests disappearing."
In fact, the state's Department of Housing reported its first increase in building permits in six years when the number of authorized units jumped in February of this year by 93.9 percent, or 797 units, over January's 411. The two-month total of 1,208 units is 41.8 percent ahead of the 852 units in the similar period last year.
One set of proposals drafted by the D.E.P. is expected to go to public hearing within the next two months. It would require for the first time that foresters be certified and loggers licensed. More than 500 individuals and 200 companies would be affected, plus out-of-staters working in Connecticut.
A second set of regulations to be proposed next year would require a harvesting plan to be submitted by a landowner before any trees are felled. The plan would state the time of harvesting, volume, size of trees, method of restoring disturbed terrain and impact on wetlands and watercourses. The plan would have to be approved before a harvesting permit was issued.
The regulations are to implement the Forest Practices Act passed by the General Assembly in 1991, giving the D.E.P. the power to regulate forestry in the state. After public hearings, the regulations will go to the legislature for passage. One member of the public -- Mr. Kohner -- called the regulations "another law to infringe on private property rights."
"You should be able to do what you want with your property," he said.
Dick Hayes, the logger working on the Kohner land, is familiar with such regulations from working in other states. "Regulations don't bother me," he said.
But Mel Harder, a forestry consultant, believes the Forest Practices Act is unnecessary and will hurt the industry.
"A hundred years ago Connecticut was 80 percent farmland and as the farms disappeared the woodlands grew," he said. "In some areas the brass and steel companies chopped wood for charcoal. They clearcut, and the woods came back. Our forests are not at risk and we are not even close to harvesting what we should."
Mr. Smith said: "If you make a living as a logger or forester it's in your best interest to get the most and best trees. And if you're a woodlot owner faced with putting braces on your kid's teeth, or college costs, motivation to cut is overwhelming.
"Many innocent landowners are taken advantage of by loggers who clearcut unneccessarily, and owners make poor decisions based on a forester's recommendation. It doesn't bode well for the future. The overall quality and vigor of the forests will decline and the resource will be unable to support the demand."
Mr. Harder estimated that almost 90 percent of Connecticut's forests of oak, maple, birch, hickory, ash and evergreens are in private hands. Lots can range in size from five to 500 acres.
Foresters select the trees to be cut. Maturity -- usually no less than 14 inches in diameter -- value, volume appropriate to the desired density and environmental impact on wetlands and waterways are the main factors. They mark the trees for cutting and collect a commission on the sale.
Loggers do the actual cutting -- but in the absence of regulations frequently do the selecting as well.
SUITS brought by landowners against overzealous loggers who cut too much, or trespassed and harvested trees illegally, led some towns to enact laws. More than 30 of Connecticut's 169 municipalities have regulations largely based on environmental concerns. Glastonbury, for example, last year prevented a resident from harvesting trees until winter, when the rattlesnakes, an endangered species, hibernate. "Once the Forest Practices Act gets rolling," said John Rook, Glastonbury's planning specialist, "we hope to see regulations regarding endangered species."
"The D.E.P. maintains a data base of the state's endangered plants, animals, birds and habitats that could be useful," said Leslie N. Corey Jr., director of the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy in Middletown. "Plans for cutting trees could be run through that office."
While there are no old-growth forests in Connecticut like those that shelter the spotted owl in the Northwest, bald eagles have been reintroduced through two decades of conservation efforts, almost all on private, densely wooded property that the birds need. A nesting pair in a Barkhamsted forest is the first in 42 years.
A cooperative effort by eight towns to preserve the natural beauty of the Connecticut River is called the Connecticut Gateway Commission. Under its 1973 state charter, no cutting or other disturbance may occur on 25,000 acres along both riverbanks without the commission's permission.
For the last three months, Joseph Willis, owner of Nationwide Timberland Management Corporation in Ellington, has been advertising in four rural newspapers, resulting in 10 logging jobs. "People who bought land at high prices three to five years ago want to sell the property or the timber," he said. He has bought three tracts totaling 145 acres, harvested them and resold them.
He feels he must continue to advertise for the often difficult backwoods jobs because, he said, "all the drive-by wood is gone."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dick Hayes, logger, at work in a private woodlot near New Hartford. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1603 words

HEADLINE: Fighting the Odds, and the F.C.C., He Got His FM Station

BYLINE: By ROBERT G. WOLETZ

DATELINE: DUMONT

 BODY:
FOR 20 years, Gerard Turro harbored a dream of starting a round-the-clock commercial FM radio station to serve Bergen County. Last month, operating from the second story of an aging brick and cinder block building here, his station, WJUX-FM, took to the airwaves.
Reality has tempered the dream somewhat. What Mr. Turro, a 38-year-old radio engineer, still lacks is a commercial station. WJUX cannot accept advertising, though Mr. Turro has not given up on that, either. 
 The station, with its 24-hour mix of crooners and big-band music along with Bergen County news, traffic and weather, now brackets the radio dial, broadcasting on 88.7 from Franklin Lakes and on 103.1 from Fort Lee.
Mr. Turro recalls stumbling upon the latter frequency in 1973. "I had been poking around the radio on the Craig eight-track in my car when I noticed an empty spot around 103 on the dial," he said.
That led him to read up on Federal Communications Commission license procedure. He learned that 103 was among those dial locations the agency had set aside as a buffer between station signals to prevent interference. The frequency was restricted to "translating" or repeating other existing FM stations in reception areas where their signals are weak. A license to operate a "repeater" station, Mr. Turro reasoned, might be the key that would unlock his dream.
In 1985, Mr. Turro, an Oradell resident who was by then a contract radio engineer for several stations in the New York area, applied for and was granted such a license. But converting it to a full-fledged radio station would not come without a fight.
 
Outmaneuvering Opponents
 For eight years Mr. Turro fought what often seemed a quixotic battle against the F.C.C. and the National Association of Broadcasters, among others. Blocked from converting his repeater station, he outmanuevered his opponents instead, obtaining with a personal investment he estimates at $100,000 what some observers think may be a small but potentially valuable piece of the nation's largest radio market.
Repeater stations may not broadcast original programming. But not long after he established his low-power FM repeater in Fort Lee, Mr. Turro petitioned the F.C.C. for the right to broadcast his own programming from the tower. His argument: no existing FM stations were meeting the information needs of a major part of Bergen County.
Alpine, in Bergen County, had been the site of the nation's first experimental FM radio station in 1939, a time when AM radio was America's dominant broadcast medium. But the F.C.C. has never granted Bergen its own full-time commercial FM-dial allocation; listeners rely on stations in New York and other New Jersey counties for their community news.
"Bergen County has never truly been served by the New York radio stations," said Assemblywoman Charlotte Vandervalk, Republican of Montvale, who had intervened with the F.C.C. on Mr. Turro's behalf.
 
News About Disasters
 "The only time they focus on county news is when there is a major disaster," she said. "Even then, they tend to report on the event long after its occurrence. Besides, with 840,000 residents spread over 70 communities, why shouldn't Bergen County have its own FM radio station?"
Bergen County's only commercial radio station, WWDJ, is a Hackensack AM station that plays primarily religious programming. On the FM band, WFDU, run by Fairleigh Dickenson University, and WRPR, operated by Ramapo College of New Jersey, are part-time educational stations.
There are some who contend that the service gap does not exist. Debbie Sheehan is the director of news and community affairs at WPAT-FM, which has opposed Mr. Turro's efforts. "While our signal covers four states," she said, "we do cover Bergen County news, weather and traffic. We even air a weekly show produced by Bergen Community College."
 
'Lost Dogs and All of That'
 Her station, which is based in Paterson, has a different mission from that of WJUX, she acknowledges. "As a noncommercial station," she said, "he can be much more local, looking for lost dogs and all of that."
A half-century after the original Alpine radio experiments, FM's superior sound has stolen the march from AM radio. With that shift, the price of acquiring an FM radio license in the New York metropolitan area has risen into the tens of millions of dollars. With licenses hard to come by, Mr. Turro reached back to his college days for a way to shoehorn a new station onto the crowded radio dial.
As a student at Montclair State College in the 1970's, Mr. Turro had learned that even a low-power FM station could cover a respectable distance if its tower were placed at a high enough spot. He began a tutorial in radio engineering under Lee Martin, who had been hired to build and run WMSC-FM, the college's low-power educational station.
Mr. Martin, 49 -- now WJUX's vice president, music director and "morning man" on the air -- said that "up until that point no one had realized the potential of low-power FM stations." Full-power commercial FM radio stations routinely operate with 5,000 to as much as 100,000 watts of transmission power. "But there we were with a college radio station that put out less than nine-tenths of a watt, and our signal could be heard in New York City," Mr. Martin said.
Mr. Turro received F.C.C. permission to increase the output of his transmission towers atop the Mediterranean Towers apartment complex in Fort Lee, from 4 watts to 35 watts, offsetting the expense of the expansion, in part, with the retransmission fees he received from a handful of commercial radio stations. Now he was ready to ask the Federal agency for permission to originate his own local programming.
The National Association of Broadcasters, a trade group, opposed Mr. Turro's petition on the basis that allowing the conversion of an FM repeater station represented unfair competition. Several stations in the New York, including WPAT, also opposed the petition. Concerned that Mr. Turro's request might produce an avalanche of similar proposals, the agency turned him down in 1987. The decision was affirmed by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
In 1991, Mr. Turro was an engineering consultant to WRRH, the educational station at 88.7 FM operated by Ramapo-Indian Hills Regional High School, when the school board decided to trim its budget and close the station. Mr. Turro offered to buy the 10-watt operation for $100,000 spread over 10 years. The board accepted.
 
Foundation Established
 Now, Mr. Turro was in a position to originate programming, under his WRRH license, and to increase that station's signal countywide from his tower in Fort Lee. But the Franklin Lakes educational license prevents WJUX from accepting commercial advertising. So he and Mr. Martin have established the Bergen County Community Broadcast Foundation, a nonprofit organization, to operate the station, which, Mr. Turro said, "is seeking sponsorships from area businesses, not unlike the enhanced underwriting grants solicited by public TV stations like Channel 13."
In addition, he said, "our educational license requires us to broadcast programming produced by educational institutions in the area."
David E. Schutz, a media analyst and vice president of Hoffman Schutz Media Capital, an investment banking concern in New York, offered this view of Mr. Turro and his business:
"On one hand, WJUX is a testament to Gerry Turro's perseverance. But ultimately the question is 'How valuable is this station that he has created?' Mr. Turro would like to believe that he has created a station that has the economic value of a traditional station. But because he is dramatically limited in the amount of time he can sell,the most optimistic revenue estimate that I have been able to come up with is something around three-quarters of a million dollars a year."
To which Mr. Turro replied, "I only hope he's right."
Still, the engineer won't allow his dream to be dismissed so easily. "I might again consider approaching the commission," he said, challenging the F.C.C. programming restrictions for FM repeaters once more.
As WJUX was gearing up for its start, word arrived that WNEW-AM, the longtime New York station where Mr. Turro's wife, Jeanne Starr, was a news announcer, was dropping its own big-band jazz format in favor of business news. WNEW's musical format and a number of its on-the-air personalities have since migrated to WQEW-AM, the New York Times station formerly known as WQXR-AM.
WJUX's reliance on nostalgic tunes from the 40's and 50's, Mr. Martin said, closely matches the tastes of a potentially large audience because Bergen County's population is older than that found elsewhere in the New York market.
 
Taste for Times Past
 In the studios here, Mr. Turro's own taste for times past, as well as his tenacious nature, is on display. The wall racks are lined with thousands of tape cartridges of 40's and 50's music he says he "rescued" from WNEW's garbage Dumpster. Framed WNEW promotional posters were also dredged from the garbage. The chromed 50's-vintage microphone, the worn 1970's control panel and a tan Formica console of the same radio era were all salvaged by Mr. Turro from the stations where he had worked. He had collected and stored the items at his home in the steadfast belief that he would ultimately get his way.
"On the day we went on the air," Mr. Turro said, "I told our listeners: 'Never give up on your dreams, no matter what people say or do. Because if you want it you will get it.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gerard Turro, at left, president of WJUX-FM in Dumont, with Lee Martin, right, vice president, in station's control room. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Phillip Beverly and Courtney Small

 BODY:
Courtney Lisa Small, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Small of New York, and Phillip Adrian Beverly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Beverly of Chicago, were married yesterday on Roosevelt Island in New York. The Rev. Dwight M. Jackson performed the Baptist ceremony at the Chapel of the Good Shepherd.
Mrs. Beverly, 27, teaches sociology and economics at Robert Morris College in Chicago. She graduated from Brown University and received a master's degree in social service administration from the University of Chicago. Her father is a supervisor in the New York City Family Preservation Program. Her mother, Shaila M. Small, is an assistant to the president of the Conceptual Communications Group, a New York company that produces corporate annual reports. 
 Mr. Beverly, 29, teaches political science at Chicago State University. He graduated from Arizona State University and received a master's degree in political science from Troy State University. His previous marriage ended in divorce. His mother, Arta Beverly, is a counselor at Carver High School in Chicago. His father is an administrator for the Department of Academic and Vocational Instructional Support of the Chicago Public Schools.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Stocks Are High, Even in the Face of Inflation

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
IF one measure of an investment is its ability to keep up with inflation, then the stock market has been brilliant over the past decade.
The accompanying chart shows the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, measured as a multiple of the consumer price index. When share prices rise exactly as much as inflation, that figure stays even. If inflation outstrips stock price gains, as happened in the late 1970's, the index plunges dramatically. 
 The consumer price index, measuring the cost of a basket of consumer goods, rose only 0.1 percent in March, while the S.& P. climbed 1.9 percent. So stock prices adjusted for inflation climbed to a new high, at 3.15 times the consumer price index. One way to look at that number is that it would have taken 3.15 baskets of consumer goods to buy a combination of the stocks in the S.& P. at the end of March. By contrast, back in 1982 the stocks were worth only 1.1 baskets of consumer goods. Over that period, stock prices rose almost three times as much as did inflation.

HEADLINE: What BMW Sees In South Carolina

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: SPARTANBURG, S.C.

 BODY:
GLEAMING black BMW 740 sedans, costing $60,000 each, glide up and down the broad boulevard that is this city's main street, their elegance a striking contrast to the crumbling buildings and vacant lots, once home to so many knitting mills.
The cars belong mostly to BMW executives, who are becoming more numerous by the week. They are here because BMW A.G., after scouring the world, has chosen a 900-acre stretch of red clay halfway between Spartanburg and Greenville to build a car assembly plant. The attraction: promises of an eager, technically trained work force, the proximity of both the port of Charleston and numerous automotive suppliers, tax incentives and a favorable climate. 
 The BMW plant, with its high-paying jobs and bountiful spinoff revenue for local business and government, represents hope to a diverse group of South Carolinians, from young students in technical colleges to state development officers. Moreover, it is a crowning flourish to the migration of manufacturers and automotive suppliers to the foothills along Interstate 85: It is the first car-assembly plant in the Carolinas.
It may not be the last. Many industrial development experts are convinced that Mercedes-Benz A.G. is leaning toward the nearby Charlotte, N.C., area. Mercedes said last Monday that within a few months it would select an American site at which to build a new model of a sport-utility vehicle.
Rumors also abound that Volkswagen A.G. is looking for an American site to make its Audi luxury cars. All three German auto makers have slipped badly in the United States market since the early 1980's, as the mark has climbed in value and the Japanese have introduced successful luxury imports like Acura, Lexus and Infiniti.
Conversely, the weak dollar, eager recruiters from regions like the Carolinas and generous tax incentives are turning the United States into an attractive manufacturing site and a base for export.
Whether the Carolinas evolve into an important German automotive production center -- in the way Ohio, Kentucky and Tennessee became a haven for Japanese transplants -- will depend largely on BMW's success in hiring, organizing and training an innovative work force that can produce high-quality luxury cars economically.
Labor unions, distressed that South Carolina is a right-to-work state, have accused BMW of exploiting America as though it were the third world. Company officials scoff at union predictions of a $10-an-hour wage -- about two-thirds the auto industry's average and only a bit above South Carolina's average manufacturing wage of $9.78 an hour. If only to remove an incentive to join the union, BMW's wage will be on par with the American auto industry's wage of $15 to $16 an hour, but its labor costs could be less than half what they are in Germany. Mercedes and Volkswagen would also enjoy big cost advantages over their plants in Germany.
BMW's plant will initially be smaller than conventional plants like the General Motors Corporation's Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., or the Toyota Motor Corporation's plant in Georgetown, Ky. With relatively high prices on its cars -- $30,000 and up -- and below-average capital costs, BMW expects to be profitable with initial annual production of only 60,000 cars, about a third the size of most American auto assembly lines.
But profitability will require a work force unlike that in most plants, and even better than those in Japanese plants.
"A lot of auto makers invest in technology, not in people. We're going back to the base line and investing in people," said Allen O. Kinzer, president of BMW's manufacturing plant here. He was the first American manager hired by the Honda Motor Company 15 years ago and is a former Honda senior vice president who helped supervise the Marysville, Ohio, operations.
Borrowing from Honda and others, BMW wants to enlarge on the concept of work teams, in which members can perform one another's jobs. Eventually BMW wants to authorize teams to operate quickly and independently, with little moment-to-moment supervision. If a model isn't selling well, the work force must be able to adapt quickly to building a different model.
Like the Japanese auto makers who located transplants in rural locations, BMW expects to benefit from the strong agrarian work ethic that still influences many workers in South Carolina. Susan E. Conway, who helped introduce "self-directed" work teams in five Sara Lee Corporation knitting mills in the South, has been hired as vice president for human resources. She will help recruit the workers and shape the teams.
"By the time we were finished, Sara Lee team members could literally board a plane and fly to California without permission," Ms. Conway recalled. She and others have been studying G.M.'s Saturn plant, where teams elect their own leaders, and Honda, where top management appoints leaders.
A distinctive touch, Mr. Kinzer said, is that the variety of tasks will demand more technical skills of every worker than at most car plants. "Our plant won't be highly automated," he said. "In a way, it is a return to the craft system," used early in the century when cars were built mostly by hand.
At the rate applications for jobs have been pouring into BMW's temporary offices in Spartanburg, the company expects 100,000 or more applications for the first 1,000 jobs, Mr. Kinzer said. Eventually the work force will swell to 2,000. So BMW can be selective. Mr. Kinzer said he wants workers who are highly motivated, independent and adaptable. Undoubtedly, BMW also hopes enthusiastic new hires will reject U.A.W. representation.
"The reason people here haven't joined unions is that they're an independent lot, who don't like anyone telling them where and when they'll work," said Bruce Yandle, a professor of economics and legal studies at Clemson University. He traces anti-union spirit to the yeoman farmers who left the fields for factories in the 1800's: "The history of people working to the rhythm of factories is long, and the relationship between mill owners and their workers is close."
That fits with BMW's plans. Instead of constantly repeating one or two 20-second tasks, a worker might perform several tasks, requiring several minutes. Low absenteeism is crucial, because a multi-skilled worker is difficult to replace.
The workers will also use fewer automated machines. For example, some workers will be trained as spot welders -- almost a forgotten skill at some assembly plants -- because BMW is not buying an automated body welder, which can cost several million dollars. Automated welding machinery must often must be scrapped when a new model is built, Mr. Kinzer said, and having a highly skilled work force will enable BMW to switch models more easily, quickly and cheaply. Eventually, he said, higher production and automation may come, but only after everyone becomes expert at building cars.
South Carolina's 16 technical colleges, which tailor their courses to manufacturers' requirements, were a strong attraction to BMW, said Jay Gogue, vice president of research for Clemson. After a manufacturer enumerates the skills it needs, the colleges buy tools and teach courses. Afterward, the manufacturer may hire as many or as few students as it needs, without obligation.
 
 
 
A TRICKY WALTZ WITH LABOR
 BMW wishes to avoid a bruising fight against organized labor. Organized labor, on the other hand, can ill afford to lose more members and prestige.
But when it comes to winning workers to the union, the Carolinas are not Detroit. Once known chiefly for carpets, cloth and garments, the region has been striving to live down a history of low-skill jobs, poor school systems and a consequent dearth of economic opportunity. Unions fared poorly in their bids to organize textile mills.
This bitter legacy was recalled only last week when Robert A. Georgine, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s building trades department, vilified BMW, accusing it of selecting South Carolina for its low wages, to take advantage of "American workers as if we were a third-world country." At a demonstration outside BMW's North American headquarters in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., Mr. Georgine demanded that the German automaker and the Fluor Corporation, which will build the 1.2 million square foot factory, hire only union contractors. Groundbreaking is scheduled within weeks, with completion by the fall of 1994. Likewise, the United Automobile Workers has vowed to organize BMW.
"I don't think the union is going to make too many friends down here by calling us a third-world country," said Ron Oakley, a vice president of Fluor, whose modern campus in Greenville bespeaks the economic renaissance of the New South.
Fluor announced it would give preference to construction subcontractors from South Carolina -- who happen to be mostly nonunion -- for the BMW project. Mr. Oakley said: "We do what our clients request.
Because unions have few members and little sympathy in South Carolina, labor relations experts agree that BMW and Fluor stand an excellent chance to keep the unions out, but no one is absolutely sure.
Daimler Benz A.G., Mercedes's parent, may be cautious in selecting a North Carolina site for its new sport-utility vehicle assembly plant because it lost a U.A.W. recognition election at a Freightliner truck plant in Mount Holly, N.C., in 1991.
On the other hand, the U.A.W. concluded it couldn't organize Honda's Marysville, Ohio, plant five years ago and canceled its recognition election. Allen O. Kinzer, president of BMW's new North American assembly plant, was working at Honda then.
