SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1609 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 4-9

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Attaching Numbers to the Clinton Economic Vision 

Here's the Clinton vision for America, now with dollar signs attached, as seen in the $1.52 trillion budget sent to Congress: a nation that needs more health care (Medicare and Medicaid spending up strongly) and is less military-minded (Pentagon spending way down), a nation that squanders less on farm-price supports and invests more in mass transit (with much of that new money going to New York and New Jersey). A nation that spends more on public works, education and retraining, and one that -- through tax credits -- lets fewer people slip into poverty. Who will pay the bill? Corporations and the wealthy will chip in more, anyone who uses any fuel will ante up, and some Social Security recipients will pay more taxes. The Administration is "trying to change the priorities for this country," said Leon Panetta, the budget director. And that change is given a good chance to become reality; as Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan put it, "We simply have to do it."
 
Jobs: Seeking Balance
 
President Clinton is learning that dealing with Congress is a balancing act, with compromise often needed. After his $19.5 billion jobs bill got mired by a Republican filibuster in the Senate, he finally admitted that he would have to trim back his stimulus proposal. The bill includes, among other things, $4 billion for extending unemployment benefits, $6 billion for public works, $2 billion for summer jobs and $2.5 billion for community development grants. (That last item has drawn special criticism from Republicans, who suspect pork-barrel projects.) But Mr. Clinton "is going to fight for as much of this program as he can get," George Stephanopoulos said. His first goal: to soften up a few key Republicans after the Senate gets back from its recess.
 
Tax Million-Plus Pay! (Maybe.)
 
It happens every time. A strong, simple campaign one-liner becomes a Presidential paragraph, littered with footnotes. Why, candidate Clinton asked, should taxpayers subsidize those multimillion-dollar corporate salaries? Let's cut off tax deductibility of such largess at an even million. Period. But President Clinton, a bit older and a lot wiser to Washington realities, has softened that considerably. Administration officials now say, well, they guess it's O.K. to deduct pay over $1 million -- as long as the compensation is tied to performance and as long as shareholders approve. (Commission income -- for, say, real estate sales -- is exempt.) There would be shareholder committees, compensation committees -- but in the end a lot of those people who have decided they really need $5 million a year to pay the bills will probably get it. Reason not the need.
 
Don't Bury the Airlines Yet
 
Just as mourners were gathered to bury the domestic airline industry, trumpets sounded a flurry of good news. The big surprise was a sharp jump in March traffic (which would have been even greater without the blizzard), coupled with word of strong bookings for coming months. After five bleak years, airline executives started whispering a bizarre idea: a profitable summer. On top of this, airlines did some serious whittling: United trimmed some plane orders, American dropped some flights from its San Jose hub and Delta abandoned its no-layoff policy. Investors were jolted awake, sending the S.&P. airline index to a 52-week high.
 
For Sale: 'Koresh's Last Stand'
 
General Custer clearly lived in the wrong era. If he'd been at Little Bighorn in the 1990's, he'd have battled the Sioux with one hand and clutched a cellular phone in the other, hawking his story to book agents. David Koresh is another matter. You'd think he had his hands full last week, weighing the fate of his Branch Davidian followers, bombarded with jarring music, nursing his wounds. But no. He must truly have heaven-sent powers, for with all that, he found time to get two New York lawyers to act as his literary agents. And for his story, they're talking millions. Multimillions.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
With This Check I Thee Wed
 
The generalities, the vague promises, are over. As Boris Yeltsin put it, his talks with Bill Clinton last weekend signaled "a shift from general assurances of support to Russia to pragmatic, specific, nitty-gritty projects." As the two Presidents kept tripping over each other in their vows of everlasting devotion, Mr. Clinton pledged a larger-than-expected $1.6 billion in aid. Central to that aid are credits to allow immediate grain exports and help for small businesses and a market economy. "We are with Russian reforms," Mr. Clinton vowed. "We are with Russian markets." Mr. Yeltsin's assessment: The aid deal "is going to make history."
 
One Space Station Is Plenty
 
One world, one space station -- it makes perfect sense. With the cold war over, why should both the United States and Russia spend the grocery money building rival outposts in space? Why indeed, the White House said last week, ordering NASA to work with the Russians to design a smaller, cheaper space station. The Administration had already ordered a cut of up to two-thirds in the $31 billion price tag, and this step could make such a cut possible. And, it seems, it's a win-win-win situation for President Clinton -- contractors are happy because the project's alive, Boris Yeltsin is happy to be aboard and budget-cutters are always glad for a few dollars.
 
Germany, Still Inflation-Shy
 
Ever since the catastrophic 1920's, Germany has been terrified of inflation -- and it's not about to let its guard down now. Inflation did rear up a bit after the Government borrowed heavily to finance reunification, and the Bundesbank put a stop to it by raising interest rates. And now, high as they are, the central bank is going to be awfully careful about relaxing them. Helmut Schlesinger, the Bundesbank president, reiterated this commitment last week, though he did say, "As we see maneuvering room opening up, we will use it" to lower rates gradually.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Leslie Fay Seeks Refuge
 
Even untroubled apparel makers live hand to mouth, buying materials on credit and paying it back when clothes are sold. So when trouble strikes, this delicate fabric unravels -- no credit, no clothes, nothing. After Leslie Fay was turned upside down by an accounting scandal in which losses had been called profits, it quickly became a lot harder to borrow money -- even though business was good and orders were strong. So last week, perhaps inevitably, Leslie Fay sought refuge in bankruptcy court to try to get the cycle going again. The company is expected to come out of the ordeal stronger, but probably smaller.
 
Westinghouse Sheds Its 'Junk'
 
The 60's may be back in style, but a lot of companies are still trying to put the 80's behind them. Westinghouse did its penance last week, selling most of the "junk real estate" its finance unit took on in those strange days.
 
Circuit City, Kick Those Tires
 
Selling used cars is a lot different from selling electronic gadgets. A VCR is a VCR. You know what it costs, and you know it's identical to its cousin in the next box. A used car is murkier. A fair price? Pick a number. Under that polished hood could lurk untold demons, waiting to do their worst a mile from the dealer's lot. But Circuit City saw its future last week, and it had a car lot in it. Startling Wall Street and just about everyone else, the home electronics giant said it would try out the used-car game. It may be onto something: As one analyst pointed out, when you're through kicking tires, they just may be able to sell you a car alarm or a cellular phone.
 
Filling Size-20 Shoes at G.M.
 
Try to imagine it: Corporate giants across the globe battle over an executive, treating him as if he were Henry Ford, the Messiah and Attila the Hun's smarter brother rolled into one. Then, when your company loses out, you -- gulp! -- get his job. "Tough act to follow" -- that doesn't begin to describe the pressure. Well somebody had to replace Ignacio Lopez, the near-mythic G.M. cost-cutter who abruptly drove off to Volkswagen recently. That somebody is G. Richard Wagoner, G.M.'s chief financial officer, who at the tender age of 40 will be charged with keeping up the Lopez cost-saving momentum. Don't worry: only the whole automotive world is watching.
 
He Tripled Life's Word Score
 
Can you imagine life without Lexiko? You probably can, until you discover that that's what Alfred Butts wanted to call the board game he invented during the Depression. Game makers weren't interested. But nearly two decades later, renamed Scrabble by a friend of Mr. Butts and given a mass market by Macy's, the game took its permanent place among life's fixtures. Mr. Butts got 3 cents in royalties for every set sold -- and there were nearly 100 million of them. But could that buy him a Q and a Z on a triple word score? Well, no -- his wife, Nina, usually beat him. Mr. Butts, having made this a more lettered world, died last week at 93.
 
Trouble for Surgical Stocks
 
As the nation waits to see how the Clinton team will rewrite the rules for health care, investors are taking no chances. Drug stocks have taken a beating, and last week two surgical stocks took their lumps. United States Surgical and Medtronic, the highest of high fliers in recent years, both hit 52-week lows. United States Surgical, which also forecast poor quarterly results, was hit the hardest. After trading well over $100 a year ago, the stock plummeted to $31.375.

HEADLINE: A New Rush Into Latin America

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
EVEN as much of the world dissolves into a single, faceless market, some things just won't happen. Dunkin' Donuts would not try to sell baguettes to Parisians. Benihana would not open hot-dog stands in the United States. Pepsico, surely, would not sell tacos to the Mexicans.
Think again on that last one. Pepsico, which owns the Taco Bell chain, saw the fattening wallets of Mexico's younger generation, splashed some extra hot sauce onto its tacos and headed across the border. 
 Call it Pepsi's Latin invasion. And it's not just tacos, and not just Mexico. Last month the company announced a $750 million, five-year assault in Mexico, including plans to buy interests in big bottlers, buy distribution routes and advertise heavily. The company is opening Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC franchises throughout Latin America, and selling Fritos, Ruffles and Doritos chips as far south as Tierra del Fuego. And it will soon announce that later this year it will spend tens of millions of dollars to sponsor Michael Jackson on an eight-city tour of Latin America.
"Latin America is our highest strategic priority and we do not see a more compelling investment opportunity anywhere in the world," said Ken Ross, chief spokesman for the corporation's international division. "We've had explosive growth in the region."
Pepsico has company. Led by the consumer-products, technology and service sectors, businesses in the United States, Japan and Europe have quadrupled their investments in Latin America in the past three years. Nearly $100 billion was invested in the region from 1990 through 1992, primarily in Mexico, Chile, Argentina, Venezuela and Brazil, up from $24 billion for the previous three years.
A few examples: Wal-Mart, Kmart, Sears, J. C. Penney, Price Club and other retailers have entered Mexico in the last year or stepped up operations there. Anheuser-Busch is buying a $477 million stake in Mexico's largest brewery. Ford has opened a modern axle factory in Argentina. Digital Equipment has teamed with Chile's largest software producer to sell its machines across Latin America. A small California disk-drive maker, Memotech, is moving its manufacturing operations to Chile.
NBC and Fox have announced plans for Latin American cable television networks. China's state-owned steel group has acquired Peru's state iron company. The NEC Corporation has entered a telecommunications joint venture with Argentina's largest industrial concern, Perez Companc. Mitsubishi has won a $150 million contract to build a power-generation plant for Chile's state copper company. And Hilton is building a luxury hotel in Punta del Este, the posh Uruguayan resort.
In addition, investors seeking profits in Latin America's volatile emerging stock markets have poured billions into the Buenos Aires, Santiago, Sao Paulo, Caracas and Mexico City stock exchanges.
 
A Surging Population
 The rush into Latin America is based on an idea that only a few years ago would have seemed unthinkable -- that this market of 470 million people from Mexico to Argentina (including the Caribbean) could be one of the more stable growth investments of the closing years of this century and beyond.
Some economists and government officials are arguing that now is the time for the United States to alter longstanding economic policies that favor Europe and Asia in favor of one that promotes closer ties in the Americas, arguing that Latin America's booming markets can be a critical source of economic strength to American business.
"If you are the new President of the United States and your top priority is restoring domestic economic growth, then Latin America is your best customer," said David Mulford, former Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs under Presidents Bush and Reagan and now vice chairman of First Boston. "It is returning to strength at a time when Europe and Japan are in recession, and you should be very much aware of the fact that Latin America is contributing to Main Street America, creating jobs and economic activity."
Indeed, since the region's collective nadir in 1989, most Latin American nations have significantly increased their growth and lowered their inflation rates. Only Brazil and Peru lack a healthy rate of growth, and only Brazil currently suffers hyperinflation, although several other countries have rates above 25 percent.
Mr. Mulford argues that Latin America has a number of other attractions. "We have a common historical religious and social heritage with Latin America, and it is now made up almost exclusively of democratic governments," he said. "They have much more sophisticated market economies than the new states of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. "It's a market of almost 600 million," he said, referring to an estimate for the population in 15 years. That would even put Europe in the shade.
He added that the United States already accounts for 57 percent of Latin American imports, compared with only 11 percent of Japan's and 22 percent of Europe's.
 
The Risks
 That is not to say that Latin America is not still a risky investment.
To keep investment dollars coming, many of its central banks have kept real interest rates high, a drag on growth. Much of the pent-up consumer demand from the 1980's was satiated in 1991 and 1992, dimming the outlook for this year. There is pressure on governments to devalue their currencies to make exports more competitive, but such devaluations would quickly lift inflation.
In December, the International Monetary Fund lowered its growth projections for the region, to 2 percent in 1993, from 3.9 percent. The main reasons were a continued recession in Brazil and slower than expected growth in Mexico and Argentina as high trade deficits robbed local industry of production and jobs.
And politics could change the picture for the worse. This is a year of presidential or other important elections in Chile, Bolivia, Mexico, Paraguay, Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela. The elections tend to put more pressure on governments to increase spending, which can lead to higher rates of inflation.
Moreover, memories of a troubled past are still fresh. The democratic regimes that now govern all Central and South American countries except French Guiana are still fragile -- susceptible to military coup attempts, as was seen last year in Venezuela, and leaders who seize extraordinary powers, as has Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori. Social unrest, the product of entrenched poverty and guerrilla and drug-trade violence, threatens the political order in Brazil, Colombia, Peru and Venezuela.
 
Remember the 1970's
 The recent surge in interest in Latin America is not the first.
In the 1970's, banks and international lending organizations lent hundreds of billions of dollars in the region, primarily to governments and state-owned businesses. But the money went to cover budget deficits and finance projects that became plagued by bureaucratic tangles, corruption and mismanagement. Foreign companies followed the lead of the lenders and set up shop in Latin America, but frequently encountered attempts at nationalization, high inflation and policies favoring local companies.
The investment climate here has changed radically since then. Now, much more of the lending is to privately owned local industrial groups for specific projects. And foreign investors are being much more cautious, often refusing to commit unless they can find prestigious local partners to share the risk.
The economic approaches recently embraced by most Latin governments -- emphasizing open markets, low inflation and balanced budgets -- have enabled them to strike agreements with commercial banks to reduce once-onerous debt levels. That has opened the door to the international markets and new borrowing both by companies and governments, reversing a history of defaulting on debt payments that left Latin America a pariah throughout the 1980's.
In 1991 and 1992, for example, Latin America raised an average of $12 billion each year in bond and stock offerings in the international markets, compared with an annual average of less than $1 billion throughout most of the 1980's.
Still, corporate managers say they are moving much more cautiously than in the past. William Rhodes, the Citicorp vice chairman who heads negotiations with countries over reorganizing their commercial bank debt, said the most important thing to businesses is the assurance that the new economic thinking will last.
Investors, he said, are waiting longer than they did in the 1970's before jumping in. "Corporate executives want to have the feeling that the continuity is there," he said, "that after two years of reform, the change is permanent, not a fleeting thing."
 
Five Favorites
 Economists and bankers generally agree that the most attractive Latin American countries for investment are these:
* Mexico, the top choice, because of proximity to the United States and the chance of a free-trade agreement with Washington, plus a huge domestic market and economic reforms.
* Chile, the second choice, with the fastest-growing and perhaps most open economy; the smallness of its market and distance from the United States are slight disadvantages.
* Argentina, third, because of the vast changes in the past two years in a country that was prone to hyperinflation and military government; but investors are worried about an overvalued peso and continued government corruption.
* Venezuela, fourth, with vast oil reserves and open markets; but two attempted coups against President Carlos Andres Perez have worried investors.
* Brazil, fifth, for its sheer size, industrial strength and natural resources; but 1,200 percent inflation and a lack of a coherent economic policy have investors essentially in a holding pattern.
The cautious new invasion of Latin America is not led by heavy industry, nor by the historical attraction of exploiting low-cost labor and abundant natural resources. Rather, it tends to be a tapping of parts of the local market that sorely need development.
Throughout Latin America there is an acute shortage of banking services, computerization, telecommunications, shopping centers, supermarkets, hotels, insurance and a host of other services. Thus, many of the corporate players are in consumer-products, technology and services.
"Most people think computer sales can only grow more or less at the rate of overall economic growth, but that is just wrong for less developed countries such as in Latin America," said Richard O. Martorana, president of I.B.M. in Argentina. "In these markets, the demand for such services often far exceeds growth."
 
The Move Into Chile
 Chile is a good example of heightened investment by consumer-product and technology companies. Pepsico late last year announced a $100 million investment program, buying the country's largest bottler and snack-food concerns, and opening KFC's and Pizza Huts in Santiago. In late 1991, Digital Equipment teamed up with Chile's largest software manufacturer, Sonda, adapting its hardware to accommodate Sonda software and marketing it in 14 Latin countries. It is now the largest Latin computer company.
Also, Sonda recently joined Memotech International of Milpitas, Calif., which found the costs of making hard disk drives prohibitive in California. Memotech now plans to start manufacturing in Chile in July, not only for the Latin American market but for Europe and the United States as well.
Foreign investment in mining, fishing, energy and other natural resources is also strong. In Chile, for example, the Phelps Dodge Corporation and the Sumitomo Mining and Metals Company announced last November a $1.5 billion mining project for copper and gold. And in Venezuela last month, the Exxon Corporation, the Mitsubishi Corporation and Royal Dutch Shell signed a $3 billion joint venture agreement with the state gas company to develop natural gas.
As for Pepsico, the attraction of Latin America seems obvious. "It's a very young population and a growing one," Mr. Ross said. "The markers are all favorable."
 
 
 
CHANGING THE PERSPECTIVE IN WASHINGTON
 BUENOS AIRES
IN Washington, it is generally acknowledged that United States policy toward Latin America has historically involved little more than worrying about containment of Communism and the promotion of democracy.
As a strategic economic market, Latin America has been hardly a blip on the political radar in Washington, with the exception of Mexico and the occasions when governments defaulted on debt payments in the 1980's, threatening the stability of the international banking system.
But if Latin America continues to show growth as it has in the past two years, to control inflation and to maintain stability, it may have to be considered in a different light.
Some are arguing that Washington should take a lead in this, if for no other reason than safeguarding the United States' own commercial interests.
Policy recommendations generally have two goals. One is to insure that the region, historically prone to protectionism, remains open to American business by keeping tariffs low and helping governments in modernizing their capital markets, banking systems and regulation of industry -- in effect, integrating them more into the world financial markets.
Don E. Newquist, chairman of the International Trade Commission, has recommended that the United States use the hope of bilateral free trade pacts as a prod. He has suggested that such an accord be signed with Chile even before the one with Mexico, arguing that it would send a signal to other Latin countries that democratic governments promoting open markets will be rewarded.
David Mulford, former Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and now vice chairman of First Boston, says the Clinton Administration should continue many of the programs begun under President Bush's Initiative for the Americas.
Among other things, these would create investment funds to help the development of small businesses, to study ways of reducing regulation and to institute changes in the judicial process to insure equal protection for foreign investors.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Labor's Return to Prominence

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
HERE'S one more sign that the Labor Department is working through the post-traumatic stress of its 12 years in the hands of Republicans. Early this month, Labor Secretary Robert Reich appointed a longtime union activist to run the Glass Ceiling Commission, a group devoted to figuring out why women and minorities seem to get stuck in the pipeline below the top tier of large corporations.
The lack of female C.E.O.'s has not heretofore been viewed as a critical labor issue, and Joyce Miller, a vice president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and president of the Coalition of Labor Union Women, can be expected to expand her constituency beyond those with their eyes on a corner office. Ms. Miller has been around the glass ceiling problems of the labor movement long enough to bring relevant experience to the job she will begin on May 3. 
 The Miller appointment represents in a small way a change in the attitude, most recently articulated by Lynn Martin, George Bush's last Labor Secretary, that the Labor Department ministers to a gorgeous mosaic of interests, one insignificant tile of which is organized labor. Robert Reich has restored a labor agenda -- if not in every detail the one labor itself wants -- to a central place in the department and has made several appointments from the labor movement. He has through sheer peripatetism moved Labor into a position of prominence it hasn't had in decades. Ms. Martin's high profile, especially between the Republican Convention and the election in November, derived mostly from the confidence of Bush campaign officials that she could be relied upon to use verbs when speaking.
When asked to enumerate her accomplishments, Ms. Martin invariably referred to the department's 1991 "Report on the Glass Ceiling Initiative" and "Pipelines of Progress," the update that followed in 1992. Both documents encouraged corporations to work toward "full and equal employment opportunity," and Ms. Martin frequently spoke out on the issue.
The glass ceiling commission, which she chaired, appears to have played a less than influential role in the Secretary's interest in the advancement of women and minorities. Since it was created by the Civil Rights Act of 1991, it has had one meeting and one field hearing. Ms. Miller, who is resigning from her various positions in the labor movement to take the Washington job, plans to begin by redefining the "glass ceiling." Miller says she told Secretary Reich, "I want to help people with their feet stuck in the mud." Ms. Miller said she would consider appointing a blue-collar advisory committee immediately, with other subcommittees in special problem areas -- the needs of minority women, for example -- to follow as necessary.
ROBERT REICH arrived at the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s winter meetings in Florida last February with ambiguous word of mouth. His sympathies were not well known, and he had rarely mentioned unions or the labor movement in his crusade -- already under way only a few weeks into the new An occasional roundup of labor news.
Administration -- for global competitiveness, increased productivity and well-paid work. Labor leaders were pleasantly amazed when he promised to appoint a commission to study labor law reform, a cause filibustered to death by Congressional Republicans in 1978 that had been universally regarded as unresurrectable -- until Mr. Reich slouched into Bal Harbour.
Mr. Reich, a man who frequently denies that he is a politician, has followed through on his promise. Late last month, he and Commerce Secretary Ron Brown announced the "formation of a panel to investigate methods to improve the productivity and global competitiveness of the American workplace." Mr. Reich still puts his fingernails to the chalkboard, as far as labor is concerned, by using such phrases as worker-management "cooperation." "Cooperation," in labor's view, is too close to "co-optation." The labor word of choice: "participation."
But if Mr. Reich doesn't always talk the talk, he seems to be walking the walk. Business, especially small business, must be wondering what price it will pay for the banging labor took during the 1980's. The Commission for the Future of Worker-Management Relations, as the reform panel is known at parties and mixers all over Washington, is composed of 10 of the cultural elite, many of them labor's usual suspects: John Dunlop, Ray Marshall and William Usery, former Labor Secretaries; Douglas Fraser, former president of the United Auto Workers; Juanita Kreps, Commerce Secretary in the Carter Administration; Richard Freeman, a Harvard economist; Thomas Kochan, an industrial relations expert from M.I.T.; Walter Gould 4th, a Stanford Law professor, Paula Voos, an economist at the University of Wisconsin. Only Paul Allaire, head of Xerox, comes from the corporate sector, and not from the rough-and-tumble environment of small and medium-sized businesses.
To labor, reform means at least loosening restrictions on organizing and more enforcement of existing laws. Business associations oppose as implacably as ever any changes that would give labor leverage and would like to unleash themselves from various regulatory agencies. The fight over reform may end up being a deja-vu-all-over-again scenario, with Senator Orrin Hatch, who led the filibuster in 1978, back up on the rostrum for another long haul.
 
 
JOBS, JOBS AND MORE JOBS
 ROBERT REICH'S -- and Bill Clinton's -- emphasis on jobs is evident in the budget announced last week. Mr. Reich has earmarked $10.9 billion over five years for employment and training programs. The highlights of the proposed fiscal year '94 budget: $657 million to help and retrain workers dislocated by military base closings or the North American Free Trade Agreement; $1.3 billion for a youth summer jobs program; $16 million for an apprentice program for the three-quarters of high school graduates who do not go on to college.
Mr. Reich used the unveiling on Wednesday to sound a warning: "This is a jobless recovery. We are not even at the level where we were before, or let's say nine months before the trough" of the recession.
Money for new programs will be squeezed out of other areas of the budget. Mr. Reich said he had already saved $95,000 by closing Labor's executive dining room.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Automotive Lighting: Leaving the Dark Ages Behind

BYLINE: By ERIC A. TAUB; Eric A. Taub is a Los Angeles-based freelance writer specializing in technology and author of "Taurus: The Making of the Car That Saved Ford."

 BODY:
ANYONE who has driven down a dark street and found it difficult to see, even though the car's headlights are on, can take heart.
Over the next several years, an entirely new type of automotive lighting will become commonplace, one that promises to light up the roads of America like never before. It's called high-intensity discharge, or HID lighting. 
 A HID lamp will produce up to two and one half times more light than today's low-beam headlamps, use less electricity, and last 10 times as long. HID is the centerpiece of several new lighting innovations that manufacturers including BMW, Ford and General Motors will introduce this decade, to meet an expected demand from an aging, less visually acute population for improved and more extensive lighting sources.
In terms of automotive lighting, America has historically been in the dark ages. The main reason is standards set by the Federal Government. For decades, tungsten sealed-beam headlamps were the only legal car lighting. The lamp -- with filament, reflector and lens permanently sealed -- came in only round, two- or four-lamp versions.
By the late 1970's, standard-sized rectangular units could also be fitted. In the mid-1980's the Government deregulated the lamps' shape. Consequently, today's car headlamps look significantly more modern than those that graced the boxy Chevrolet Impalas and Ford Fairmonts of 15 years ago, but they perform no better.
At the same time, European and Japanese manufacturers were selling cars in their own markets with brighter, multi-sized headlamps designed to go with the styling and dimensions of the vehicle. Despite the brightness, a sharply defined beam pattern reduced glare to oncoming drivers. Yet, when those cars were shipped to America, the bright lights were replaced by standard low-output tungsten units.
"U.S. headlamp specifications came about when lighting manufacturers took samples to empty airfields, shone them down the runway and then voted for which looked the best," said Barry Felrice, the associate administrator of rule making for the National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration. "There's been no scientific study to determine the ideal pattern of light that a car headlamp should throw."
"Lighting standards have a lot of room for improvement," agreed Tom Troy, BMW's product training manager in this country. "Ideal headlights would be brighter and shine more light to the sides of the road to improve peripheral vision."
Yet, faced with an increasing need to improve vehicles' aerodynamics to increase fuel economy and pressure from car designers to integrate lights better into the overall shape of the car, domestic manufacturers have concentrated on changing the shape of the headlight, not its capabilities.
In the mid-1980's, Ford's Lincoln division became the first Detroit distributor to offer cars that used non-sealed-beam lamps that sat flush with the body panels, allowing air to flow over rather than into the lamp, streamlining the air flow. But most headlights are still of the old-fashioned variety and do not even transmit as much light as the Government standards allow.
"WE'RE allowed by regulation to produce headlights that deliver 20,000 candelas on low and 75,000 on high beam," noted Walter Kosmatka, a General Electric lighting engineer, "but regular tungsten sealed beams put out only 8,000 to 10,000; with halogen, the output rises to 12,000 on low," or 60 percent of maximum. (Halogen light is whiter than tungsten, so drivers often perceive it to be brighter.) High beams perform somewhat better; two lamps typically produce 50,000 candelas per side, while a four-lamp setup delivers 70,000, close to the legal limit.
High-intensity discharge lighting, on the other hand, delivers the permissible 20,000 candelas of brightness on low; it consumes 40 percent less electric current and generates a correspondingly smaller amount of heat. As a result, HID headlamp units can be made narrower and thinner, increasing usable space in the engine compartment and allowing smoother sculpting of the front of the vehicle.
HID lighting has been used for years in sports arenas. For cars, engineers had to reduce the bulb size and dramatically speed up the time it took the unit to illuminate, to a split second from several minutes.
Here's how HID car lighting works: a quartz glass capsule filled with inert xenon gas receives a momentary high-intensity 10,000-volt charge from an electronic ballast incorporated in the unit, causing an arc to light between two electrodes. Once lit, the charge drops back to a constant 85 volts. To protect drivers and mechanics from electrical hazards, opening the headlamp unit or ballast deactivates the system.
The extremely bright light produces a white beam mimicking the sun's rays in color. Additionally, ultraviolet light emitted by the bulb helps illuminate reflectors in road signs and any neon coloring in pedestrians' clothing. Coupled with a projection-type lens that focuses the beam and reduces glare to oncoming vehicles, the light dramatically increases illumination to the side and directly in front of the vehicle.
"These lights are demonstrably brighter, and they'll last 10,000 hours, rather than the 1,000 typical of a halogen lamp. That's the life of the vehicle," said Gil Davenport, project manager at Buick's advanced concept group. "When I drive friends around -- who know nothing about cars -- in my special HID-lit Buick, they all want to know why my headlights are so good."
BMW is the only manufacturer to offer HID lamps at present. It charges a $900 premium for the system in Europe, but includes it in the $80,900 list price of its 1993 model 750 in the United States.
Ford will introduce HID lamps as an extra-cost option in the next few years. "Once we get the price down to $50 per vehicle, it will really take off," said Larry Kazanowski, Ford's director of vehicle exterior systems, for the plastic and trim products division. Mr. Davenport's group at G.M. has asked the company to include HID lighting in its 1997 Buick Park Avenue and Oldsmobile 98, "but now I think our HID program will be extremely accelerated," he said.
The major Japanese manufacturers, Honda, Nissan and Toyota, said they were investigating HID systems, but would not comment on whether or when they would introduce them.
HID lights are so intense that, in the foreseeable future, they could become one of just two sources of a vehicle's entire lighting. In a concept called a "light engine," developed and promoted by General Electric, fiber optics, in combination with high-intensity lighting, would be used to reduce dramatically the number of replaceable bulbs in a vehicle. A car equipped with a light engine would have about 10 bulbs, in contrast to the 80 now typically used.
FIBER optic cable would feed light to wherever it was needed: headlamps, stop and turn signals could be powered by HID lamps, while halogen or light-emitting diode (L.E.D.) bulbs would do the same for interior instruments. With only a thin fiber cable transmitting light to the front of a vehicle, the area devoted to the car's lighting system can become even smaller, presenting less of a challenge to designers.
Perhaps more important to drivers, lighting door handles and floor areas, for example, which has been impractical and expensive, would be feasible with fiber optic cable. That should prove a boon to the growing number of Americans making the transition from John Lennon-style glasses to bifocals.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A tiny arc lamp, right, may replace the halogen model, below, now in use. (General Electric); Mercury Cyclone, with a high-intensity discharge light bar. (Ford Motor Company)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 598 words

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
Form 1040? What's a Form 1040?

BYLINE: By ALAN SIEGEL and KENNETH MORRIS; Alan Siegel is chairman and chief executive, and Kenneth Morris is president, of Siegel & Gale, a company that simplifies government and business information. The Internal Revenue Service retained the firm to make tax forms easier to use but did not take its recommendations.

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON has proposed one of the most sweeping tax-reform programs in a decade, but most Americans don't really understand what he is talking about. This will become even clearer when taxpayers face up to the annual rite of filing returns for 1994, the first year that would be affected by any Clinton overhaul.
If his efforts to rally the nation behind his tax program are to succeed, the President must recognize that the country is suffering from a massive case of tax illiteracy that goes beyond the inherent complexity of the system and cuts across every economic and educational stratum. 
 Six in 10 Americans use someone else to prepare their Federal returns. Nearly 40 percent of those people turn to professional preparers because they believe it is too difficult or because they don't know how to complete a return. An additional 30 percent feel that professionals will save them money or protect them from making costly errors.
Research shows that more than half the population does not know the meaning of a progressive tax system -- in which the more you earn, the higher your tax rate -- even when given the correct answer in a multiple-choice question.
THE level of understanding drops even more with terms and concepts that taxpayers have to deal with in preparing returns.
Three in four do not understand that to be in the 28 percent bracket means that only the highest portion of a person's income is taxed at 28 percent. And only half know the difference between itemized and standard deductions -- items that must be understood to complete a return.
Compare key terms in the President's tax initiatives with the nation's tax understanding. The knowledge gap is striking. For example, nearly 8 people in 10 don't know that a tax credit, rather than a tax exemption or deduction, can reduce taxes the most. Eight of 10 also cannot define value-added taxes -- one remedy that has been proposed to help raise revenues.
Is it any surprise that Americans perceive so much inequity in the system -- especially when they understand so little about it and face such complexity in trying to comply with the rules?
To gain support for his program, the President needs to help people understand the tax system. But for true reform to occur, he must spearhead a program to simplify the tax system and make it accessible to all Americans.
Here's what the President should do:
* Make the tax system part of the educational curriculum and begin teaching in high school, or even earlier, how the system works.
* Create a "Tax Channel" on television, where people can learn tax basics and preparation.
* Set up an on-line Internal Revenue Service data base to give the growing number of taxpayers with personal computers instant access to learning materials and electronic forms.
* Simplify the tax forms. Make them easier on the eye by using more white space, fewer typefaces and frequent headings. Use plain English, more charts and examples, and instructions that teach with an easy-to-follow "how to" format. Be more informative and less adversarial in tone.
* Set a national goal of simplifying and streamlining the taxpaying process, and make it a continuing and visible part of the Administration's overall political agenda.
President Clinton is asking the nation to sacrifice for the future. Taxpayers need to understand how the system works, to have confidence that everyone shares the burden and to know they can pay their taxes without the help of experts. This would go a long way toward encouraging tax compliance rather than tax avoidance.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Style Desk

LENGTH: 2402 words

HEADLINE: Street of Dreams

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
THERE are many signs of revival along 125th Street, the heart of Harlem, and some of them are baffling. There is a former mugger ("That was my job," he says) who scoops sweet potato pie ice cream at Ben & Jerry's. And how to explain the 136 Italian tourists, stylish but unruly, singing phonetic English at a gospel brunch at the Cotton Club?
"Lemme hear you calling: Jesus!" Annie Sinclair, a Baptist minister, belted out on a recent Sunday afternoon. 
 "Jeeesus!" answered Giovanni Boromei, bald, 54, Roman and quite excited.
"Jesus!" Ms. Sinclair sang.
"Jeeesus!" Mr. Boromei sang back. He is the executive in charge of service operations for Rank Xerox Italy. "Very intense," he said afterward.
Ice cream and tourists are not new to 125th Street, which stretches from the Hudson River to the foot of the Triborough Bridge, through two miles of shops and street stands and decades of a rich history. This is, after all, the home of the Apollo Theater, the street that rejoiced over Joe Louis's victories, the place where Adam Clayton Powell Jr. conferred Harlem's blessing on John F. Kennedy. Riots have exploded here half a dozen times.
In many ways, this is ground zero for black America.
But after years of decline, a new vibrancy is mingling with the ghosts of a brilliant and stormy past: the boosters of 125th Street call it revitalization. For a dozen years now, they have pointed to new projects, high rents and low vacancy rates as proof that Harlem's splendor is returning.
Now, change seems tangible: Ben & Jerry's and the Body Shop have come to 125th Street as the most visible symbols. The ice-cream parlor is staffed by formerly homeless men, and the Body Shop has pledged to give all profits from its Harlem store back to the neighborhood. There are also local stores that sell fine African art and artifacts, expensive seafood, no-fat yogurt, $25 T-shirts and $100 figurines of African-American soldiers, grandmothers and other archetypes.
These high-end shops, though still few in number, have settled squarely if at times uneasily amid the usual confusion of street life. From boxes or folding tables some vendors sell generic street stuff: jeans, baseball caps, no-iron sheets, Tootsie Rolls and a vibrating mazelike game called Racing Car. And then there are other vendors, many from West Africa, who sell the products that make 125th Street the crossroads of black culture: kente cloth, black nationalist texts, fertility necklaces, dashikis, bean pies. You can buy Malcolm X potato chips on the street, just west of Malcolm X Boulevard, or Lenox Avenue.
"People do not come to 125th Street for Woolworth's or Foot Locker," said Khakira Hikmah, a 41-year-old vendor who sells crystals and incense. "They come for the cultural experience and the historical experience." (Ms. Hikmah is known on 125th Street as the lady who smokes cigars.)
Fueled by a decade of housing development, the average income in Harlem rose to $23,230 in 1990, up from $18,503 in 1980, census data show. Now 50,600 Harlem residents, out of a population of 475,000, have college degrees. Twelve years ago, the number was only 12,000. In short, Harlemites have more money to spend, and they seem to want to spend it where they live.
"People want the best," said Barbara Ann Teer, the founder of the National Black Theater. "They want to be prosperous. When a people display prosperity that means they are becoming whole."
Ms. Teer calls the street's change "a transformation or a reinvention," and she has played a large and somewhat unconventional role. A former Broadway actress who founded the theater for black productions in 1968, she watched unmoved as the theater's building on 125th Street and Fifth Avenue burned to the ground in 1983.
"People were crying, 'Oh, the National Black Theater is going,' " she said. "But I didn't feel sad, because I understood we could invent a whole new reality."
That phoenix was a $10 million arts and retail complex, built with government and private money, that serves as the anchor for the upgrading of East 125th Street, long the low-rent end of the street. The Body Shop opened there in November, and the complex also houses the Jubilee Christian Bookstore; the Uptown Comedy Club; the Gadabout restaurant; an art gallery; a mosque; a church, and a supermarket.
Ms. Teer also plans a fitting symbol for the roof: seven 15-foot statues of Nigerian gods will guard the perimeter, "as witness to our business corridor," she said.
"Our ancestors are watching us," she added. "They are going to see if we are going to get our acts together."
THERE are reminders everywhere just how far 125th Street has to go: three doors down from the complex, above a furniture store, there are six charred and boarded-up windows, a common site above the bustling street. The failure of the Freedom National Bank two years ago hacked into the street's psyche. The long recession has not helped.
Still, people are looking up these days. Five years ago, Celeste Fraser and her boss, now dead, decided to move their hair salon from the Upper West Side to 125th Street, between Fifth and Madison avenues. Despite her fears of violence, and the fact that the block had only five other businesses at the time, the salon, called Hair Nails and Things, has thrived.
Ms. Fraser, who now owns the salon, has noticed a distinct change along 125th Street.
"There is something on the avenue, and I guess you'd call it money," she said.
"One. One. One. I owe you one. One dollar. One peso. One. That's it." Rodney Love pounded the last two words into the shivering young man at the corner of 125th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard. The man had brought his six albums, his second load of the day, to Mr. Love's sidewalk music stand in front of the Optical Center.
Mr. Love proclaimed each record garbage, though many of the names in both batches looked promising: Diana Ross, Freda Payne, Parliament. "What have you been doing, eating these albums?" he demanded. The young man took the dollar.
But five minutes later, Mr. Love flagged down a customer, smiled his you're-so-special smile and pointed to the same stack. "Now these are the ones that just came in today," he said. "Let me show you."
Mr. Love's business philosophy is simple: "You prey on the ones who can be preyed on. I didn't learn that from me. I learned that from the white man."
One Hundred Twenty-Fifth Street has always been about commerce, but there has always been a battle over exactly who does the selling and where. On one level, the issue today centers on street vendors like Mr. Love, some of whom clog the streets and siphon business from stores.
But there is something deeper: only half the 500 or so stores along 125th Street are black-owned. So it is notable that much of the street's improvement over the last decade is a direct result of black merchants' selling items that relate directly to black American and African culture.
"It all is kind of blending together, but the dominant thing will always be the cultural piece," said Donald J. Coggsville, the president of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, a state-sponsored group. "That's what attracts the people."
The issue digs into Harlem's history: the area was settled originally by wealthy whites, and by the turn of the century, West 125th Street was the site of the Harlem Opera House, Hurdig & Seamon's Music Hall (later the Apollo Theater), movie theaters, restaurants and department stores.
In a tumult with national reverberations, black boycotters waged battles in the 1930's to integrate the sales staffs in department stores after Harlem became the center of the city's black life.
Blumstein's integrated first, in 1934, and its huge red sign stands to this day. Just a few stores down, Harlem's first race riot erupted in March 1935 when Lino Rivera, 16, was accused of stealing a 10-cent penknife from the white-owned Kress Five and Ten. Three people died.
A second riot erupted in August 1943, amid rumors that a white policeman had shot a black soldier. Sidney Poitier, Roy Wilkins and James Baldwin, on his way to bury his father, were all on 125th Street that day, as recounted in "King of the Cats: The Life and Times of Adam Clayton Powell Jr." (Houghton Mifflin, 1993).
"It seemed to me that God himself had devised, to mark my father's end, the most sustained and brutally dissonant of codas," Baldwin wrote.
More protest, peaceful and not, punctuated the 60's, as the street slid into decline. By the late 70's, two out of every five stores were vacant, and many of those that remained open were owned by Koreans.
Life is different today.
"It's such a hustle, hustle, a lot of hustle," said Inez Kennedy, a 49-year-old nurse standing at the site of the 1935 riot, now an Everyone's Drug, at 256 West 125th Street. "You have to be fast. When you look around you, you ask, 'Is this 125th Street?' It's the new 125th Street. It's the new fast breed."
People on 125th Street see its recent renewal as a cultural continuum, though a renewal that has not neared the potential -- perhaps unreachable -- that many along the street dream of. A dozen years ago, the street began its new spark with a project, still planned but not yet built, for a a $160 million International Trade Center: its focus is investment and trade in Africa.
During the 1980's, the Apollo Theater underwent a $20 million renovation, headed by Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President. Now a nonprofit foundation, the Apollo is redefining itself, as it tries to attract top names in black entertainment and also to fight off its long history of financial trouble.
"What do I think of them?" Mr. Sutton grumbled when asked about Ice Cube, Kool G Rap and D.J. Polo playing in the same Apollo he fell in love with during World War II. "They are all part of the culture."
Next door to the Everyone's Drug is Mart 125, a bazaar of black merchants who sell everything from goat curry to Malcolm X tapes to African jewelry. The mart, now in its fifth year, is a success, often called the incubator for business on 125th Street because a handful of shops have moved from the mart into regular storefronts.
Jean Jackson, 48, has noticed broad improvement in her five years as a vendor at Mart 125. She sells clothing she sews herself from African cloth, everything from shirts to suspenders to bright hats.
"There has been an awakening here because people feel the freedom to wear pieces of their culture," she said, as she put the final touches on a deep blue and gold cummerbund and bow tie in her stall.
And still within the tradition are the scores of street vendors, some American blacks but many West Africans, who congregate in colorful quadrants, especially at the corner of Malcolm X Boulevard.
Ligar Ahmed, a vendor from Mali, said in French (he speaks little English) that everything he sold was from Africa except his medallions and cheap silver pieces shaped like the African continent.
"I get those from the Koreans downtown," Mr. Ahmed said. "We don't make things like that where I am from."
Some vendors make good money: Ray A. Wirt said he now earns more selling framed photos of people like Miles Davis and Martin Luther King Jr. than he did as an architect downtown. But Mr. Ahmed said that street life was unpredictable and often a hardship because he sends much of his earnings to his mother and two wives in Mali.
"Some days I make $50, sometimes I go home with not one dollar," he said. "It is up and down, very so-so. Who knows how much I will make each day? Only God."
The woman could not keep her hands off the glycerin soaps, the bath beads, the cute bottles of bubbly blue goop. What, she wondered in the sweet-smelling Body Shop, would rid her of the bumps that sprouted just above her brow?
"Do you use anything for the dead skin on your face?" asked John Boyd, the store's 25-year-old assistant manager. "Have you had any kind of change in your diet?"
"I've been eating more," the woman said absently, as she picked up yet another bottle. "Is this a bubble bath?"
It was in fact nonfoaming bath oil, a brackish green. Mr. Boyd, endlessly patient with fussy customers, said the Body Shop had already turned a small profit.
To many Harlem residents, the presence of the Body Shop and Ben & Jerry's is a sort of symbolic triumph. Not only have these major upscale chains come to Harlem, but Harlemites are buying.
"There are a lot of people shopping in this store who had shopped for years in Body Shops downtown," Mr. Boyd said. "I mean, it's about time."
Joseph H. Holland, 36, a Harvard Law School graduate, said people were skeptical when he decided to open a Ben & Jerry's franchise in Harlem. It is not wildly successful yet (he got a late start last summer), but he is optimistic.
"The feeling was these upscale shops are too pricey for 125th Street," he said. "That's just not true."
Like the Body Shop, Ben & Jerry's has come with a corporate philosophy that suits an area ravaged over the years by poverty and drugs. The ice-cream parlor is staffed by men from Harkhomes, a shelter and rehabilitation program Mr. Holland founded. There are scores of other projects planned, including Caldor and Pathmark, and community leaders hope that they will follow the same pattern of helping and hiring.
The idea of communal improvement along 125th Street seems tied to a notion of individual betterment. For years, Roberto Harden, 43, was a heroin addict who had a dozen assault and robbery convictions. Now, as the manager of Ben & Jerry's, he directs a staff of a dozen men, all learning new skills that have nothing to do with crime and drugs. Some cannot take the discipline. Others do well. Mr. Harden mentioned one constant frustration:
"They want to give out mounds of ice cream," he said. "They don't understand this is a business. They want to be too nice."
And though the parlor is decorated with the chain's usual emblem of cows grazing on a deep green field, it has touches of Harlem beyond its employees: it was renovated to look like an Harlem ice-cream parlor of the 1940's. And April's flavor of the month was concocted, in part, by Mr. Holland: Harlem Blues Berries, a mix of rasberry ice cream, blueberries and strawberries, is being served at the 92 Ben & Jerry's around the nation.
It's the flavor from here to San Diego to Maine.

HEADLINE: In Health Care Too, Price Controls Don't Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Clinton and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York should be informed that price controls on health care or anything else do not work. I know firsthand. In 1972 and 1973, during Richard M. Nixon Presidency, I was involved in developing price controls for the Cost of Living Council, the agency set up to control all prices. 
 The only positive thing to come out of the Nixon policies was to educate the nation that price controls are ineffective and actually exacerbate economic imbalances. They are a waste of time and taxpayer money. It appears these memories have dimmed.
Price controls don't work because:
* Black markets develop.
* The supply of goods and services is reduced.
* Government bureaucracy, regulation and "red tape" multiply to enforce controls. And no bureaucrat knows as much as the market knows.
* Market inefficiencies will be created as health care providers spend more time coping with regulations than serving the public.
I watched these inevitable effects take place in the 70's. Let's not make the same mistakes in the 90's.
The best way to set prices now, as it was then, is to let the market operate with the establishment of an equilibrium among many sellers and many buyers.
 
WILLIAM C. CROOKS
Greenwich, Conn., April 1, 1993

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Taking on Iran and Iraq, but Separately

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE way the Clinton Administration sees it, if Iran's President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, were to take off his turban and his clerical robe, put on a uniform and grow a fuller, darker mustache, he might look a lot like Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein.
It is not that the new Administration cannot recognize the difference between the two leaders or the two countries. Mr. Hussein, a secular, totalitarian Arab leader, came to power by force and continues to rely on force to achieve his goals. Mr. Rafsanjani, an Islamic clergyman whose family runs the largest pistachio empire in Iran, was popularly elected -- albeit in a less than pristinely democratic contest -- and is running for re-election next month. Iraq runs on its terror; Iran runs despite its increasing anarchy. 
 Rather, the Clinton Administration views both leaders as dangerous men in charge of dangerous countries that do things that are inimical to American interests. Iran's baffling recent purchase of oil from its arch-enemy Iraq in violation of United Nations sanctions and Iraq's anti-aircraft fire last week directed at American fighter jets are but the most recent examples.
So how to deal with them? Past Administrations routinely looked at the two nations as players in a balancing act, historic rivals that could be -- and indeed had to be -- used against each other to insure that one did not become too strong at the expense of the other. During the war between the two countries in the 1980's, the prevailing view of the Reagan Administration was the one best articulated by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, that "both sides should lose."
Now the Clinton Administration argues that neither regime should be strengthened and that each should be dealt with as a separate problem -- a sort of parallel containment. In addition, Mr. Clinton, unlike President Bush, is more likely to use the behavior of the regimes, rather than the individual leaders themselves, as policy determinants. Mr. Clinton would neither be likely to label Mr. Hussein "worse than Hitler" nor inclined to pick up the phone in the mistaken belief that Mr. Rafsanjani was on the other end in Teheran, as Mr. Bush did.
But the new Administration has thus far failed to articulate a regional policy in a coherent and convincing way. Administration officials say they are abandoning the Bush fixation with Mr. Hussein, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher has branded Iran an "international outlaw," citing its support for terrorism abroad and its determination to develop a nuclear weapon. Framing the policy in that way leaves the unfortunate impression that Iraq is less and Iran is more of an enemy and that parallel containment may be just a reworked version of old-fashioned power balancing.
The Administration argues that the Bush emphasis on Mr. Hussein's ouster raised false hopes, created a gap between American goals and those laid out in tough Security Council sanctions and threatened to divide the American-led international coalition formed to confront Iraq. It has a convoluted explanation for its own policy: Mr. Hussein must comply with United Nations sanctions so tough that he could not possibly comply and still remain in power. In fact, the argument continues, the new approach is even tougher than the Bush policy, because it requires not only Mr. Hussein but also his successors to fulfill all United Nations resolutions.
But the policy glosses over the fact that in the Middle East, perception is often more important than reason. The subtlety of the new argument is bound to be lost on Mr. Hussein, who proved during the Persian Gulf crisis just how poor he was at reading American intentions.
"The Clinton people have to formulate the policy better," said Talib Shibib, an Iraqi opposition leader and ex-Foreign Minister. "It has been very confusing. Most people think that the Clinton people are softening. And we the opposition are losing support among the Iraqi people, who either want the lifting of the sanctions or the removal of Saddam."
As for Iran, the Clinton Administration has already decided that it remains a foreign policy mine field. Despite its help in winning the release of American hostages held by Iranian-backed groups in Lebanon, Iran has not improved its behavior, officials say. They cite its support for terrorism and for Islamic fundamentalist movements, its determination to rebuild its military, including the development of weapons of mass destruction, its poor human rights record and its opposition to the American-sponsored Middle East peace talks.
 
The Saddam Syndrome
 But the new Administration is looking at much the same behavior as the Bush Administration did, and reaching different conclusions. When Mr. Clinton concludes his current policy review on Iran, he is likely to abandon the "good will begets good will" approach of Mr. Bush, which left open the door for dialogue. The question is why?
First, there is the Saddam syndrome. The Administration is determined not to make the same mistakes with Iran that Mr. Bush did with Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait, trying to moderate behavior through economic and political incentives.
Second, the new Administration wants to move the Middle East peace talks forward, and feels that Iran's opposition as well as its support for terrorist groups opposed to the negotiations cannot go unpunished.
Third, the Clinton team is taking its cue from countries in the region. Israel, for example, sees Iran as the nuclear threat of the next decade -- a threat that helps justify Israel's own arms buildup and continued levels of American aid. And when Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, met with Mr. Clinton last week, he blamed Iran for much of the fundamentalist turmoil in his own country.
Fourth, the new Administration's most experienced diplomat in dealing with Iran is the Secretary of State himself. Mr. Christopher still bears the scars from his experiences with Iran in the Carter Administration, which suffered through the overthrow of its best friend in the Persian Gulf, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi. As the chief American negotiator in winning the release of Americans held hostage by Iran's revolutionary regime, Mr. Christopher has no illusions about the Administration's ability to shape Iran's policy.
But this approach ignores the fact that the United States could do worse than coexist with an Iran led by Mr. Rafsanjani, by no means a Western-style democrat, but at least a pragmatic state-builder determined to rebuild his country's economy. He has proven that he is capable of responsible action: when he remained neutral in the gulf war with Iraq and again when he pressed for the release of American hostages in Lebanon.
"I still don't think the analysis of Rafsanjani as a pragmatist who wants to improve relations with the West is wrong," said Shaul Bakhash, a historian and author. "Yes, he is ultimately responsible for what Iranians do abroad, and this is no time for constructive engagement. But we don't want to make it any worse, and it will be much harder for Iranians to resume a policy of seeking dialogue after all this name-calling."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran faces re-election next month. (Al Jawad/Sipa)

HEADLINE: Clinton's Jobs Plan Rallies the Republicans

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE tug of war between President Clinton and Senate Republicans over Mr. Clinton's proposed $19.5 billion economic stimulus package is about many things besides the pork barrels, loopholes and swimming pools supposedly in the package itself. It is about political body-building by Republicans getting ready for 1994. It is about the ambivalent mood of the country on the big economic issues and, as with almost everything in American politics today, it is about Ross Perot and how to steal his voters.
In some ways, Mr. Clinton has been a victim of his own success. The outlines of the larger $1.52 trillion budget package he announced last week -- consisting of long-term tax increases, new spending programs and defense cuts -- have breezed so easily through Congress so far that many Americans seemed to be ignoring the fight over the smaller job-stimulus plan, designed to give a shove to the current recovery. 
 "I think one reason that the public has not been engaged more is that it thinks Clinton has already won," said Thomas Mann of the Brookings Institution, an expert on Congress. "But that is a political failure on Clinton's part. He is suffering a public relations defeat on a secondary issue, when he has been winning the larger battle."
Senate Republicans successfully entrapped the stimulus package in a filibuster, forcing the President to seek a compromise that will take some of their demands for spending cuts into account. But this was not only a public relations blunder growing out of a bit of hubris at the White House. The public's silence over the Republican filibuster also stems from the voters' ambivalence, or confusion, about the whole concept of a stimulus package, which calls for spending more billions now on roads, bridges and other projects to create jobs, preceding a $1.52 trillion budget that calls for more taxes and spending cuts. There is a logic to all this, but it does not fit on a bumper sticker.
Indeed, if to name something is to own it, how this stimulus package is named will determine a lot about which party ends up owning it. Will it be called a jobs bill or a pork barrel bill? Will it be seen as "action," the opposite of which is "gridlock," or as "business as usual," the opposite of which is "change"?
Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, a Republican back in his home district last week, reported: "I saw one headline that said, 'Republicans Hold Up Jobs Bill.' When you paint the issue that way, the public is not sympathetic to the Republicans. Then the other day I saw another headline: 'Republicans Try to Stop Administration on New Spending.' With that vocabulary, the Republicans look pretty good. All of this reflects the public's ambivalent mood: It wants more programs and less taxes."
But this battle was also training for future political combat. In trying to show that they have the muscle to force the President to compromise on an essential element of his economic program, the Republican leaders were trying to make sure that he would not be able to ignore their views in the looming battles on health care and welfare reform, let alone the big budget.
That new 1,478-page Clinton budget for 1994 proposes tax increases on energy, Social Security benefits, corporate profits and personal income in higher brackets, along with spending reductions including $108 billion in military and civilian programs.
What the Republicans have done with the stimulus package is to show that it has loose threads, like swimming pools for poor neighborhoods, that can be tugged for political gain. Even some Democrats have defected on another central element of the plan, the investment tax credit, which is likely to hasten its unraveling.
And there are more loose threads in a $1.52 trillion budget. The real danger for Mr. Clinton is that what is happening on the stimulus package will happen to the larger budget: that it will be defined by its parts rather than by the whole.
"The more concessions Clinton has to make on the stimulus package," said the Republican political consultant Kevin Phillips, "the more he is made to look like just another wheeler-dealer, the more chance there will be unraveling on the larger budget. When you start to get threads pulled on you, people all of a sudden start to say, 'Hey, look, this is coming loose.' "
 
Recalling Ross Perot
 Republicans are clearly betting that their stance will draw the Perot voters they will need for a comeback. As Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole told CNN last week: "I think we'd like to bring them back to the Republican Party. We believe our philosophy is pretty much what they voted for when they voted for Ross Perot last November -- they want less spending, less regulation."
No doubt casting the Democrats as tied in with special interests and pork, and incapable of turning the economy around, is a way to appeal to Perot voters. But there is a risk here. The more Perotism is made an issue, the more people may seek the real thing, not a Republican imitation. "Clinton will succeed with Perot voters, if he succeeds in governing," said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's polltaker. "Republicans will succeed if they make themselves an effective opposition. But to do that they need an alternative Republican vision, and there is no sign of that yet. By constantly referencing Perot, the Republicans may enlarge Perot at their own expense."
