HEADLINE: PRESIDENT IS URGED TO CONSIDER FORCE TO HELP BOSNIANS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
A team of experts sent to Bosnia by President Clinton to assess the plight of civilians caught in the fighting has urged Washington to give serious consideration to military intervention to end the suffering.
In a draft report, the group recommended that the Administration consider civilian "safe havens" protected by international forces and stronger military action to both insure the delivery of aid and silence the heavy artillery Serbian forces have used to shell besieged cities. 
 But at the instruction of senior officials, the group withheld recommendations on the use of force -- which run counter to current Administration policy -- from Congress in closed-door briefings that took place this week.
 
White House Is Silent
 A White House official refused to say if President Clinton had been informed about the team's conclusions.
An executive summary of the draft report, prepared in March, was obtained by The New York Times from an official who believes the material should be part of the public debate on policy toward the crisis. The group's findings question the fundamental premise of the West's approach in Bosnia, which has been to deliver food to Muslim towns and cities shelled by Bosnian Serbs while refraining from using force to protect the civilians.
The 26-member team said the main threat to Bosnian civilians is not starvation but attacks by Bosnian Serbs on populated areas, which have killed and wounded civilians and forced them to flee through mountainous terrain in sub-zero temperatures. Under such circumstances, United Nations deliveries of food and supplies were doing little to address the real cause of suffering, the team found.
The team's members included State Department and military officials, relief experts from the Agency for International Development and doctors from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.
 
A Call for 'Safe Havens'
 "Even the best humanitarian program," their summary states, "will be of limited utility as long as more direct or forceful means are not applied to end the conflict itself or, at least, to shift its focus away from the civilian population."
Their proposal to consider creating "safe havens," in which Western military power would be used to protect civilians, has stirred consternation at high levels of the Clinton Administration because it implies the use of ground troops and the use of air power to deter Serbian attacks.
The team's report comes as the Clinton Administration has reached a crossroads on its Bosnia policy. With Bosnian Serbs adamantly refusing to sign a peace accord, and their attacks on civilians continuing, the Clinton Administration is struggling over what to do next.
Senior Administration officials acknowledged that they ordered the omission of the recommendations on force in the briefings to House and Senate committees.
In explaining the decision to withhold the team's key conclusions, one top Administration official said that the recommendations were meant for internal review and that the experts had been sent to assess the needs for relief in Bosnia, not propose new policies on military intervention.
But another official insisted that the team had a broad mandate and that the cool response to its views by the State Department and National Security Council amounted to "a shoot the messenger approach."
The State Department has not decided how much, if any, of the material will be made public.
 
 
Mission Returned March 11
 The team's mission was announced by Secretary of State Warren Christopher on Feb. 10 as part of a package of measures President Clinton had approved to stem the bloodshed. Mr. Christopher said the team was to "urgently" search for means of easing the suffering of the hundreds of thousands of civilians in Bosnia.
Two weeks later, the team led by Hugh G. Hamilton, deputy adviser for East European assistance at the State Department, arrived in Bosnia and interviewed aid workers, refugees and others with direct knowledge of the conflict. They returned to Washington on March 11 and summarized their findings in a draft report.
The team, in its draft proposing ways to ease the suffering, said "safe havens" could protect Bosnian civilians who were being shelled or at risk of being attacked. "This process should focus on areas being subjected to purposeful shelling of local populations and nonmilitary targets, and infers a willingness to protect those safe havens," the summary noted.
While the team urged serious consideration of this idea, a Pentagon member of the group reportedly expressed reservations, reflecting Defense Department concerns about being drawn into the fighting in Bosnia.
 
Supplies Called Critical
 In another of its recommendations, the team suggested that the Administration encourage and assist the United Nations in opening the airport in Tuzla, a city in eastern Bosnia that the team said would be swamped with refugees if nearby enclaves fell to attacking Serbian forces. Refugees fleeing the advancing Bosnian Serbs have already been evacuated to Tuzla, which is under Muslim control.
Delivering supplies to the town, the report noted, was also critical because the city produces coal and plays a key role in "what remains" of the economy in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The report also suggested that experts in communications and logistics from the Pentagon and Agency for International Development help the United Nations peacekeepers and refugee officials in Bosnia. American military doctors and relief workers from the Agency for International Development should be sent to improve medical care, the report said.
"Short of stopping attacks on civilian populations, these steps will save the greatest number of innocent lives," the summary said.
Among the members of the assessment team was Dr. Michael Toole of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who visited the besieged town of Zepa, in eastern Bosnia.
 
'It Was Unbelievably Cold'
 Dr. Toole said in a telephone interview that an examination of records showed that in the past year, the death rate had increased fourfold. The records said 40 to 45 percent died of wounds inflicted by the fighting and that about 40 percent had died of hunger.
"It was unbelievably cold," Dr. Toole said. "The people of Zepa looked tired, exhausted, and hungry but not critically malnourished."
The Clinton Administration's handling of the assessment is in some ways a case study of the inner workings of Washington, illustrating how the executive branch can use its control over the machinery of government to shape public debate.
Although President Clinton said during the Presidential campaign that he advocated the use of force to halt Serbian aggression, he now seems to view that option as imprudent and impractical. His aides appear to be doing what they can to defuse pressure for intervention from either Congress or the public by withholding the team's recommendations from lawmakers, much as the Bush Administration did initially by downplaying reports on Serbian detention centers.
 
Suppression Is Denied
 "Folks are not in a 'let the chips fall where they may mode,' " an Administration official said. "Individual policymakers do not want any more pressure brought to bear on them than they already have."
Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, denied that the Administration was suppressing the team's findings by withholding the recommendations from lawmakers.
"It is inaccurate to suggest that there is anything unusual about the Administration wanting to follow through on its own deliberations before briefing parties outside the Administration, whether on Capitol Hill or elsewhere, on the status of those issues," Mr. Boucher said.
Administration officials said the draft report was still being revised.
"They're putting a lot of pressure on," said an official, referring to the State Department's review of the draft report. "It's not like they're trying to kill it, it's more like 'Tone it down.' "
 
Criticism of Team Ignored
 Despite criticism that the team has overstepped its mandate, the latest revision of the March draft still includes military action as among the recommended options because the team believes force is needed to save lives. Administration officials said the latest version of the draft calls on the Clinton Administration to consider the creation of "safe havens," and the use of force to insure the delivery of relief supplies and to knock out artillery.
The revised draft report is also said to include these recommendations:
*Station United Nations peacekeeping troops in or near contested areas to deter fighting.
*Develop punitive measures that will persuade Serbian leaders in Bosnia and Serbia to permit food aid to reach besieged communities.
*Insist that the Government of Croatia take similar steps to assure that Croatian soldiers in Bosnia "cease harassment of Muslim civilians and relief operations."
*Deliver seeds to the Bosnians so that they grow some of their own food.
*Help establish a radio station in Bosnia so that civilians can learn what is happening in their own country.
*Continue the airdrop of relief supplies over Bosnia.
*Help repair power plants and improve coal production.
Representative Frank McCloskey, the Indiana Democrat who is one of the few voices in Congress calling for American involvement in Bosnia, said the decision to withhold the recommendations came as no surprise.
"The Administration has totally backed away from the idea of doing anything significant to stop the slaughter," Mr. McCloskey said.
 
 
 
BALKAN UPDATE
 A team the Administration sent to BOSNIA is recommending that Washington consider military intervention to create civilian "safe havens" and is seeking stronger military action to silence the heavy artillery of Serbian forces and insure that aid reaches civilians.
United Nations officials said yesterday that they feared that Bosnian Serbs, emboldened by recent events, might be planning to tighten their noose around SREBRENICA and mount a tank offensive in an attempt to seize parts of SARAJEVO.
Bosnian Muslims in SREBRENICA once again blocked the evacuation of refugees on a United Nations convoy. Local officials have blocked mass evacuations for fear they would leave the town vulnerable to assault.
United Nations aid flights to SARAJEVO were suspended after reports that Serbs placed anti-aircraft guns near the airport.
In ZAGREB, Iran's parliamentary leader said TEHERAN would supply Muslims with weapons if the arms embargo was lifted.
 Two French peacekeepers were killed when their gasoline tanker overturned near BIHAC in northwest Bosnia on Friday, an army spokesman said.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Drop the Mop, Bless the Mess: The Decline of Housekeeping

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
Dust bunnies under the couch. Cobwebs in the corners. A grimy shellac over the contents of kitchen cupboards. In a culture where cleanliness has long been equated with godliness, these telltale signs should be anathema. But rather than repenting with a vigorous spring cleaning, many Americans are changing creeds.
"I'll never be the housekeeper my mother is, and I've made peace with that," said Kristen Jaeger, whose family owns a winery in Napa Valley, Calif. "Of course, my mother isn't the housekeeper her mother was. My grandmother used to take Lysol to hotel rooms and clean before she unpacked." 
 The decline of cleanliness seems to prick the nation's Spic and Span conscience. Home economists and representatives of the cleaning-products industry refer euphemistically to the rise of dirt and dust on the domestic scene. "I'd prefer to say that modern homemakers are reprioritizing," said Carolyn Forte, associate director of the Good Housekeeping Institute in New York, the magazine's research group. Others are blunter and advocate accepting reality.
 
'Better Things to Do'
 "Bless the mess," said Mary Ellen Pinkham, whose housecleaning advice column is syndicated in 150 newspapers. While she maintains white-glove standards in her own home, she believes this level of cleanliness is rapidly becoming an anomaly.
"The American home is getting dirtier," she said. "People have better things to do with their time than clean."
Housekeeping standards have dipped strikingly in the last five years, in the opinion of executives with moving companies, maid services and extermination businesses in New York, Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Cincinnati and San Francisco. The professionals who regularly enter private homes say the change cuts across socioeconomic lines but is most evident in households with young children and two working parents.
Such couples seem able to maintain a tidy facade, but a closer look reveals that neither Mr. Clean nor the White Tornado have visited in years.
"You walk into a fancy house, everything looks tidy, and then you move the couch and pull up enough dust to give you asthma," said Tom Davis, the vice president of Mini Moves, a 30-year-old moving company in Cincinnati. "Move a refrigerator, and you're looking at a third-world nation."
Lack of time, more than a slothful nature, accounts for the decline in spotlessness, said Dr. Juliet Schorr, a professor of economics at Harvard University and the author of "The Overworked American: The Unexpected Decline of Leisure" (Basic Books, 1992). Studying time-use diaries of 1,000 Americans, she found that for every hour a woman works outside the home, she cuts back 30 minutes of housekeeping time.
Men pick up some of the slack in cleaning time, but not all of it, said John Robinson, the director of the Survey Research Center of the University of Maryland in College Park. Also studying time-use data, he found that in 1985, women spent about an hour and a half less cleaning house each week than they did in 1965. In the same period, men devoted about an hour more to cleaning, which left a 30-minute void for dust to grow.
 
Ever More Dirt
 According to a telephone survey of 500 adults, released by Black & Decker last week, the discrepancy -- and the dust -- have grown. Forty-three percent of the women surveyed said they were doing less housecleaning than they had done five years ago, but only 21 percent felt their husbands were contributing more than they had in 1987.
"It's easier to cut back on scrubbing the floor than it is to cut back on child care, laundry or meal preparation," Dr. Schorr said.
But can a country admonished by the antiseptic precepts of "Beeton's Book of Household Management," first published in 1861, make peace with scrubbing, mopping, dusting and polishing left undone? Certainly a fear of the "discomfort and suffering" that Isabella Beeton found inherent in "untidy ways," must linger.
 
'People Get Depressed'
 Of course, it does, said Martha Stewart, the cooking, gardening and entertaining doyenne, who discusses the decline in cleaning habits in her book, "Home Keeping," to be published next year by Clarkson N. Potter. "People get depressed when they can't see out their windows," she added.
Mrs. Pinkham, the columnist, said that the depressing effects of hidden dirt had resulted in a fanaticism for clean counter tops among the generation raised to expect tidiness a la June Cleaver.
"They try to project perfect housekeeping by being maniacs about appearance," she said. "Meanwhile, their closets are full of stuff they've been dragging around since Gerald Ford was President."
 
Sales of Deodorizers Gain
 George Rosenbaum, an analyst at Leo J. Shapiro, a market-research organization in Chicago, said that after a decade of disappointing sales in floor-care products and all-purpose cleaners, the cleaning-products industry evidenced gains last year, particularly in the sale of surface cleaners, many in spray bottles, and carpet and bathroom deodorizers.
"There's a boon in combined products, the detergent with bleach, the glass cleaner that can double as a counter cleaner, the bath gel that also eliminates tub rings and deodorizes," he said. Such multipurpose products, he added, seem to promise time saving as well as a tidy appearance.
Ham Carson, the editor of Household and Personal Products Industry, a monthly trade journal known by its acronym, Happi, said, "People are less the proverbial Dutch housewives, down on their hands and knees scrubbing, but they're eager for convenience and quick cleans."
Whether felled by the limits of time or the extinction of elbow-grease, Americans are increasingly employing maids and cleaning services to use the cleaning products they buy.
 
More Housekeeping Services
 In Manhattan alone, the number of businesses listed under the "Housekeeping," heading in the Nynex Yellow Pages has jumped to 51 in the current directory from 34 in 1983, said Patrick Marshall, a sales agent for the directory. And across the country, businesses are diversifying to include cleaning services. Orkin, the pest-control company, for example, recently formed a housecleaning subsidiary in Atlanta, where the company has its headquarters.
"We're noticing home-improvement stores and even grocery stores offering maid services," Mr. Rosenbaum said. In response, cleaning services like Maids Unlimited Citywide in New York, one of the oldest cleaning services in the country, have added "general handyman services," said the company's president, Van Lederer.
Blurring the lines between housecleaning and home maintenance is more than a marketing tool. It also reflects how some wealthy households contend with a buildup of deep-down dirt that seems to elude maids.
 
Don't Clean; Paint
 "Many of our clients renovate more frequently," said Jerry Caldari, a partner in Bromley & Caldari, a New York architectural firm. "One told me that a new coat of paint eats the dust mites."
Iris Kaplan, an artist, found it daunting to maintain a plush Park Avenue apartment when she returned to her painting full time. "All that chintz, those drapes, those curving wood surfaces," she said. "Well, I decided you won't have dusty drapes if you don't have drapes." Five years ago, she turned her apartment into a sleek, wall-less loft, with easily cleaned marble and stainless-steel surfaces.
"Nothing touches the floor, so a maid with a mop can keep the place spotless in two hours a week," Mrs. Kaplan said. "It's easier to knock down a wall than to clean a wall."
This striking response to domestic dirt and dust is endorsed by home mavens like Ms. Stewart and Mrs. Pinkham. "I'm not trying to be the new Mrs. Beeton and create work," Ms. Stewart said. "I advocate practicality before elbow grease."
 
'An Outmoded Notion'
 Likewise, Mrs. Pinkham's seventh book, "Mary Ellen's Clean House!" (Crown), written with Dale Burg and scheduled to be issued later this month, would certainly have caused the good Mrs. Beeton to fear a heathen invasion and reach for the smelling salts. "I've suggested shortcuts that get the job done well enough," Mrs. Pinkham said. "Perfection in housecleaning is an outmoded notion."
Those guilt stricken at their own reluctance to scour corners, beat rugs and squeegee windows might find Dr. Peggy Meszaros's analysis useful. Dr. Meszaros, the dean of human and environmental sciences at the University of Kentucky in Lexington and president-elect of the American Home Economics Association, said that today a spotless home is a better reason for guilt than free-ranging dust bunnies are.
"In a time-pressured society, the prudent homemaker should make a priority of the people who make the home, their children and spouses, rather than making the physical structure of the home top priority," she said. "Assuming, of course, that the kitchen and bathroom still get cleaned."

HEADLINE: Japan Weighs Aid to Russia Against an Old Feud

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 10

 BODY:
When Japan announced this week that the Russian Foreign Minister would attend next week's meeting of senior officials from the wealthiest industrial nations, the news set off a furious debate among Government officials here. The issue was not how democracy could be fostered in Russia, but whether Japan would be able to use the visit to press Moscow to return a group of islands seized at the close of World War II.
The chief cabinet secretary, Yohei Kono, first said the territorial issue would not be raised, since the point of the meeting is to provide financial support for the programs of the beleaguered Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin. But later Mr. Kono abruptly changed course, saying the long-sought northern islands might be discussed when the Japanese and Russian foreign ministers meet separately. 
 It was a revealing moment in what is proving to be a remarkably difficult process for the policymakers in Tokyo. Japan is chairman and host of the conference, which will bring together the foreign and finance ministers of the Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. The meeting will not only discuss an increase in the West's role in Russia's struggle to build a market economy, but could also prove a milestone in Japan's efforts to gain an influence in international affairs equal to its economic might.
But the dispute with Russia over the bleak, lightly populated islands, part of the Kurile chain, is tying Government officials in knots as they struggle to balance a nationalistic urge to limit aid to Russia until the islands are returned with a desire to be seen as cooperating with Western aid efforts.
The effort to strike that balance seems to be leaving no one here happy. Under heavy pressure from the other countries in the Group of Seven, the Government has all but abandoned its policy of linking financial assistance with progress on the islands questions. But Japan is also afraid of acknowledging a change in policy for fear that such an admission will give away any leverage it has over Russia.
 
No Linkage Is Asserted
 "We have never said that we have separated the Northern Territories issue and aid," insisted one senior Foreign Ministry official last week, referring to the disputed Kuriles. "But they are not linked."
The total aid package to be worked out here next week is expected to come to more than $25 billion, and Japan may be pressed to contribute as much as $3 billion in direct aid. Several billion dollars of the new package will simply be funds promised a year ago that were never disbursed because of the economic disarray in Russia.
Whether Western leaders like it or not, the territorial issue will thus be important for them, too, because even if the islands are not discussed here they are having an impact on how much aid the Japanese will provide.
For instance, Japan is pushing for most of the money to be channeled through multilateral institutions, like the International Monetary Fund, rather than as bilateral aid. Japanese officials also express reservations about providing aid that would benefit the military, such as the construction of housing for Russian soldiers returning from former Soviet republics and Eastern Europe.
In addition, Japanese officials say they favor policies that would benefit Russia by bringing it foreign currency earnings through trade rather than giveaways. This might involve targeting aid to specific industries so Russia could profit from self-sustaining commercial operations, and then use that capital to finance other businesses.
Any discussion of aid for Russia with Japanese officials usually begins with an angry description of what they regard as the injustice of Moscow's seizure of the islands at the end of World War II and of the more than 60,000 Japanese who died in Soviet detention camps afterwards. The Kuriles were ceded to the Soviet Union at the Yalta Conference and occupied by Soviet troops in September 1945, a month after the Japanese surrender.
Japanese officials also complain that they are sometimes wrongly accused of having given little at all to Russia. Japan committed $2.7 billion last year. Of that about $700 million has been disbursed, and another $400 million to $500 million will be disbursed shortly, officials said, which is in line with other donor nations.
These commitments were calculated with enormous care, a senior Foreign Ministry official explained, to place Japan squarely in the middle of the nations giving aid to Russia, at a level high enough to avoid criticism but low enough to let Moscow know that Tokyo could do more if the islands were returned.
"The political solution over the islands and the economic assistance should be balanced," said Sozaburo Okamatsu, head of trade policy at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. "But the huge assistance should come after solution of the territorial issue."
 
What's More Important?
 Western countries have said they generally support Japan's aim of regaining the islands, but they clearly have little sympathy for the idea of making aid contingent on the issue when the future of a nuclear-armed Russia hangs in the balance.
It is not clear that the Japanese people support a linkage either. There is a vocal minority that feels strongly about the islands, and polls show people generally feel the territory should be returned. But many editorials here have condemned the Government for what they say are its inflexible methods and lack of statesmanship.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Scale Down Program to Oust Iraqi Leader

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has concluded that the Bush Administration's covert program to overthrow Saddam Hussein has failed to weaken the Iraqi leader, but it plans to maintain a scaled-down version of the program anyway, Administration and other Government officials say.
In reviewing the program, the new Administration has concluded that much of the aid has been misdirected to groups with no popular following, and that too much money has been spent on leaflets and other propaganda devices that have had little impact, the officials said. They added that the Administration would try to make less money do more in trying to destabilize the Iraqi Government and make life more difficult for Mr. Hussein. 
 The expected changes in the Iraqi program, which is run by the Central Intelligence Agency, are part of an ambitious and systematic review of all of the covert programs that the Clinton Administration inherited from the Bush Administration, the officials said.
The decision to continue the secret program despite misgivings about its effectiveness reflects conflicting pressures on the Administration.
 
Different Emphasis Hinted
 On the one hand, senior Administration officials have said that President George Bush's demonization of Mr. Hussein by labeling him "worse than Hitler" was foolish because it raised expectations that he would have to be overthrown even though the United States did not have the tools to do it.
On the other hand, even as the new officials seek to "depersonalize" Iraq policy by focusing on the importance of Iraq's compliance with United Nations sanctions, the Administration is sensitive to charges that it is being soft on Mr. Hussein.
A result has been a sometimes confusing mix of new signals and status quo. While officials hint at a different emphasis, they have left in place many of the specific decisions, like the rules of engagement for American pilots enforcing the no-flight zone. These rules led jets to drop bombs on Iraqi antiaircraft batteries on Friday after the pilots said the batteries had opened fire.
Administration officials are reluctant to discuss the covert program to oust Mr. Hussein, citing its secret nature. But in classified briefings with the C.I.A., some lawmakers are said to have asked why they should approve money for a program that has no chance of succeeding.
"As far as I'm concerned, it's a let's-throw-money-and-hope-it-works approach," said one lawmaker, who says the program should be reorganized.
 
$40 Million Plan Last Year
 President Bush harbored the hope that the Iraqi military could be encouraged to foment a coup against Mr. Hussein, and toward the end of 1991, several months after the Persian Gulf war ended, he authorized a $15 million covert plan to help oust him. Last year, the program was expanded to $40 million, after a number of lawmakers argued forcefully that the United States had made only a halfhearted effort against the Iraqi leader.
Officials said that the Clinton Administration might cut the $40 million program by about half, although they emphasized that no final budget decision had been made.
The secret program has financed opposition groups inside and outside Iraq, propaganda by clandestine radio stations, leaflets and a disinformation campaign inside the country. Several groups receive money.
The longstanding Congressional ban on trying to assassinate a foreign leader precludes direct American involvement in any plot to kill Mr. Hussein.
Almost from the time that the gulf war ended, C.I.A. analysts have argued that economic sanctions alone are unlikely to weaken Mr. Hussein. In the last two years, he has been able to rebuild much of the country's highways, bridges, electrical and communications networks and other installations. To a large extent, he has sheltered his military from the sanctions, which continue to hurt the Iraqi people.
 
A Hard Man to Dislodge
 These intelligence analysts have held to the position that it would be unlikely that anything short of an assassination would dislodge Mr. Hussein from power.
Even the Bush Administration had few illusions that the covert program would lead to Mr. Hussein's overthrow. In briefing members of Congress about the plan to expand the program last May, Bush Administration officials did not claim that American opposition contacts were capable of overthrowing Mr. Hussein or even that they were well placed, officials said.
The intelligence agencies of the United States and other Western governments have had little success in penetrating Iraqi society. Despite the presence of American troops in restricted no-flight zones in northern and southern Iraq, American intelligence officials have acknowledged that the United States has little direct knowledge of or contacts with Mr. Hussein's inner circle, the Iraqi military and the intelligence services.
In an interview with The Washington Post in January, Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, said an effort to oust Mr. Hussein had come "pretty close" last summer. It failed, he said, only because the Iraqi leader "has one of the most efficient systems in the world." Mr. Scowcroft added that the coup attempt, which he suggested involved the Iraqi military, had not been an American effort. rule

IRAQ AGAIN DENIES ATTACK
 WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Iraq denied again today that its troops had fired on American warplanes patrolling its northern region and accused the United States of having attacked a tourist site to scare civilians.
On Friday, American jet fighters bombed Iraqi antiaircraft batteries in the northern no-flight zone, which is patrolled by the United States to insure that Iraqi planes in the Kurdish region remain grounded. Clinton Administration officials said the Iraqi installations had provoked the air raid by firing on the American planes.

HEADLINE: Moves by Serbs Raise Fears They Plan an All-Out Drive

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, April 10

 BODY:
Serbian forces pressed closer to Srebrenica today and intensified assaults on the capital, deepening concern among United Nations officials that the Serbs may think they can resume all-out "ethnic cleansing" without fear of serious international reprisals.
Other officials familiar with Western intelligence reports said they feared that Serbian nationalists might be planning a tank offensive to seize parts of Sarajevo. 
 The United Nations suspended the Western aid airlift this morning after military observers spotted potentially threatening movements by Serbian truck-borne antiaircraft batteries immediately beneath the approach to the airport, a United Nations official said.
Comdr. Barry Frewer, the United Nations military spokesman, denied that account. He attributed the suspension to apprehension among the air forces flying the airlift that they would become targets of Serbian gunners prepared for patrols that are to begin on Monday to enforce the no-flight zone over Bosnia.
Two developments in recent days appear to have encouraged the Serbian leaders to press ahead. Although the idea of using force is still under debate in Washington, the Bosnian Serbs apparently have concluded that the threat of American military intervention, or even a serious tightening of economic sanctions, is receding.
 
Hidden Ammunition Found
 And on Thursday, Serbian troops discovered ammunition hidden in a United Nations relief truck carrying flour to a Sarajevo suburb controlled by the Muslim-led Bosnian Government.
Later, United Nations officials uncovered more ammunition and sacks of what they described as "gunpowder" in relief containers outside the United Nations warehouse at the airport, in an area where local Serbian and Muslim employees move freely.
As a United Nations investigation began, Gen. Manojlo Milanovic, a senior Serbian officer, sent a letter warning that Serbian forces would halt all convoys and open all packages, further delaying deliveries that already spend days at Serbian roadblocks.
"We know that supplying Muslims and Croats with weapons and ammunition has been done for a long time," General Milanovic said. "All this has been done with your approval. You have not respected our tolerance and our previous warnings."
 Serbian commanders say that, in effect, the Serbian forces reserve the right to shut down all relief efforts here, a move that would quickly starve many of the Muslim cities and towns that survive.
Relief convoys from the Croatian coast to Sarajevo, 180 miles away, have been halted since the Serbian troops discovered the ammunition in the truck of flour.
Senior United Nations officials say the prospects now are for a spring and summer of intensified assaults by Serbian forces in an effort to seize control of territory from Bosnia.
This grim prospect, at a time when Serbian leaders are being pressed to accept a peace plan that has already been signed by the Bosnian Government, representing Muslims, and by leaders of Bosnia's Croatian minority, appears to have come closer to reality with a series of aggressive Serbian military moves in recent days.
 
Pressure on Srebrenica Grows
 Among these has been the growing Serbian pressure on Srebrenica in eastern Bosnia, where Serbian forces have defied their own commanders' repeated promises to observe a cease-fire, and calls by the Security Council for a halt to their attacks, by pushing forward ever closer to the town.
Although the Serbian military commander promised on Friday that his troops would stop their attacks on Srebrenica and its outlying Muslim villages at 2 P.M. today, the small peacekeeping detachment in the enclave reported that a volley of Serbian mortar fire struck close to a storage building 20 minutes after the Serbian deadline, and that Serbian bombardments elsewhere in the enclave continued past dusk.
Commander Frewer, the United Nations spokesman, told reporters: "The area under Bosnian control continues to be squeezed. It's getting smaller every day."
After driving hundreds of thousands of Muslims out of regions that have been their homes for centuries, the Serbian leaders have recently made it plain that they want to eliminate Muslims around Srebrenica, Zepa and Gorazde.
On Thursday, Serbian commanders allowed, or possibly encouraged, hundreds of Serbian civilians to halt two United Nations armored vehicles carrying Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon, the United Nations military commander in Bosnia, as they headed for Srebrenica from Sarajevo.
The civilians tore radio aerials and other equipment off the vehicles, and scrawled "Morillon-Hitler" and other abusive messages on the vehicles, before Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Serbian military commander, arrived at the scene in a Serbian military helicopter and suggested that Gen. Morillon follow the helicopter out of the area, away from Srebrenica.
On Friday, after General Morillon had made a 700-mile journey by land and air to skirt Serbian-controlled territory in Bosnia and reach Belgrade, he met General Mladic again, this time at a meeting arranged by the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, only to have General Mladic declare he would not tolerate any further attempts to intervene in the Srebrenica fighting.
Asked by reporters for his response to General Morillon's demands that 150 Canadian troops be stationed in Srebrenica as a United Nations "tripwire" against the fall of the town, General Mladic replied, "Over my dead body, and the bodies of my family."
Although General Morillon has been an opponent of Western military intervention against the Serbian forces, his stand at Srebrenica, where he hoisted the United Nations flag last month and promised to save the town from the Serbian forces, has infuriated Serbian leaders, who have demanded his removal from the United Nations command.
Reports in French newspapers in Paris today suggested that the French Government might be about to withdraw the commander, but General Morillon, returning to Sarajevo after the abortive Belgrade talks, told reporters that there was no truth to the reports.
"I have a job to do here, and I will be remaining on the ground here to do it," he said.
The only concession Serbian forces have made to United Nations pressures on Srebrenica to permit convoys to enter the enclave with limited amounts of food and medical supplies, and to carry Muslim residents of the enclave on the outbound journey across the siege lines to the Bosnian-held city of Tuzla, 50 miles away.
This two-way traffic, which has resulted in the evacuation of about 6,500 of the 60,000 people living in the enclave in the past three weeks, was to have resumed today, but Bosnian commanders in Srebrenica surrounded nine United Nations trucks with armed soldiers and refused to allow a large crowd of desperate Muslim civilians to board the trucks.
United Nations officials said that the Bosnian officers had explained their action by saying that they were not prepared to allow those seeking evacuation to travel aboard open trucks, as they did on previous convoys out of the enclave, which resulted in the deaths of at least 13 of the people packed onto the flatbeds of the trucks in below freezing temperatures.
But United Nations officials said they believed the real reason for halting today's planned evacuation was that Bosnian commanders fear that reducing the population will weaken the town's claim on the conscience of Western governments that might intervene against the Serbian forces.
"They used the uncovered trucks as an excuse," John McMillan, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said in Sarajevo.
The Serbs have also made a crucial move against Gorazde by cutting the mountain trail that has been used by Bosnian forces for horse-borne convoys of food and weapons that have sustained the city.
And increasingly, United Nations officials say they believe that seizing part, or even most, of Sarajevo is part of the plan.
 
Ammunition Stocks Built Up
 Although Serbian artillery bombardments of Sarajevo have been sharply reduced during the cease-fire, people familiar with Western intelligence reports say that the lull has been used to build up stocks of ammunition at gun batteries overlooking the Bosnian capital, and that Serbian military commanders have drawn up plans for a new attempt soon to seize strategic territory around Sarajevo airport. These sources say that an advance of only a few hundred yards around one critical highway overpass would put the Serbian forces in a position to mount a tank offensive into the heart of the city.
Planes reaching their artillery batteries around Sarajevo have continued to fire into the city, although at much lower levels of bombardment than in the past.

HEADLINE: President's Budget Plans Worry Some Scientists

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
President Clinton's $1.52 trillion budget package, sent to Congress on Thursday, recommended a modest 4.1 percent overall increase in Federal financing of American science. Much of it was earmarked for programs that would stimulate technology and seek medical cures, however, and many scientists fear that the White House initiative will bleed off financial support for basic research.
Mr. Clinton's budget has yet to pass through the Congressional gantlet, and Congress seems certain to introduce major revisions, but many scientists are already scrutinizing the President's request for indications of the new Administration's priorities. 
 The most conspicuous of these is Mr. Clinton's proposal to increase spending for programs that produce technological applications that can improve the economy and public health.
But to accommodate these application-oriented programs, the kinds of research that have no immediate practical use, like particle physics or astronomy, will be held back. The Administration has recommended an increase of only 3 percent for such basic research in the civilian sector -- an increase that barely keeps pace with inflation -- and a cut of 11 percent for basic military research.
 
Some Worry About Restraints
 Some scientists worry that by being too specific about research goals, the Administration and Congress may inadvertently block great discoveries that come from freedom in experimentation. Serendipitous discovery, they say, is possible only for the scientist who is not constrained to follow too structured a research path.
Others were optimistic. "Reactions among scientists to President Clinton's science program are generally very cheerful," said Dr. Leon M. Lederman, a Nobel laureate in physics who has been president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science for the last year.
But he noted that there were some proposals with "undercurrents" that might be enacted at the cost of basic scientific research. Among these are the proposal for the National Science Foundation, the nation's premier science financing agency, which would receive $3.2 billion in 1994, a 7.2 percent increase from the budget for the 1993 fiscal year for overall research financing, including both basic and applied research. Many American scientists have expressed satisfaction that Mr. Clinton intends to back the foundation strongly. But some have misgivings about the way grants will have to be spent.
The spending plans might "tend to convert the N.S.F. into a quick-fix agency," Dr. Lederman said. "That kind of thing has been tried before, and it was a disaster. But I believe the N.S.F. will survive the onslaught, once things settle down. The Administration doesn't yet have enough people on board to sort things out, but President Clinton's general views seem reasonable and favorable to science."
 
Focus on Certain Diseases
 Another major granting agency, the National Institutes of Health, will increase spending on the search for cures of certain diseases, notably breast cancer, AIDS and ailments that afflict minorities, while holding its overall budget to a 3 percent increase over the present year. Among the losers in such a budget would be research programs dealing with heart disease and strokes.
An official of the health institutes, who agreed to comment only on the condition that his name not be disclosed, said the cuts had been worked out by the agency itself, not by the Administration. "We were confronted with a need to reduce overall expenses while adding some new priorities," he said, "and within the constraints, we did the best we could."
The Clinton proposal includes substantial increases in financing for such practical research fields as materials science, a shift that pleases many applied-science researchers. Materials science is a field that includes the development of new building materials, materials with novel electronic or optical properties, special acoustical materials and many other substances regarded as essential to keeping American technology competitive with that of other countries.
In recent years many materials scientists have complained of low financing that they said was forced on them because of large Federal appropriations for such basic research programs as the superconducting supercollider, the $8.4-billion proton accelerator being built in Texas.
The future of the supercollider, which is strongly supported by the Clinton Administration, may depend partly on winning support from materials scientists.
 
'Circle Their Wagons'
 Dr. Robert Park, a spokesman for the American Physical Society, said an official of the Department of Energy had recently met with the High Energy Physics Advisory Panel to warn it of impending fiscal crises.
"He told the physicists that if they want to save the S.S.C., they'd better circle their wagons and remember to shoot out, not at each other."
Moreover, the official said, the accelerator physicists should recruit some of the materials scientists who now oppose them. Construction of the proposed Advanced Neutron Source at Oak Ridge, Tenn., would benefit materials scientists but would cost several billion dollars. It could be lumped together by Congress with the supercollider, "and if the S.S.C. goes, the Advanced Neutron Source could go with it," Dr. Park said. "That would be a real blow to materials science in the United States."
Among the physicists specializing in high-energy particle research, some believe that politics has distorted financial priorities.
The Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory is building a particle injector for its Tevatron accelerator, the most powerful proton accelerator in the world. The injector, which is expected to cost about $230 million, would pour many more protons and antiprotons into the Tevatron's colliding beams, and this is expected to produce many more discoveries than is possible now. Most high-energy physicists therefore give the Fermilab injector a very high priority.
But the Clinton budget would stretch out construction of the Fermilab injector while appropriating about $200 million for a "B Factory," an accelerator designed to produce large numbers of particles containing the "bottom" quark, a rare form of matter that could shed light on the nature of all matter.
One of the leading "B Factory" proposals would build the new accelerator inside an existing tunnel at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center in California. Dr. Lederman said that Representative George E. Brown Jr., Democrat of California, is interested in financing the B Factory at the expense of the Tevatron injector less because of scientific merit than because of the supposition that construction of a B Factory would create jobs in California.
Such budget considerations are far from basic research. Dr. Ernest L. Eliel, president of the American Chemical Society and a leading academic scientist, cautioned in a recent essay that serendipity, the accidental discovery of something valuable while searching for something else, is vital to scientific progress.

HEADLINE: An Edgy Los Angeles Awaits a Jury's Verdict

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 10

 BODY:
The City of Los Angeles has a bad case of frayed nerves.
Less than a decade since the city preened as a national exemplar of urban efficiency and racial harmony during the 1984 Olympics, the city must ponder now what has gone wrong -- and whether matters will get even worse when a jury renders a verdict, if it can. 
 In a narrow sense, the jury is deciding the guilt or innocence of four white Los Angeles police officers who beat a black man, Rodney G. King, after stopping him for speeding. But as every Angeleno knows, and many fear, the jurors may also cast the very fate of this city, whose mood now ranges from hysterical to apprehensive.
Around dinner tables, over barber chairs, in offices and movie studios, in Koreatown restaurants, on the streets of the Mexican-American Eastside, the main questions are these: Will a verdict of not guilty bring another wave of racial disorders of the sort that caused nearly $1 billion damage and more than 50 deaths last year? Has anything changed? Has the city learned anything?
 
Where Fear Increases
 The level of fear seems to increase with the distance from the riot's epicenter in South-Central Los Angeles. In distant white enclaves like Bel-Air and Brentwood, many residents are bracing with weapons amid wild, unsubstantiated rumors that gangs are planning forays into those sanctuaries of privilege. But in South-Central, community leaders are generally not anticipating big trouble, though not because of much palpable improvement in social conditions.
"The only people I've seen that's so damned worried about it is Koreans and reporters," said Milton Mallory, an unemployed black construction worker. "Nobody here is so scared. Not much left for me to be scared that I haven't already seen."
The attitudes in the city vary widely, as do those of the following people:
*A prominent local architect and his wife, whites who live in the Wilshire district, a wealthy gated enclave, planned to leave town with their two children to visit relatives in Northern California today. "A lot of people are planning to leave," the woman said. "Our plan is to leave the day the jury goes out for deliberations. I expect everything will be under control, but I'd rather be prepared for the worst, especially with children."
*Outside her home on East 105th Street in South-Central Los Angeles, Michele Galloway foresees calm. "I may be wrong," said Ms. Galloway, who is black and works as a computer analyst. "But I don't think people will express their emotions with violence. The initial shock is all done; the system is not going to change. And the police have sent a message they are prepared -- it's going to dissuade a lot of people." But her neighbor Charles Adams, 25, sees war against the police.
*Inside Luisito's Market, a bright yellow grocery at the corner of Vermont Avenue and 30th Street, Lydia E. Sandoval sits on a milk crate, all eyes and ears. "I think maybe tomorrow, I won't have my business," said Mrs. Sandoval, who spent 14 years working at a hotel to buy this shop seven months ago. "Sometimes I can't sleep, especially this week."
*A couple of miles north, in Koreatown, Mike Kim vows to protect the convenience store he rebuilt after last year's riots, with a new gun. "I don't leave this time," he said, but added he was more confident of police protection now. "I think no more riot. The police, they work good this time, I hope."
So it goes around Los Angeles and its suburbs, land of hope and despair, wealth and poverty. All week the voices of reason and stability have spoken urging calm, Mayor Tom Bradley, Chief Willie L. Williams, Gov. Pete Wilson, the pastors, the teachers, community leaders. Schoolchildren made "peace balloons" and discussed justice and racism in class.
But if soothing words were not enough today, there was also Chief Williams's deployment of 6,500 officers armed with rubber bullets and pepper gas, not to the mention 1,000 Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies and 800 California Highway Patrol officers, all backed up by National Guard troops waiting in armories.
For now, though, all Rob Markley and his father, Les Markley, are thinking about is how to protect their family business, the Atlas Furniture Company on Santa Monica Boulevard near Western Avenue in Hollywood, for the next week. The store was looted in the rioting last year, and the four stores the Markley's rented to Korean merchants next door were burned down.
 
Security Measures
 The furniture store has been restocked; the windows gated and doors fortified, and a full-time security guard walks amid the merchandise, too.
"I am hoping the city will give us one-day notice before the verdict," said Rob Markley. "We will probably not open that day."
From his listening post behind the counter of the Nate-N-Al Delicatessen in Beverly Hills, Mark Marietta said their patrons were scared of rioters. "They say they're coming to the three B's, "Beverly Hills, Brentwood and Bel-Air," he said, referring to three wealthy areas.
 
TV Generates Fear
 There is no evidence of that, but such fears have been stirred by breathless reporting by local television stations and by all the preparations being made by large organizations. The computer network at the University of Southern California has spread word of how to respond to an emergency. Loyola High School, a Roman Catholic school near downtown, has asked parents to sign waivers relieving it of responsibility for their children after school. The Orange Street Neighborhood Watch Group in the Wilshire district has urged residents to ready the survival gear they keep in case of earthquakes.
A growing chorus complained that news coverage might cause incidents. "Newspeople who do not live in South-Central L.A. have been whipped up into hysteria," John Mack, president of the Urban League chapter, said on Wednesday's edition of "Which Way L.A.?," a radio discussion show on public radio station KCRW that has become the chief broadcast forum for serious issues that television avoids.
On the same show, Chilton Alphonse, director of the Community Youth Sports and Arts Foundation, complained of camera crews asking youths in South-Central Los Angeles with questions like, "If the officers are found not guilty, you're going to riot, aren't you?"
 
Some Trouble Expected
 Cooler heads expect some trouble but nothing like last year's explosion. "The kind of outbreak we had last year requires an enormous amount of energy," Warren Olney, a veteran television reporter and the host of the radio show, said in an interview.
The Rev. Leonard Jackson, associate pastor of the First African Methodist Episcopal Church, one of the main black churches, agreed. "I strongly believe that peace will prevail," he said. "It would be suicidal for anyone to go against the odds. Who wants to be a martyr?"
On the streets of the South-Central district, the mood is complex, difficult to fathom. The main streets like Crenshaw Boulevard, Vermont Avenue and Central Avenue still show the rubble and desolation of the disorders, though there has been much rebuilding. As night falls and the gang members emerge, Cleve Freeman drove warily through the streets he has known since youth.
He is a leader of the 75th Street/ Crenshaw Block Club, a group of homeowners who try to protect their neat well-kept houses against the ravages of drug gangs. A supervisor for Southern California Edison, he is a member of a growing black middle class that is as fearful of gangs as whites are, if not more. "Even though I am black and raised in a tough part of this city, there are two different cultures of black people," said Mr. Freeman, 45. "They are operating in a different world. We don't know them."
 
Police Officers a Targets
 Mr. Freeman, a reserve police officer, did not foresee a riot, but something just as ominous -- an assault by young blacks on police officers.
And there were heightened tensions in the area this week after two Los Angeles police officers shot and killed 30-year-old Darrell Harts in the driveway of his home on East 93d Street. The police said he had fired at the officers; some witnesses disputed that.
On Thursday evening, with tensions building over the impending verdict, fraternity brothers and friends of the slain man, a college graduate, held a candlelight vigil under the bright red flowers of a bottle brush tree in front of the Southeast police station on East 108th Street. "I am very concerned about the killing of young African-American men," said one of those who spoke, the Rev. Monroe Woods Jr., who counseled calm. "We just do not need another civil uprising in this city."
But the younger black men in the crowd were filled with anger over Mr. Harts's death and spoke darkly of the weapons they say they have for use against the police.
For their part, the police were wary. "We really have no idea whether something's going to happen or not," said Officer Mario Munoz of the 77th Street Division. "I'm sure we'll have some troublemakers try to start something, but I think the readiness of the department right now is pretty good. Generally, when you have expectations that something is going to happen, nothing happens."

HEADLINE: Satellites Bring Information Revolution to China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 10

 BODY:
Four years after China's leaders crushed a movement by millions of prodemocracy protesters, they are facing a new challenge -- one that is quieter and less confrontational but eventually perhaps more serious.
The challenge is most visible in the form of hundreds of thousands of satellite dishes that are sprouting, as the Chinese say, like bamboo shoots after a spring rain. 
 Already millions of Chinese can hook in via satellite to the "global village," bypassing the Communist Party commissars and leaving them feuding over how to respond.
 
State Control Is Slipping
 In short, the information revolution is coming to China, and in the long run it threatens to supplant the Communist revolution. For while political power here grows out of the barrel of a gun, as Mao once observed, it is sustained by the Communist Party's monopoly on news and propaganda -- a monopoly that is now crumbling.
"The Government has already lost control over information," a senior Chinese journalist said. "The leaders may not know it yet, but these days they simply can't control what people know."
Most satellite dishes are technically illegal, but hard-liners are finding themselves stymied in their efforts to organize a crackdown. Fundamentally, their frustrations reflect the headaches that the party encounters as it tries to maintain political controls while liberalizing the economy.
The information revolution in China began in the 1980's, with the spread of short-wave radios and the end of the ban on listening to broadcasts by the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation. But the pace has picked up enormously in the last couple of years.
 
Direct-Dial to the Outside
 Fax machines are everywhere, even in private homes, and direct-dial international telephones are multiplying much more quickly than the number of State Security employees who bug such calls. The number of long-distance phone calls doubled from 1989 to 1991, when 1.7 billion were recorded.
Computers are spreading as well, so that a growing number of people can communicate via electronic bulletin boards and electronic mail. Young people exchange information with Chinese students studying in the United States, and they can even swap computer viruses -- like the one developed a couple of years ago that appears on a screen to ask whether the computer operator likes Prime Minister Li Peng.
If the person at the keyboard says no, regular work can continue. If the person says he likes the Prime Minister, the virus wipes out all the computer's memory.
In Fujian Province, opposite Taiwan, millions of Chinese aim their antennas eastward and tune in Taiwan television news and other programs. In Guangdong Province in the south, families watch Hong Kong television, sometimes with official cable systems.
 
Voices From Abroad
 Short-wave radios have proliferated and are now an important source of news for dissidents and officials alike. Chinese listen not only to BBC and Voice of America but also to broadcasts from Australia, France and Taiwan.
The next technological wave may belong to satellite dishes, which first appeared in shops about a year ago and now seem to be everywhere. In Beijing alone, dozens of shops sell the dishes, typically about five feet in diameter, for about $500 including the receiver.
"Lots of customers can afford them now, because they're hardly more expensive than a video recorder," said Cao Hongxia, a manager at an electronics shop on the bustling Wangfujing Street. "I get people coming in who want to buy a hundred dishes and then resell them elsewhere."
The hard-liners staked out their position recently in a confidential Communist Party document prepared by the city of Beijing. The paper, one of a series about how to improve social order in Beijing as it applies to be host to the Olympics in the year 2000, uses harsh language to argue that satellite dishes can be used to watch pornography and reactionary programming.
 
Some Welcome the Change
 Another briefing paper, prepared by Shanghai authorities and published in "Internal Reference Selections," a confidential magazine, takes the opposite view. It argues that if China is to modernize its economy, then it must give its people access to instant information and embrace new technologies like satellite television.
"We should have confidence in the viewers," the report declares. "We shouldn't seal the window just because a fly might slip in."
Senior Government leaders recently agreed in principle on a crackdown, and they have held inter-ministry meetings in the last week to decide how to proceed. But the authorities seem deeply constrained because of conflicts of interest within the Government.
The Army General Staff Department and the Ministry of Radio, Film and Television, for example, both turn a good profit by selling satellite equipment to the public. The Ministry of Electronics operates a factory that says it plans to build 60,000 to 70,000 satellite dishes this year.
It may seem surprising that Government ministries should manufacture and sell products that the same Government bans. But with China's push toward a market economy in recent years, this is not so unusual.
A clinic in southern China run by the family planning commission switched its focus when it discovered it could make more money as a fertility clinic. And a branch of the official Women's Association was caught last year running a prostitution racket.
 
A Shattered Monolith
 As a result, the Government sometimes resembles not so much a Communist monolith as a disorganized conglomerate. The Politburo, acting as a fractious board of directors, often ignores tacit disobedience.
Even if the central Government ordered a major crackdown, it is unclear that it would be enforced outside the capital. Local governments, always lethargic about implementing edicts they dislike, are making money by running cable television systems that depend on satellite television.
"The leaders are trying to ban the dishes," said another Chinese journalist. "But I don't see how they can succeed."
Governments throughout the world are fretting over the same realization: their armies can repel invading troops but are useless against television broadcasts.
 
Banned Images, New Ideas
 In Arab countries, dishes offer viewers a chance to see programs racier than those broadcast by local stations. In Taiwan, people tune in to mainland China television news programs. In India, millions of people are hooking into cable systems connected to satellite dishes, directly encountering foreign ideas and values that never bother to apply for a visa.
No one yet knows what the sociological or political consequences will be.
China passed a law in 1990 banning the use of satellite dishes to receive foreign television signals, except with permission from the police. But the law does not ban the sale of the dishes, nor even their installation, so long as they are used to receive China's own programming.
"When I bought my dish, the salesman told me that if the police ever asked, I should tell them that I use it only to watch China Central Television," said a 28-year-old businessman who bought his dish a few months ago. "The police know that's absurd, but they can't prove it."
The huge white dishes now perch on the roofs of apartment and office buildings in cities like Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou, and sometimes even on the roofs of newly built peasant homes.
 
Grass-Roots Sabotage
 The latest trend is for employers and "street committees" to erect one or two huge dishes and then hook up everyone in an apartment building for a fee. The street committees are supposed to be the Communist Party's grass-roots monitoring organizations, but they like to make money too.
"We don't have enough people to implement the law against satellite receivers," said Jin Guojun, an official of the Beijing Radio and Television Bureau, and simultaneously the president of the Beijing Cable TV Network. "And the best approach is not to ban satellite dishes and leave it at that, but rather to give the public an alternative -- like cable TV."
At last count, 1,800 cable television systems were operating in China, with 429 set up in just the first three months of this year.
Some simply show videos, but many show satellite programs, of which by far the most popular are those broadcast by Star Television in Hong Kong. A State Statistical Bureau survey several months ago found that 4.8 million households in China can receive Star Television -- presumably a significant underestimation, since the bureau counted only Government-authorized satellite dishes.
"There's a tremendous amount of potential as the economy of China opens up more and more," said Arnold Tucker, executive vice president of Star Television. "That's as true for satellite TV as for toothpaste or ads or bicycles or anything else."
 
Films, Sports and News
 Star Television, which belongs to the stable of companies controlled by Li Ka-shing, a Hong Kong billionaire, gets its revenue only from commercials. It offers five channels: Chinese-language films and television serials; music television; English-language sports; English-language films and serials; and BBC Television news.
The most politically sensitive by far is BBC. Chinese are beginning to discover that the BBC broadcasts a separate Chinese-language soundtrack, and so they can watch the BBC television news in Chinese.
To be sure, most viewers are more interested in sit-coms or cops-and-robber shows than in news programs.
"What people want is entertainment," said Zhang Zedong, manager of the satellite sales counter at a state-owned shop. "They're not so interested in BBC, but rather in MTV and sports and Chinese-language serials."
Yet even mundane programming like Taiwanese sit-coms seems to have a corrosive effect on the authority of the Communist Party. The sit-coms offer a window into how people overseas live, underscoring the wealth and freedom abroad.
American cops-and-robbers shows sometimes play on Chinese television, and viewers often find the plot twists full of surprises -- like the moments when the bad guys are read their rights and allowed to call a lawyer. To some Chinese, that kind of novelty is more memorable than the plot itself.

HEADLINE: An Environmental Plan Threatens an Old Industry

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOODLAND TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 9

 BODY:
The water in the Ward Sand and Materials Company dredging pond is as clear as a cloudless sky as the company's little blue dredge steadily vacuums the pond bottom for sand and gravel to feed the region's concrete mixers.
But however clean the water may be or however well the new pine seedlings grow on the mined-over restoration areas, the independent commission that regulates land use in New Jersey's 1.1 million-acre Pinelands National Reserve seems ready to force out most sand mines like this one. 
 A decision to preserve more of the pinelands by curbing one of the oldest industries in the region -- sand mines supplied glassmakers here beginning in the 18th century -- would be the Pinelands Commission's biggest single regulatory step since the national reserve was carved out of southern New Jersey in 1978.
"I can't think of any other proposal that is more far-reaching than this one," said Richard J. Sullivan, chairman of the commission. The proposal appears to have the support of a majority of the panel's members, but no final vote is expected until January.
 
Proposed Changes
 The proposed changes, strongly opposed by industry and some landowners, would reduce the total allowable mining area to 2,800 acres from the current 10,000 acres. Because as about 900 acres have been mined since the pinelands reserve was created, environmentalists favoring the proposed rules argue that the sand operators could have another 30 years of work before being forced to shut down.
Robert Ellis, who has managed the Ward Sand and Materials site since he opened the mining operation in 1972, would be left 99 acres of the 244 acres remaining in his present mining permit, enough for another 10 or 15 years work at the present rate. But Mr. Ellis maintains that private property rights are at stake in the fight, and does not want to be told by preservationists or anyone else that less than half of what he has is enough.
"What do they mean, 'enough'?" he demanded. "I could argue that it would be enough for them to leave me the hell alone."
The anger that the proposed regulations has sparked among the quarry workers comes just as the pinelands management system, in which development is strictly directed away from natural areas into designated growth areas, is being held up as an example for other states.
The system clusters development on the edges of the reserve and allows landowners in restricted areas to sell their development rights to builders operating within development areas.
 
Pattern for New York
 In New York, Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County Executive, has proposed turning the 138,000-acre Long Island Pine Barrens into a similar reserve, borrowing heavily from the pinelands' preservation system. Mr. Gaffney visited the pinelands Wednesday in preparation for a Pine Barrens management conference scheduled for Monday in Melville.
Last Thursday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed changes in the way the six-million-acre Adirondack State Park, like the pinelands a mix of public and private lands, is managed. The proposal includes elements similar to the pinelands plan.
But the spread of the pinelands idea only enrages many of the "Pineys" who make their living within the borders of the reserve. Phasing out the last big industry in the pinelands, other than cranberry growing and some timber cutting, will increase unemployment, reduce municipal tax receipts and make the South Jersey region less secure, said William J. Cleary, executive director of the New Jersey Concrete and Aggregate Association, which is leading the fight against the new policy on sand mining.
 
44 Companies Operating
 "What disturbs me is that they're going to spread this idea on the basis that the pinelands have been this amazing success, but it's not for the people who live and work here," Mr. Cleary said. "We have taxation problems, unemployment problems, and those are things that are going to come back and haunt places that copy the pinelands in the future."
Some impacts of the proposed changes were supposed to have been spelled out at a special hearing on Thursday. But so many people crowded the Barnegat Township Municipal Building that the meeting was postponed until April 17 so it could be moved to Burlington County College, to make room for what Pinelands Commission members said was the biggest turnout they had seen for a hearing on a proposed rule change.
Digging sand and gravel from the immense, forested sand dune that underlies most of New Jersey's coastal plain is a fairly simple matter for the 44 sand and gravel companies still operating within the reserve. Dredges pump up the material from a maximum allowable depth of 65 feet below the water table and pipe it to machines that separate the sand and gravel by size. The pumped water is passed through special ponds to allow the mud to settle out, and is then returned to the excavation hole, which is filled with water from the underground aquifer.
Once an area is pumped out, the bank of the dredge pond is sloped and new pines are planted on it.
The proposed changes are aimed at phasing out sand dredging in the two most environmentally sensitive areas of the pinelands, the so-called Preservation Area District, covering 365,000 acres, and the Forest Areas, covering 280,000 acres. Two-thirds of the pinelands reserve is privately owned.
 
Worry About Harm
 Since so little else is allowed in these areas, Terrence D. Moore, executive director of the Pinelands Commission said, why should sand mining continue?
"You could go and buy a thousand acres in the Preservation Area for your vacation home or your dream house, and you wouldn't get a permit to build it," Mr. Moore said. "So the interesting question is, if we aren't going to let a person build one house on all that land, should we be allowing an activity that is tearing up hundreds and hundreds of acres?"
The mine operators say that no evidence has surfaced to show that the sand mining is affecting water quality or wildlife outside the mine areas, but Mr. Moore said that the absence of information does not prove that no harm is being done.
"The normal procedure in the pinelands is not to proceed when there is no information available," he said. One possible problem, he said, is that non-native fish might be infiltrating the 65-foot deep dredge ponds, which he said are ecologically different form the shallow ponds that occur naturally in the pinelands.
Mr. Ellis has been fighting the Pinelands Commission since its creation. He believes that changes will eventually impoverish an already heavily regulated region, reduce tax receipts for local townships and ultimately hurt 200,000 pinelands workers who are directly or indirectly dependent on the sand pits.
"And after they take this away," he asked, "what are they going to take away next?"

HEADLINE: Clark Clifford's Judgment

 BODY:
Maneuverings in the courts of New York and Washington have lowered the chances for a satisfying judgment about Clark Clifford, the erstwhile statesman accused of committing fraud for a crooked bank, the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. Several years after B.C.C.I.'s global financial crimes began to surface, the question persists: Was Mr. Clifford a crook himself -- or a dupe, as he claims?
Mr. Clifford, 86 and recovering from a heart operation, is excused from the trial that has just begun in state court in Manhattan. That leaves his law partner, Robert Altman, to plead that both men were deceived about B.C.C.I.'s illegal foreign control of the American bank they chaired. 
 Meanwhile the Justice Department has dropped similar Federal fraud charges against both men rather than try to meet a June 1 trial deadline in Washington. The Federal dismissal may have less bearing on events than Mr. Clifford's health, since Federal prosecutors have never matched the zeal of Robert Morgenthau, Manhattan's District Attorney, for this case.
Ostensibly a funding resource for third world development, B.C.C.I. bankrolled drug lords, laundered their money and looted depositors on a grand scale. American bank regulators accepted Mr. Clifford's assurances that B.C.C.I. was not in control of First American Bankshares, of which he was chairman and Mr. Altman vice chairman. But the regulators, Congressional investigators and prosecutors say otherwise.
It matters whether Mr. Clifford deliberately or unwittingly fronted for international criminals, delaying for years their detection by bank regulators and drug agents. A trial with Mr. Clifford in the dock might spotlight failures by Federal agencies that allowed the crime to flourish.
Mr. Clifford's character, and his decades of prestigious public service as adviser to Presidents and as Secretary of Defense, are side issues at Mr. Altman's trial. The prosecutor plays up Mr. Clifford's public probity that made his assurances effective; the defense emphasizes his brains, saying he was too smart to risk his reputation on shady deals. But he won't be squarely judged unless later deemed fit to stand trial.
Whatever happens now, one Washington industry has been severely shaken: the special practice of law in the nation's capital. Lawyers there trade heavily on their reputations and claim they deserve social credit for policing their clients. Guilty or innocent, tried or excused, Clark Clifford, a towering figure in that trade, has shattered the image.
