HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
No Success, No Power

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Success feeds power. And President Clinton has little prospect of a power-building success in foreign policy, one that would catapult him to new stature at home and abroad.
From potshots in Iraq to human rights in China, from genocide in Bosnia to trade negotiations with Europe and Japan, from propping up Boris Yeltsin in Russia to cajoling Arabs back to the bargaining table with Israelis, Bill Clinton faces mostly quicksand and mudholes. His best bet for a quick diplomatic score might be in Haiti, but even there peace talks remain wobbly. 
 For 50 years, Presidents have defined themselves decisively and dramatically by their actions on the world stage. John F. Kennedy flew to the Berlin Wall to proclaim his solidarity with besieged Berliners. Ronald Reagan's popularity soared after he "conquered" Grenada. George Bush led a world crusade against Saddam Hussein and instantly transformed himself into a world leader.
Mr. Clinton is not likely to have such opportunities, and his foreign policy successes are likely to be much more modest. In his search for post-cold-war glory, he may well have to focus less on traditional security concerns and more on international economics. Money lacks the sex appeal of a tidy, victorious war, but has its political attractions in times of economic distress.
Americans would not applaud Mr. Clinton's dragging them into military conflicts. They might even be quietly grateful to him for making questionable excuses to avoid intervention. But they will not show their gratitude by lifting him onto their shoulders as a non-conquering hero.
The new President's choices in Bosnia and Iraq are like President Lyndon Johnson's dilemma in Vietnam: damned if he got into an Asian land war, damned if he gave the Vietnamese Communists a victory at the negotiating table.
No nation now has the stomach for another fight against Saddam Hussein or a new war against the Serbs. At the same time, none is openly willing to accept Saddam's staying in power. Nor are American and European leaders prepared for what has become the only realistic way to stop the slaughter of Bosnians -- trisecting Bosnia among the warring factions and thereby legitimizing Serb aggression and genocide. Dreading both war and peace, Mr. Clinton and the others prefer the classic approach: stall and pray for a miracle.
No miracles are needed on China policy. Mr. Clinton simply has to walk the high wire between standing up for human rights and getting along with this growing power on the Asian block. Best for him to explain this difficult stunt forthrightly now before people start accusing him of playing games.
Conversely, a little diplomatic sleight of hand will help Mr. Clinton promote a Syrian-Israeli deal. First the two sides must position themselves for agreement. When the time is ripe, he has to jump in personally and powerfully.
Mr. Clinton handled the Vancouver love feast with Mr. Yeltsin well, yet the Russian leader still could lose his referendum later this month. A Yeltsin defeat won't destroy Mr. Clinton, because he's worked so hard for more aid to Russia. But avoiding political blame for "losing Russia" does not constitute a diplomatic triumph.
The U.S. President needs to demonstrate that he knows how to orchestrate a triumph and close a tough diplomatic deal. He could help reinstate democracy in Haiti if he involved himself directly.
The man from Arkansas has to keep his eye on all these political and military flash points. But the real payoff for him is bound to be in the international economic arena. At home and abroad, everyone wants growth and jobs, which means promoting freer trade.
Mr. Clinton's first test will come on April 16 when he meets with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan. Japanese-American trade has gotten tense and messy. The two industrial giants could slip into mini-trade wars unless the two leaders signal a commitment to compromise. That will require both to show some political guts.
It's going to be harder for Bill Clinton to make his mark in the world arena than it was for his predecessors. But he needs to start somewhere. He has to begin lining up diplomatic triumphs to prove his mettle and skill. For without successes, he will lack the power to lead an unruly world.

HEADLINE: A Clinton Report Card, So Far

BYLINE: By Arthur Schlesinger Jr.; Arthur Schlesinger Jr. is professor in the humanities at the City University of New York.

 BODY:
Before long, the 100 days will be upon us, and we can expect a rush to judgment on the Clinton Presidency. Of course the 100 days test is silly. Franklin Roosevelt gave the 100 days mythic status, but he had a national crisis so urgent and indisputable that the country pleaded for action and Congress dared not say him nay. Except for F.D.R., no President has ever accomplished much legislatively in his first 100 days. Still, the 100 days represent a shakedown cruise that tells the people a good deal about a new President -- and tells him a good deal about the people.
For a man who a short year ago was an unknown quantity to most Americans, and a very dubious figure to some of them, Mr. Clinton has quickly established himself as an articulate, ebullient, untiring and, thus far, rather endearing occupant of the White House. 
 He is plainly a man of marked intellectual force and lively intellectual curiosity, a good listener and a good talker, generally cheerful though given to flashes of bad temper. He is at home with ideas, enjoys politics, understands that successful government requires persuasion and consent and appears to have a guileless faith in the latent idealism and decency of the American people. And in Albert Gore Jr. the nation has (for a change) a serious and thoughtful Vice President.
In a way, Mr. Clinton is a merger of two Democratic leaders of the previous generation who also combined professionalism in politics with idealism in policy -- John Kennedy and Hubert Humphrey. Mr. Clinton has J.F.K.'s analytical bent, his detachment and his mastery of detail, and he has Humphrey's exuberance, his gregariousness and his inability to say anything briefly.
Like Kennedy and Humphrey and Lyndon Johnson and like F.D.R. and Harry Truman before them, Mr. Clinton believes in government as an instrument of reform. Like J.F.K. 30 years ago and F.D.R. 30 years before that, he takes over from Presidents who had no use for government at all.
When Ronald Reagan became President, he signaled the change in national direction by proclaiming in his first inaugural: "Government is not the solution to our problem. Government is the problem." Get government off our backs, the Reaganites declared, and our problems will solve themselves, or rather the free market will solve them.
President Clinton took care to respond in his address to Congress, "I want to talk with you about what the Government can do, because I believe government must do more." He evidently sees himself in the apostolic tradition. One of his early acts was to make a pilgrimage, in the company of F.D.R.'s grandson and Robert Kennedy's son, to the Roosevelt house in Hyde Park. And one of his favorite quotations, used often in the campaign and since, is F.D.R.'s call for "bold, persistent experimentation. It is common sense to take a method and try it: If it fails, admit it frankly and try another. But above all, try something." Except for the part about admitting failure frankly, that was the story of Roosevelt's New Deal.
In embracing the Roosevelt-Truman-Kennedy-Johnson inheritance, President Clinton departs from neo-conservative Democrats who backed his candidacy and now feel aggrieved by lack of subsequent recognition. He differs too from Jimmy Carter, who disbelieved in government, disliked the Kennedys and refused as President even to send a greeting to a reunion of New Dealers celebrating the anniversary of F.D.R.'s first inauguration.
Oddly enough for a believer in government, Mr. Clinton has been dilatory in forming one. I cannot recall a time when a new Administration taking over the White House from the other party has taken so long in making key appointments.
The Department of Defense, for example, still lacks most of its top officials. No doubt filling out financial forms, F.B.I. investigations, etc., account for some of the delay. But the Administration's "diversity" requirement -- "looking like America" -- compounds the problem. The determination to bring in more women and minorities is praiseworthy. But the mechanical application of a diversity standard may at times sacrifice substantive competence to what John Kennedy used to call "visual reassurance."
When Mr. Clinton says he believes government must do more, he does not mean government should do everything. He has no doubt that the free market is the great engine of production, distribution and growth. But he is not under the illusion that the market by itself can cure a lot of the troubles that assail the Republic. The market by itself will not repair America's crumbling infrastructure, or produce universal health care, or protect the environment, or promote racial justice, or save the public schools, or rehabilitate the cities, or salvage the homeless. The market cannot even provide jobs for all Americans ready and willing to work. He sees no alternative to a measure of affirmative government.
Like Roosevelt in 1933 and Kennedy in 1961, Mr. Clinton has the benefit of the pent-up flood of ideas germinating in universities and think-tanks during the conservative phase of the political cycle.
His reform agenda casts an astonishingly wide net: from health insurance and national service through election finance and abortion for poor women to support for high technology and higher fees for logging, grazing and mining on the public lands. Perhaps most important of all, a grand opportunity awaits him to reconstruct the Supreme Court.
But the centerpiece of his agenda, on the success of which much else depends, is his economic plan. In the wine-and-roses days of Kennedy and Johnson, Federal funds were relatively available for social programs. This is no longer the case. Every Republican President since the New Deal has hoped to stop the advance of the welfare state. But Ronald Reagan was the first to figure out how to do it. By cutting taxes, he contrived deficits so large as to discourage further social spending. Then, by persuading voters of the innate depravity of tax increases and by persuading politicians that raising taxes was political suicide, he made it hard to reduce deficits except by social retrenchment.
In February, Mr. Clinton proposed a comprehensive plan designed to deal all at once with the needs for deficit reduction, fiscal stimulus, infrastructure modernization and increased taxes. The plan is based on the premise that long-term growth is the only reliable means of bringing deficits down. It aims to promote such growth not only by short-run stimulus but also by strengthening the foundations for enduring growth -- that is, by rehabilitating infrastructure, retraining workers, improving education, reinforcing research and development.
Herbert Stein, Richard Nixon's chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, described it as "probably the most far-reaching effort ever made by a President to control the budget deficit." Most of the plan has moved ahead with minor adjustments, but the $16.3 billion fiscal-stimulus package has provoked a Republican filibuster in the Senate, and action has been postponed until after the Easter recess. The Republican argument is that Mr. Clinton's is a pork-barrel program and that it is not even necessary because recovery is just around the corner.
In fact, the so-called recovery is feeble. It has not been accompanied by corresponding re-employment; indeed, the economy actually lost 22,000 jobs in March. A higher percentage of Americans -- more than one out of 10 -- now resorts to food stamps than at any time since the modern food-stamp program started in 1964. Opponents of stimulus forget that a market economy is quite capable of reaching equilibrium at a low as at a high level of employment. The stronger argument against the package is that it is too small, not too large. Japan, also faced with stagnation, is contemplating a $100 billion package.
Stimulus would seem a good idea. But no one really knows what is likely to work. Anyone under the impression that economics is an exact science should examine the recent Wall Street Journal in which 10 American winners of the Nobel Prize in economics assessed the Clinton plan. The result was cacophony. Economists are about as useful as astrologers in predicting the future (and, like astrologers, they never let failure on one occasion diminish certitude on the next).
There is even dispute as to how tragically we must take budget deficits. Conservative supply-siders like Jude Wanniski and liberal Keynesians like Robert Eisner join in regarding deficit reduction as an overrated issue. For all a mere historian knows, they may be right. In view of the discord within the guild, Mr. Clinton has a point in pinning his flag on F.D.R.'s theory of experimentation.
The Republican filibuster against the fiscal stimulus package is an important if unappreciated step in the education of a President. Obstructionist tactics may identify the Republicans as the party of unemployment and gridlock. Still, they are only doing what an opposition party is supposed to do: opposing. And they are thereby reminding the new President of a difficulty he will face again and again: the difficulty created by the constitutional separation of powers.
Theodore Roosevelt once clenched his fist and said to his young kinsman Franklin Roosevelt, "Sometimes I wish I could be President and Congress too." F.D.R., telling the story 30 years later, added, "I suppose if the truth were told, he is not the only President that has had that idea." The thought may well be passing through President Clinton's mind.
He is already starting to do what the Roosevelts did so well: carrying his program to the country. A lot of nonsense has been written about the iniquity of Mr. Clinton's "permanent campaign." What higher obligation does a President have than to explain his intentions to the people and persuade them that the direction he wishes to go is right? Politics in a democracy is, at the end, an educational process.
Mr. Clinton is also dealing with opposition in another traditional way: by concessions. This is trickier terrain. When a concession policy goes too far, Presidents can concede away the heart of their proposals. Mr. Clinton is already in some trouble for the abandonment of campaign promises, and he will be in far more serious trouble if he starts abandoning Presidential promises.
His quick retreat on grazing, mining and logging fees and certain farm subsidies and his acceptance of exemptions from the energy tax may well persuade Congress that he is an easy fellow to push around -- unless, of course, concessions on minor points assure victory on major ones. Capitulation to the Republican demand that he cut the stimulus program might send a disastrous message to the Hill and the nation.
In due course, Mr. Clinton will learn, as all Presidents learn, that if his hope is to redefine the Republic, he can't please all the people all the time. Some of the most "divisive" Presidents -- Jackson, Lincoln, the Roosevelts -- are accounted among the greatest.
The ability of foreign policy to upset desired priorities is another step in the President's education. Mr. Clinton is no isolationist and regards the revitalization of America as necessary not only for its own sake but for sake of giving foreign policy a solid domestic base. Yet he could hardly have expected the barrage of foreign crises -- Yeltsin, Bosnia, Somalia, Saddam Hussein, GATT, North American Free Trade Agreement, Israeli-Palestine peace talks, North Korean nuclear weapons -- clamoring for instant attention. Still, he has passed his first summit test with distinction, and in his well-reasoned argument for aid to Russia he can count on a degree of bipartisan support.
The political tide is still turning. Kennedy came to the White House in a similar mixed-up time of transition from one phase of the cycle to the next; and, like Kennedy in 1961, President Clinton has narrow Congressional margins in the face of contradictory pressures, some urging him forward to activism, some pulling him back toward conservatism.
But if the past is any precedent, the tide will soon be running fast in the activist direction. If the cyclical rhythm holds, the 1996 election should do for Mr. Clinton what the 1936 election did for Roosevelt and the 1964 election did for Johnson (and would have done for Kennedy): confirm the course and give a reform program the unmistakable stamp of popular approval.
Political leadership appears in collapse around the planet. In Russia, Boris Yeltsin is fighting for his life. China is run by octogenarians. In France, Francois Mitterrand has gone down to humiliating defeat. In Japan and Italy, the political system is unraveling. In Canada, the Prime Minister has announced his resignation. In Britain, Germany, Spain, India, South Africa and elsewhere, governments are in deep trouble.
Only in the U.S. does there seem a surge of confidence and hope. If the young President can rise to the occasion -- and he seems to be doing his damnedest -- he can make quite a difference to the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Filling 'Papa's' Radical Shoes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As another child of a radical 60's visionary, I offer my opinions to provide further evidence that we won't go away. 
 My name is Andrew Hoffman. I'm the son of the late Abbie Hoffman: 60's radical, 70's fugitive and 80's environmental crusader. I am 32 and an artist. My half-brother, America Hoffman, 22, is an electronics expert in San Francisco. My sister, Ilya Hoffman, 30, is graduating from Western New England Law School and plans to work as a criminal lawyer. My sister and I grew up in Cambridge, Mass., where we sat in on Harvard University courses, and with our mother, Sheila, attended lectures by Herbert Marcuse. Dick Gregory's "No More Lies" is one of the first books I read.
We accompanied Papa to many rallies and witnessed a few days of the Chicago Eight trial. We visited him on an island in the St. Lawrence River, where, using the name Barry Freed, he and Johanna Lawrenson helped to save the river.
Ever since he left me a legacy instead of an estate, I have been more active. Like him, I am involved with politics in a theatrical, radical way.
In 1989 in Boston, I held a memorial benefit for my father called Organizers International, to draw bickering left-wing groups together for a night of community fund-raising, music and coalition. There was a feeling of unity sadly lacking in liberal politics today.
Last summer, I was arrested in Chicago because of my work in a needle-exchange program to prevent the spread of AIDS.
I am setting up America's Soup Kitchen on Wheels (Askow), a nonprofit corporation in Boston, to feed, clothe and befriend homeless people. We are involved with street theater on college campuses to feed people's minds as well as their bellies. I plan to write "Son of 'Steal This Book.' "
I am part of the train of enthusiasts working for peaceful revolution, like David Dellinger ("From Yale to Jail"). Being a revolutionary is as simple as making whatever efforts one can to arrest the ongoing slide toward an environmentally polluted and socially toxic society. We have to fight corporate insensitivity and the power and greed it breeds. We must move toward economic and racial justice if we are to have a true democracy and avoid violent rebellion, like the Los Angeles riots. Everyone can make a difference; all they have to do is get involved.
 
ANDREW HOFFMAN
Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: How to Help Russia And Create U.S. Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Military Cuts: A Millstone for Ex-Workers" (front page, April 5) describes the difficult plight of workers laid off because of cuts in military spending. "President Urges America to Back Help for Moscow" (front page, April 2) reports that only 41 percent of American adults favor giving economic aid to help reform Russia's economy. Many people oppose helping Russia as long as so many Americans are out of work. 
 Why not solve both of those problems in one stroke? Building modern oil-drilling equipment, fiber-optics telephone networks, computers, food-processing equipment and technology to clean up the environment, which Russia needs desperately, could create jobs for many unemployed defense workers.
Helping Russia and the other former Soviet republics become free and prosperous countries can employ even more Americans than building bombs and missiles to destroy them, and serves our own security better in the long run.
 
DIETRICH FISCHER
Professor of Computer Science
Pace University
Robbinsville, N.J., April 5, 1993

HEADLINE: Plight of Architects Who Are Women

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
IF you are an architect, particularly an architect who is a woman, the maxim "Stay alive until '95" is wearing thin.
"By '95, the building industry is supposed to have rebounded, but those of us affiliated with construction are skeptical," said Erika Krieger, an architect and now Mount Vernon's Building Commissioner. "We sense the downturn that started long before the administration had recognized it formally because when it comes to women architects, it's the old story of last hired, first fired, and when the recession hits, among the first to be let go by the larger architectural firms were women architects. There had never been a lot of us in the profession until recently." 
 Ms. Krieger, a registered architect who previously ran her own architectural business in Dobbs Ferry, has been working in her city post for a little more than a year.
 
A Demanding Position
 "As the recession began to worsen, those of us in practice as one-person firms began to quickly see the handwriting on the wall," Ms. Krieger said. "The larger firms were willing to take on smaller projects, leaving the rest of us competing for fewer jobs.
"When I heard of the building commissioner's position opening up, I applied for it immediately. I'm a native of Mount Vernon, and I know the city well. I still have a practice, but it is limited to a few clients for whom I do residential work and a couple of small offices."
As Building Commissioner, Ms. Krieger has a staff of 16 to deal with literally "everything to do with building -- from reviewing housing plans and heat complaints to demolition," she said. "It's a demanding position, and being an architect is helpful."
 
'Architecture Is Underpaid
 Ms. Krieger, 36, is licensed in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut. She said that when she graduated from McGill University in Montreal, 20 percent of the class was women. "Now women make up 50 percent of newly graduated architects, and that's good," she said. "What is bad is that most of them can't find jobs today after going through tough and demanding courses. As professions go, architecture is underpaid. Those of us in it really love it."
Noel R. F. Shaw Jr., president of the Westchester/Mid-Hudson chapter of the American Institute of Architects, said that all architects are having trouble finding jobs in Westchester.
"It's probably the worst time in a decade for architects in the area," Mr. Shaw said. "Our association membership has decreased by about 20 percent this year. I think architects have either left the profession or else they are out of work and can't pay their dues."
New residential construction is almost nonexistent, Mr. Shaw said, adding that the one bright spot is renovation. "Residential and commercial renovations have picked up, and we hope that is a sign that this year is going to be better."
 
Renovation Filling the Gap
 Renovation jobs are keeping architects alive, said Suellen DeFrancis, head of her own architectural and interior-design firm in Scarsdale.
"Having a dual profession, wearing two hats, as an architect and an interior designer, has been a strong selling point for me," Ms. DeFrancis said. "During the recession it is an advantage to be able to tell clients that you can take on the whole job, from drafting plans for a new roof down to installing the carpet, and bring it in more economically than two different professionals would be able to do."
 
Handmade Tiles
 Ms. DeFrancis added: "I find that in the recession there is some good, because you get top value for renovation and restoration work. The contractors who have survived are willing to do smaller jobs. Good workers are plentiful, and many excellent craftsmen are available. People are staying put, and many have refinanced their houses favorably, which has freed up money for renovation."
Ms. DeFrancis is now renovating a three-story 1908 American Craftsman house in Bronxville for Eloise Morgan, her client. "The house, which appeared in the November 1912 edition of House and Garden magazine as a good example of the Arts and Crafts movement, is being restored as much as possible," Ms. DeFrancis said.
"We're working from old photographs and, for example, in the lodge room, which was originally an informal billiards and game room, the sliding doors installed by previous owners have been removed and stone work is being done on the fireplace. And the dropped ceiling, also put in by a former owner, has been taken out," Ms. DeFrancis added.
In the living room, she said, tiles are being handmade to match the old tiles by the same company that did the original work.
"The fake molding and the bookcases, which were also added by other owners, are being replaced," she said. "The work is fascinating. We started about three years ago, and when we are finished all 12 rooms will have been restored."
 
'I Feel I Am Very Lucky'
 Ms. DeFrancis's assistant, Theresa Beyer, a registered architect, takes her 7-month-old infant to the office. "Few offices are so flexible, and there are few jobs around, so I feel I am very lucky," Ms. Beyer said. "In this profession it's very important to keep a finger on the pulse. When you are away too long, you lose contacts, and when you're ready to go back, it becomes harder to convince clients to hire you."
Barbara Rogge Maloy, who was an art major in college, said she always wanted to be an architect but waited until her children were grown to go to architectural school. "I commuted to the New York Institute of Technology from Katonah for three years," Ms. Maloy said. "And then when I passed my exam to become registered in 1990, it was probably the worst of times for new architects. There was a trickle-down effect going on. Medium-size firms with high overhead were hit the hardest so they began competing with smaller firms who were becoming even smaller still."
Yet Ms. Maloy, now a member of the board of the Westchester chapter of the American Institute of Architects, said she was surprised that she was offered a job in an architect's office in Greenwich. "I know my art background helped," she said. "It gave me an edge as an architect."
Six months ago she started her own practice in Katonah.
"What happened was that several people approached me and queried me about residential renovations and additions, and so I took the plunge," she said. "I've done a few jobs, and currently I'm working on a very interesting project: a generation-span house, which means carving out a wing with a separate entrance but connected to the house -- for my client's elderly mother. I think the demand for that type of flexible three-generation housing is certainly growing. And I enjoy this kind of assignment."
 
Working for Herself
 Susan R. Bresler, a graduate of Cornell University's School of Architecture and Harvard University's School of Business, is also licensed as a contractor in Florida, but Ms. Bresler said she is waiting for the upturn in the economy before she starts her own business.
"In the interim, I am working for myself," Ms. Bresler, who lives in Mamaroneck, said. "I'm designing a house for my own family, which includes my husband and three young sons. I'm going to do my own contracting and hope to start building by summer."
Ms. Bresler, who intends to specialize in residential design, said that although she believes that men and women have the same architectural capabilities, when it comes to residential design, women may have an edge.
"It's not a sexist thing but a practical observation I've made," she said. "Women still do most of the work in the home, and a woman architect understands her client's needs firsthand. I look at home design as a jigsaw puzzle. It's a matter of best fitting the site, the house and the family together to make a coherent whole."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Eloise Morgan, right, homeowner, reviewing plans with Suellen DeFrancis, architect; Ms. Morgan and Ms. DeFrancis in one of the rooms that will be renovated at the house in Bronxville. (Photographs by Susan Harris for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1391 words

HEADLINE: Focus; Seattle;
Developers Turning to Farms and Forests

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
HOME builders are turning to virgin forests and farmland far from this city's job markets because closer sites are locked up in land-use disputes.
Longtime developers like William Conner are rethinking strategies and focusing on rural towns because, they say, the state's 1989 Growth Management Act requires cities to designate certain areas as rural, closing thousands of acres to development. 
 The act was a response to the alarm of residents who saw a 1980's-type housing boom, spurred by a job spurt at Boeing, creating urban sprawl, chaotic traffic and soaring home prices in the suburbs.
Seattle sprawls for about 20 miles along Puget Sound and for two decades developers have followed the Interstate 5 corridor to the north toward Everett and south to Kent and Tacoma, turning the area into a congested, 100-mile-long megacity. Since the early 80's the Kent Valley's lush farmlands have given way to homes, strip malls and warehouses.
With Interstate 90, on which work began in the early 80's, nearing completion, Mr. Conner and other builders now are looking 30 miles east of Seattle in towns like North Bend, Snoqualmie and Carnation. I-90 stretches eastward through the Snoqualmie Valley into the rugged Cascade Mountains.
"We shouldn't be in these towns," said Mr. Conner. "They're a long way out." He said that he would rather be on I-90 some 15 miles closer to Seattle on the Sammamish Plateau, but that zoning there prevented development.
Some Seattle workers also don't want to be in these towns or on the east side of Lake Washington because they must cross it on one of the two bridges, where rush hour traffic often is snarled. One bridge section, damaged in a 1990 storm, is still being replaced.
Snoqualmie Valley towns also can be snowy, making commuting difficult. Farther east, at Snoqualmie Pass, winter avalanches often close I-90 for hours or days and big-rig trucks line up for miles waiting for roads to reopen.
Mr. Conner has watched the growth patterns change since he formed Conner Development in 1957. He will build about 140 homes this year, the same as in 1992, compared to 180 homes a year when the market was strong.
Near North Bend, he sold 50 speculative homes in his Riverpoint project in 1992 at prices of $224,000 to $285,000. The appeal there is one-acre lots with stunning views of the Cascades. To lure buyers a year ago, Mr. Conner urged each visitor to cut a Christmas tree on the forested lots that had to be cleared.
This winter, because of the poor economy, he didn't have a bite on the last seven Riverpoint homes until mid-February, when he sold three in one week. An offer on a fourth was canceled because the hopeful buyer's company lost an important contract when Boeing pared production.
Uncertainties at Boeing contributed to sluggish home sales in the last half of 1992 and the market has not yet snapped back. The aerospace company has been cutting jobs for more than a year and announced in February it would give pink slips to 15,000 more Seattle-area workers this year and 4,000 next year. Builders are concerned over how this will affect future sales but say a bright spot is that companies such as Microsoft are healthy.
MOST of the Riverpoint buyers were from Seattle or its suburbs and are professionals working for Boeing or Microsoft, both of which are based in Redmond, an east-side suburb.
The North Bend City Council has been besieged with development proposals and annexation requests. In Washington, a large land owner or group of owners in an unincorporated area outside a city's limits can ask the city for annexation. Some developers have sought this because North Bend allows a 15,000-square-foot minimum lot size compared to mostly five-acre lots in King County.
The influx of "outsiders" angers many residents who are fighting development. At council hearings, they have protested development, angry that soaring home prices are causing property taxes to double, and concerned that runoff from mountain ridges cleared for houses will flood their homes. They say their children will not be able to afford homes there and they fear gridlock in towns like North Bend, which now only has one stoplight, or in Snoqualmie, which has none. Opposition initially halted one of Mr. Conner's projects, Tannerwood, near North Bend. Last fall, King County denied his application to build 109 homes, saying it would threaten the rural character of the area. He won an appeal taken to the King County Zoning and Subdivision Office and expects to get his approvals within several weeks.
"IN our eyes, Tannerwood is one of the last pieces of land left for development near Interstate 90," Mr. Conner said. "Most of the area has been downzoned to 5-acre lots."
His land costs, he said, have soared by $7,000 an acre since he first optioned the property in 1992 and record high lumber prices will add $5,000 to the price of a home.
"I've got $12,000 per lot I've got to get rid of to appeal to the same market segment," he said. "I will have to trim about 200 square feet from the size of the house."
To test market strength and preference, he will at first build a half dozen speculative houses of 2,400 to 2,600 square feet using several designs.
Gordon and Karen Byrd, who sold their home in Chicago eight months ago and left the advertising field, would like to buy in Tannerwood. "You can get more for your money," Mr. Byrd said. "Friends say their kids thrive in the school system here. And there is no busing, the reason we won't buy in Seattle."
Banks, including Seafirst, Mr. Conner's banker of 30 years, have stiffened rules on lending and require him to invest 10 to 40 percent of his costs up front before they will provide loans. Until about 1991 banks lent 100 percent, with few questions asked -- a major factor in the savings-and-loan debacle.
Nearly five years ago Mr. Conner and a fellow Bellevue builder, Fred Burnstead, spent $1 million, or $20,000 an acre, for 50 acres in Snoqualmie. The property is next to the site of Snoqualmie Ridge, a 2,000-home, billion-dollar residential development proposed in 1989 by the Weyerhaeuser Real Estate Company. It has been held up by financing problems and a long approval process. Nothing has been built yet. And last fall the Snoqualmie Indian tribe opposed access road plans, saying Wyerhaeuser had not adequately considered the tribe's culture and heritage.
The two partners cannot get their project under way until Weyerhaeuser builds roads and utilities. When Weyerhaeuser does move forward, Mr. Conner and Mr. Burnstead could be among those building the Snoqualmie Ridge homes.
Paul Wozniak, manager of the real estate and land department of John L. Scott's, a large Seattle broker, said he believed that by 1995 land for new housing would reach "a critically low level." He just made a study that indicates the shortage will most greatly affect affordable housing in the Puget Sound area. Causing the shortage are increasingly complex development regulations on several government levels, unwillingness by banks to lend money to developers and rising mitigation fees for roads and schools.
MR. WOZNIAK said that in Redmond, two developers with adjacent land, Quadrant and Blackhawk Port Blakely Communities, had spent $10 million on development fees since 1990 but recently refused to invest more until major hurdles were cleared.
Seattle, which supplies water to most of King County, is embroiled in regional water issues and says it will no longer commit to providing water. The state also has yet to build access to Route 18, which links up to I-90, from the Snoqualmie Ridge project.
Mr. Conner started building homes along I-90 in 1985 at a development called Klahanie, in Issaquah, 15 miles from Seattle. When he began there, he said, even Issaquah "seemed like it was too far out," but "now I consider it close in."
Mr. Conner paid $19,000 for 50- by 100-foot lots for $85,000 Klahanie homes. The homes have sold well because they were marketed as affordable in an attractive foothills setting with good freeway access.
In recent months, as the last few land parcels available there rose in price to $65,000 a lot, Mr. Conner decided against even bidding because the homes would sell for $200,000. Now he wishes he had bid because of the scarcity of available land.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Conner at his Riverpoint project in North Bend, east of Seattle. (Doug Wilson for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PERSON: CONNER, WILLIAM (HOUSING DEVELOPER); KING, HARRIET MICHAEL MCMAHON (54%); MICHAEL MCMAHON (54%); 

LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1993

HEADLINE: FOCUS;

HEADLINE: Putting the Poor in Uniform

BYLINE: By Russell F. Weigley; Russell F. Weigley, the Distinguished University Professor at Temple University, is the author of "The Age of Battles: The Quest for Decisive Warfare From Breitenfeld to Waterloo."

 BODY:

WORKING-CLASS WAR
American Combat Soldiers and Vietnam.
By Christian G. Appy.
365 pp. Chapel Hill:
The University of North Carolina Press.
Cloth, $39.95. Paper, $14.95.
 
RED THUNDER, TROPIC LIGHTNING
The World of a Combat Division in Vietnam.
By Eric M. Bergerud.
Illustrated. 328 pp. Boulder, Colo.:
Westview Press. $24.95. 
 HE war in Vietnam corrupted nearly everything American that it touched. Not least, it sorely injured the equalitarian ideal by imposing its burdens of combat, wounds and death with gross disproportion upon the underclasses of American society. Yet this particular toll of the war has not received its due recognition.
Christian G. Appy, in "Working-Class War," reminds us of the disturbing truth that some 80 percent of the 2.5 million enlisted men who served in Vietnam -- out of 27 million men who reached draft age during the war -- came from working-class and impoverished backgrounds. Eric M. Bergerud -- a professor of military and American history at Lincoln University in San Francisco whose first book was "The Dynamics of Defeat: The Vietnam War in Hau Nghia Province" -- now offers a microcosmic view of the fighting that further develops the implications of the working-class character of the United States Army.
Mr. Bergerud's explicit concern in "Red Thunder, Tropic Lightning" is not with such class issues but with a detailed recounting of the experiences of the 25th Infantry Division, the "Tropic Lightning Division," so called because of its historic base in Hawaii and its taro-leaf and lightning-bolt shoulder patch. But his book closely complements Mr. Appy's.
Both, for example, emphasize a tactical difference between the Vietnam War and other American wars that acquires special significance in light of Mr. Appy's theme. Because, lacking a better strategy, the United States made imposing a high body count upon the enemy a central purpose of its Vietnam campaigns, and because the enemy was difficult to find for the purpose of killing him, American infantry habitually acted as human bait to lure the National Liberation Front forces, the Vietcong in general and occasionally the North Vietnamese Army out of hiding, so aircraft and artillery could maul them.
The modern American military has always preferred to substitute firepower for manpower, to accomplish the killing with large and high-technology weapons. In Vietnam, however, the substitution was incomplete. Although infantrymen were not expected to do the main fighting, they had to offer themselves up as sacrifices to precipitate the fighting, or rather the killing by heavy weapons. Because a hostile, or at least distrustful, local population severely limited intelligence of the enemy's whereabouts, the American infantry tended to blunder into ambushes.
But from the perspective of the American high command, the blundering was not altogether unintentional. If an ambush drew out the enemy, then it was worthwhile. Whether this role as sacrificial offering, as bait, would have been permitted had the troops represented a fuller cross section of American society, if the educated middle class had been losing more of its sons in the process, is an especially unpleasant question for the reader of these books to ponder.
Both books also evoke the sense of futility that accompanied the infantry's mission as bait. The soldiers seemed to "hump the boonies" endlessly, prowl through jungles, marshes, savannas and mountains, parched by heat. Often in the drier areas they were so thirsty that when they reached a watercourse they drank mud filled with insects before bothering to pop their disinfectant pills into their canteens. All the while they were fighting off leeches; at best, they were half-sick and dog-tired long before the enemy allowed them to complete their sacrificial role.
The whereabouts of the enemy was almost always mysterious, but the lay of the land was not; not least of the reasons for feeling it was all senseless was the return over the same ground again and again, forever retaking landmarks that had been visited a week or a month before. The men came to know their area of operations all too well, but they never securely "owned" any of it. Again, the question arises: would the United States have supported a war so lacking in evident strategic purpose had its Army comprised different classes of men?
Mr. Appy, who teaches history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, deals especially well with the apparent paradox that the working-class soldiers' families back home mainly opposed the antiwar movement, and for that matter so with few exceptions did the soldiers themselves. Opposing the antiwar movement, however, was not the same as supporting the war. The middle-class and upper-class war protesters at home, particularly the college students, fumbled their chance to forge some sort of unity with the soldiers. They did so by speaking and behaving in ways that emphasized the social and economic divisions between them and the fighting men. Mr. Appy acknowledges that in time the protesters helped reform some of the inequities of the Selective Service System, but he finds that on the whole their attitudes toward the soldiers were arrogant, sanctimonious and insensitive to the moral quandaries of those who had to fight.
All of this retains its pertinence. The present all-volunteer armed forces still suffer from much of the class skewing of the Vietnam-era draft. The consequent difficulties could therefore recur. Nevertheless, the United States Government demonstrated during the Persian Gulf war that it had profited at least in some degree from the experience of Vietnam, that it can conduct a limited war not only more purposefully but also, through mobilizing National Guard and Reserve units, with greater concern for equity. The antiwar movement, in contrast, re-emerged during the gulf war to show that its members still resided mentally in the 1960's and had learned nothing. The nation is not where we might wish it to be either in democratizing the burdens of war or in trying to halt or curtail it. Mr. Appy and Mr. Bergerud provide information and insights that move one to reflect on both issues.

GRAPHIC: Photo: American soldiers waiting to board helicopters bound for Saigon on the first day of the Tet offensive in 1968. (Gerry S. Schooler/From "Red Thunder, Tropic Lightning")

HEADLINE: U.S. Aides in Egypt Said to Have Met With Group Tied to New York Blast

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, April 11

 BODY:
Officials from the United States Embassy have had meetings since 1991 with militant leaders of the Islamic Group, an organization that is being scrutinized in connection with the World Trade Center bombing, said two members of the group who took part in the sessions and Western diplomats who said they were aware of the contacts.
The militants, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the initial meetings had been held at the embassy's request and centered on allegations of human rights abuses committed by the Egyptian Government. 
 They said that sessions had been held in Egypt and elsewhere but that the contacts had been suspended after the bombing of the World Trade Center on Feb. 26. The blast killed 6 people, injured 1,000 others and caused hundreds of millions of dollars in damage.
 
Exiled Cleric as Mentor
 Several suspects charged in connection with the bombing attended services at mosques in New Jersey and Brooklyn to hear the preaching of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, an Egyptian cleric regarded as a key spiritual mentor of the Islamic Group. The United States is trying to deport Mr. Abdel Rahman, but has not charged him. He has said he had no connection with the bombing.
Three Islamic Group leaders who took part in the talks, though well known for their ties with the clandestine organization and their friendship with Mr. Abdel Rahman, said they had never officially identified themselves to the Embassy employees as belonging to or speaking for the Islamic Group. Membership in the group is considered a crime in Egypt punishable by death.
They said the last meeting had been held a little more than six weeks ago, shortly before the explosion at the World Trade Center.
"We were never told why the dialogue was broken off," said one Islamic Group leader who met with embassy officials. "As far as we are concerned, the Americans are welcome to see us at any time."
The United States Embassy denied that it had ever formally requested a meeting with representatives of the group, which has called for the violent ouster of the Government of President Hosni Mubarak. But embassy officials did not deny that several meetings involving three staff members and militant leaders had been held in Cairo.
 
Statement From the Embassy
 "There has been no effort to establish contact with members of the Islamic Group and organizations that have claimed responsibility for acts of terrorism," a spokeswoman for the Embassy said.
"The Islamic Group has not contacted the State Department to discuss human rights or any other issue," she said. "The United States strongly opposes the use of terrorist tactics by any organization to achieve its political goals. We have no intention of meeting with these people."
Western diplomats who were aware of the contacts said United States officials were walking a fine line between seeking to understand the goals and nature of the opposition group and refraining from any official relationship with a known terrorist organization.
The Islamic Group has attacked police officers, Coptic Christians, Egyptian Government officials and tourists in its drive to destabilize the state. The attacks, and police raids carried out against Islamic militants, have left at least 120 people dead in the last year.
The militant leaders said the Americans -- three political officers from the Embassy, who often visited separately -- appeared to be interested in documenting reports of human rights abuses, as well as understanding the group's philosophy and aims.
 
Memories of Iran and Sudan
 United States diplomats and intelligence officials stationed in countries with revolutionary movements, like Iran before the overthrow of the Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, were later criticized for failing to grasp the depth of popular discontent or the goals and structure of the revolutionary opposition. Western diplomats were also caught off guard by the rise to power of an Islamic Government in Sudan after a 1989 military coup.
Some analysts have called President Jimmy Carter's decision to stand behind the Shah until his ouster in January 1979 a devastating failure in United States foreign policy.
"The U.S. officials wanted to know of human rights abuses in great detail," said one Egyptian militant who took part in the talks, "but they also wanted to understand our ideology and outlook. The Americans do not want to repeat the mistakes they committed in Iran and the Sudan, when they supported unpopular regimes when everyone else had turned against them."
While few Western diplomats go so far as to suggest that the Egyptian Government is in danger of falling, many now acknowledge that they had seriously underestimated the power and strength of the Islamic Group. Most diplomats expect violence against the Government to intensify, especially if it does not begin to introduce political and economic changes.
 
Party's Grip on Power
 But the governing National Democratic Party, which has dominated the country under various names since the overthrow of the monarchy in 1952, appears to have little inclination to release its grip on power or restructure the economy. Western analysts say that Egypt's state sector is bloated and inefficient and that its bureaucracy is riddled with corruption.
Government officials blame the surge of violence on outside forces. They contend that the Islamic Government in Iran and the infusion into the militant movement here of Egyptians who fought in the Afghan civil war are the root causes behind the new wave of attacks. Mr. Mubarak's Government is counting on a tough new campaign by the country's security forces to break the back of the movement.
"The Mubarak regime is weak," one of the militant leaders asserted, "and it is our impression that the Americans are beginning to realize this."
Yet while the militants said that the embassy officers with whom they had met had a grasp of the popular disenchantment with the Mubarak administration, they also sensed that American officials had a deep distrust of Islamic fundamentalist groups.
"These diplomats understand what is happening on the street," said one member who took part in the meetings, "but they also have an irrational fear of us. We do not have a problem with America. We can have good relations, but they insist on propping up Mubarak."
 
An Important U.S. Ally
 The loss of Egypt as a close ally would be a devastating blow to United States policy in the Middle East. With one-third of the Arab world's population, Egypt is a critical supporter of American interests in the region and is the only Arab state that has made peace with Israel.
Israel and Egypt receive 36 percent of all foreign aid in the United States budget -- $5.1 billion out of a total this year of $13.9 billion. The Embassy in Cairo has the biggest staff of any United States mission in the world. It maintains contact with a spectrum of individuals, groups and organizations, and the fortress-like compound is the headquarters of regional intelligence-gathering offices.

PUB-DATE: April 12, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1772 words

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Critics of Bankruptcy Law See Inefficiency and Waste

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
As the economy has slogged its way through recession and a slow recovery, hundreds of large publicly held corporations -- from Continental Airlines to R. H. Macy -- have sought shelter from their creditors in bankruptcy court.
Now, with many of these cases mired in the courtroom, complaints are rising that a more permissive Federal Bankruptcy Code, adopted in 1978, has become a refuge for incompetent executives and a cornucopia for greedy lawyers. 
 Until 1978, the American bankruptcy process was less forgiving to debtors, turning their operations over to outside trustees. The Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978 gave the benefit of the doubt to managers who wanted to stay in charge, in hopes of conserving jobs and salvaging businesses. It also left few limits on what lawyers and other professionals could be paid in the bankruptcy process.
But critics of the current bankruptcy law contend that policies intended to conserve corporate cash -- by allowing knowledgeable managers to patch up problems instead of selling a company's assets off piecemeal -- are contributing to corporate waste. And as companies have increasingly spent more time operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, their protected status has come to affect the economic conditions faced by competing businesses that are not operating under court protection.
 
Attention to Airlines
 Indeed, Chapter 11 and its abuse are Topic A for a new commission charged by Congress with devising a plan by midsummer to put the bloom back in the cheeks of the ailing airlines, an industry severely affected by the changes in bankruptcy law.
While the commission is worried about the health of the airlines, others are concerned with the health of the bankruptcy system. Howell T. Heflin, an Alabama Democrat who is chairman of a Senate Judiciary subcommittee on courts and administrative practice, is pressing for legislation that would, among other provisions, put strict limits on how long a corporation could tarry in Chapter 11. He can count on broad support: the Senate passed a similar bill without dissent last year, although it later died in conference committee.
 
Put to New Uses
 The 1978 law made bankruptcy more attractive to troubled companies, as had been expected. But both the public and lawmakers were startled when corporations began to use Chapter 11 for purposes ranging from breaking tough labor contracts to resolving complex liability claims, including damages from asbestos and from birth-control devices.
But the bankruptcy process -- the quintessentially American idea of allowing a new start with a clean slate -- was further tarnished as more traditional cases took ever longer to resolve and fees began to soar.
 
 
Calls for Change Grow
 Bold plans for abolishing Chapter 11 altogether -- or making it unattractive to any but the most desperate petitioners -- are still just gleams in the eyes of academics. But the notion that significant change is needed is gaining converts.
"A year ago I would have said radical reform was impossible," said Michael Rosenzweig, a partner in an Atlanta law firm, Rogers & Hardin. "Not today."
On first glance, the classic rationale for Chapter 11 seems rock solid. An insolvent public corporation may be worth more as a going concern than as a pile of assets to be sold quickly and cheaply to the highest bidders. Because managers generally understand their companies better than anyone else, it behooves creditors and stockholders as a group -- not to mention employees, suppliers and affected communities -- to give the boss time to devise a plan that most claimants would prefer to a fire sale.
Yet economists agree that Chapter 11 invites abuse by managers of large publicly held corporations who want to keep their jobs, and it creates conflicts among creditors that pull bankruptcy judges in a variety of directions.
 
 
Self-Interest Served by Delay
 Once driven to take refuge in Chapter 11, well-paid executives who have little hope of salvaging a business still may have selfish reasons to delay the inevitable. And delay is usually not difficult to arrange.
Under the 1978 law, management has 120 days to come up with a reorganization plan before creditors can petition for liquidation. But because judges often see their own mission as saving failing businesses, managers are usually given extension after extension if they can offer a shred of hope for success.
Worse, perhaps, managers have incentives to take chances with the creditors' money in the interim. If they strike out, the personal consequences -- unemployment -- would be no worse than under a prudent liquidation.
Mr. Rosenzweig, along with Michael Bradley of the University of Michigan, contends that managers' incentives are so distorted that Chapter 11 wastes more capital than would a system of virtually automatic liquidation. Indeed, they say that the burst of bankruptcy filings by large companies in the 1980's was partly a response to the attractions of Chapter 11 after its liberalization in 1978.
In a 1992 article in the Yale Law Journal entitled "The Untenable Case For Chapter 11," they proposed that stockholders and junior creditors be given the opportunity to come up with the cash to pay off secured creditors, thereby taking control of the bankrupt company, or face the speedy sale of assets and the likelihood of walking away empty-handed, since they are the last on the chain of claims in a bankruptcy case.
 
 
Creditors Too Quick to Liquidate
 If managers are typically eager to throw good money after bad, senior creditors are too eager to call in the auctioneer, asserts Oliver Hart, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Consider a bank with first claim on $100 million owed by a bankrupt company that still has $200 million in liquid assets. If the company is sold or dismantled immediately, the bank is sure to recoup the $100 million. On the other hand, if the corporation is given leeway to restructure, $100 million is still the most the bank can get -- and it may take much longer and the bank may get far less.
Mr. Hart, along with Philippe Aghion of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and John Moore of the London School of Economics, offers a creative plan for harmonizing competing interests in bankruptcies.
The first step, based on the idea of Lucian Bebchuk of the Harvard Law School, would be to wipe out a bankrupt corporation's debts. Senior creditors would exchange their i.o.u.'s for all the stock; junior creditors and the old stockholders would exchange their claims for options to purchase the stock at a price that would pay off the creditors ahead of them in line.
In the example above, the bank owed $100 million would get all the shares. Junior creditors owed, say, $200 million would get options to buy the shares for $100 million from the bank. The old stockholders, last in line, would get options to buy back all the stock for $300 million -- enough money to make both classes of creditors whole.
Within a few months of a corporation's entering Chapter 11, the court would then be required to solicit bids for the company's assets -- perhaps hiring outside experts to provide objective comparisons of competing bids. With this information in hand, junior creditors and former shareholders would be given a chance to exercise their stock-purchase options, or to sell them to others who think the business is salvageable. Then there would be a vote of the share owners to choose a plan for restructuring or to proceed to liquidation.
 
 
The Case of the Airlines
 Such a plan might at least have reduced the bankruptcy problems ailing the embattled airlines. Eastern and Pan Am expired by degrees on the Chapter 11 resuscitator, while Continental, T.W.A. and America West have lingered for years -- at what some critics say has been disastrous expense to healthy carriers, which have themselves lost billions of dollars in recent years.
Bankrupt carriers "worry only about the cash in the bank today," complained Michael Durham, the chief financial officer of American Airlines. He says this has created a discount mentality that makes it virtually impossible for competitors to maintain fares at levels that will keep them solvent.
Defenders of Chapter 11 would argue that the bankrupt carriers are probably worth more intact than their planes, gates and computers would fetch at auction. And from the broader social perspective, it appears to pay to keep the multibillion-dollar fleets in the air as long as fares cover fuel, maintenance and labor.
The approach advocated by Messrs. Hart, Aghion and Moore would probably have terminated Eastern Airlines long before it had run through $1 billion in Chapter 11. That might have spared Delta Air Lines a punishing fare war for control of routes through Atlanta, and prevented the spread of what Darryl Jenkins, a partner in Aviation Forecasting and Economics of Arlington Va., calls "the bankruptcy virus."
And the pressure to act would probably have accelerated the reorganization of more competitive carriers like Continental and America West, leaving them debt free and far abler to do battle for market share with the other major carriers.
 
 
One Skeptic
 Elizabeth Warren, a visiting professor at the Harvard Law School, expresses reservations about the economists' plan that go well beyond its possible impact on the airline industry. She doubts that a fast-track version of Chapter 11 would force bad managers to shape up. Any change making it less likely that managers of a corporation could retain control in bankruptcy, she says, would also make it less likely they would seek Chapter 11 protection before the company is in irremediable trouble.
Economists also focus on the apparent failure of Chapter 11 to direct corporate capital toward its most productive uses. And the public is repelled by hefty legal fees that ultimately come out of the pockets of creditors. While legal bills, on average, soak up just a few percent of the assets of bankrupt corporations, a small percentage can still mean big money. In the R. H. Macy bankruptcy, for example, lawyers have already hauled away $25 million.
Washington seems likely, at the least, to put more of a legal burden on companies seeking bankruptcy-law protection to show why they deserve more than a year's respite in Chapter 11. But while there is a clamor for some improvement, no fix, quick or slow, is likely to end the debates over who should control failing companies and when creditors should be permitted to cut their losses.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1288 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON CONTINUES OLD DRUG POLICIES

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
When President Clinton moved into the White House in January, specialists in academia, health care and law enforcement around the country were expecting big changes in the way the Federal Government dealt with the national drug problem.
But Mr. Clinton surprised and disappointed many specialists last week by presenting a $13.04 billion anti-drug budget that offered little change from the widely criticized approach followed for 12 years by Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush. That approach relied heavily on law enforcement instead of emphasizing rehabilitation and prevention. 
 "What we have here is a budget that says 'business as usual,' " said Dr. LaMond Tullis, a professor of political science at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, and a drug policy consultant to the United Nations. "It seems we're going to go on doing things we know don't work."
 
Health-Care Overhaul Cited
 Administration officials said the budget was prepared before a detailed drug strategy could be worked out, and they added that the health-care overhaul being developed under the leadership of Hillary Rodham Clinton was likely to include increased spending for drug treatment.
Even so, specialists pointed out that the budget represented a general statement of the Administration's plans for the coming year. Regardless of the outcome of the new health-care measures, they said, the budget suggests no major change in philosophy and offers no hope of stanching what many regard as the waste of tens of millions of dollars on ineffective law-enforcement measures.
While Mr. Clinton has devoted considerable energy to the economy and has made general health care a priority, he has been virtually silent on the drug problem and has not chosen the official who will be in charge of developing strategy.
As a result, specialists say Mr. Clinton's handling of the budget has deepened their concern that the new Administration is neglecting the fight against drugs.
While departing little from his predecessor's spending policies, Mr. Clinton chose not to adopt Mr. Bush's practice of using the annual presentation of the budget as a means of calling attention to the drug problem. Instead, Mr. Clinton's anti-drug program was inconspicuously tucked into two pages among the more than 1,300 pages of the Federal budget.
Besides not yet appointing a director of the White House's Office of National Drug Control Policy to serve as his senior anti-drug aide, Mr. Clinton has also left most other Federal positions in the field in the hands of acting directors or holdovers from the Bush Administration.
During the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton raised the hopes of drug experts by saying he favored treatment on demand, which would make drug rehabilitation available to anyone who asks for it and would cost hundreds of millions of dollars. At present, the nation's drug treatment centers can handle only about a third of the estimated six million heavy drug abusers.
 
Appointments Praised
 The drug experts say they have been encouraged by Mr. Clinton's appointments of Janet Reno as Attorney General and Dr. Joycelyn Elders as Surgeon General, both of whom are regarded as understanding the nuances of the drug problem.
The staff at the Office of National Drug Control Policy, which was President Bush's center for anti-drug information, is referring inquiries about the Clinton Administration's drug policy to the White House. But Arthur L. Jones, a deputy White House press secretary, said that details would not be forthcoming until the President selected the chief drug policy aide.
He could not say when that selection might come. And he would not comment on reports that several people had declined the nomination since the drug office, in an economizing step earlier this year, was cut by five-sixths -- to 25 staff members from 147 -- and the director's post was simultaneously elevated to Cabinet rank.
Cocaine and most other drugs are not being talked about as much as they were just a few years ago, when they attained a certain chic in some middle-class circles. But crack is still a crippling problem in the inner cities and heroin abuse is on the rise, Federal studies indicate.
"This is not a time when we can pull back and say the drug problem is over," said Dr. Herbert D. Kleber, a professor of psychiatry at Columbia University Medical School who resigned as Mr. Bush's senior aide on anti-drug health issues after failing to win $1 billion more for treatment, research and anti-drug education.
 
Questions and More Questions
 Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, asserted that the Administration, pressed on concerns like the economy and the turmoil in Russia, was simply ignoring illegal drugs.
"There is absolutely nobody in the Administration willing to accept any responsibility on any subject relating to our drug problem," said Mr. Rangel, who was chairman of the recently eliminated House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control and is now a leader of the newly formed House Caucus on Drug Abuse. "They haven't the foggiest idea where the Administration is heading. I've got a letter on my desk from the President of Colombia asking me if I can share with him as to the direction in which the Administration is going on this."
William S. Smith, a senior official in the White House anti-drug office under President Bush, said national drug policy appeared to be "on cruise control."
Robert O. Boorstin, another White House spokesman, said that rather than being ignored drug abuse and treatment had been "part and parcel of one of the working groups" on the President's Task Force on National Health Care, headed by Mrs. Clinton. One possibility being explored, other Administration officials said, is extending drug treatment coverage to the 50 percent of the nation's poor who do not receive the coverage provided through Medicaid.
In his new budget, Mr. Clinton designated $8.30 billion for law enforcement and $4.74 billion for such things as rehabilitation and anti-drug education. That is a proportional split of 63.66 percent to 36.34 percent, or about one percent more for health and education than Mr. Bush in his last drug budget.
Among the most criticized aspects of the Reagan-Bush drug policies were the expensive and largely unsuccessful efforts to stop overseas farmers from producing the raw material for cocaine and opium and to block the smuggling of the drugs into the United States.
Mr. Clinton cut financing for some international operations in South America and Asia by 8 percent. That will trim $44 million from spending last year of $536 million. But he added $19 million for anti-smuggling efforts, bringing spending in that category to $1.765 billion, much of it going to the Defense Department.
In his last year in office, Mr. Bush cut $336 million from international operations and anti-smuggling efforts. He increased spending for drug treatment $168 million while Mr. Clinton is proposing a $170 million increase.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who heads the Subcommittee on Crime and Criminal Justice, which oversees the Drug Enforcement Administration, said that by increasing the total anti-drug budget by 7 percent Mr. Clinton was showing his commitment to the issue.
Mark A. R. Kleiman, a drug expert at Harvard University, said that with $850 billion being spent on national health care, the reforms being developed by Mrs. Clinton could become far more important than the anti-drug budget. "If drug treatment could get a small fraction of what the country spends on health care," he said, "that would be much better than having a big fraction of the drug budget."

HEADLINE: Russia Seeks to Delay Vote on Further Sanctions Against Belgrade

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 11

 BODY:
Russia pressed tonight for further postponement of a Security Council vote planned for Monday on tightening the economic embargo against Yugoslavia, diplomats said.
Consultations continued between Council members over sanctions that are intended to press what remains of Yugoslavia to use its influence to help end the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where Bosnian Serbs have been fighting Muslims and Croats for more than a year. One diplomat involved in the issue thought postponement of the vote was likely, but others said a final decision on whether to proceed with the new sanctions probably would be made on Monday. 
 President Boris N. Yeltsin, who sent a message directly to President Clinton on the matter, said he believes that new Security Council action against the Serbian-dominated Yugoslavia would be unpopular in Russia and could damage his chances of victory in his power struggle with the Parliament, which will reach its climax in a national referendum scheduled for April 25. Russian nationalists feel they have special ties to the Serbs as fellow Slavs and Orthodox Christians.
 
Offered Amendments
 As a result, Russia presented a number of amendments last week that would soften the proposed new sanctions. Some amendments were incorporated into the text of the resolution, which was then accepted by other Council members. But Russia then refused to take a position on the entire resolution, saying Moscow would decide how to vote by Monday.
Russia contends that the government of Slobodan Milosevic, the president of Serbia, is showing greater flexibility and is making an effort to persuade Bosnia's Serbs to accept something close to the peace proposals put forward by mediators in the Balkans dispute. The plan was developed by Cyrus R. Vance, who was the representative of the United Nations at that time, and Lord Owen, representing the European Community.
Russia is contending that Serbia's effort should be encouraged rather than punished with further sanctions.
In the past, President Clinton has shown that he considers helping President Yeltsin stay in power a higher priority than applying extra pressure on Belgrade to end the civil war in Bosnia. And the United States has already held up action on the new sanctions twice at Moscow's urging.
 
Met in Washington
 Vitaly I. Churkin, the Russian Deputy Foreign Minister, was in Washington over the weekend to talk with top Administration officials about his visit to Belgrade last week.
In Belgrade, Mr. Churkin said he would propose changes to the mediators' plan that would make the division of Bosnia and Herzegovina into ten largely autonomous provinces more acceptable to Bosnian Serbs. Muslims and Croats have accepted the plan in its present form.
At the same time Mr. Churkin warned against "hasty steps and decisions that could produce a reverse effect and simply escalate the Bosnian conflict."
As one of the five permanent Security Council members, Russia can veto any action on fresh sanctions. But these days the five -- the others are Britain, France, the United States and China -- do not call for a vote until they are all ready to see the resolution adopted. No veto has been cast since 1990.
 
Pressure on Belgrade
 The United States, Britain and France, together with the Council's third world members, are pressing for the new sanctions as a means of encouraging Yugoslavia's Serbs to pressure Bosnian Serbs to accept the Vance-Owen plan.
Belgrade is doing nothing to stop Bosnian Serbs from tightening their grip on the Muslim town of Srebrenica, driving out the Muslims and completing their campaign of "ethnic cleansing" in this part of Eastern Bosnia.
Under the proposed new sanctions resolution, Yugoslavia's coastal waters would be closed to all shipping, its financial assets overseas confiscated and ships, trucks, trains and planes outside the country impounded. Other steps are planned to prevent certain goods from entering or leaving the country.
