HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Tina Brown's Progress At the New New Yorker

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Despite the lamentations of loyalists last summer that Tina Brown would tart up The New Yorker and destroy its very soul, six months into her tenure as editor in chief, subscription renewals are strong, newsstand sales have doubled, and advertising pages are up a hefty 16 percent just since Jan. 1.
However, what no one knows except S. I. Newhouse, the magazine's owner, and a few top executives at the parent company, Advance Publications Inc., is whether The New Yorker has begun to stanch its losses. Ms. Brown, asked her timetable for turning around The New Yorker economically, replied, "We would like to see it in profit in five years." 
 But whatever the effect on the magazine's finances, Tina Brown's tenure has provided the best theater to come from the world of magazine publishing in a long time.
 
Damping Down an Old Flame
 For better or worse, she has made it clear that the 68-year-old New Yorker, which some enthusiasts call the best-loved magazine in America, will not be the same again.
Since her first issue, dated Oct. 5, Ms. Brown has introduced sections, expanded the table of contents, hired new writers, put bylines at the top of articles, increased the use of color through comics and vivid sketches, and made splashier use of cartoons. She has reintroduced the magazine's original body type and an array of decorative art, including logos and other ornamentation, from the days of its founding editor, Harold Ross.
She hired Richard Avedon as the first staff photographer, and his striking pictures brought drama enough to the magazine even before his full-page nudes of the actress Tilde Swinton appeared in the March 8 issue.
Ms. Brown, British-born and 39, has caused clamor and comment, much of the latter mixed.
Supporters say that Ms. Brown, until last summer editor in chief of Vanity Fair, has brought life, topicality and change of pace to a moribund magazine.
Her detractors see vulgarization, a loss of elegance and of timelessness, and, perhaps the harshest criticism of all, an increasing lack of differentiation from other publications.
"It has become much livelier, more interesting, more topical," said Maynard Parker, editor of Newsweek. "I think she has done a good job of reinventing the magazine while keeping much of what was good."
But Lewis Lapham, editor of Harper's, deplored a new trendiness. "She is taking it in the direction of a fashion magazine and presenting what's fashionable in culture and politics," he said. "Her competitors are now Mirabella, Vogue and Vanity Fair."
The fact is that Ms. Brown, faced with the daunting task of attracting new readers while not losing old ones, has probably made changes less rapidly than some feared she would and more rapidly than those who thought she would not change it fast enough.
"She has set out to appeal to a larger audience, one that will draw a larger circulation," said John Mack Carter, editor in chief of Good Housekeeping. "And when you appeal to a broader base, you run the risk of being coarser than a magazine as polished as The New Yorker was previously perceived."
Ms. Brown, tossing her blond hair and speaking intently, dismissed much of the criticism.
"Rubbish!" she said. "It's that New Yorker fakery! Anyone who talks about the lack of timelessness isn't reading the magazine. If they were reading it, they would see that the pieces I'm publishing are exactly those kinds of pieces that were previously published, but are now being mixed up with other kinds of pieces."
 
A Tradition of Long Articles
 Charles McGrath, the deputy editor, who worked under Ms. Brown's two immediate predecessors, Robert Gottlieb and William Shawn, agrees for the most part. He says that many of the long articles -- some of these 25,000 to 30,000 words despite all the talk of shorter pieces -- would have appeared under Mr. Shawn or Mr. Gottlieb.
He thinks many critics are responding more to the new layout than to the content. "The magazine has added or expanded its range," he said. "I would say that the magazine is even more unlike other magazines than it used to be."
A constant complaint is the increased use of obscenity or vulgarity, which, Mr. McGrath said, began when Mr. Shawn was editor. "Under Shawn, one had to go and negotiate every time," he said. "Under Bob, the rules relaxed a little."
 
Of WASP's and Authenticity
 About all this Ms. Brown said, "I think that you cannot have street people talking like Connecticut WASP's, and we have done a number of pieces on street people."
Some things, she conceded, she would not do again, including an unsigned Talk of the Town column defending Erich Honecker, the ousted East German Communist leader, in the Jan. 11 issue. The article, it turns out, was written by Irene Dische, the wife of Mr. Honecker's lawyer.
"She had written for The New Yorker before, so questions were not asked that should have been asked," Ms. Brown said.
She said it has taken a long time to get The Talk of The Town section to hit its stride, but thinks it has now. "It had become too much of a belles-lettres wannabe and E. B. White manque," she said, referring to the great New Yorker writer. 'My feeling is if you don't have E. B. White, then don't have E. B. White manque."
As for the Valentine cover of a Hasidic man kissing a black woman, which many found offensive, she said simply that it was her best-selling cover.
Roger Angell, the writer and fiction editor, described The New Yorker these days as "a cheerful and interesting place to work."
"I also think there is general agreement that she is the first non-neurotic editor The New Yorker has ever had," he said.
 
Encouraging Numbers
 As for the magazine's financial performance, Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive, talks of "a huge, huge turnaround."
Circulation for the last six months of 1992 (the first three of those months under Mr. Gottlieb) was 659,000, up 5 percent over 1991, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Mr. Florio projects an average of 750,000 for the first half of 1993 and says he will raise the 600,000 circulation base the magazine guarantees advertisers, to 650,000 in July.
Bookings for ad pages for the second quarter, he said, are 20 percent ahead of last year's, although that does not necessarily translate into an equivalent increase in revenue.
Newsstand sales average 45,000 an issue, compared with 20,000 in 1992, partly because of increased promotion. And the most recent survey shows that the average age of readers has dropped from 45.7 to 42.
Subscription renewals, the best barometer of how longtime readers feel about the new New Yorker, are at 71.8 percent, strikingly high for a magazine. Mr. Florio said he had received about 400 cancellations. One woman canceled her subscription, saying she did not like what Tina Brown had done to The New Yorker. The letter, however, was written about a month before Ms. Brown took over.
Expenses are being watched closely, Mr. Florio said. Advance Publications, a privately held company, does not discuss its finances, but industry estimates are that The New Yorker was losing $10 million a year.
The magazine has nonetheless made a major investment in upgraded paper stock, which is heavier, brighter and better able to accommodate the increased use of color. People in the industry estimate the cost at something less than $3 million a year.
Another big expense has been for severance packages given to 15 writers whose contracts were quietly terminated. They were each given a year's salary and lifetime medical benefits. (New contract writers do not receive benefits.)
Ms. Brown said that generally speaking, she is paying writers less at The New Yorker than she did at Vanity Fair. Many of those she brought over from Vanity Fair are being paid the same amount for more work. Even a superstar like Richard Avedon, who reportedly turned down a $2 million contract from Hearst Magazines, is working for The New Yorker "as an artistic commitment," in Ms. Brown's words, and not for the kind of fee he usually commands.
Ms. Brown will clearly continue to make waves. She will be cheered by many. But she will probably never erase the unease of old-time readers who consider topicality declasse and see her stewardship as tantamount to selling out to the Philistines.
 
A Dissent Over Taste
 In no area is this more evident than in the matter of taste. Joseph Epstein, editor of The American Scholar, writing under the nom de plume Aristides in the spring issue, declared:
"When good taste is removed, one feels the loss rather dramatically. A strong case in point is the changes that have taken place in recent years at The New Yorker magazine since the removal from the magazine's editorship of William Shawn.
"Read the magazine today, with its unbuttoned and often sloppy language, its edge of political meanness, the childish obviousness of its attempts to outrage, and one comes to yearn for the quiet good taste that could once be counted on in a magazine one has been reading for decades."
The criticism, to be sure, is aimed at both of Mr. Shawn's successors, Mr. Gottlieb and Ms. Brown. But let Ms. Brown have the last word.
"Well, you know there is a lot of faux Puritanism out there," she said. "It's all part of the New Yorker fakery. Good taste in the prissy sense has never been of interest to me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tina Brown, moving into the editor in chief's office at The New Yorker last September, as she succeeded Robert Gottlieb in the post. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Traveling Miami Roads Without Becoming Prey

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 11

 BODY:
As tourists wait in line for their cars at an Alamo Rent-a-Car office near Miami International Airport, they are given a flier and hear a recorded message that repeats a warning about the dangers lurking ahead.
"We have just handed you a safety-tip brochure," a woman's voice calmly intones every five minutes. "We ask that you read it before leaving the premises." 
 In stark letters, drivers are warned against actions that once might have been routine: pulling over if urged to by a passing motorist or getting out to check for damage if bumped from behind by another car.
But the conditions are no longer routine. Criminals here and elsewhere appear to be increasingly finding motorists easy prey, and they are using a variety of tactics to assault and rob.
 
'Flow of Potential Targets'
 "Roads are perfect for criminals because they offer easy access, fast escape and a constant flow of potential targets," said Louis R. Mizzell Jr., a security consultant in Bethesda, Md., who collects information about crimes against motorists.
Two weeks ago, a German tourist was killed after leaving the Miami airport when her rental car was bumped from behind and she got out to inspect it. The woman, Barbara Jensen Meller, a victim of a tactic known as "bump and rob," was robbed, beaten and run over. Three men have been arrested in connection with the incident.
Other motorists have been victims of "smash and grab" attacks in which a robber approaches a stopped car, shatters a window with a hard object, snatches valuables from inside and runs. Many of the attacks here have occurred after drivers, like Mrs. Meller, became lost and wandered into rundown neighborhoods.
Statistics on crimes against motorists are hard to come by, although police officers interviewed here say it is their impression that such attacks have increased over the last two years. And the problem, while severe here, is by no means limited to the Miami area.
 
Tactics Aren't New
 Mr. Mizzell said that last year he had received reports of 3,000 bump-and-rob incidents from across the country.
Some police officials say growing concern about the safety of motorists is largely one of perception, created by an increase in vivid news accounts of carjackings and similar incidents.
And, in fact, tactics like bump and rob have been around for years. In a three-month period in 1989, for example, 10 motorists were robbed along Interstate 280 in New Jersey when they pulled their cars off the highway after being bumped from behind.
In Miami, such attacks have drawn particular attention lately because many of the victims have been tourists, especially from outside the country, who help make up a vital element of the state's economy.
Some visitors interviewed this weekend said they were not concerned about driving, but others have changed their travel plans.
"We were planning to tour around the city for a few days," said Ross Townsend, who owns a moving company in Alberta, Canada, as he and his wife waited to pick up a rental car at the Alamo office near the Miami airport. "But I can tell you, we are more than just a little worried. We are just going to drive straight on out of here."
Public and corporate officials have made efforts to calm such fears. In addition to the safety brochures, rental companies are replacing the license plates that previously designated a car as a rented vehicle. Law-enforcement agencies have formed undercover units intended to catch criminals who prey on motorists.
On Saturday night, for example, Officer Jorge Martin of the Miami Police Department patrolled the Overtown district, a blighted neighborhood that borders the affluent downtown area. It is a maze of badly lit streets where tourists often find themselves after missing a poorly marked entrance to Interstate 95.
 
'A Dead Giveaway'
 "People drive right past the ramp and in two blocks they are in the middle of it," Officer Martin said. "Then, they drive around with maps pulled out or luggage piled up in the back seat. It is a dead giveaway."
Officials here have vowed to put up new road signs.
As part of a new unit formed several weeks ago, Officer Martin is on the street to find lost motorists. He and other Miami officers estimated that for the last two years about 10 motorists a night, 80 percent of them tourists, were attacked in their vehicles in Overtown after getting lost. The majority of the incidents involved smash-and-grab attacks by teen-agers who waited on a dark corner or by an underpass.
On Saturday night, a bright new vehicle with rental-car plates and luggage visible in the back seat appeared ahead of Officer Martin's car, hesitantly making its way down an Overtown street. The vehicle's occupants, a couple from Norway, had become lost trying to find the airport.
"I'm following this map from Avis, and it is not good enough," said Reidulf Stige, a travel agent from Grimstad, Norway, . Officer Martin guided him out of the neighborhood.
Over five hours, Officer Martin did the same with five other motorists, four of them tourists.
Thomas Culpepper, the managing director of traffic safety for the American Automobile Association in Heathrow, Fla., said that drivers should clearly study maps and obtain directions before they travel in unfamiliar areas and that they should be aware of tactics like "bump and rob."
If motorists believe they have been involved in an accident, he said, they should drive to a police or fire station or any well-lighted area where there are people around before getting out of their cars.

Tourist Robbed and 3 Arrested
 MIAMI, April 11 (Reuters) -- A Dade County official who saw a man rob a Venezuelan woman at a gas station in Miami alerted the police on his car phone and two men and a woman were arrested, the police said today. The official, Commissioner Art Teele, alerted the police after he saw a thief jump from a car and grab a purse from the woman, Nancy Semprun of Caracas, Venezuela, as she was buying gasoline for her rented car.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
A more permissive bankruptcy code has become a refuge for incompetent executives and a cornucopia for greedy lawyers, a growing number of critics say. Hundreds of publicly held corporations have sought shelter from creditors in bankruptcy court since the recession began, and many cases remain mired in the courtroom. Economic Watch. [Page A1.]
Congress plans to investigate the merits of an antitrust case filed by the Justice Department, in response to an alliance of airlines and consumer groups. The agency accused the eight largest U.S. airlines of using reservation systems to fix air fares. [D1.] 
 Thursday is still the deadline for filing tax returns, and penalties still exist. But the I.R.S. has made changes that should ease the seasonal panic of the dilatory, the disorderly and the accounting-impaired. [D9.]
Thousands of employers will become deeply involved in the next two years in determining how workers get to their jobs. Amendments to the Clean Air Act require companies in some polluted regions to increase the number of employees using car pools or mass transit. [B1.]

International
More U.S. investors are taking Mexico's stocks seriously, despite the volatility of the Mexican market, as they hope for long-term returns and the completion of a free trade agreement. [D1.]
 
Companies
The nation's largest cable television company is embarking on a $2 billion program to lay fiber-optic cable in more than 400 communities, in the biggest gamble yet that Americans want an "information superhighway" to their homes. [D1.]
By asking G.M. to recall 4.7 million full-size pickups, the Government has set in motion a process that may drag on for years. The request also dealt a serious setback, although not a decisive one, to the company's efforts to emerge from a legal, political and public relations quagmire. News analysis. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
Six months into Tina Brown's tenure at The New Yorker, subscription renewals are strong, newsstand sales have doubled, and ad pages are up. But only a few top executives know whether the magazine has begun to stanch its losses. [D1.]
By giving broadcast rights to the Emmys to ABC for four years, the Television Academy of Arts and Sciences greatly upset the other networks. Indeed, they are so angry that they are planning to put on their own television awards show. [D6.]
Confidential documents confirm speculation that Macmillan's performance has been dismal. On Friday, the bankruptcy administrator for the book publisher's parent, Maxwell Communication, got the first idea of how much the asset might fetch. [D8.]
An F.C.C. decision may have ended a battle that the big Hollywood studios and the networks have been waging for 20 years over financial interest and syndication rules. But by no means did it end a war of words between the industries. Television. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Executive Brief: THE TREASURY DEPARTMENT;
Bentsen Remembers Way Around the Hill

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
The Lloyd Bentsen who is Treasury Secretary is proving to be little different from the Lloyd Bentsen who was chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
Mr. Bentsen, his colleagues report, remains a good listener, still knows how to horse-trade and has not lost his knack at pushing the right button at the right time to move legislation along. 
 Take last week's Senate vote to increase the $4.145 trillion debt ceiling. In past years, raising the ceiling was an inglorious occasion for Congressional grandstanding, sniping, posturing and shaking down the President. But this year, notwithstanding the filibuster over President Clinton's $19.5 billion plan to speed up economic growth, the debt-ceiling increase sailed through the Senate, thanks in part to Mr. Bentsen's well-timed lobbying.
And although Mr. Bentsen was chosen as Treasury Secretary partly because he knew his way around Congress, Administration officials do not fault him for failing to prevent Senate Republicans from bogging down the spending package.
Mr. Bentsen has not forgotten the importance of compromising around the edges to help win approval of the big enchiladas, like the President's economic package.
An example: The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell of Maine, and other New England senators voiced their displeasure with the proposed energy tax because it placed a higher levy on oil than other fuels. That would squeeze New Englanders, who tend to heat their homes with oil. Presto, the Administration announced that oil used for home heating face a lower levy.
The testing of Mr. Bentsen will begin in earnest over the next few weeks when Congress starts dissecting the economic package. The first hurdle may be the highest: the President's proposal for the investment tax credit, a $21 billion tax break that represents half of his spending package. Senior lawmakers said last week that the proposal had little support in either chamber.
And after that comes the tax increases. "A $272 billion tax increase is a doozy," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee. "If Lloyd doesn't help, there won't be one."
 
Old Faces,
Better Offices
 When one walks around the austere halls of the Treasury Department, it is hard not to bump into people who worked with Mr. Bentsen in the Senate. He has taken a dozen Senate aides to the columned building next to the White House.
Mr. Bentsen has probably moved faster than other Cabinet Secretaries to assemble a team of aides, but then again he had a large pool of respected aides to choose from.
Among the aides who have made the pilgrimage to Treasury is Marina Weiss, who was the Senate Finance Committee's chief analyst for health and human resources and is now deputy assistant secretary of economic policy for health issues. Samuel Sessions, the committee's chief tax counsel, is deputy assistant secretary for tax analysis. Philip Diehl, who was Mr. Bentsen's legislative director, is now his personal counselor.
Mr. Bentsen has also named Jack R. DeVore Jr., his longtime press secretary, to be assistant secretary for public affairs.
These Senate transplants acknowledge they must be far more careful about what they say and do than when they were on Capitol Hill. If a Congressional aide says something about the yen's value, no one cares, but if a Treasury official talks about the yen, currency traders will do somersaults.
"When the Treasury speaks out on an issue, it has enormous consequences, certainly more than I imagined," Mr. DeVore said.
 
Theory? Theory?
Oh, THAT Theory
 Mr. Bentsen got more controversy than he bargained for in naming two star economists to senior posts.
Lawrence Summers, his choice for under secretary for international affairs, has become a punching bag for environmentalists ever since he wrote a memorandum, as the World Bank's chief economist, suggesting that it made economic sense to move dirty industries to third-world countries, which worry less about pollution than the industrialized countries.
Alicia Munnell, who has been nominated as assistant secretary for economic policy, stirred up a hornet's nest when, as research director for the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, she called for taxing increases in the value of union pension plans, individual retirement accounts and Keogh plans every year.
Republicans senators, fearful that this idea would sabotage the retirement saving system, are threatening to grill Ms. Munnell when her confirmation hearing is held over the next few weeks. Mr. Bentsen has not embraced her idea, and few analysts think he ever will because it would be political suicide.
And Mr. Summers, a longtime Harvard economics professor, faced considerable heat from environmentalists and a few senators at his hearings last month.
In one of those peculiarly Washington scenes, by the time one of his confirmation hearings was over environmentalists had littered the room with hundreds of leaflets denouncing him, while he had changed his tune to sound like the best friend the environmentalists ever had.
The lesson: provocative ideas that make for good debates in academe are not always so welcome in the halls of power.

HEADLINE: Fortunes and Fear in Mexican Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Although still not totally comfortable with the volatility of the Mexican stock market, more United States investors are taking Mexico's stocks seriously, hoping for long-term returns and the completion of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Despite the Mexican market's lackluster performance this year, and despite the worries of some about the outcome of the nation's next election and even about economic stability, analysts remain optimistic about the Mexican stock market. They expect several more years of solid growth. 
 Foreign investors, most from the United States, have grown increasingly comfortable putting money into Mexican stocks. Such investment soared last year to $27 billion, up from slightly more than $4.2 billion in 1991. Investment activity has moderated a bit this year, but foreigners still account for nearly 20 percent of the market's total capitalization and more than half its trading volume.
 
Stunning Returns
 The Bolsa Mexicana de Valores -- literally the "Mexican sack of values" -- is already Latin America's largest stock exchange in terms of capitalization, or the number of shares multiplied by their value. And for more than a decade, it has been one of the best-performing stock markets in the world, some analysts say. The market, as tracked by The Financial Times of London, is 10 times its level in 1982.
"There has been some reluctance to investing in Mexico until recently, but investors have finally realized that our economy has slowed down, whereas in Mexico the prospect for higher returns remains much greater," said David G. Marshall, a senior research analyst at the Investment Placement Group of San Diego, a management company.
Large investment fund companies like Kemper Financial Companies; Scudder, Stevens & Clark; Fidelity Investments, and Capital Research Managers have become major Mexican players, investing heavily in both equities and fixed-rate investments. At the same time, midsize investors like the Investment Placement Group and pension funds like the State of Wisconsin Investment Board have been drawn to Mexico by its slowing inflation and consistent growth.
"Technically, Mexico is still considered an emerging market," said Kathleen M. Harris, who manages the $1 billion international equity portfolio of the State of Wisconsin Investment Board, which has substantially increased its Mexican holdings over the last three years. "But from the standpoint of how we view it currently, we tend to think of it as being a not expensive market that still has some attractive risk-reward situations."
 
Inherent Risks Seen
 The risks, however, can be substantial. "The long-term prospects are outstanding," said Mr. Marshall of the Investment Placement Group, which controls about $70 million in Mexico, "but you have to deal with the short-term volatility."
Although the Bolsa is the eighth-largest exchange in the world in capitalization, it is essentially a very thin market, tied to the performance of a few large companies.
A few more than 180 stocks are listed, compared with more than 1,600 on the New York Stock Exchange. Telefonos de Mexico, widely known as Telmex, the national telecommunications monopoly, is capitalized at about 25 percent of the total Bolsa value, and its fortunes count heavily in the Bolsa's 38-share index.
Most analysts expect the exchange to be influenced by politics both in the United States and in Mexico for the rest of the year. There is the debate now in the United States over the North American Free Trade Agreement. Then, there is the matter of the Mexican governing party's selection of its candidate to run in next year's presidential election.
Analysts are split over the possibility of a major devaluation of the peso. But many believe that the high interest rates that have restricted credit and strapped the Bolsa will be lowered later in the year in an attempt to bolster the economy just as the presidential candidate of the governing party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, is announced in November.
The PRI's candidate is favored to win the election; no Mexican President since 1929 has come from the opposition, although the leftist candidate, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, made a strong run for the presidency in 1988.
Some of the largest investors have been willing to overlook the Bolsa's many slips and dips, which can be set off by a rumor about Telmex or a proposed change in Government policy. "At the moment we're pretty unambiguously optimistic about investment in Mexico," said A. Peter Monaco, portfolio manager for the Scudder Latin America Fund, which has more than $500 million in Mexico.
Mexican companies and United States investors have benefited greatly from the recent growth in American depository receipts, negotiable certificates based on United States dollars that represent a foreign company's stock and can be traded in the United States.
Investments by Americans in Mexican stocks have largely been in a handful of big companies, led by Telmex. The phone company's depository receipts were the seventh most actively traded issue in the United States in 1992.
Nearly 465 million shares of Telmex -- with a dollar volume exceeding $23 billion -- were traded on the New York Stock Exchange last year, according to the Bank of New York.
 
Some Other Big Companies
 The receipts of five other large Mexican companies are traded on the New York Stock Exchange. One concern, Tubos de Acero de Mexico, a large manufacturing company that makes pipes and tubes, is listed on the American Stock Exchange.
"Dealing in the Mexican market has become almost commonplace," said Timothy C. Davis, a vice president for emerging markets at Lazard Freres & Company. "There is a lot of Mexican volume trading between New York institutions. You don't need the Mexican Bolsa anymore to trade share purchases. In many ways, the Bolsa is moving to New York."
Until recently, many Americans seemed willing to buy anything with Mexico in its name. The Bolsa rose sharply through much of the 1980's, more than doubled in value in 1991, and started 1992 with a 30 percent jump. But then it went into a free fall over the political uncertainty of the Presidential election in the United States and concerns about the trade agreement, which would wipe away most tariffs on goods moving among Canada, Mexico and the United States. Much of that lost value was regained after Bill Clinton was elected and he expressed tempered support for the accord if side agreements that protect United States interests could be negotiated.
 
A Winning Play
 The first Mexican stock in many portfolios was Telmex. Anyone who bought the stock in 1988, when its shares were available on Nasdaq, for less than $3 and sold when Telmex, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, reached its peak of $60 in February 1992, made a ton of money.
"Telmex really represented for a lot of people the Mexican economic success," said Eduardo M. Cabrera, manager of Latin American Equity Research at Merrill Lynch & Company. But anyone who bought Telmex in early 1992, hoping that the rise would continue and believing that the free trade pact would be quickly enacted, has lost money. The Telmex A.D.R. is now trading at $54.
Aeromexico, which practically has an aviation monopoly, once seemed a sure bet, but has floundered. Its stock sold last summer for $16 a share, and has since dropped as low as $5. Tubos de Mexico and Grupo Gigante of Mexico, which sells food and general merchandise and operates restaurants, are poor performers of late.
Although investors worry about Mexico's growing current accounts deficit -- which is forecast to reach $22 billion this year -- investors are encouraged by recent corporate decisions. Anheuser-Busch, for example, recently agreed to take a $477 million stake in one of Mexico's largest brewing companies, Grupo Modelo, which makes Corona beer. Grupo Modelo executives have said they are planning the company's first public offering, perhaps by the end of this year.

HEADLINE: As Tax Day Nears, a Kinder I.R.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
They just don't make April 15 the way they used to.
Thursday is still the deadline for filing personal income tax returns, and yes, there are still penalties for people who don't file or who don't pay what they owe. 
 But the Internal Revenue Service has made changes this year that should ease the seasonal panic of the dilatory, the disorderly and the accounting-impaired.
The changes have moved the long-feared agency further than ever toward encouraging people to pay what they owe voluntarily. For the past several years, faced with 10 million people who don't file each year, the agency's leaders have spoken of the importance of putting forward a more sympathetic face. This year, there are more conciliatory rules behind the smile.
 
Borrowing From the I.R.S.
 The new rules make it easier to file for an automatic four-month extension of the deadline, as about 5 million people do every year. They also make it simpler for most people to legally put off paying what they owe, effectively borrowing from the I.R.S. and paying in installments. And they provide a way for taxpayers in financial distress to negotiate compromises that actually reduce the amount they must pay.
"It is clearly a taxpayer-friendly type of approach," said William J. Goldberg, national director of personal financial planning for KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm.
At I.R.S. headquarters in Washington, a steady stream of taxpayers came and went on Friday, many of them picking up either Form 4868, the application for a filing extension, or Form 9465, which is used to request installment payments of taxes owed.
Sandra Gould, 41, who works for the Federal Aviation Administration, said she was there to apply for an extension. She said that she had just moved to Washington from Missouri, did not have all the paperwork she needed to file on time, and had considered not filing at all this year until she learned that she could do so without paying her estimated tax next week.
"That gave me the incentive to file for the extension," she said.
Charlie Ingram, who works at the Treasury Department, was planning to request the installment plan. "I'm going to file on time, give them some money, and tell them I'll pay the rest later," he said.
Officials said that it is still advisable to pay as much as possible as soon as possible -- and extremely important to file for any extension by April 15.
Late applications for extensions are invalid, subjecting taxpayers to the agency's full penalties for failing to file and ruling out the use of several dozen important tax breaks when the return is eventually filed. For example, a couple who fail to obtain a valid extension may not later include their child's dividend income on their own return; their mistake may spawn a juvenile tax delinquent. And a self-employed person who files late without a valid extension cannot deduct contributions to a Keogh retirement plan.
So far this year, the I.R.S. has received about 5 million fewer tax returns than at the same time last year. I.R.S. officials speculated that many people have delayed filing their returns after discovering that they will not get their customary refund this year -- or that they may even owe tax -- because of changes in the tax withholding formulas instituted last year by the Bush Administration in an effort to pump cash into the economy.
Ellen Murphy, the I.R.S. spokesman, said the agency was aware of the refund drought when it changed some of its rules last week, but that the purpose of the change was to dissuade taxpayers from neglecting to file just because they couldn't afford to pay right away.
 
Interest Charges Still Apply
 The decision to let delayed filers pay later was announced on Wednesday. The I.R.S. said that this is the first year it would accept an application for the automatic four-month extension of the deadline even if the taxpayer could not not pay what is owed with the application.
In the past, an application filed without a check for any tax due would be rejected. The I.R.S. would consider the tax return delinquent and assess a penalty of 5 percent each month on the balance due, up to 25 percent.
Even with the extension, there are interest charges of 7 percent on any taxes paid after April 15. If payments made by April 15 are less than 90 percent of the total tax, there is also a monthly late-payment penalty of five-tenths of a percent of the unpaid taxes. Together, those charges would be equivalent to a 13 percent annual interest rate on delayed payments.
Financial advisers say it is probably more sensible to borrow the owed amount from a bank than from the Government. By paying interest to the I.R.S., however, "you don't have to make a credit application and you don't have to fill out a financial statement, and it may be your only source of credit," Mr. Goldberg said.
This year, any taxpayer who owes less than $10,000 will have an easier time obtaining an agreement for paying in installments. When the debt is that small, the I.R.S. will not file liens against delinquent taxpayers, and the payment schedules can be approved routinely by officials at regional I.R.S. offices.
Form 9465 lets taxpayers propose their own terms for periodic payments. The I.R.S. would not say what kinds of offers it would consider reasonable, but anyone who offered to pay a few thousand dollars, plus interest, in monthly payments over less than two years would be likely to get the deal approved, officials said. The average installment agreement is for about $2,300 paid over 20 months.
Taxpayers who find that they did not have enough taxes withheld last year should file new W-4 forms with their employers to correct the problem. But a taxpayer in arrears cannot simply increase withholding as a way of paying the I.R.S. under an installment plan.
However, a taxpayer can propose that the I.R.S. put a modest levy on a paycheck. The agency would contact the employer and the periodic payments of overdue taxes would then be withheld automatically.
Last year, installment payment agreements increased 47 percent, and collections from installment agreements went up 27 percent, the I.R.S. said. The numbers are still relatively small, however; so far this year, the agency has received about 100,000 requests for installment payments.
Taxpayers are also choosing more frequently to negotiate a compromise payment, which the I.R.S. will accept in cases where there is virtually no hope of ever collecting the full amount owed. That process requires detailed financial statements and usually a meeting with a revenue agent.

HEADLINE: Greenwich Feels Pain of Change

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., April 9

 BODY:
If the Disney people wanted to update Main Street, U.S.A., they might copy Greenwich Avenue, a broad, sloping street of historic storefronts where police officers, not traffic lights, direct cars through busy intersections.
D. W. Rogers, descended from a local general store, is a neighbor of F. W. Woolworth. Boswell's, Finch's and Grannick's pharmacies endure. But Victoria's Secret and Banana Republic are also neighbors, and each end of the avenue is now anchored by an office plaza. 
 Greenwich Avenue may already be a Disney-like illusion, in which the old and new seem to coexist peaceably. And its changing face is just part of the price that this wealthy Fairfield County community is paying for its transformation in the 1970's and 80's from small town to small city.
Now that the diaspora of corporations from Manhattan appears over, towns that welcomed their buildings and tax revenues are learning the true costs. In Greenwich, a looming property-tax increase has made clear that office buildings are not financial saviors. Too late, some residents are also concluding that the tax revenues are not worth the loss of harbor views, or the traffic congestion, or the opening of this serene community to the more harried world around it.
In a town that has long clung to a simpler image of itself than its population (58,400), wealth (per-capita income: $46,000) or better-known residents (Ivan Lendl, Ivana Trump, Tom Seaver) might suggest, second-guessing is common.
"I have the feeling that I'm sitting in a lawyer's office at the reading of a will, and everybody in the family is fighting about who got what and who didn't get what," said the First Selectman, John B. Margenot Jr.
The immediate cause of distress is a townwide revaluation of real estate, which Connecticut requires every 10 years for assessing property taxes. Ten years is a lifetime in real estate, so a revaluation can put a decade's changes in perspective with a jolt.
The revaluation found that houses had increased in value much more than offices, battered more by the recession. Commercial property now makes up 18.4 percent of the tax roll and pays $23 million in taxes; the revaluation reduces it to 12.0 percent and $15.5 million.
Homeowners will make up the difference. So while the taxes on the headquarters of U.S. Tobacco could fall 40 percent, to $261,800 from $442,755, taxes on small subdivision houses are to increase 20 to 30 percent, to around $2,500, from $2,000.
Many estates will see larger increases. On Field Point Circle on Long Island Sound, the increases range up to 100 percent, raising some taxes to more than $40,000 a year.
Compared with many towns, Greenwich will still have low taxes, despite a $160 million budget that supports excellent schools and amenities like 1,400 acres of parks and four beaches, including an island in Long Island Sound served by a municipal ferry. (Because more than 3,000 property owners challenged the new assessments, the town has delayed them until next year).
And Greenwich, while becoming home to American Can, U.S. Tobacco, Chesebrough-Pond's and other corporations, imposed building restrictions early, sending Xerox and other companies on to more willing Stamford.
The building boom ended here by 1980, and through the 80's the offices seemed to pay their way. The main cost, to many people, was the long lines of traffic caused by 20,000 commuters.
"I think most people are satisfied that we've maintained the scale of the town and limited large-scale development," said the town planner, James Sandy. "The residential property has become so valuable because we have maintained the scale."
The revaluation, however, has revived the 70's debates over allowing office development.
"The leaders of the town would say, 'This is a benefit, it will keep your tax rate low, they will not use any services, they will not use the school system, they will pay a fair share,' " recalled June Curley, a real-estate agent who has lived here since 1956.
"Nobody said to us that if they don't make the revenue they expect, you the taxpayer will have to pick up the slack," she said.
Many people regret the transformation of Greenwich over the last 10 years, when a community of nearly 60,000 people that felt like a small town suddenly, while losing population, started to feel like a small city.
Streets were widened, traffic lights installed, and yet traffic worsened. Local stores closed while national chains moved in. School enrollment dropped but the town budget swelled.
Mr. Margenot, whose family owns commercial property in Greenwich, says the corporations did help Greenwich keep its tax rate low, if only because the alternative -- more housing -- would have demanded more from the town's services and schools.
"Basically the town maintained the kind of life that we've always had," he said.
The shifting tax burden will cause pain; Greenwich has working-class families, a large middle class, retirees, and plenty of residents who are nervous about their jobs. Yet such tax shifts are common in revaluations, and have been even more extreme in poorer cities, like New Haven, and cities more dependent on commercial property, like Stamford.
Here, many people are looking at the revaluation as a warning that Greenwich must change even more, to preserve what it values most.
"Just like G.M. and I.B.M., the day of reckoning comes and somebody has to get serious about management," said George Schiele, the president of a taxpayers' group that is threatening a budget referendum.
That, however, might require remaking Greenwich's small-town government, which divides power among Mr. Margenot, an elected finance board, and a Representative Town Meeting with 230 elected members.
"I guess we do have to decide whether we're a town or a city," said Richard Stefani, the president of the Round Hill neighborhood association.
Mr. Stefani worries that higher taxes may prompt some residents to sell their extra acres to builders, filling in the fields and woodlots.
Ms. Curley worries that higher taxes will speed a trend toward younger families passing by Greenwich for New Canaan or Darien as they move up to larger houses. In their place, she sees more buyers from New York.
Others complain about the out-of-towners on Greenwich Avenue: both the shoppers taking parking spaces, and the stores like The Limited, The Gap and Polo Ralph Lauren that have replaced local merchants.
Parking is a headache, but many residents oppose building garages -- or tiered structures, as they are called here. Why, they ask, should Greenwich pay for city-like garages that will benefit national stores and shoppers from Westchester County?
But the new stores are helping to keep Greenwich Avenue alive while many downtowns die. They attract people who also spend money in the older local stores that define Greenwich for its own residents.
At D. W. Rogers, the clerks still hand-tie the bows on packages, carry bags out to customers' cars, and deliver pajamas to patients at Greenwich Hospital. "We get a lot of people who come out of the city on Saturday," said the owner, Terry Baxendale. "Maybe it's an alternative.
"Some people say, 'If we didn't have the chains, we would still be that quaint little town we were 20 years ago.' I don't necessarily buy that, because nothing remains the same."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As Greenwich, Conn., has grown into a small city, it has retained much of its "Main Street, U.S.A." look, but many residents agree that more traffic and views blocked by new building are not worth new tax revenues. (David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
Yankee Stadium: the Bronx's Diamond in the Rough

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
In the scruffy blocks around Yankee Stadium, spring blossoms today in the form of the Bronx Bombers' home opener.
At Vega Alta Bar at 880 Gerard Avenue, daily receipts will jump from the usual $200 to something like $1,200. At Stadium Hardware next door, the plumbers' helpers in the window will be totally supplanted by Yankees caps and T-shirts. The trade at River Cigars at East 161st Street and River Avenue will perk up, the owner confidently predicts. 
 Equally eager, presumably, are the entrepreneurs who extort $5 or $10 for "watching" your car after you have legally parked it on the street.
"It's a great money-making day," exulted Louie Diamontis, manager of Ball Park Lanes at 810 River Avenue.
 
Reading Mr. Steinbrenner
 The Yankees are locally perceived as a rare golden goose in a borough of street pigeons. The house that Ruth built presides over the nation's poorest Congressional district, near block upon block of dilapidated buildings, teeming streets, bodegas and bars. Many fans scurry from the parking lots to the stadium and back again, fearful of crime.
But they come, a few venturing into the neighborhood, all spending money. "At least there's some legitimate economic activity conducted in the South Bronx," said Henry Stern, president of the Citizens' Union, a government watchdog group.
Given the context, the impact is big. "The Yankees are the hub of the Bronx economy," declared Richard Guidron, chairman of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce.
"If they were to leave, it would take us years to recover," said Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President. "The emotional hole might never be filled."
The concern about possibly itchy Yankee feet, reflected in comments on sports call-in shows as well as unsolicited letters to city officials, is being fired by the return of the principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner, from two and a half years of banishment from baseball.
One of the club's first acts under his renewed leadership was to conduct a poll of season ticket holders asking, among many other things, how they would feel if the club moved from the Bronx.
Club spokesmen say the poll has not been completed, and that it most likely will not be released even when it is. Mr. Steinbrenner himself denied a move is being considered, then added, both impishly and ominously, "Nothing is certain but death and taxes."
 
Team's Importance Debated
 Bronxites can only watch nervously, squinting at elusive tea leaves. "We are all keeping our fingers crossed," said Ed Arigoni, owner of the New York Bus Company as well as a lavish Yankee Stadium box.
"My initial reaction is that it's a negotiating move," said Mr. Ferrer.
The Yankees' lease is scheduled to expire in 2002. Mr. Steinbrenner agreed in October 1987 to extend the lease with the city to 2032 in return for more parking and other improvements, but then neither he nor his agents signed the agreement. Talks are now stalled.
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, a self-described baseball hater who is still angry over the collapse of the earlier deal, nonetheless insisted it was in the city's economic interest to take large strides to retain the Yankees. "I think there are intangibles plus tangibles that make it worthwhile to subsidize keeping a major league team in the city," he said in an interview.
Economists who have studied the economic benefits of having a professional sports team are more dubious. "The Yankees are exploiting the city," declared Andrew Zimbalist, a Smith College economist who has written extensively about the economics of the baseball industry.
"You can't do anything but conclude that stadiums and teams are not likely to create anything in the way of economic activity," said Robert Baade, an economist who has studied the experience of nine cities with baseball teams, measuring retail sales, employment and personal income.
 
A Commercial Anchor
 But Mr. Baade, who teaches at Lake Forest College in Illinois, adds that the politics of helping a baseball club almost always helps incumbents, perhaps explaining the frequency of such largess. He points to a 10 percent jump in the popularity of Mayor Harold Washington of Chicago in 1986 after his administration decided to support a new stadium for the White Sox.
But most people have little doubt that big league ball helps the tattered blocks surrounding Yankee Stadium. Jackie Sanchez, a secretary who lives in the neighborhood, said game days are so much better in the area. "Mucho cops," she said. "And you feel good just looking at the people go by."
"If the Yankees go, nothing would come in" to fill the void, said Steve Manesis, manager of the Unity Coffee Shop at 58 East 161st Street. "All these people around here would go out of business."
Some feel the Yankees' gradual shift to a schedule of almost all night games has worsened business.
Louis Reda, manager of the Yankee Tavern at Gerard and 161st Street, said that after the games, fans were less likely to linger in neighborhood places. "TV is ruling the schedule," he said.
Some business people consider the Yankees largely irrelevant, given that so many fans are afraid to venture into the neighborhood and so few residents of the surrounding area can afford to go to games. "Yankee Stadium doesn't exist," said Abdul Jabbar, who sells incense at the corner of Gerard Avenue and 161st Street and is now putting two children through college. "It's just a statue."
 
A Lesson From Brooklyn
 And others, like Mark Karow, the third-generation owner of Stadium Hardware, think their businesses might actually benefit if Yankee Stadium were replaced by housing projects, as happened to Ebbets Field and the Polo Grounds.
"I would have more customers," he said. "The minus would be that I love the Yankees."
It has now been 15 years since Manny's Baseball Land picked up stakes and left its site across the street from the stadium, where it was replaced by Stan the Man's Baseball Land. From a Florida warehouse, Manny's does a nice business under the same name selling Yankee uniforms and other merchandise by mail.
"The Bronx wasn't what it used to be," Ron Meshil, one of the owners, said of the long-ago departure. "But we're still die-hard Yankee fans and always will be."

The real winners during the baseball season are the merchants in the neighborhood. (pg. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Price Data and Supply Favor Lower Yields

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Yields in the bond market are likely to move lower, following better inflation news last week than most traders had dared to hope for, and the scheduled release this week of retail sales and industrial-production data that are expected to be sluggish.
While investment markets were closed for Good Friday, the Labor Department was open, and it reported that the Consumer Price Index for March rose only one-tenth of a percent. 
 More startling was that the so-called core rate -- which excludes volatile food and energy costs -- was also up a mere one-tenth of a percent. The day before, a report that core producer prices also rose only one-tenth of a percent set off a buying surge in bonds that pushed down the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond to 6.85 percent.
Tomorrow, the Commerce Department will release the retail sales report for March, and the results are expected to be weak, in part because of the weather. Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities Inc., is forecasting a decline of five-tenths of a percent. And he expects industrial production, which will be reported by the Federal Reserve system on Thursday, to be flat.
"It almost looks like a one-way street," Mr. Fine said. "There is no threat of inflation, weak retail sales and a lackluster industrial production. It seems to me that by this time next week, we will be closer to new lows in yields than we are today."
But will yields break through the lows reached at the beginning of March: 6.72 percent on the 30-year bond and 5.82 percent on the 10-year note? If traders and investors do buy enough bonds and notes to push the yields below those levels, the new rally may have little to do with inflation fears' subsiding for the present.
The likely reason would instead be technical forces that move markets but are often immune to the ups and downs of economic data. Such forces include the pace of Government borrowing and the need for municipalities and other governments to buy Treasury securities as part of the process of paying off older debts that carry higher interest rates.
 
The Supply Variable
 Also playing a role is the currently benign stance of the Federal Reserve. Because of low inflation and the economy's slow growth, there is reason to believe that the central bank will have no cause to raise short-term interest rates any time soon. That removes a lot of the risk in buying longer-term Treasury securities.
One of the technical factors noted by traders and analysts is that the Treasury's borrowing requirements for the second quarter are unusually low. Estimates range from $25 billion down to $10 billion. Although there is debate about the effect of the supply of government notes and bonds, it seems in the near term to help support market prices when it is lower. Bond prices move in inverse direction to their yields; a rise in a bond's selling price bond reduces the percentage it yields to the purchaser.
This week, it appears that many investors and traders may be preparing to focus more on the Treasury's limited borrowing in the second quarter than on the huge increase expected in the third quarter.
The one supply variable this week is the auction of the seven-year note. Some traders suggest that this auction, which has often led to market selloffs, could again go poorly and encourage selling, even given the limited Treasury borrowing needs now.
The other technical factor is speculation on what the Treasury will do about the mixture of its borrowing in an effort to reduce costs and help cut the Federal budget deficit.
The Treasury is in the midst of a study of how it would have to alter the maturity periods of its bonds, notes and bills to produce the $16.3 billion savings over five years called for in President Clinton's budget proposals, which were released in detail last week.
One way to achieve such savings, as noted in a Senate Budget Committee proposal and an analysis by Goldman Sachs & Company, would be to reduce the total size of the 30-year bond auction, eliminate the 7-year Treasury note, cut the size of the 5-year note auction 20 percent and shift this borrowing to short-term Treasury bills. The savings would be achieved by borrowing at lower interest rates, and the analysis assumes there will not be a big jump in short-term rates.
 
Matter of Degree
 The Treasury study is expected to determine whether such a change in the borrowing mixture might prove to be too radical. If it is deemed so, the change would be more modest and the $16.3 billion savings target might have to be scaled back.
Speculation that the more radical approach will be adopted by the Treasury was reported by Stone & McCarthy Research Associates and by Goldman Sachs last week. Just this talk helped push up the price of the 30-year bond by 30/32 over two days -- on Tuesday and Wednesday -- and pushed down the yield to 6.95 percent.
At a news conference on Thursday, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said once again that he planned no radical changes. But the definition of radical has been left unclear.
Over the last five quarters, the Treasury has already reduced the 30-year auction to a total of $9.25 billion from $12 billion, a 23 percent cut that was apparently not deemed radical. It seems clear that if a further cut in the size of the 30-year auction is made, it will be done by moving from four regular auctions a year to two, rather than trimming back individual auctions. Market analysts and Treasury officials agree that reducing the size of the individual auctions any further leaves open the possibility that they would be small enough to be manipulated by large buyers.
So if a cut is made, eliminating the 30-year auction this May would be a logical choice if the Treasury thinks it is more important to achieve budget savings than to maintain a constant and predictable approach to borrowing in the Treasury market.

HEADLINE: House Panel To Examine Air Fare Suit

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Responding to an unlikely alliance of airlines and consumer groups, Congress plans to investigate the merits of a pending antitrust case filed by the Justice Department.
The department has accused the eight largest United States airlines of using a computerized reservation system to fix air fares. Specifically, the airlines are accused of signaling proposed changes in their future fares, thereby alerting other airlines that then decide whether to match, underprice or ignore their rivals. 
 The Justice Department wants the airlines to make the fares available as soon as they are entered into the computer reservation system, and not at some future date, to preclude such potential collusion. In other words, if an airline signals that it plans to change a specific fare on a certain route, it must offer that fare immediately.
Without admitting or denying the Government's accusation, United and USAir have agreed to sign a consent decree and end the practice of communicating proposed fare increases through the computerized system. But American, Delta, Northwest, Continental, T.W.A. and Alaska Airlines are defending themselves in the courts.
The Justice Department's antitrust suit is not related to a class action on price fixing filed by consumer groups on behalf of airline passengers who traveled between Jan. 1, 1988, and June 30, 1992. In the settlement of that case, consumers are to receive discount coupons for future flights.
 
An Unusual Coalition
 In the Justice Department case, airlines and consumer groups find themselves on the same side.
Neil Monroe, a spokesman for Delta, said, "We think that the airline industry is being unreasonably targeted for giving out advance information that is readily available from every other industry, from car makers to retail stores."
Consumer groups also oppose the antitrust suit, arguing that advance information on fare changes helps the public in travel planning. For example, a travel agent might alert a client that a round-trip fare between New York and Miami was scheduled to increase in one week and that it would be advantageous to buy the ticket before the increase.
Responding to complaints from consumer groups, Representative James L. Oberstar, the Minnesota Democrat who is chairman of the aviation subcommittee of the Public Works and Transportation Committee, has scheduled hearings on the matter for April 20.
"We want to find out just how this sharing of information through electronic transmission works," Mr. Oberstar said last week in an interview. "Is it a substitute for face-to-face agreements to raise prices, or is it simply a clearinghouse of information? Does it benefit consumers or disadvantage them?
"Many consumer groups say that this consent decree would adversely affect consumers by resulting in higher fares and less competition," he continued. "That's something that ought to be aired."
 
'An Interdependent Industry'
 Some industry officials acknowledge that the airlines have used the computerized reservation system to advise their competitors of future fares. "We're an interdependent industry," said Elliot Seiden, Northwest Airlines' vice president for governmental affairs, who formerly headed the Justice Department's transportation antitrust division.
"None of us can price without regard to the competitive response of our competitors," Mr. Seiden said.
From the consumer's standpoint, the product -- an airline seat on a given route -- is easily transferrable from one airline to another, Mr. Seiden noted, and therefore "if one airline has a fare increase, you lose bookings immediately," he said.
Mr. Seiden contends that price signaling is not illegal. "There's no violation in the Sherman Act called 'price signaling,' " he said, referring to the principal Federal antitrust statute. To be guilty of price fixing, Mr. Seiden said, "you need an agreement between the parties," who never meet under the existing system.
 
Frequent Fare Changes
 The Justice Department contends that price-fixing agreements are tacitly reached through the computer reservation system and that airlines collude by frequently making changes in future fares before the fares take effect.
The Justice Department claimed that in one case an airline made 11 changes in a future fare in a 30-day period, making it all but impossible for a consumer to make plans on the basis of this information because the actual ticket could not be purchased at the new fare until its effective date.
The lawsuit said that in some cases an airline would signal its intention to reduce a fare on a route that was lucrative for a competitor, which would then retaliate by signaling its intention to reduce a fare on a route that was lucrative for the first airline. In some cases, both fare reductions were then abandoned, or an accommodation was reached, the Justice Department contended in a brief filed last week.
"Consumers pay a substantial price for the airlines' communication tools -- higher fares than would otherwise prevail -- and receive little countervailing benefit from them," the department said. "Because ticket dates are used by the airlines to negotiate, not to notify consumers about fare changes, they are by their nature extremely unreliable and of minimal value to consumers."
 
Not a Typical Commodity
 Consumer groups see the issue differently. They argue that the signaled fare often takes effect as scheduled and is matched by competitors.
"The problem is the Justice Department suit doesn't give enough emphasis to the fact that consumers want flexibility when purchasing airline tickets," said Cornish Hitchcock, an aviation specialist with Public Citizen, the consumer advocates group founded by Ralph Nader.
"Unlike other commodities, airline tickets are purchased often well before consumers actually use them," he continued. "People are reluctant to commit their money if they don't have to, and want flexibility in arranging travel dates."
Mr. Hitchcock said the Justice Department had offered scant evidence to prove its case. Therefore, he said, "it's difficult to know if this is a good price-fixing case or merely economic theory that anti-competitive behavior has in fact occurred."
Similarly, Linda Golodner, president of the National Consumers League, said, "We feel that consumers should know up front what the costs are and what discounts are available."

HEADLINE: Back on Track in Aiding Nicaragua

 BODY:
Nicaragua's failure to please Senator Jesse Helms, the hard-right North Carolina Republican, will no longer cost it American support. The State Department says that $50 million in blocked U.S. aid will now be released because Nicaragua is making progress on human rights and other matters in dispute.
Senator Helms's oft-repeated complaint is that President Violeta Chamorro yielded too much power to the Sandinistas she defeated in 1990. Granted, Mrs. Chamorro opted for conciliation by retaining Humberto Ortega, brother of former Sandinista President Daniel Ortega, as head of the armed forces. 
 Yet it never troubled Mr. Helms that in Chile, an elected democratic government agreed pragmatically to permit the former rightist dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, to continue as military commander. Nor has he clamored for a purge of the Salvadoran armed forces and punishment of all their human rights crimes. The Senator's indignation is selective: his tolerance for hard-right thuggery is exceeded only by his enthusiasm for tobacco subsidies.
Nicaragua can be faulted for its failure to punish recent killings of former contras, and to move expeditiously on compensating owners of property lawlessly seized by the Sandinistas. Thus the Bush Administration last summer put $104 million in aid on hold. It then released $54 million of that aid in December, letting a new Administration decide about the balance. By any fair measure, that deferred more than enough to Mr. Helms.
Mrs. Chamorro merits praise for drastically reducing the size of the army and curbing runaway inflation. Her battered country is still recovering from a civil war that was fueled by the Reagan Administration's covert support for contra rebels. Having contributed to this mess, Washington has reason to assist in the cleanup.
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Empire Blue Cross Deserves Better Treatment;
Not the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to statements attributed to me in "The Blame for Empire's Mess" (editorial, March 31), I have never blamed the "poor economy" for Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield's problems. Nor have I, the Insurance Department or the Cuomo administration been inattentive to the real problems. The state's landmark community rating-open enrollment legislation, proposed by Governor Cuomo in 1991, was designed to address many of the concerns you implicitly raise. Moreover, an Arthur Andersen audit of Empire, encouraged by my office, will speak to the direct management concerns. 
 For years Empire accepted for coverage all domestic individuals and small groups, including those whose health histories made them unacceptable to the large commercial insurers. During this time, commercial insurers routinely skimmed off the best small-group risks for themselves, which meant larger rate increases for the pool of poor risks that remained with Empire. Most of these commercial insurers also refused to sell health insurance to individuals.
Empire's record of profits and losses for large corporate accounts in the last few years roughly parallels that of many of its commercial competitors. One big difference is that Empire rises or falls with its health insurance business, while large commercial companies can mask losses on the health side by profits generated by other lines of business.
Empire must also contend with the jump in Medical care costs, estimated at 12 percent last year and projected to increase further unless our system of health care delivery is significantly altered. And since Empire's individual and small group policyholders tend to be older and sicker than those of other carriers, the costs will rise even higher.
Finally, I have consistently said that Empire could have been managed better in the last five years. The Arthur Andersen audit, due out May 1, should determine if mismanagement played a role in the company's tailspin. In addition, a nine-member bipartisan panel has been authorized by legislation enacted this year to provide additional oversight.
Friends and critics of Empire may point to other reasons for Empire's problems, but none to my knowledge has ever cited the poor economy. To attribute such a simplistic and wrongheaded view to me, the public official charged with regulating the company, is inaccurate and irresponsible.
 
SALVATORE R. CURIALE
Superintendent of Insurance
New York, April 1, 1993

HEADLINE: Jefferson Is America -- And America Is Jefferson

BYLINE: By David K. Shipler; David K. Shipler, a Pulitzer Prize-winning author, is writing a book about race in America.

DATELINE: Chevy Chase, Md.

 BODY:
Thomas Jefferson embodied the most powerful contradiction of the American legacy. His declarations on individual liberty, which remain a moral and political compass, showed the brilliance of a transcendent mind. But he also believed in the inferiority of black people, demonstrating how even a great thinker can remain captive of the racist stereotypes of his time.
That one man could simultaneously possess such vision and such blindness is intriguing; that his attitudes on race should persist in the culture at large, as they have, tells a troubling story about American society. It is a perspective that schools, universities and libraries should adopt as they celebrate the 250th anniversary of Jefferson's birth today, , for he can be just as instructive about the wounds of racism as the nobility of democracy. And his statements about blacks are rarely taught in history courses. 
 "We routinely return to Jefferson and his era in order to discover the glory of America," wrote Charles A. Miller, a Jefferson scholar at Lake Forest College in Illinois. "We should also be willing to return in order to find early evidence of our distress." Mr. Miller added: "I believe that Jefferson was firmly -- centrally and emblematically -- in the stream of American anguish over slavery and race, and he knew it. I also believe that the present, in altered form, is like Jefferson."
Recognizing this becomes especially important in an era when many whites seem convinced that racism has abated, that blacks have equal opportunity, that the slate was wiped clean by the civil rights laws of the 1960's. Whites who oppose antidiscrimination measures often argue sincerely that they are not responsible for a past that is long gone.What they don't acknowledge is that while slavery and legal segregation have ended, many attitudes that drove those practices remain, although muted and often concealed beneath the surface of propriety.
Racism is still the most corrosive problem in America, and its major elements can be seen clearly in what Jefferson wrote and did.
In his only book, "Notes on the State of Virginia," written in 1785, Jefferson observes his slaves and endorses virtually every stereotype -- positive but largely negative -- that today characterizes the system of prejudices about black people physically, mentally, sexually, emotionally.
Their "unfortunate difference of color" makes blacks less beautiful than whites, Jefferson writes. "Are not the fine mixtures of red and white, the expressions of every passion by greater or less suffusions of color in the one, preferable to that eternal monotony . . . that immovable veil of black which covers the emotions of the other race?"
He indulges in false science. "They secrete less by the kidneys, and more by the glands of the skin, which gives them a very strong and disagreeable odor," he argues, adding that this "renders them more tolerant of heat, and less so of cold than the whites."
"They are at least as brave, and more adventuresome," he continues. "But this may perhaps proceed from a want of forethought, which prevents their seeing a danger till it be present. . . . They are more ardent after their female; but love seems with them to be more an eager desire, than a tender delicate mixture of sentiment and sensation. Their griefs are transient . . . In memory they are equal to the whites; in reason much inferior, as I think one could scarcely be found capable of tracing and comprehending the investigations of Euclid."
Jefferson excuses blacks' supposed "disposition to theft," attributing it to "their situation, and not to any depravity of the moral sense." He adds: "We find among them numerous instances of the most rigid integrity, of benevolence, gratitude, and unshaken fidelity."
Jefferson proposes "to make great allowances for the difference of condition, of education, of conversation, of the sphere in which they move." On the other hand, he notes, many slaves worked closely with whites in the crafts, and others had the opportunity to converse with their masters.
"But never yet could I find that a black had uttered a thought above the level of plain narration; never saw even an elementary trait of painting or sculpture. In music they are more generally gifted than the whites," but not in other arts. "Misery is often the parent of the most affecting touches in poetry. Among the blacks is misery enough, God knows, but no poetry."
Jefferson concludes that "their inferiority is not the effect merely of their condition of life," then later modifies himself slightly, saying that he puts forth this view "with great diffidence" and "as a suspicion only."
Such ugly suspicions, also tempered with diffidence, lie in mainstream white America today. They nag quietly at the platitudes and the fine principles and the professions of tolerance. As Jefferson demonstrated, they co-exist alongside an understanding of their damage to society.
Jefferson saw the harm done to the children of masters, who were "nursed, educated, and daily exercised in tyranny." He perceived the black-white divisions that were being created. "Deep-rooted prejudices entertained by the whites; ten thousand recollections, by the blacks, of the injuries they have sustained; new provocations; the real distinctions which nature has made; and many other circumstances, will divide us into parties, and produce convulsions, which will probably never end."
But he also tried to quell his conscience, much as we do now. Jefferson inherited 20 slaves from his father and 135 from his father-in-law, along with thousands of acres of land, and thereby found himself embedded in the slavery-dependent economy of 18th century Virginia. He eloquently deplored slavery but failed to abolish it, either as Governor or President or master of his estates. He freed only two slaves in his lifetime and five under his will.
He saw himself as benevolent, as indeed he was by the standards of the day. He usually spared the whip and was so devoted to keeping families together that he sometimes bought a slave rather than permit a couple to be separated.
In principle, if not in practice, Jefferson showed no ambivalence about slavery. It undermined the morals and the liberties of the nation; it stood against God's ultimate justice and the inevitable turn of history. In his draft of the Declaration of Independence, Jefferson included a stirring paragraph condemning the King of England for having "waged cruel war against human nature itself, violating it's [cq] most sacred rights of life and liberty" by maintaining the "execrable commerce" in in which "MEN [cq] should be bought and sold." This emphasis on the word "men" leaves no doubt that Jefferson meant slaves as well when he wrote, "All men are created equal." The Continental Congress deleted the paragraph, which he noted when he sent out copies of the text.
He was not an integrationist, however, and he opposed racial mixing and intermarriage. His idea was to free the slaves, train them for self-sufficiency and then deport them, for he saw no possibility that blacks and whites could live together.
Jefferson was accused of fathering children by a mulatto slave, Sally Hemings. This he denied in private correspondence, and most Jefferson scholars believe him. But many black Americans, including the descendants of Hemings, accept it as undisputed fact, for it symbolizes the unequal relationships, the intricate realities of black oppression, sexual and otherwise.
These are the two histories of Jefferson, the two histories of America. If we face Jefferson, we face ourselves.
