HEADLINE: Angolan Rebels Rebound, Within Reach of a Victory

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOBITO, Angola

 BODY:
Nearly six months after the elections that were supposed to cement the peace in Angola, the rebel leader who lost in the vote has resumed the civil war and scored such enormous advances that there is talk he might engineer an outright military victory.
The rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, seemed poised in September to pass into history after he lost his bid to be the country's first elected President to his longtime rival, Jose Eduardo dos Santos. Within weeks, many leaders of the rebel group, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, were either killed or captured by Government forces, and the group had lost the support of its main backers, the United States and South Africa. 
 After a major Government offensive, officials in Luanda, the capital, were predicting the imminent collapse of the movement, which is known by its Portuguese acronym Unita.
 
 
Rebels Hold More Land
 But in recent weeks, Unita has expanded its territory and is now believed to control nearly two-thirds of the country, more than double the land the rebels held before a peace accord was reached in May 1991.
With a deft combination of cunning, tenacity and ruthlessness, Mr. Savimbi and his forces have largely outmaneuvered the Government army. They have achieved their goals in part because they captured diamond and oil-producing regions that have provided the resources for their drive and also because they have capitalized on the caches of weapons and military units that were not dismantled after the 1991 accord.
"Unita has managed to accomplish in two months what they couldn't do in nearly two decades of fighting," said a Western diplomat here. "And given his recent successes on the battlefield, it would be unrealistic to think Savimbi's going to be satisfied until he has it all."
After his recent military successes, Mr. Savimbi has raised the ante for cease-fire talks, saying his soldiers will continue the struggle to "liberate" Angola until his terms are met, although he has yet to explain exactly what he wants.
[Talks on a cease-fire, aid deliveries, the division of power and the future role of the United Nations in Angola opened April 12 in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. The opening message sent by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said the United Nations would decide whether to renew the mandate of the 700 peacekeepers in Angola based on the outcome of the talks.]
 
Plans to Hold On
 In a recent radio broadcast Mr. Savimbi said, "We have now captured many, many tanks here in Huambo. We have antiaircraft guns, long-range guns and we have ammunition. We can, therefore, continue this war for a long time."
But while military prowess has contributed to Unita's recent advances, cheating and subterfuge probably played an even greater role, American officials said.
The accord called for demobilizing troops and forming a new army together. But Western officials said that, while the Government obeyed, Unita is estimated to have kept a force of 30,000 to 35,000 soldiers. The Government had roughly three times that number before the cease-fire and by some estimates has reduced its forces to no more than 10,000.
"The Government largely played by the rules, and lost big time," said a Western military analyst. "You can be assured they won't make that mistake again, and that makes resolving the civil war that much harder."
Indeed, President dos Santos has acknowledged that his forces were unprepared for the Unita offensive in the fall. But in recent weeks, Parliament passed a law reintroducing compulsory military service, and Government soldiers who had been demobilized have been drafted again.
By any standard, Angola is in desperate shape, torn by deep political divisions, devastated by years of war that have killed between 350,000 and 500,000 people, maimed tens of thousands and created an estimated 2 million refugees in a population of 10 million. The oil industry, which forms the basis of the economy and accounts for 95 percent of export earnings, continues to function, but the recent rebel gains are posing a threat.
If anything, the new round of fighting seems even more brutal than the first stage, which began in 1975 after Angola obtained independence from Portugal, its colonial ruler. Unita and the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, which fought together against the Portuguese, turned on each other and became cold war proxies. As the United States and South Africa supported Unita, the Soviet Union and Cuba backed the Popular Movement, which won control of the country.
 
15,000 Civilians Died
 Earlier this year, Unita soldiers appeared to have systematically targeted residents of Huambo, Mr. Savimbi's stronghold, during the eight-week battle for control of Angola's second-largest city, said dozens of refugees here and in the nearby town of Benguela.
The battle for control of Huambo -- in which 15,000 civilians died, by United Nations estimate -- effectively ended March 6 in a victory for Unita. But hundreds of residents have continued to make the perilous journey here in search of food and medicine.
"Huambo has a population of about 400,000, and we simply do not know how or if they are surviving," said Philippe Borel, the director of operations in Luanda for the World Food Program, a United Nations agency.
 
One Man's Journey
 It took Agostinho Buli 14 grueling days to make the 250-mile trek from Huambo in Angola's central highlands to this Atlantic Ocean port. But the 18-year-old student lost his mother, four brothers and two sisters on the journey.
Four of Mr. Buli's relatives died while trying to cross the Catumbela River. A rope was strung so people could pull themselves across, he said. But when rebel soldiers tossed hand grenades into the river, many people, including his mother, lost their grip and drowned. The remaining family members died in a similar attack at the Cubal River. They are some of the latest victims of a civil war that most people thought was over.
Many Angolans appear to feel no assurance that the formerly Marxist Government offers a better alternative. Government troops, especially in and around Luanda, are increasingly guilty of their own forms of terrorism, diplomats said.
African and Western diplomats say the capital became a virtual hunting ground as soldiers and militia leaders, armed with machetes, pistols and AK-47 rifles searched for Unita partisans. Reports indicate that the toll was heavy, with many hundreds and perhaps thousands slain.
During the long years of violence and relentless enmity, reports of torture and atrocities by Mr. Savimbi's forces against his own followers were not given much credence outside a small circle of his longtime critics. Now, as Unita's treatment of unarmed civilians fleeing provincial battlefields has come to light, the earlier reports are being given more weight. In interviews, many refugees said they took their chances and knowingly walked through areas strewn with land mines rather than face almost certain death at the hands of Unita soldiers.
"When the Cubans and South Africans were here, the war was soldier against soldier," said an American official based in Angola. "But it's no longer a fight just among soldiers. Unita is now targeting anyone that might be seen as a Government sympathizer, and that of course includes civilians." For its part, Unita says the Government has targeted Unita supporters, including civilians.
Mercedes Sayagues, a spokeswoman for the World Food Program, said that abuses of civilians are mounting. "In this new phase of war, civilians have become deeply involved, and their suffering has greatly increased," she said.
Whether Unita has indeed deliberately targeted civilians is unclear. Some analysts suggest that those killed while fleeing Huambo were victims of undisciplined or possibly renegade Unita units. A ban on travel to the area made it impossible to confirm the numbers.
But there is no doubt that Unita's recent string of military victories over Government forces -- it is said to control much of the provinces of Lunda Norte and Lunda Sul and the important cities of Cuito and Luena -- has come at a heavy cost to the population. Near Malange, for example, a city of nearly 400,000 people 200 miles southeast of Luanda, Unita has taken control of much of the surrounding countryside, severing road traffic and Government supply lines.
If the roads remain blocked, Malange's food supply will soon be reduced to whatever can be brought in by air.
"Unita has put a stranglehold on the town; we're completely cut off and at Unita's mercy," said Jorge Modesto, a Brazilian who manages the World Food Program there.
 
Diamonds Pay for War
 Ultimately, Unita's control of the countryside will depend to a large degree on its ability to provide its force with food, weapons and ammunition. For now, diplomats, relief workers and missionaries say, Unita's main source of revenue is Angola's diamond-rich Lunda Norte province, with the diamonds being sold across the border in Zaire.
Here in Lobito, the toll of the renewed fighting is etched in the haggard faces and battered bodies of people arriving from Huambo. Despite the trauma of the journey, many gave relatively lucid and detailed accounts of their ordeal. One measure of their credibility is that most described themselves as Unita supporters. Huambo is regarded as the cultural heartland of the Ovimbundu, the ethnic group to which Mr. Savimbi belongs, and a region that voted overwhelmingly for Unita in the elections.
 
Hid from the Rebels
 Several refugees said that they had tried to live in hiding in the dry savannah, but were constantly chased by Unita units, who were also pursuing fleeing Government soldiers.
"We had nothing to eat, and the only way we could get water was from the river," said Violeta Bimbi, 23 years old, who fled with six children from Huambo and arrived here after a 14-day journey.
Nito Caetano, a 34-year-old man in ragged clothing, said Unita soldiers had attacked and killed his brother with machetes after they accused him of being a Government collaborator.
"We were about 150 kilometers from Huambo," Mr. Caetano said, "but the soldiers were still chasing us." Asked why the rebels would go to such lengths to pursue him, he said that his father had been a senior official in the provincial government, and that several family members, including his brother, also held government jobs.
In a transcript from a radio account, a relief worker in Huambo told officials back in Luanda: "People ate grass to survive. Many women who had small children who could not walk alone were obliged to abandon them in the bush because the load was too heavy.
"When they were crossing the river Catumbela many people drowned because Unita was chasing them and they had to choose between jumping into the river or being caught by Unita. Those who could not swim, drowned. More than 200 people are estimated to have died in this manner."
At a makeshift refugee camp in Lobito, Agostinho Buli sat stiffly in a chair as he tried to describe the turmoil he has felt since seeing his family drown. He said that the "pain will never heal" because his mother did not have a proper burial.
"When I saw my mother drown, I tried to kill myself,' he said. "I wanted to jump in too, and join her, but I was prevented from doing so," he said.
"I still want to kill myself. What's the use of living?"

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Senate G.O.P. Tastes Success, but It Probably Won't Be a Diet

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
So the Senate's 43 Republicans have logged a Cinderella-rank upset, knocking off both the White House's $19.5 billion jobs bill and its reputation for political savvy last week with a single filibuster. Politics is a blood sport, and a party is only as good as its next victory.
The question then is this: Where can the Republicans strike next? 
 Not President Clinton's tax proposals. The taxes, as well as all spending for mandatory programs like Medicare, will move to a vote under Senate rules that forbid such delaying tactics.
Not the rest of the budget. Filibusters against major spending bills are almost unheard of; few Republicans would cut off money to an entire Cabinet department, chockablock with popular programs, just to protest the spending they don't like.
And not Hillary Rodham Clinton's health-care package in all likelihood. Many in both parties say the problem of medical costs is so urgent -- and the public's demand for a solution so angry and strong -- that they want to handle it in as bipartisan a fashion as possible.
 
Hazards of Success
 For Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, this neatly illustrates the big drawback of being a giant-killer: it raises expectations.
From freshmen senators to George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, to the President, Democrats have tried to cast Mr. Dole and his band of filibusterers as threats to Mr. Clinton's entire political agenda, if not the economy and the Republic itself.
"It seems clear that there is a determined effort to defeat the President's program," Mr. Mitchell said last week at the height of the jobs-bill debate. "Prudence dictates that we anticipate this reaction to any legislation proposed by the President."
Reality suggests otherwise. Across the landscape of Mr. Clinton's legislative agenda, only a few proposals stand out as likely targets for Republican filibusters. And most of those are not atop the White House's list of priorities.
"Campaign finance, maybe," one senior Administration official suggested last week, referring to Mr. Clinton's fervent but amorphous commitment to rewrite the rules of raising and spending political money.
Any bill to grant statehood to the lopsidedly Democratic District of Columbia would certainly be filibustered. So might a Democratic proposal that would bar companies from the union-busting practice of hiring permanent replacements for striking workers.
While some other bills are certain to be stalled at least briefly by talkathons -- in Congress's last two-year session, there were 48 attempts to break filibusters -- few of the filibusters are likely to last long or have much success. Their recent victory aside, Republicans in Congress are far weaker this year than at any other time in the last 12.
Arithmetic shows why. When George Bush was President, the Democratic-controlled Senate needed to muster two-thirds of the body's 100 lawmakers -- 67 votes -- to override his frequent vetoes. With Bill Clinton in power, and vetoes of Democratic legislation unlikely at best, the magic number drops to three-fifths of the Senate, or 60 votes, the number Democrats must summon to cut off debate on a bill and force a final vote.
At a result, Republicans must hold on to 41 of their 43 members, in most debates, or lose control of the floor and the legislation. Being a fractious group of politicians these days, that is not easy.
 
One of the Wavering
 "We had all gotten used to having a President who backs us with vetoes," said Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, "so you could do things with 33 or 34 votes. Now you have a situation where you need 40 votes, and it has to get pretty tight before we have any purpose" as a serious political opponent.
Mr. Jeffords knows the arithmetic well. A Republican liberal, and therefore a member of a vanishing species, he is regularly courted by Democrats to desert his party on close votes.
He remained loyal during the jobs-bill filibuster. But "if it gets down to the point of quibbling over a few dollars," Mr. Jeffords said, "don't count on me to be for a filibuster. I'm not going to hold up the President" over small change.
For Mr. Dole, the man charged with keeping filibusters going, susceptible lawmakers like Mr. Jeffords are but part of the problem. At the other end of the party's spectrum are advocates of ideological war with the Democrats, like Phil Gramm of Texas and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, who pull the entire party rightward and make it difficult to retain 41 votes on any issue.
The result is that Republicans are able to stop only two kinds of Democratic initiatives: Those they are not so passionate about and thus do not really disagree over, and those they care about so deeply that any internal differences can be papered over for the sake of the cause.
Last month, Senate Republicans filibustered a bill in the first category, the proposal to increase voter registration by allowing it when renewing a driver's license, for example. And they forced Democrats to make significant changes in the measure to pass it.
Mr. Clinton's jobs bill -- a title that the Republicans assert is false advertising -- is of the care-deeply variety, and Republicans have so adamantly refused to swallow it that it now seems possible that it will not pass at all.
Senator Gramm said most observers misunderstood the reason for the latest filibuster. "People are focused on the wrong end of the spectrum," he said. "They're focused on what this means about the relative power of the President as opposed to the Republicans in Congress, or what this means about the political power struggle. We're very united on this because we're on the issue that defines the Republican party: tax and spend."
The bill allots $19.5 billion for a grab-bag of public-works projects, social welfare programs and budget increases for Federal agencies, all with the stated purpose of creating jobs and stoking the economy's fires. Republicans contend that only about $4 billion in payments to the unemployed is really needed right now, and they are insistent that the Federal deficit should not be increased to pay for the rest.
But Senator Jeffords says there is less to this than meets the eye. The collision over the legislation is less a test of political strength, he says, than a learning experience for Republicans and Democrats who have not worked in a one-party Government since the days of Jimmy Carter. Had the White House stroked the opposition a bit more and offered to spend a little less, he suggests, the filibuster might never have occurred.
Which is another reason the Republicans may not enjoy such success again soon, a senior Administration aide contended. "From now on," he said, "let's just say the White House probably will be more sensitive to internal Republican politics."

HEADLINE: Japan Leader Takes Hard Line on Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 12

 BODY:
Despite growing pressure from the Clinton Administration on trade issues, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa today rejected the idea of establishing new specific targets for Japanese imports of American goods and cautioned that trade tensions could not be solved quickly.
In a wide-ranging interview with American correspondents today, Mr. Miyazawa said that in his first meeting with President Clinton this week, he would offer what Japanese describe as a step that could improve the trade imbalance, a plan to stimulate the Japanese economy with more than $100 billion in new Government spending. 
 But the Prime Minister offered virtually no new ideas or plans to ease economic tensions between the two countries, saying he planned to remind Mr. Clinton that Japan and the United States had been struggling for a decade to close the trade gap, and "there is no reason why we should solve it overnight."
 
Spur to Japan's Economy
 The idea of new Government spending is that it would stimulate the Japanese economy and lead to more imports. But Japan has declined to set aside a specific portion of that money for the purchase of imported goods.
In fact, Mr. Miyazawa today all but rejected making any agreements that would set a target share of the Japanese market for American products, a technique many in the Administration favor after the relative success of that approach in greatly increasing the sales of American computer chips here.
"We must never agree on managed trade," the Prime Minister said. "We really cannot tell private industries to purchase something from this country or that country."
His comments, a day before foreign ministers and finance ministers from the world's richest nations arrive here to come up with a package of aid for President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, and three days before Mr. Miyazawa's trip to Washington, came at a critical moment for the quiet-spoken internationalist who was supposed to groom Japan for a new age of influence.
While Mr. Miyazawa renewed his pledge to help Mr. Yeltsin, he said he could not offer any assurance that the amount of aid offered by Japan would rank second only to that provided by the United States. That is where many American officials say it should be, given the size of Japan's economy. "I think we are probably doing the best of Japan's ability," he said.
 
Criticized at Home and Abroad
 Yet at home and abroad Mr. Miyazawa finds himself constantly criticized these days for lacking vision and gumption. Ducking to avoid criticism from France and Germany about Japan's reluctance to prove large-scale aid to Russia before a territorial dispute is settled, hoping President Clinton's recent tough language about Japan's economic practices will somehow evaporate before they meet on Friday, and unwilling to criticize his political colleagues caught up in the center of an enormous influence-peddling scandal, Mr. Miyazawa sometimes seems like a man more comfortable as the savvy Finance Ministry bureaucrat he once was than the leader of the world's second-largest economy.
Today he cautioned that "I can't promise anything that I can't deliver on," a seeming acknowledgment of his domestic political weakness. But he is known for a deep commitment, inherited from mentors who served as Japan's first postwar leaders, to improving relations with the United States.
He readily laughed off Mr. Clinton's recent comments, leaked from the Vancouver summit meeting with Mr. Yeltsin, that the Japanese often say yes when they mean no.
"I think this yes or no thing is something I myself might say," he mused, speaking in English. "You all remember, don't you, 'Yes, We Have No Bananas?' That reminded me of that particular song." He added, "The more I think about it, the more that is the way we converse, we Japanese."
Mr. Miyazawa's aides insist he will not go to Washington totally empty-handed: he will propose a program to share technology on magnetically levitated trains and subways, and offer to send more Japanese language teachers to the United States to train future business people to deal with Japan.
 
Hard Line on Trade
 But a senior Foreign Ministry official, taking a hard line during a briefing for reporters about the trip earlier today, made it clear that the Japanese Government would take the view that most of the problem was in the United States. "The idea that a closed Japanese market is linked to our trade surplus, this is the thought we have to contest," the official said.
The official contended that American companies were still looking to "shift the responsibility for the failure of American exporters" on Japanese firms and regulations, rather than on themselves. "Many Japanese Government and business leaders view much of the grumbling in America as excuses," he said.
Some Japanese say Mr. Miyazawa's personality explains the lack of action. "He has an extremely subtle mind," one of his close advisers said the other day. "He is just a very passive personality. He reacts to things. He grew up in an age when Japan did what it was told, and he doesn't think in terms of breaking new ground."
Indeed, pressed for concrete ideas he will be taking to Washington, Mr. Miyazawa talked only of "closer consultation between our two Governments."
In recent times the approval ratings for Mr. Miyazawa's Cabinet have dropped to around 20 percent, in the past often a signal that ouster from office was in the offing. But Mr. Miyazawa's rivals have almost all been neutralized, and he seems likely to stay for some time.
Today Mr. Miyazawa was careful not to give away much about what Japan is willing to contribute to the Russian aid package when the foreign and finance ministers of the Group of Seven major industrial countries -- including Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen -- arrive here on Tuesday night. But he strongly suggested that despite pressure from aborad, Japan's enthusiasm for the program would have its limits.
 
Territorial Dispute With Russia
 Referring to the dispute over the group of islands that the Soviet Union seized from Japan in the waning days of World War II, the Prime Minister said: "It may be difficult for the Russian Federation to solve the territorial issue immediately, as they are in turmoil.
"At the same time, for Japanese to send them a great amount of aid -- a large amount of aid -- then the people would be more amenable if this issue between our two countries had been solved."
The two goals of propping up Mr. Yeltsin and retaining leverage in the islands issue "are not imcompatible," he said.
Asked if Japan could tolerate a nuclear-armed North Korea, Mr. Miyazawa offered the most definitive answer of the afternoon, saying simply, "No."
But when he was pressed on the question of what Japan was prepared to do in the wake of North Korea's withdrawal from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, he said that his country "would rather give them some time to reconsider" before imposing economic sanctions.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Urges Japanese Stimulus
 WASHINGTON, April 12 (Special to The New York Times) -- Seeking to press Japan just days before its Prime Minister visits Washington, Administration officials are urging Tokyo to spend more money to stimulate its economy in an effort to lift the world economy and reduce Japan's mammoth trade surplus.
"The United States and many other countries need export-led growth," a senior Administration official said in an interview late Sunday. This, he said, can come only if Japan reduces its trade surplus, which soared to a record $120 billion last year.
The Administration official, who insisted on anonymity, suggested that Tokyo's economic stimulus package for last year, which Japanese officials said totaled $80 billion, amounted to less than that. As a result, the official suggested, Japan's economy remains mired in its worst slump in two decades.
Many American economists agree. For instance, they say, using Japan's social security trust fund to buy municipal bonds rather than Government bonds should not be counted as an economic stimulus.

HEADLINE: Health Planners' Radical Idea: Same Coverage for All

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
At the core of President Clinton's health-care plan is a radical new concept: a standard package of health benefits that would be guaranteed to all Americans and perhaps be more generous than the health insurance most have now.
The idea of a uniform benefit package appears to have immense appeal. It could improve health care for many people,, including the 37 million who now have no health insurance, and it could help reduce administrative costs by standardizing policies. 
 But this idea, which sounds so simple, could prove politically explosive.
By defining the minimum benefits, the Federal Government would make decisions that are now left to state laws or to negotiations among insurers, employers and employees.
Congress will almost surely want to play a large role in determining what benefits are offered, raising the possibility of debate so intense that it could disrupt the entire effort to overhaul the nation's health-care system.
For example, some women's groups are demanding coverage of reproductive health services, including abortion. Dozens of other interest groups are lining up to make sure that their special concerns are well treated, too. The political horse-trading could drive costs to intolerable heights.
Elderly people are insisting on coverage of long-term care. Psychiatrists, marriage counselors, dentists, chiropractors, surgeons and other specialists are pleading for coverage of their services.
 
Undeterred By Pressures
 At the state level, where such debates now occur, similar pressures have led to a proliferation of insurance laws requiring coverage of particular services. Insurers say those mandates have pushed up costs.
Despite these concerns, Clinton Administration officials are contemplating a package of benefits more comprehensive that what is now available through Medicare or most private health insurance plans.
Confidential work papers from the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform show that the panel is drafting detailed requirements for coverage of items like vaccines, routine preventive care for babies, Pap smears, mammograms, physical examinations, prescription drugs, mental health services and drug-abuse treatment.
The contents of the benefit package will directly affect not only the costs, but also the plan's political acceptability. Benefits must be generous enough to attract broad support, to protect public health and to eliminate the temptation for people to buy private insurance to supplement the standard coverage. But if the package is too comprehensive, it will probably be too costly for the Government and for many employers.
"The problem is trying to determine what is superfluous, not what is necessary," said Representative Fred Grandy, an Iowa Republican who is a member of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. At a recent subcommittee hearing, Mr. Grandy repeatedly asked, "What should not be in the core benefits package?" He rarely got an answer.
 
Standard Benefits Are a Central Idea
 The idea of a standard benefit package is central to the health policy favored by Mr. Clinton. Under that policy, known as managed competition, large groups of consumers and businesses would buy the standard package of benefits from health maintenance organizations and other networks of doctors and hospitals. The networks are supposed to compete by offering high-quality care at low prices.
Presumably, most of the networks would be H.M.O.'s and similar prepaid group plans. But Administration officials say there would be provisions allowing people to obtain their health care on a "fee for service" basis as most people do now.
At present, it is difficult for consumers to shop for health insurance. "When each health plan is allowed to vary its benefits, consumers cannot easily make price comparisons," said Linda A. Bergthold, an expert on employee benefits, now working for the task force. Ms. Bergthold, an executive at the consulting firm William M. Mercer Inc., analyzed "benefit design choices" in a recent issue of the journal Health Affairs.
The Government could encourage reliance on the standard benefits through tax law. While employers can now take tax deductions for the cost of providing employee health benefits, some versions of managed competition call for limiting such deductions to the value of the standard package of benefits.
People would be free to buy more coverage with their own money, but Administration officials say they hope the package will be so attractive that most people accept it as adequate.
In the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton suggested that a new agency, the National Health Board, would design the benefit package. But members of Congress said they would never leave such an important decision to an administrative agency.
White House officials got the message. They now say the benefits must be specified in law by Congress. "It would be difficult to ask the American people to accept a pig in a poke," said Ira C. Magaziner, coordinator of the task force.
 
How a Plan Might Work
 Under the plan now being developed, patients would have to pay a certain amount for each medical service, depending on who provided it. The charges would be lower for people enrolled in health maintenance organizations. For example, a person in an H.M.O. might have to pay $10 for a visit to a doctor's office, while other patients would have to pay as much as 40 percent of the doctor's charges.
Mr. Magaziner said President Clinton's plan would propose "a comprehensive package of benefits toward the top end of the range" of the plans that are now available. Another official said, "It will be at the 80th or 90th percentile of generosity," meaning that it will be more generous than all but 10 percent or 20 percent of the policies now sold.
But that vision of an ideal health plan may collide with fiscal reality. While the Administration has made great progress in defining the benefits that ought to be guaranteed to all Americans, it has only begun to compute the cost.
Frank B. McArdle, manager of the Washington research office of Hewitt Associates, an employee benefits consulting firm, notes that controlling health costs is supposed to be a major goal of Mr. Clinton's plan. "Whom does it help if you require employers to provide a package of benefits so generous that people are laid off as a result?" Mr. McArdle asks.
Mary Nell Lehnhard, senior vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, said: "There are a lot of good benefits that people would like, but they increase the cost -- mental health services, prescription drugs, long-term care, home health care. There should be options. Small employers just won't be able to afford what big employers have been providing for a long time."
But the Administration says the standard benefit package must be comprehensive, or else millions of people will buy private insurance to supplement the basic coverage, and the inequities of the current health-care system will continue.
Moreover, Administration officials say if the standard coverage is comprehensive, the Government will be better able to control the costs of services. The Government will have far less control over services that people buy with their own money.
 
Benefits Now: A Dizzying Array
 A standard package of benefits would be a major change. American employers now provide health benefits to 140 million people, but "there is no standard health benefit package," said Mr. McArdle of Hewitt Associates. "Employees get a lot of choice among plans and among health-care providers," he said. "They value and appreciate that choice."
The average medium-sized to large employer offers workers a choice of at least one conventional insurance plan and one health maintenance organization, which provides a wide range of services in return for a fixed monthly payment. Data compiled by Hewitt Associates show that when given such a choice, 25 percent of employees typically join the H.M.O.
Benefit levels vary from industry to industry. If the Government defines a standard package, "it may not increase costs much for industries like aerospace and utilities, which already provide comprehensive benefits," Mr. McArdle said. But such a requirement could sharply increase costs for retail stores and other industries that now provide limited benefits, he said.
Likewise, Mr. McArdle said, "the same Federal mandate could be an insignificant new cost in the Northeast, where there is relatively generous coverage, but a large economic shock in Texas and the Southwest, where certain benefits like mental health are more limited."
 
Likely Components Of Basic Package
 The plan now envisioned by Administration officials would probably require employers and insurers to cover hospital services without limits on the number of days in the hospital or visits to hospital clinics.
White House officials say the standard benefits will include coverage for services provided by community health centers and other clinics serving low-income people.
It will also include coverage of preventive services like immunizations, prenatal care, mammograms, Pap smears and routine physical examinations, provided they are performed at regular intervals specified by the Government.
The Administration is considering requirements for coverage of mental health care, occupational therapy and physical therapy, but has not decided how to limit the scope or cost of these services.
Tipper Gore, the wife of Vice President Al Gore, has repeatedly said that mental illness must be covered on the same basis as physical illness. Private insurance policies often restrict coverage of mental health care by setting limits on the number of days of hospitalization, the number of therapy sessions or the total cost. Many Administration officials want to abolish such limits and are seeking other ways to control costs.
The Administration wants to include hearing, vision and dental services for children, but has not decided how far to go in covering such care for adults.
In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would expand coverage of long-term care for elderly and disabled people. The standard benefits will probably include some long-term care, emphasizing services provided outside nursing homes. But long-term care is expensive, and the new benefits may be introduced gradually over 10 or 20 years, Administration officials say.
The basic benefit package will almost certainly include treatment for drug abuse. Hillary Rodham Clinton, head of the task force developing the President's plan, has said that treatment for mental illness and drug abuse must be included because they are "a problem that permeates the whole system." Dr. Steven A. Schroeder, president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, says, "Substance abuse -- cigarettes, alcohol and drug abuse -- is the nation's No. 1 health problem."

HEADLINE: Japan Details Stimulus Plan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, April 13

 BODY:
The Liberal Democratic Party released details of a $117 billion economic stimulus plan today.
In a summary, the ruling party cited the recent rise in the yen, the sluggish Japanese and United States economies and Japan's growing trade surplus as reasons for the plan. The package empashizes what the party called the "three E's": education, electronics and ecology. 
 The 13.2 trillion yen plan is Japan's largest ever, exceeding a 10.7 trillion yen package announced in August. It is to be approved at a special Cabinet meeting later today.
The package includes 1.2 trillion yen for local Government purchases of land for public projects. The Government will build an additional 50,000 public rental housing units. The package will also expand lending for the purchase and building of homes at reduced rates.

HEADLINE: Banks Seek Big Victory On Accounting Today

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
A vote today by the Financial Accounting Standards Board on whether to force financial institutions to report changes in the market value of some of the securities they hold could produce a major victory for bank lobbyists.
Four of the seven board members have indicated support for the proposal, which is being fought by the banks. But a simple majority is not sufficient to take action. 
 Under a policy adopted two years ago, five votes -- a "super-majority" -- are required. If none of the three other members decides to also vote for the proposal, it would be the first time that a major accounting issue was blocked under this requirement.
The Financial Accounting Standards Board is a private-industry body to which the Securities and Exchange Commission has delegated responsibility for financial statements. The standards board determines accounting rules in the United States.
Dennis Beresford, the board's chairman and a supporter of the proposed accounting change, said in an interview that he had not rounded up a fifth vote and was concerned that one might not be found. Banks and other financial institutions have argued that no change should be made.
Financial institutions say they should have considerable flexibility to decide whether the securities they hold -- like bonds -- are to be classified as for trading or for investment. While bonds held for trading purposes are required to be valued at their market price under the existing rules, those held as investments are carried on the books at their purchase price, regardless of whether they have risen or fallen in value.
 
S.E.C. Has Sought Change
 The Securities and Exchange Commission, under the leadership of Richard C. Breeden, who will soon leave as chairman, has pushed for market-value accounting of financial assets, arguing that it would present a clearer picture of financial institutions' strength to investors. That has been opposed by some regulators, who fear that banks would be damaged in situations where interest rates rise, causing bond prices to fall and forcing the banks to report losses.
The proposal to be voted on today is basically the one put forth by the Financial Accounting Standards Board in September. Under board rules, further ballots would be required if it is approved today, but a defeat might end the project.
It calls for debt securities -- but not bank loans -- to be stated at market value unless the institution could prove, to its auditor's satisfaction, that it had both the intention and the ability to hold a particular security until it matured.
Under current rules, banks and other financial institutions effectively have the ability to decide how to account for a security. They can classify securities as investments, meaning they need not report losses if the market price declines. If the price rises, they can turn around and sell them, thus reporting the profit.
The issue has been before the accounting standards board for many years, and been subject to strong lobbying. As an interim step, the board required financial institutions to begin disclosing the market value of securities in footnotes to annual reports. That begins this year for institutions with at least $150 million in assets, and two years from now for smaller institutions.
 
Protests, and Change
 Many companies have been annoyed by accounting rules issued by the standards board. The Financial Accounting Foundation, which appoints the board's members, decided two years ago that new rules could be adopted only by a vote of at least five members, instead of four as had been the case. Banks were among those who lobbied for that change, and if today's vote produces a standoff, they will be the first beneficiaries.
In the intervening two years, the board has issued important statements, including new accounting rules for income taxes and for the cost of retirement health benefits. But the scope of the proposal on financial instruments was scaled back, in large part because it was clear that five votes could not be found.
All three members who expressed reservations about the proposal have indicated that they would like to go further in some way, and it is possible that at least one of them will decide to vote for the current plan rather than see nothing accomplished.
"The proposal is closer to my view than where we are in practice today," Robert Swieringa, a board member who hoped that the board would go much further, said yesterday. He declined to say if he would vote for the proposal.

HEADLINE: Clinton Adopts Tougher Tactics In Pushing His Stalled Jobs Plan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
President Clinton used the annual White House Easter Egg Roll today to step up his campaign against Republicans who are blocking his $19.5 billion jobs bill. Pointing to the thousands of children rolling eggs on the South Lawn, Mr. Clinton said they would benefit from the child immunization funds in his legislation but instead are the "hostages" of a Republican filibuster.
White House officials said the President's remarks, his harshest yet in the debate over the jobs plan, were the opening salvo of an intensified drive to salvage as much as possible of the package, which has been frozen in the Senate by a Republican filibuster. 
 Speaking to reporters in the Oval Office after signing a proclamation encouraging child immunizations, Mr. Clinton suddenly turned, looked out his window and remarked: "I just want to say that today we're having the Easter Egg Roll on the White House lawn. You can look out there at those kids. They are the hostages of the Senate filibuster on the stimulus program."
Thumping his big Oval Office desk for emphasis, Mr. Clinton said Republican complaints that his jobs bill was larded with wasteful, pork barrel spending was "hot air rhetoric."
 
Diverted by Other Issues
 Having concluded that a series of foreign policy issues, health care debates and general overconfidence had combined to divert the President from his focus on selling the bill, Mr. Clinton has decided to use virtually every public event possible to drum up support for his package. The strategy: go for the Republicans' throats in public while offering them legislative compromises in private in hopes of striking a deal.
"They've just got to decide, as I said, how many people they want to keep out of work and how many people we want to put to work, and I think we can work something out," Mr. Clinton said. "I'm hopeful that we can."
Most of the $19.5 billion package goes for spending on new highways and bridges and summer jobs for teen-agers. Some $4 billion of it goes for extending unemployment benefits, and a fraction -- $300 million -- is for immunizing pre-school children.
Mr. Clinton's use of egg-rolling children as ammunition seemed to be a sign of White House nervousness that it may be losing the public debate over the proposal. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, responded with a salvo of faxes and puns. He said the President was getting "egg on his face" in resorting to emotional tactics, and was only trying to "hatch" a new excuse for getting the American people to support his jobs bill.
Mr. Clinton's ferocious defense of his package to stimulate the economy has focused national attention on the skirmish over what is a modest jobs bill that few economists think will have much impact, making a defeat potentially more embarrassing. Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton's much more important $1.52 trillion budget package has been sailing through Congress.
The President said today of the Senate Republicans: "These people, most of them, have been here the last 12 years while we have run immunization into the ground, while we've developed the third-worst rate in the hemisphere. And they've always got some excuse, some of them, for not doing anything. Now, what are we going to do about those children? That ought to be the question of the week. When I go out there on the lawn, and I think about those kids picking up Easter eggs, I want to be able to think about them all being immunized, and all those children coming along behind them being immunized."
Senator Dole faxed to Washington news bureaus a statement in response to Mr. Clinton's remarks.
"It looks like the President has egg on his face," said Mr. Dole, "considering the fact that the childhood immunization program still has more than $137 million in unspent funds."
Warming to the debate, Senator Dole added: "It's a shame President Clinton has resorted to using the children at the Easter egg hunt as a partisan political backdrop to hatch a new excuse for his so-called stimulus package. What President Clinton should tell those children is that he wants to saddle them with bigger deficits instead of paying for this new immunization spending and hundreds of other spending and taxing plans, which will rob them of their full potential."
Administration officials say they are open to changes in the jobs package and are discussing some ideas during the Senate recess with the Republicans. The issue, say White House officials, is how much the President will have to concede on the spending side of the bill to line up enough Republicans for a deal, and how much the President will have to concede on the tax side of the bill to hold Democrats. Many Democrats do not like the investment tax credits in the package, which are intended to encourage businesses to buy new machinery; the credits could cost the Treasury $21 billion over five years in lost revenue.

With him was Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: With Fishes, Sake and Silk, Japan's Prince Plights His Troth

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 12

 BODY:
Helicopters hovered overhead, beaming to television viewers the path of her car through the morning traffic, and newspapers carried front-page articles with sketches showing where everyone sat for the ceremony as an American-educated commoner came one step closer to Japan's version of the ultimate fairy tale.
Masako Owada accepted two red fish, six bottles of sake and five bolts of silk today to signify her formal engagement to Crown Prince Naruhito, 33. June 9 was set as the wedding date. 
 Japan's economy may be bumping along the bottom of a recession, scandals are dogging the ruling party and the Government is bracing for serious trade problems with the United States, but the buzz in Tokyo today was pomp and ceremony of a magnitude the Japanese get to witness just a few times a century. They loved every bit of it.
No detail of the ancient rites celebrated today went unremarked in the tsunami of coverage of what was a relatively simple ceremony. As just about every commentator noted, it lasted from 9:00 A.M. to 9:03 A.M. But what a three minutes.
 
Imperial Van Delivers Gifts
 First there was the imperial van, which arrived at the home of Ms. Owada, a 29-year-old former diplomat, early this morning. It carried the plainly wrapped gifts, all determined by tradition. They were presented, along with the formal request of marriage, by Hiroo Kanno, grand master of the Crown Prince's Household.
The engagement was made official in January, but today's ceremony was a reminder that the marriage of an emperor-to-be is richly embroidered with threads of tradition and wealth, making them remarkably popular events.
There were two enormous tai, or red sea bream, an extremely expensive fish similar to a Florida red snapper. The fish, which weighed about 15 pounds each, cost some 100,000 yen, the equivalent of $885.
They were laid out head to head, at a slight angle to each other, forming the lucky symbol of the number eight, which is supposed to bring increasing prosperity to the couple, who will someday reign as Emperor and Empress on the Chrysanthemum Throne.
 
Evoking Famous Poems
 Officials of the Imperial Household Agency confirmed that the fish were fresh and quite delicious, and are usually shared among friends and relatives of the family of the betrothed.
Two elegant but simple unpainted wood boxes carried the other presents, the six 1.8-liter bottles of sake, and the five bolts of silk, lavish fabrics that were selected and named by Empress Michiko. The names, meant to evoke famous poems or tender moments, included "Shining Silk of Birds of Luck," "Black Bamboo" and "Moments of Musical Joy."
The expensive silk -- each bolt of which was about 12 yards long -- will be fashioned into Western-style evening gowns for the Princess-to-be.
"Today, Crown Prince Naruhito presents imperial betrothal gifts to confirm his pledge of marriage with the consent of the Emperor and Empress," said Mr. Kanno, the grand master, after everything was prepared at the home of Ms. Owada's parents.
Ms. Owada responded, according to the tradition, "I accept humbly."
Ms. Owada then paid a visit to the Imperial Palace, wearing a pale yellow kimono. Her father, Hisashi Owada, who happens to be the Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, was attired in a morning coat, as was the imperial grand master. Mr. Owada carried a shiny black top hat when he accompanied his daughter to the Imperial Palace after the ceremony in his family's home. Ms. Owada's mother wore a traditional kimono.
Since the marriage plans were reported several months ago, there has been speculation that Ms. Owada, educated at Harvard and Oxford and with a promising career as a diplomat, was being pressed into the marriage and had agreed more out of duty than love. Some have argued, too, that her decision to abandon her career was a bad example for women who want to build lives outside the home.
Such thoughts played no role in today's press coverage, however, which was unquestioning in its celebration of things Japanese and the traditions surrounding a monarchy said to stretch back more than 1,500 years.

HEADLINE: Crackdown On Vendors In the Streets

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the city would step up its efforts against the 10,000 unlicensed street vendors who have flooded New York City sidewalks with everything from tube socks to fake Rolex watches.
The problem of illegal vendors, long the bane of Fifth Avenue retailers, has now become a hot economic and political issue in the bustling retail areas on 125th Street in Harlem and on Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn, where the vendors have taken over sidewalks, crowding out and undercutting small black and Hispanic shop owners. The illegal vendors, mostly poor immigrants, now account for 10 of every 11 sidewalk peddlers and cost the city as much as $300 million a year in unpaid sales taxes, officials said. 
 The heart of the crackdown involves seizing the illegal vendors' merchandise. The Mayor said he would assign 36 additional police officers to the 46-member peddler enforcement unit and deploy 31 more city inspectors and other personnel, along with 12 vans and trucks.
 
Mayor Was Teen-Age Peddler
 "We recognize that illegal vending has become a thorn in the side of small businesses and legal vendors," the Mayor told a City Hall audience largely made up of appreciative small businesses interests and shop owners.
But the Mayor said he was not against sidewalk vending and admitted he was a teen-age peddler in his Harlem youth, first hawking shopping bags and later selling Liberty Magazine. "For better or for worse," he said, "street vending constitutes a thriving industry in New York City."
He said he was seeking a kind of balance in which the rights of small businesses and shops were weighed evenly against "an appropriate role for legal vendors." He said such a balance was out of reach so long as illegal vendors were crowding in.
The Mayor's get-tough policy comes at the beginning of his election campaign in which the votes of small shop owners and politically potent organizations that represent them are regarded as far more compelling than the power of illegal sidewalk vendors who are breaking the law and who have virtually no political constituency.
"Let's cut to the chase," said Commissioner Wallace Ford of the Department of Business Services. "The plan is a political positive for the Mayor because it shows him taking action on an issue that has concerns in all five boroughs and which shows him listening to those concerns."
With that in mind, Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President who is running against Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic mayoral primary, said the Mayor's plan was not tough enough and that it offered too little and too late.
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the probable Republican candidate, said he was "glad the Mayor finally got a wake up call on the problem because I've been sounding the alarm for two years."
 
Retailers Endorse Plan
 As for the relatively modest number of additional police and inspectors to crack down on 10,000 unlicensed vendors, Commissioner Ford said, "the need for more enforcement in the future is quite possible."
Thomas Cusick, head of the Fifth Avenue Association, described the Mayor's program "as broad based and well thought out."
"Our members can recognize the rights of legitimate street vendors," he said after the Mayor had finished. "But they take umbrage at things like vendors selling counterfeit goods on Fifth Avenue outside the store where the real goods are retailed."
In increasing numbers, small shop owners complain that they must compete against sidewalk vendors who can undercut them because they offer no warranties and pay no rent or taxes.
At the Kay Bee store at 732 Broadway, a sales clerk, Stefaine Joshua, looked hard at the illegal vendors on the sidewalk outside. "They steal what they sell and sell it for much less than we can," she said.
"They crowd the sidewalk and when someone calls the police they run away, but are back doing business 10 minutes later."
 
'Trying to Survive'
 Edward Felder, homeless, unlicensed and selling used record albums in Cooper Square, had a different story.
"I'm homeless and I've got to do something to make a living," he said. "When I panhandled, I was cursed and spit at. Now I'm just selling, trying to survive."
But at Broadway and West Third Street, Shane Pettaway, who has a vendor's license, said: "I think everyone has a right to eat. But it isn't fair if I have a license and pay all these taxes to have someone set up beside me who doesn't."
In addition to stronger enforcement, Mr. Dinkins said the city would reduce the long waiting list for vendor licenses by taking away 355 licenses from military veterans who are not required to be licensed, thus freeing them for 355 applicants who are not veterans.
All told, the city limits vendor licenses to 853, and food carts to 3,000.
 
An Education Plan
 He said the city also would help legal vendors by offering them education and English language courses, small-business management and capital access training, and immigration services.
Mr. Dinkins also said he would create a new Vendor Policy Group headed by Police and Business Services Commissioners. He said the new group would review whether the maximum fine of $200 for illegal vending should be increased; whether a vending license lottery should be established, and whether vacant, city-owned storefronts should be offered at discount rates to legal street vendors.
In addition, Mr. Dinkins said he would support several vendor measures that have been introduced in the City Council, including those that would:
*Restrict the location of book vending tables, which do not require a city license, on crowded sidewalks.
*Provide 100 food-cart permits for disabled veterans.
*Require that all new food-cart permits be issued to individuals instead of corporations, limiting one permit per person.
*Raising the current limit of 853 vending licenses.
Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for Peter Vallone, the City Council majority leader, said, "Over all, the Mayor's legislative package is a good idea." But she said a pending measure seeking to create 2,000 new vendor licenses did not receive much support at a recent committee hearing.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Putting Ideas (Old and New) to Work

BYLINE: By Kirk Johnson

DATELINE: NORWICH, Conn.

 BODY:
DAVID COUTU and Dale Plummer are both entrepreneurs, both struggling to build small manufacturing businesses in a bad economy, and both tenants in one corner of the old Ponemah Mill complex here. On most other fronts, however, they might as well be in different universes.
Mr. Coutu's company, Intelligent Motion Systems, hits technology at its leading edge, an offshoot branch of robotics, while Mr. Plummer's shop, called the Quinnehticut Woolen Company, uses 75-year-old textile machines, which were bought for the price of scrap, to make wool yarn that is sold in knitting hobby stores. 
 At Intelligent Motion, everything seems clean, with a feel that comes closer to Pacific Rim high-tech than Northeast cotton-mill retread. It is a place of blue jeans and computer screens, where Lynyrd Skynyrd and Billy Joel pump on the radio. Six of the eight employees are engineers or technicians. The technology is cool.
At Quinnehticut Woolen, the technology is old. Everything smells of machine oil, and spun wool fibers cling to every surface like thin fur coats. The huge machines, some of which were only hours from being trashed as worthless curios, now clatter and roar, run by six employees who also do the marketing and maintenance. There is not a computer chip in the house -- yet.
But both places are holding onto a corner of Connecticut's industrial culture.
Mr. Coutu, a 35-year-old electrical engineer, grew up in Norwich watching the slow death of the Ponemah Mill, which employed his father and once dominated every aspect of life here. Now he competes in world trade with companies in Japan (a shrinking threat, he says) and China (a rapidly growing threat).
Mr. Plummer, a 43-year-old former historian, has it in his blood to love the past, he said, but only became a yarn mogul when he realized that plummeting rents, displaced workers and all-but-abandoned technology had created a market niche. One of his employees, Muriel Denomme, has 26 years in the textile business, through three mills that closed down around her. These are the same machines she ran at her last job.
Ponemah Mills stands hulking by the Shetucket River like a scar from the age of the industrial dinosaur. Founded by two brothers named Taft, who created the Taftville section of Norwich as a company town, it was one of the largest cloth-making plants in the world from the 1870's until it began shutting down in 1962. The company owned all the land, all the workers' homes, all the stores, and even had its own farm.
By the seat-of-the-pants rules that Mr. Coutu and Mr. Plummer must live by as start-up business owners, such large scale operations seem outmoded. That is not to say that today's marketplace is free of bloat and waste. The two men point to the case of the Electric Boat shipyard. Just down the road in Groton, the shipyard is this region's modern industrial leviathan and is shrinking steadily as submarine contracts for the Navy sink with the end of the Cold War.
In January, the state gave Electric Boat $1 million, with only the thinnest strings attached, to help encourage diversification of the product line. Last week, the company that so needed help three months ago said it paid its chairman $29 million in 1992. Mr. Coutu doubled his entire product line last year for only $200,000. The only help he received from the state was a loan, which he must repay.
"There are some industries that you're not going to hang onto," Mr. Coutu said. "How many Band-Aids are we going to use before we realize that guns are not really where we want to be spending our money?"
One element of the old ethic of Yankee Connecticut is not widely known: networking. If your uncle or your neighbor had a business, you shopped there. If he needed something, he went to you. It is part of what built the economic vitality of the state. Then, after years of prosperous complacency, the system faded because it was not particularly needed anymore.
Now, in harder times, every small business owner knows that survival cannot be taken for granted, and the old mutual-aid network has been revived. Mr. Plummer has found a nearby machine shop that still knows how to make the parts for his old machines. Mr. Coutu hires out most of his manufacturing locally.
And an even more startling example of cross-pollination is expected, perhaps later this year: Quinnehticut Woolen's first computer component will be built by Intelligent Motion Systems and installed on a 1919 vintage carding machine. The part will allow the machine to adjust its processing wheels automatically to produce the desired weight of yarn -- a small revolution for those still working in the Iron Age.
And there is one more small glimmer from the future: A student from a high school in Norwich worked part time at the woolen company last year and liked it enough to want to come back this summer after graduation to learn the old skills.
"We were very pleased with him," Mr. Plummer said. "As soon as he's available, I'd like to hire him."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Inflation News Takes Effect: Yield Falls on 30-Year Bond

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Yields on Treasury bonds and notes dropped yesterday as investors and traders bought securities in a sharp but delayed reaction to positive news on inflation last week.
The surge in buying, which began on Thursday with a report showing restrained producer price inflation in March, has brought the yields on Treasury bonds and notes back within striking range of the lows reached at the beginning of last month. 
 A report on Friday that the Consumer Price Index rose just a tenth of a percent in March reinforced the belief that inflation will remain low, even if it ends up a little higher than the 2.9 percent increase last year. But the bond market was closed for Good Friday, so the response to that positive news did not come until financial markets opened in Asia on Monday, which was Sunday night in New York.
In fact, most of yesterday's jump in prices came before trading opened in New York.
"The minute the market opened overseas, they gapped up," said Matthew Alexy, a government bond trading strategist at the First Boston Corporation who was watching bond prices leap in the Japanese market Sunday night. "The inflation data generated a powerful move in prices."
But some of the gains from East Asian trading (leading European markets were closed yesterday) were lost in a day of moderate dealings in New York. The price of the 30-year bond, which was up 110/32 early in New York trading, was just 24/32 higher in late trading in the secondary market. The yield fell to 6.79 percent, from 6.85 percent late Thursday. The 16-year low yield on the 30-year bond was 6.72 percent, set on March 8.
The price of the 10-year note, which was up 23/32 earlier, ended up 11/32 ; the yield fell to 5.91 percent from 5.96 percent on Thursday. The 20-year low for the yield on the 10-year note was 5.82 percent on March 4.
The price moves were smaller on shorter maturities, in part because inflation affects these issues less than it affects longer-term securities. But prices of short-term Treasury bills did gain, which is a positive sign for the overall market because it reflects a belief that the Federal Reserve is not close to raising short-term rates.
At the weekly auction of Treasury bills yesterday, the average discount rate on the three-month bill was 2.88 percent, down from 2.92 percent last week; the average discount rate on the six-month bill was 2.98 percent, down from 3.04 percent.
 
 
Fears Are Eased
 The bond market has sold off since early March because of concerns about rising inflation. Traders and investors were not worried about a surge in prices, but because many had bet that the rate of inflation would decline this year, they were concerned that sharp jumps in the Consumer Price Index and the Producer Price Index in January and February signaled that price increases would be higher than anticipated.
The low increases for March seemed to ease fears about inflation, but the reports did not give assurance that the rate of price increases would fall this year. Because this question is still open to debate, it is hard to say what the outlook for the market is from here, analysts say.
On a short-term basis -- the next couple of weeks -- it appears there is a chance for yields to move lower, perhaps to new lows. Data expected on the economy, including retail sales for March, which are due out today, are expected to show growth at a moderate annual pace of 3 to 3.5 percent, at best. This means little pressure on prices is expected.
 
 
Small Borrowing Needs
 In addition, the very small borrowing requirements of the Treasury this quarter will help to support prices, as will continued speculation about cutting the size of the 30-year bond auction. Estimates of the Treasury's borrowing needs are around $25 billion or less, and some analysts are predicting that the 30-year bond auction expected in May will be skipped.
But beyond a few weeks, the course could be more erratic. If the April jobs data once again fool the market expectations -- as the jobs report has in the last two months -- and are stronger than expected, then inflation will be thought about again. And that would make the April price indexes a focus again. If they came in above expectations, just as the March data came in well below, any rally could be limited.
And as the second quarter draws to an end, traders and investors will have to focus again on the expected large borrowing needs of the Treasury in the third quarter. These estimates are in the $100 billion range.
 
 
Yields Could Hit New Lows
 Mr. Alexy of First Boston said that since inflation concerns have been calmed for the moment, the yields on Treasury bonds and notes could move to new lows. But he also said there might have to be a correction first, given the fact that the price of the 30-year bond, for example, has jumped more than 2 points in the last two trading days, while the yield has dropped 16 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
He also warned that today's Treasury auction of seven-year notes could have a negative impact on the market if it does not go well.
"In the past, it has been viewed as a catalyst," he said of the seven-year note, which makes "it difficult to read market signals around the seven-year auction." In trading yesterday in the when-issued, or pre-auction, market, the yield on the seven-year note was 5.51 percent, down from 5.58 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Saudi Takes A Big Profit In Citicorp

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Cashing in on what may be one of the smartest investment moves in recent years, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia sold more than 8.9 million shares of Citicorp stock yesterday for $268.1 million, nearly two and a half times what he paid.
In late 1990 and early 1991, Prince Waleed, one of 4,000 members of the Saudi royal family, invested nearly $800 million in Citicorp when its shares were depressed because of the bank's problems with bad real estate loans. 
 Now, with the bank on the rebound and its stock trading at its highest level in three years, Prince Waleed decided to take some of his profits, selling about a sixth of his total investment in Citicorp, said Faissal M. Fahad, the Prince's lawyer in San Francisco.
 
Big Block Is Traded
 A block of 8,914,566 shares of Citicorp stock at $30.125 a share was traded on the New York Stock Exchange at 1:25 P.M. yesterday by Salomon Brothers. A Salomon spokesman declined to say how much of the stock the firm was keeping on its own books and how much it had already sold to customers.
Traders and bank stock analysts said the market was bullish on Citicorp stock and that finding a buyer for the shares, which represent 2.4 percent of those outstanding, would not be difficult.
"The stock has been widely recommended and there is strong earnings momentum and price momentum," said Judah Kraushaar, a bank analyst with Merrill Lynch. Moreover, with interest rates again heading lower, "the market has been buying bank stocks with a little bit of reckless abandon," he said.
Citicorp stock closed yesterday at $30.25, up $1.125. With more than 11 million shares traded, the stock was by far the most active on the New York Stock Exchange.
The stock is very different now from what it was at the end of 1990, a year in which the price of Citicorp's stock fell by half. That fall, Prince Waleed bought 16.6 million Citicorp shares for $207 million, or about $12.40 each.
 
Financed by Citibank
 The 37-year-old prince is an entrepreneur with various interests and is chairman of the United Saudi Commercial Bank. He received much of the initial financing for his enterprises from a Saudi Arabian branch of Citibank.
To replenish its capital in early 1991, Citicorp also sold Prince Waleed 5,900 shares of a special nonvoting preferred stock that yields 11 percent and is convertible into 36.875 million new shares of common stock at $16 a share.
If they were converted today, those preferred shares would represent 9.1 percent of Citicorp's common shares. After yesterday's transaction, Prince Waleed apparently still has 7.7 million shares of his initial investment of 16.6 million common shares, or 2.1 percent of the shares outstanding.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Stocks Surge on Positive Inflation News

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market came to attention yesterday, mainly because of hard-to-ignore good news on consumer price inflation.
The rising stock tide lifted, if not all the boats, at least a fair number of them. 
 The rally was in contrast to the listlessness last week, which persisted whether the perception had been good (wholesale inflation is low), bad (Philip Morris profits will drop) or dubious (Coca-Cola and other brand names will suffer, too).
Seven prominent blue-chip stocks, all rising a point or more, pushed up the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday. They included J. P. Morgan, Aluminum Company of America and Philip Morris.
 
 
Surge in Transportation Issues
 Perhaps on the theory that an expanding industrial sector would need planes and trains to distribute goods and services, the Dow Jones transportation average rose to its second record high in three trading sessions. Nine large transportation companies dominated trading, including Consolidated Rail; UAL, the parent of United Airlines, and AMR, parent of American Airlines.
The Dow Jones industrials rose strongly throughout the day, closing at 3,428.09, up 31.61 points, with an advance in the morning of as much as 36 points. The Dow transportation average jumped 35.46 points, to 1,648.84.
Broader market indexes also posted robust increases. The New York Stock Exchange's composite Index rose 3.07 points, to 246.91, while the Standard & Poor's 500 index advanced 6.53 points, to 448.57, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 6.79 points, to 673.12.
But the trading volume was a less-than-torrid 261.5 million shares, far below the more than 323 million shares during what traders are calling Marlboro Friday -- April 2 -- when Philip Morris said it would discount its main product. Advancing stocks led decliners yesterday by 13 to 6.
Investors received their first chance yesterday to react to the tame one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index in March, which was announced by the Government Friday when most markets were closed for Good Friday. The small increase in March producer prices, reported Thursday, had been similarly encouraging.
 
 
'Temporary Worry'
 "We had some temporary worry about inflation until the figures came in," said Gene J. Seagle, vice president and director of technical market research at Gruntal. "The market's reactions, as usual, were overblown."
He noted that some of the consumer-products stocks, like Philip Morris and Procter & Gamble, were beginning to recover.
Mr. Seagle saw yesterday's surge as a sign of a summer rally in the next several weeks. "But seriously," he said, "I believe this will probably take the Dow to the next round number, which is 3,500."
Some other market watchers were not impressed by yesterday's buying.
"I would very much like to have seen different leadership" in the stock gainers, said Lawrence R. Rice, chief market strategist for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross.
 
 
'Cash Is Trash'
 He noted that some of the most prominent leaders were airlines and casino stocks like Casino Data Systems and President Riverboat. "This market is following the old 'cash is trash' scenario," Mr. Rice said. "But I wish they'd put their money in depressed quality groups like pharmaceuticals, food and computers."
Among other issues, Citicorp, the big bank, jumped 1 1/8, to 30 1/4. But three-quarters of the 11.9 million shares traded could be traced to a Saudi prince, who had announced in February that he planned to a sell a big block of shares.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Japan's Stimulus Program Drives Dollar Even Lower

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar skidded to yet another postwar low against the yen yesterday, as investors bet the Japanese Government's economic stimulus plan would further strengthen the yen.
Trading was relatively quiet, as the European markets and some markets in Asia were closed for Easter Monday. 
 Gold prices, meanwhile, moved lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for delivery in June fell 70 cents, to $338.20 an ounce, as concerns about inflation waned.
The dollar finished trading in New York yesterday at 112.80 yen, down from 113.12 yen on Friday. During the day, the dollar traded as low 112.75 yen.
The dollar also fell against most other leading currencies, losing more than a pfennig, to 1.595 German marks.
 
 
'Single Biggest Factor'
 "The single biggest factor for the yen right now is the fiscal stimulus package" in Japan, said Frank Pusateri, a vice president at the Bank of Boston. Japan plans to spend more than $100 billion to bolster its slumping economy.
The yen, up 10 percent on the dollar so far this year, is expected to go higher if the stimulus works, traders said. People are buying yen because they think Japan has "more ability to rebound," even though economic conditions are worse there than in the United States, Mr. Pusateri said.
The yen started breaking records in Tokyo trading overnight, until the Bank of Japan stepped in to stem the currency's rise, traders said. The yen resumed its rise in New York trading, with the dollar closing near its lows.
Some traders expect the Japanese currency to reach 111 yen to the dollar before Friday, when President Clinton is scheduled to meet with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa in Washington.
"You've got to have a strong yen before the meeting," said Earl Johnson, foreign exchange adviser at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Japan is under pressure from its trading partners to shrink its swelling trade surplus, and Mr. Miyazawa will be eager to point to the yen's record strength as a means of achieving that end, Mr. Johnson said.
That means the Bank of Japan will not be aggressive in its efforts to slow the yen's rise, Mr. Johnson said. A stronger currency makes a country's exports more expensive and is considered less destructive than tariffs for shrinking trade imbalances.
Persistent concern about the pace of the American economic recovery clears the way for more gains by the yen, traders said. Last week's producer and consumer price reports showed the economy was not building enough steam to fuel inflation, indicating that new economic reports would be weaker than expected.
Elsewhere, the British pound jumped 1.7 cents, to $1.5455, as investors turned more optimistic about Britain's economy.
