HEADLINE: Meeting of Minds on Pine Barrens' Future

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MELVILLE, L.I., April 12

 BODY:
After years of bitter confrontation, developers and environmentalists held peace talks today on the future of the Long Island Pine Barrens, a 100,000-acre expanse that sits above the purest drinking water left on the Island.
"We've checked our guns at the door and are giving conciliation its first real chance," said Edwin M. Schwenk, executive director of the Long Island Builders Institute. "The time has arrived for us to settle our differences peacefully." 
 He said the Long Island building community had about $11 billion worth of real estate tied up in the Pine Barrens. "So our pocketbook needs to know where we can build and what we can build."
But he added: "Just because we're builders doesn't mean we're not concerned about the environment. Many of us have grandchildren and we want to leave behind a heritage they'll all be proud of."
 
Spirit of Cooperation
 There were no major breakthroughs today, but after the many battles of recent years, even an attempt at conciliation was remarkable.
An environmentalist, Kevin McDonald, vice president of the Group for the South Fork, noted that President Clinton went to the Pacific Northwest last week on a similar quest "to set the stage for cooperative efforts to protect the environment while encouraging the economy."
"We're applying the same spirit and approach," he said.
Development in and around the Pine Barrens, which cover nearly a fourth of Long Island's East End, was the subject of a lawsuit brought by environmentalists more than four years ago. They sought to bar construction on 224 real-estate projects in the area, arguing that state environmental law required the towns of Brookhaven, Riverhead and Southampton to assess the cumulative environmental impact before approving individual projects.
But the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, dismissed the case in November, observing that while the protection of the Pine Barrens was vital to the health of the Island's population, there was no binding plan to preserve its vast water supply.
But the ruling did not mean the battle was over. Construction in the Pine Barrens remains on hold, not only because of lingering environmental questions, but also because of a slow economy with little demand for new housing and commercial office space.
"With respect to what's happening here today," Mr. Schwenk said, "I think it's about time, and I'm looking forward to getting this all behind us."
 
Reconsidering Land Use
 Mr. Schwenk was among almost 300 leaders from business, government and environmental groups who gathered in the ballroom of the Radison Plaza Hotel here this morning, seeking to achieve a balance between the preservation of the Pine Barrens and real-estate development.
John Bierwirth, former chairman of the Grumman Corporation, said the clash between environmentalists and people who need space in which to grow their businesses was nationwide.
He said it was time to reconsider ways to re-use land that has already been developed but is standing idle. People who would buy such land should be relieved of the liability for cleaning pollution they might find on and beneath the land, he said.
"It's time to tell Albany to change the rules," said Mr. Bierwirth, who is also president of the Long Island chapter of the Nature Conservancy, which last year designated the Pine Barrens as one of the 12 "last great places" in the Western Hemisphere.
James L. Larocca, executive director of the Long Island Association and one of the sponsors of today's meeting, warned of the continuing economic impact of stalled development in the Pine Barrens and elsewhere on the Island. He said this all had to be balanced against a loss of from 100,000 to 125,000 jobs since 1989, as well as loss of 25 percent of the Island's youth between the ages of 18 and 24 over the last five years.
Richard Amper, executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, the organization which brought the suit against the builders, said this morning that he "looked forward to developing a plan that would be fair to the environmental community and to the building community."
"No one is saying any longer, 'We're either going to pave the place over or absolutely halt all growth.' We don't hear that from anybody any more." Mr. Amper said. "We're hearing for the first time that proper planning will allow us to do both."
He welcomed suggestions from Terrence Moore, executive director of the New Jersey Pinelands Commission, and Armando Carbonell, executive director of the Cape Cod Commission, who said they went through many of the same problems that Long Island was now experiencing.
Mr. Moore predicted that the meeting would mark a turning point for the Pine Barrens. "Eventually a solution has to be found." he said. "At least there is agreement that the Pine Barrens is a special place, and that's a good place to begin."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sears Said to Be Near Pact to Sell Coldwell Banker

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company is nearing an agreement to sell its Coldwell Banker Residential Services unit to the subsidiary's management and two investment groups, one of which includes the Texas investor Robert Bass, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.
Sears said in September that it was planning to sell the unit, which has more than 2,000 brokerage offices nationwide and a mortgage servicing group, as part of its effort to shift its energies back to its core business of retailing. No estimate was available on what Coldwell Banker might fetch. 
 The backers of the management acquisition attempt are Bain Capital of Boston and Acadia Partners, a partnership based in Fort Worth whose investors include Mr. Bass. While none of those involved -- Sears, Coldwell Banker, Acadia or Bain -- would confirm that a sale was pending, people close to the negotiations confirmed a report in Crain's Chicago Business that the talks are "in final negotiations."
 
 
Strengthening Market
 The prospective purchasers are most likely interested in Coldwell Banker because the residential real estate market has recently strengthened as interest rates have declined. Many real estate companies, large and small, went out of business or cut back sharply as a result of the market's problems of the 1980's and their further repercussions. But Coldwell Banker, an established brokerage and relocation company that is one of the top in the country, said its residential real estate transactions last year increased 14 percent over the previous year, while total sales of existing homes in the United States were up only 9 percent for the year.
Coldwell Banker said that one in every nine homes sold in America in 1992 involved a Coldwell Banker sales associate. The unit earned $19 million in the fourth quarter of 1992, compared with $1.6 million in the comparable quarter a year earlier.
A Coldwell Banker spokeswoman referred calls to Sears. When asked about the report, Perry Chlan, a Sears spokesman, said: "We have not announced any agreements regarding the planned sale of Coldwell Banker. The actions related to the planned sale of Coldwell Banker are proceeding as planned."
Owen Blicksilver, a spokesman for Acadia Partners, said the group would have no comment. Adam Kirsch, general partner of Bain Capital, said, "We're in the acquisitions business, and we can't comment on transactions whether or not we're working on them."
Joseph Ronning, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman, noted that Coldwell Banker had turned its business around over the past year, partly as result of tighter management and partly as a result of favorable market conditions.
 
 
'Best Level' in Years
 "The residential real estate business appears to have turned," he said, adding that "housing affordability is at its best level in a number of years."
Consequently, the Coldwell Banker Residential unit might well be considered a good investment with considerable growth potential if the economy remains stable or grows.
Sears is known to be eager to spin off the unit, and has announced that it wants to have a deal completed by June. Further, both Bain and Acadia tend to invest where there is strong management, and a management buyout fits this strategy.
One analyst speculated that the attraction of the deal was the Sears Mortgage Banking Group, which operates as a part of Coldwell Banker. The mortgage banking group, through its Sears Mortgage Corporation, Sears Mortgage Securities Corporation and Sears Savings Bank, increased its mortgage loan production 43 percent, to a record $11.75 billion in 1992, from $8.2 billion in 1991.
 
 
Two Sales Possible
 Although this might be an attractive business for Acadia and Bain, one person close to the negotiations suggested that Coldwell Banker and the mortgage banking group would be sold separately.
For Sears itself, the move is part of a strategy to shrink and concentrate on retailing, in line with its September announcement that it would sell its Dean Witter Financial Services unit and part of its Allstate Insurance Group, as well as spin off Coldwell Banker.
When Sears announced the plans in September, analysts said the moves would more than halve the company's $38 billion debt load. The company started to accumulate debt in the 1980's to finance its expansion into financial services, even as it invested money in store renovations and new promotions of its retail stock.
Sears stock rose $3.375 a share, to $44.75, on the day Sears made its announcement in September. Yesterday, it gained 37.5 cents, to $53.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Price of Natural Gas Soars On Reports of Tight Supply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Natural gas futures prices soared to a five-month high on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday in reaction to reports of tightening supplies.
Natural gas for May delivery soared 11.5 cents, to $2.344 for 1,000 cubic feet, the highest settlement for a near-term contract since Nov. 18. 
 In other energy trading on the New York Merc, light crude oil for May delivery rose 24 cents, to $20.46 a barrel. May heating oil climbed 0.53, cent, to 56.52 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline rose 0.26 cent, to 60.24 cents a gallon.
Natural gas futures have risen for five straight days, gaining more than 15 percent since April 2, in reaction to industry reports showing the amount of gas in storage to be 15 to 23 percent below year-ago levels.
 
Buying Distant Contracts
 Yesterday, the average price to secure gas through a 12-month supply agreement on the cash market reached $2.30 for 1,000 cubic feet, which suggests buyers think prices are unlikely to drop.
"People are so confident the market is going higher that they're willing to buy aggressively for the farther-out months," said Thomas Blakeslee, an analyst at Brody, White & Company in New York.
The use of natural gas as an alternative to petroleum-based fuels is expanding at a time when supplies have been drawn down by the coldest winter in several years.
Mr. Blakeslee said demand was depleting the excess supply "bubble" that has long characterized the natural gas market and held down prices.
David Pruner, president of KCS Energy Risk Management Inc. in Edison, N.J., said it was too soon to declare the bubble burst. But, he said, "If these prices hold on during the summer, we are willing to go ahead and say the bubble dissipated."
In other commodity markets, livestock and meat were mostly higher, while most grains and soybean futures rose.

HEADLINE: Large Role For Russia Expected On Station

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
STRIKING new details have emerged about the plan announced last week to invite Russia's collaboration in designing a sharply smaller outpost for American astronauts. It now appears that Russian aid will amount to far more than mere ideas, as a pivotal ground rule of NASA's proposed redesign makes clear.
If at all possible, the redesigned space station is to fly in an orbit where the angle of inclination to the equator is 51.6 degrees, according to NASA experts and internal agency documents. That seemingly obscure figure speaks volumes, for it is a path through space that has been used exclusively by Moscow for virtually all its manned voyages. 
 For reasons of orbital geometry, the United States would have to adopt such an unusual orbit if it were to rely on the Russians for substantive help in launching a joint space venture. America used that orbit only once before, in 1975, when Apollo and Soyuz capsules joined briefly some 140 miles above the Earth to mark a thaw in the cold war. Daniel S. Goldin, Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said yesterday in an interview that teamwork with Russia and use of the 51.6-degree inclination were requirements stemming from the need to boost the space station's capabilities while cutting its construction costs by up to two-thirds. The highly inclined orbit, he said, would give the revamped outpost greater powers of Earth observation and pave the way for wide Russian participation.
"It's not absolutely necessary but it opens up all the new vistas," he said of the 51.6-degree orbit, adding that its utilization was a general goal of the redesign process. "We said, 'Shoot for 51.6. If you can't get it, tell us the best you can do.' "
The space agency's 50-member redesign team was informed of Moscow's entry into the turbulent nine-year history of the space station by Dr. John H. Gibbons, the White House science adviser, on April 3 as President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia discussed the issue at the Vancouver summit meeting.
"The overall goal of the redesign effort is to develop options for reducing station costs," Dr. Gibbons told the team, an agency statement made public last week showed. "Careful integration of Russian assets could be a key factor in achieving that goal."
In recent years Moscow and Washington have increasingly teamed up on relatively minor space projects. But experts say that designing and building a space outpost together, if it comes to that, would be a watershed in East-West relations.
 
Competition to Cooperation
 "We have implemented a process that a few years ago would have been inconceivable," said a White House official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It's ironic," the official added, "but cooperation with the Russians may help us save a program that conflict with the Russians begat," referring to the space program's cold war roots.
The space station effort was begun in 1984 by President Ronald Reagan and was to be a high-technology triumph over Moscow, which had a long history of success with outposts for astronauts. Although design work has so far consumed more than $8 billion, the planned outpost has long been mired in technical and political problems. Most recently it was envisioned as a 350-foot-long structure costing some $31 billion, its price seeming to rise almost daily.
The United States is turning to the Russians for help mainly in an effort to cut costs and only secondarily to advance a post-cold-war agenda, the White House official said. Moscow itself has independently and vigorously promoted such an East-West realignment.
On March 16, two top Russian officials, Yuri Koptev, head of the Russian space agency, and Yuri Semenov, head of Russia's main rocket builder, NPO Energia, wrote Mr. Goldin to propose a celestial union.
 
'They Want You to Buy'
 "Billions of dollars" could be saved, the Russians wrote, by the "unification of efforts" of the two nations to realize a "joint advanced orbital station." They made no mention of the beneficial effects that Western currency could have on idle Russian production lines.
"When the Russians say they want to cooperate," noted the White House official, "they mean they want you to buy their hardware."
The two Russian officials called for a physical merger in space of an upgraded version of Moscow's station currently in orbit, Mir, with elements of the Western plan, including an American laboratory, the European laboratory "Columbus" and a Japanese experimental module. The outpost could house three astronauts by 1997 and, with further expansions, nine astronauts by the year 2000.
 
Offering Better View
 The Russians proposed an orbital inclination of more than "50 degrees, providing essential capabilities for Earth surface observation." This is considered a strong selling point given the push for global data on climate change and habitat destruction.
A law of orbital geometry says the area of Earth surveillance increases with rising inclination. This is because the angle at which an orbiting spacecraft crosses the equator is just another way of stating extremes of latitude it hits as the Earth turns beneath it. For instance, an outpost orbiting at 50 degrees inclination to the equator would travel across the Earth's face as high as 50 degrees north latitude in Canada and as low as 50 degrees south latitude near the tip of South America. A smaller angle of inclination means less of the Earth's surface is visible.
Although the American space shuttles are usually launched due east from Cape Canaveral over the Atlantic, at an inclination of 28.5 degrees, they can go as high as 57 degrees and still avoid land. The shuttles have done so occasionally for Earth-observation missions and other reasons.
In theory the Russians have less flexibility. They fly their manned missions from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Central Asia, which is located at 45.9 degrees north latitude. If spacecraft flew due east from there, getting the greatest possible boost into space from the Earth's own rotation, they would have an orbital inclination of 45.9 degrees. But they never do since this path would take them over neighboring countries.
 
Avoiding China and Mongolia
 Instead, the Russians fly slightly higher at an inclination of 51.6 degrees, staying over their own territory during the fiery ascent and avoiding the risk of dropping astronauts or spent rocket stages on Mongolia or northern China.
Just as the Russians lose some rotational boost by flying a more northerly course, so will the Americans if they link up with the Russians in Moscow's traditional space orbit. In fact, NASA experts say shuttles launched from Cape Canaveral would loose about one-third of their payload-lifting power. This is clearly a drawback of the cooperative plan, since the shuttle's powers are already overtaxed for the planned lifting of big outpost modules.
One aid would be the debut of more powerful shuttle booster rockets, which were once envisioned as starting work around 1996 but now have been delayed to the year 2000.
James E. Oberg, an American specialist on the Russian space program and author of "Red Star in Orbit," said a different kind of aid would be for the Russians to move toward the preferred American orbit by bringing their own inclination down to 45.9 degrees, the best one for Russian rockets energetically.
 
'Cold War Fossil'
 "Operationally, dynamically and politically," he said, "51.6 degrees is a cold war fossil."
But experts at two NASA centers said an inclination of 51.6 degrees was now a ground rule in station redesign. And late last month agency headquarters in Washington issued an internal document stating that the new outpost should have an "orbital inclination to provide dual access by multinational launch systems."
Such an orbit is a necessary but not sufficient condition for close East-West teamwork, so exactly what will become of Moscow's participation in the effort remains an open question.
Experts say a 51.6-degree orbit could allow the Russians to do as little as making symbolic visits to an American station, or as much as becoming major partners in constructing and putting it into orbit. Mr. Goldin noted in the interview that the orbit would also allow stranded American astronauts to be rescued by Moscow. Not weighing such merits, he said, "would be irresponsible."
 
$25 Billion Savings?
 An intermediate possibility for cooperation was sketched out in the October 1992 issue of Aerospace America by Dr. Jerry Grey, director of science and technology policy for the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, a professional group based in Washington.
He posited that American shuttles from Cape Canaveral would ferry astronauts to an orbit of 51.6 degrees but carry no cargo, and that the 20-story Russian rocket known as Energia, the world's most powerful, would blast off concurrently loaded with American station gear.
Only four such pairs of launchings would be needed to produce a full station, he wrote, in contrast to more than 30 shuttle flights if the United States did the job alone. Shuttle flights are estimated by private experts to cost about $1 billion a piece, and Energia flights about half that, so the savings on transportation alone could in theory amount to about $25 billion.
Dr. Grey noted, however, that the Energia is a new vehicle whose reliability is unproven.
Moreover, he said in an interview, "a whole bunch of questions exist about whether we can rely on the Russians with their economy the way it is," adding, "And integrating the space programs would not be easy. You run into severe engineering problems."
But if these and other questions can be addressed with open-eyed realism, he said, "the benefits of a truly international space program far exceed the costs."
Mr. Yeltsin, in his prepared statement on April 4 at the end of the Vancouver meeting, said the foundations had been laid for a peaceful new era of space exploration.
"We decided to cooperate in this area and decided to join forces," he told reporters.
Mr. Clinton echoed those remarks, saying he saw "real opportunity for joint activity."

HEADLINE: U.S. Cracks Door to World Forest Agreement

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
THE Clinton Administration will offer an olive branch this week to tropical countries on the bitterly divisive issue of protecting the world's forests, according to Administration and State Department officials. Environmentalists say the move might eventually open the way for negotiation of a world forest treaty.
It could also be one of a series of actions this spring and summer signaling an Administration intention to reassert American leadership on international environmental issues after the Bush Administration's diplomatic floundering at the Earth Summit last year in Rio de Janeiro. 
 The meeting often pitted developing countries jealous of their valuable natural resources against industrialized countries who see uncontrolled exploitation of those resources as dangerous to the global environment. Nowhere was the clash more rancorous than over the issue of forests.
Tropical countries led by Malaysia, a major timber exporter, charged that the main burden for protecting forests was being forced on them by temperate countries that had long since over-exploited their own forests. Malaysia and its allies torpedoed an American-led effort to negotiate a forest treaty even before the summit began, and the United States and its allies were lucky to salvage even a weak statement on forest management principles.
 
Talks on Timber Agreement
 The forum for a possible start in recouping the situation is the opening of talks today in Geneva to renegotiate the 1987 International Tropical Timber Agreement. Under the agreement, countries that export tropical timber undertake voluntary efforts to exploit their forests while preserving them ecologically. Tropical forests contain a majority of the world's dwindling store of plant, animal and microbial species. But the tropical countries, charging discrimination and unfair competition, want the agreement expanded to include forests in temperate countries like the United States and subarctic climates like those of Canada and Russia.
Environmentalists support this view and want the agreement to have some teeth as well. If tropical and temperate countries agree on these issues, they hope, the rancor that has surrounded the forest question will be dispelled and the main roadblock to negotiating a treaty for all types of forest exploitation will be removed.
The Bush Administration adamantly opposed expanding the timber agreement to include temperate forests. But officials close to the situation, who would speak only on the condition that they not be named, said that American representatives in Geneva were there with an open mind and would explore ways in which both temperate and tropical countries could pledge themselves to a policy of harvesting timber while preserving forests. This goal of sustainable cutting of trees would be achieved by the end of this decade under proposals for revising the timber agreement.
"We could agree to those kinds of principles," said one Administration official, who added that the United States would acknowledge in Geneva that some complaints by tropical countries about a double standard were valid. But how any agreement on principles gets translated into specific provisions is critical, and it is far from clear that the United States can ultimately agree with tropical countries on the details.
Further, it is unclear how an effective agreement applying sustainable harvesting principles to temperate countries would affect forestry practices in the United States itself. The Administration is wrestling now, for instance, with how to reconcile economic and ecological interests in the Pacific Northwest, and the outcome of that dispute is far from assured.
 
Shift Would Be Significant
 No conclusions are likely to be reached in four days of meetings this week in Geneva, said a State Department official involved in the talks who characterized this first round as exploratory. A second round of talks is to take place in late June.
The United States has been the spokesman for the temperate countries' caucus in preliminary meetings leading up to the timber talks, and any shift in its position would carry great weight. Its new stance is therefore "very, very encouraging," said Bill Mankin, the coordinator of the Global Forest Policy Project of the National Wildlife Federation, Sierra Club and Friends of the Earth.
"It's the first opening, the first break" in the temperate-tropical impasse on forests, Mr. Mankin said.
The rebuff to the Bush Administration on forests at the Earth Summit was accompanied by an outcry over its standing alone among major countries in refusing to sign the global biodiversity treaty designed to help protect the world's array of biological species. It was also widely criticized for winning weaker controls than other countries wanted on emissions of heat-trapping gases that could cause global warming.
The Clinton Administration has been engaged in a reassessment of international environmental issues.The Administration is reviewing the biodiversity treaty and is widely expected to reverse the Bush policy and sign the pact. It has also signaled to a meeting of countries that negotiated the global-warming treaty signed in Rio that the Administration was willing to consider stronger steps to control heat-trapping gases.
On forests, Mr. Mankin had this to say: "The Bush Administration dug a deep hole for us to get out of, and the Clinton Administration is beginning to peek over the edge and say, 'H-m-m. What's outside this hole?' "

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HILLENBRAND IN TALKS TO SELL AMERICAN TOURISTER

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Hillenbrand Industries said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its American Tourister luggage-making unit. Hillenbrand declined to name the potential buyer or the asking price. The company, based in Batesville, Ind., said that it had retained Morgan Stanley & Company to help evaluate options. Analysts said they expected the company to complete a sale within two months. American Tourister had about $100 million in sales last year, about 7 percent of Hillenbrand's $1.43 billion total. The unit has been hurt by weak business travel and sluggish consumer spending.

HEADLINE: Anger at Tokyo Grows in Asia

SERIES: Japan: The Consummate Trade -- Two Case Studies -- First of two articles

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
After decades of focusing its exporting sights on the United States and, to a lesser extent, Europe, Japan is now in a race to dominate trade in East Asia, the world's fastest-growing region. And it is succeeding with a strategy that is as well crafted as it is irritating to many of the region's countries.
What is emerging is a new source of anger over Japan's trading practices that goes beyond the war of words between Washington and Tokyo to Japan's already difficult relations with its Asian neighbors. 
 This is one reason that President Clinton's tough line on Japan strikes a resonant chord in this part of the world. South Korea and other Asian countries complain about many of the same practices that American companies cite: They call Tokyo's export policies predatory and insist that there are tough barriers to selling foreign products in Japan.
Tokyo's trade surpluses have been transformed from an issue with the United States into a global matter.
 
Beyond Consumer Goods
 Japanese companies have built their products into the engine of this region's growth by selling not just consumer goods like cars and electronic gadgets, but the industrial equipment and manufacturing technology on which Asian exporters depend. As a result, the trade surpluses of Japan with South Korea, Taiwan and Southeast Asian countries are rising far more swiftly than its surpluses with Western countries.
"We're hooked on Japan, I'm afraid," complained Lee Sang Yul, director general of the international trade bureau at the South Korean Ministry of Trade and Industry. "When the Korean economy was just beginning to develop, we had to rely on Japan for technology and parts. Once we had their systems, we kept buying them. So as our exports to the rest of the world increased, our imports from Japan had to grow."
Japanese officials "have this model in which Japan controls everything, and they are just applying that model to a new area, Asia," said Chuh Young Souk, vice chairman of the Korea-Japan Economic Association, an industry body.
 
 
Steep Rises in Surplus
 Over the last four years, Japan's trade surplus with East Asia has more than doubled, to $42 billion last year from $18 billion in 1989. By contrast, Japan's surplus with the United States declined in that period, according to Japanese figures, to $43.7 billion last year from $45 billion in 1989.
Japan's exports to East Asia -- $116.4 billion last year -- now far exceed its exports to the United States, which came to $95.9 billion.
"Everyone in the world has the same problem with Japan," said Suh Sang Mok, a member of Parliament and a key policy adviser to President Kim Young Sam. "It gets to be a friendship and a philosophy issue."
The issue becomes more complicated because many Asian nations, especially South Korea, are protectionists themselves. Several of the Asian "tigers," as these prosperous countries are often called, rely heavily on exports while keeping their markets relatively closed to others.
 Inflaming feelings further is Japan's history of brutal occupation of most of East Asia in World War II -- preceded in the Korean case by modern colonial rule going back to 1910. Such memories help make trade imbalances a tense issue in the region.
Japanese officials argue that the Japanese success in selling a limited range of industrial goods to South Korea obscures the fact that it is all but impossible for Japanese companies to sell consumer goods, from autos to stereos, here. They also complain that the surpluses are more a result of Japanese customers rejecting shoddy Korean goods than a product of trade barriers.
The problems created by Japan's surpluses are acute in South Korea, which is struggling to revive a faltering economy and is clearly feeling a touch of wounded pride in finding itself dependent on its old enemy. Kim Young Sam, the new President, won election in December partly by playing on a perception that the economy was losing its competitiveness; the economy grew by 4.7 percent last year, its worst showing since 1980. The trade deficit with Japan is popularly viewed as another measure of that lost competitiveness.
There is also some oddity in the fact that South Korea has consciously modeled its export-driven economy on Japan's, with one important difference: Japan never permitted its manufacturers to become so dependent on foreign suppliers.
 
 
Trade Reversal for South Korea
 During better times, in 1988, South Korea boasted an overall surplus of $8.9 billion, including a $3.9 billion surplus with Japan. By last year, however, trade had deteriorated to a deficit of $5.1 billion, chiefly because of a $7.9 billion deficit with Japan.
The turnaround was the result of a large increase in Korean imports of Japanese machinery, while Japanese purchases of Korean goods declined. Sales of inexpensive Korean-made consumer products have suffered in part because of the economic slowdown, and partly because they have increasingly been depicted as being of poor quality.
Many South Korean executives and policy makers acknowledge that part of the solution lies in Korean industries' developing higher quality products that are more attractive to demanding Japanese consumers.
But they also complain that several years of trade talks have removed few barriers to the export of Korean goods to Japan. Mr. Lee of the Trade and Industry Ministry said that efforts to open up Japanese markets for foreign-made leather and footwear, for instance, had been fruitless.
"We've been sending export promotion missions to Japan since 1985, but the results are nominal," Mr. Chuh of the Korea-Japan Economic Association said.
And because Japanese equipment and technology are so critical to South Korea's exporting capability, little thought is given to restricting the purchase of these goods as retaliation. The buying just marches on.
Japan has used a variety of methods to expand its trade throughout East Asia. It sends more than half its $13 billion a year in foreign aid to East Asia, and that helps build good will that ultimately benefits commercial relations. Japanese companies are also by far the largest foreign investors in Asia, as they move factories to countries with lower wages.
Perhaps more important, some of Japan's aid to East Asian countries for years had to be used to buy goods and services from Japan; Korean experts say that some of this money was used to buy Japanese manufacturing technology, which began the cycle of dependence. But what has particularly angered some manufacturers is what they say is the reluctance of Japan to sell its most advanced manufacturing technologies.
 "Japan is afraid of the boomerang effect, that products from Korea made with their technology would come back and take over their markets," Mr. Lee said.
For instance, the Samsung Electronics Company in South Korea has complained that the Sony Corporation has refused to cooperate in its efforts to develop a video camera suitable for television broadcasting.
Sony officials in Tokyo deny this, saying that the two companies held commercial negotiations but broke them off because Samsung was not willing to pay an appropriate fee for the camera technology.
Japanese officials offer few apologies for the surpluses. They say they are reluctant to make it easier for Korean companies to sell their products in Japan until Seoul takes stronger steps to liberalize its economy. There are 258 items, from autos and fax machines to television sets, that foreign manufacturers are blocked from exporting to South Korea, Japanese officials say.
 
 
'China Is More Open Than Korea'
 "Their Government does so many things to protect their economy," said Yukio Kitazume, director of the Northwest Asia division at Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry in Tokyo. "China is more open than Korea. Honestly speaking, Japanese companies don't believe the Korean Government proposals for opening their market."
He added that the structural nature of the imbalance meant that it was likely to get worse before it got better. The bottom line, Mr. Kitazume insisted, is that until the Korean Government becomes less protectionist, Korean companies can never hope to obtain the best of Japan's technology.
"If Japanese companies could set up 100 percent owned subsidiaries and sell their products in the Korean market, then they would provide high technology," he said.
Some cautious steps are being taken to address these problems. Japan and South Korea reached an historic moment last year when Kiichi Miyazawa, Japan's Prime Minister, and Roh Tae Woo, South Korea's President at the time, met in Kyoto, Japan. It was the first time the leaders of the two countries had held an informal working meeting, despite their being neighbors.
An important item on the agenda was trade, and Japan agreed to set up a foundation to pursue joint industrial research and to encourage the transfer of technology to South Korea.
"There's a lot of disappointment over this issue, but we realize we have to focus on a few issues ourselves," said Mr. Suh, the Korean legislator. "It's really a question of what sort of identity this region will have."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 22, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a chart in Business Day on April 13, about conflicts between Japan and its Asian neighbors over its trade policies, misstated three years' trade balances between Japan and South Korea. South Korea had a $5.2 billion trade deficit with Japan in 1987, a $3.9 billion deficit in 1988 and a $4 billion deficit in 1989.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Double Aid for Russia, Diplomats Say

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, April 14

 BODY:
President Clinton told Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa Tuesday night that American contributions to Russia would increase by at least $2 billion, officials here said today.
The figure would more than double the original $1.6 billion the President had pledged to Russia. 
 In the telephone conversation with Washington on the eve of an international conference here on Russian aid, Mr. Miyazawa reportedly said that his country would offer $1.8 billion in direct bilateral financial assistance to support President Boris N. Yeltsin's programs for democratic change.
The pledges, which are expected to be announced officially here later today at a meeting of the seven richest industrialized nations, should insure that the aid package American officials had sought for Russia will reach $30 billion.
At a news conference today, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen indicated that the telephone call had taken place, but he and other officials remained deliberately vague as to the aid total. He did say that Japanese press reports about American assistance to Russia growing by $2.5 billion were incorrect.
Other American officials, who insisted on anonymity, said President Clinton would offer about $2 billion in trade credits from the Export-Import Bank as well as hundreds of millions of dollars in additional assistance.
President Clinton said in the conversation that he must consult with Congressional leaders before settling the terms of the assistance, the officials here said.
In Washington, a White House spokeswoman, Lorraine Voles, said that Mr. Clinton spoke by telephone to Mr. Miyazawa about "the need for substantial support for Russian reform," but she declined to provide any details or to say whether the President had decided to increase the amount of aid.
The original $1.6 billion pledged at the recent summit meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia, was to include $700 million in agricultural credits, $690.9 million in grant assistance and $232 million in other credits.
Mr. Bentsen said at a news conference on Tuesday evening that he was more optimistic this year than last year that large amounts of aid would be pledged and disbursed to push Russia further on the road to a capitalist economy. He said that if the Russian central bank carries through on a pledge to reduce soaring inflation, the prospects for the aid from America, Japan and the other industrial nations supporting change in Russia were high.
 
A New Agenda
 The comments set a positive tone for a gathering that has already established a far different agenda and style from such meetings during the cold-war era. The meeting includes the Foreign and Finance Ministers of the so-called Group of Seven countries, the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada.
In particular, the early discussions between American and Japanese officials were of a far different nature than those of just a few years ago. In a striking shift of emphasis, Mr. Bentsen and Secretary of State Warren Christopher used their initial encounters with senior Japanese officials here to pressure them to reduce Japan's yawning trade surplus, but said little about the security issues that had dominated the relationship in the past.
The Japanese were at pains to show that they were making such efforts. The Government announced on Tuesday a $116.5 billion program to stimulate its faltering domestic economy. The spending is intended to moderate the growth of Japan's trade surplus by increasing imports.
 
Cordiality With an Edge
 The American officials were cordial in applauding these Japanese measures. But behind the courtliness there was an edge. The Americans made it clear that more would have to be done to revivify Japan's domestic economy and that they expected Japan to continue to take a leading role in assisting Russia, even without progress on a lingering World War II territorial dispute between the two countries.
Mr. Christopher reportedly called Japan's domestic economic stimulus program a "useful first step," and indicated that the United States expected several years of efforts to moderate the trade surplus.
Underscoring the new primacy of economic issues, Mr. Christopher was quoted by a senior American official as using his first meeting with Kabun Muto, the new Japanese Foreign Minister, to ask if Japan would be using some of the new appropriations to purchase American personal computers.
Just a few years ago, such high-level contacts were generally devoted to discussions of the United States-Japan security treaty and military threats in East Asia.
 
Talking Money, Not Security
 "Economic relations must be addressed with great intensity in order to maintain and indeed expand our partnership with Japan," Mr. Christopher was quoted by an American official as telling Mr. Muto. "We're going to have to make progress on economic issues."
Although it is supposed to be secret, just about every Japanese newspaper has reported that the Government will offer $1.8 billion in aid, or $600 million more than was planned a few days ago, because of pressure from other Group of Seven countries.
This will reportedly consist of $1.1 billion worth of trade insurance, $400 million in loans from Japan's Export-Import Bank, and $320 million in relief and help in dismantling nuclear weapons. The trade insurance and loans often require extensive documentation, which has been a stumbling block for Russia in the recent past. It thus remains uncertain if Japan's offer will benefit Russia swiftly.
American officials were critical of Japan's inclusion of so many trade credits in their package.
 The package would represent a big step for Japan, which has been reluctant to provide substantial aid to Russia until it makes progress in returning four lightly-populated northern islands seized in the waning days of the war. Japan did provide nearly $800 million last year, but it also indicated more would be forthcoming if Moscow would negotiate a return of the territories, part of the Kurile chain.
The difficulties that that policy presents were painfully in evidence when Mr. Muto contradicted a Foreign Ministry paper released on Tuesday.
Mr. Muto, who became Foreign Minister only last week, declared that Japan was dropping any linkage between aid and the territorial dispute. He said, for the first time, that the need for democratic change transcended Japan's bilateral problems.
The ministry's position paper noted, however, that while Japan has been providing financial assistance to Russia for the past two years, the island issue is standing in the way of "further full-scale cooperation in Japan-Russian Federation relations."

HEADLINE: Recycling Answer Sought for Computer Junk

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELLEVILLE, N.J.

 BODY:
Eric Buechel tours his domain at a brisk pace, assessing his inventory with the pragmatic humor of an undertaker. In his warehouse sit rows of hulking computers, each weighing tons. They once whirred and flashed, but now they rest cold, unplugged, discarded.
"This is where mainframes come to die," Mr. Buechel declared, smiling and patting one of the big metal boxes with mercenary affection. 
 Mr. Buechel's company, Advanced Recovery Inc., is one of several offering an entrepreneurial response to a looming environmental problem: millions of obsolete computers.
 
Byproduct of Efficiency
 This unwelcome byproduct of the computer age, oddly, is the result of technology's virtuous spiral -- ever-lower prices for increasingly powerful machines. Consequently, American businesses and individuals are discarding their old mainframes, personal computers and work stations at a rate of more than 10 million a year.
Recognizing the problem, the computer industry and the Federal Government have begun collaborating to cope with this high-tech headache. A joint industry-government study last month concluded that developing a "green work station" -- one easier to upgrade or recycle than discard -- is now "both a business and technological issue, not simply a mission for the environmentalist movement."
If the pace of discarding continues, some 150 million computer carcasses will reside in the nation's landfills by the year 2005, according to a Carnegie-Mellon University study. The disposal costs alone for the machines could be $1 billion, ignoring the landfill space required -- an acre of land dug to a depth of three and a half miles, room to stack about 15 Empire State Buildings end to end.
"The numbers are huge and it could be an enormous environmental problem," said Mark Greenwood, director of the Environmental Protection Agency's Office of Pollution Prevention. "But we also believe that companies can make choices in the design and manufacture of computers that reduce the environmental impact, and open up great new areas for recycling."
Which is precisely the opportunity Mr. Buechel sees for Advanced Recovery, a two-year-old company that has become one of the nation's largest computer recyclers. Business is booming.
Situated 10 miles west of Manhattan, the nine-person company is handling 400,000 pounds of computers and other electronic gear a month, four times the volume of a year ago. Mr. Buechel, the 34-year-old president, expects revenues to jump to $3 million this year, and he is looking for more space.
Outside the warehouse, there are piles of personal computers of every make and model, some clearly outdated but others just a few years old. "A hot machine one year is tossed out the next," Mr. Buechel said.
At Advanced Recovery, the cast-off computers are pulled apart and mined for metals from aluminum to gold. The semiconductor chips are plucked out and sold to parts wholesalers and computer maintenance shops. But what can't be resold is trucked away -- and dumped in a nearby landfill.
The computer industry, now hoping to largely eliminate the landfill from the machines' life cycle, is proving a willing conscript to the green movement. Many of the industry's leaders grew up in the 1960's and 70's, reading the Whole Earth Catalogue and schooled in the tenets of environmentalism.
It is also an industry accustomed to change and attuned to international standards -- and aware that Europe, led by Germany, is taking some pioneering steps in recycling computers.
The United States Government views the computer-industry effort as a model of its new "Design for Environment" program in which business and government collaborate early to prevent pollution rather than having the E.P.A. be the cop that tries to catch corporate polluters after they have damaged the environment. This collaborative approach, along with stressing the competitive and marketing advantages of green products, is to be a hallmark of the Clinton Administration.
"And the computer industry is a very good partner," said Mr. Greenwood of the E.P.A.
 
Saving Electricity, Too
 The industry's collaborative approach seems to have been a success on another environmental front: energy conservation. For more than a year, computer companies and the E.P.A. have worked to cut electricity consumption of desktop personal computers by half, by putting them in the electronic equivalent of hibernation when they are turned on but not being used.
Prototypes, which deploy energy-saving chips and circuitry, were demonstrated last fall. The E.P.A. will begin issuing "Energy Star" logos for approved machines in June, and the machines are expected to be widely available by next year. Dozens of companies have signed up, including I.B.M., Apple, Compaq, Dell and Zenith Data Systems.
The E.P.A. estimates that converting the computer population to the Energy Star standards will result in an energy saving of 26 billion kilowatts annually by the year 2000. That amounts to the yearly electricity consumption of Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine combined, said Brian Johnson, director of the Energy Star program. Viewed in terms of curbing pollution by reducing the volume of fuel burned, it is the equivalent of taking five million cars off the road.
But the mounting pile of obsolete computers remains the more difficult environmental challenge. An ambitious study of the problem completed last month by the Government and an industry consortium, "Environmental Consciousness: A Strategic Competitiveness Issue for the Electronics and Computer Industry," sought to lay out the issues and serve as a guide for efforts by the computer companies, chip makers and others.
 
Design, Not Disposal
 "The key is designing for the environment instead of trying to cope with environmental problems at the end of the pipeline -- disposal," said Greg Pitts, the environmental project manager for the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, an industry consortium, which coordinated the study.
In pursuit of a green computer, companies are beginning to work on changing the manufacturing process, using recyclable materials, minimizing the amount of materials used, and altering designs so that computers can be easily taken apart for recycling.
In Research Triangle Park, N.C., J. Ray Kirby heads the International Business Machines Corporation's Engineering Center for Environmentally Conscious Products. For a year, Mr. Kirby's team has worked on recycling the plastics used in I.B.M. personal computers. Plastics in old machines are coded by polymer type and, starting this summer, Mr. Kirby plans to begin making housings and parts with a blend of recycled plastic and fresh resin.
"The goal we're working toward is to keep all I.B.M. products out of landfills," Mr. Kirby said.
 
'It's Cost Avoidance'
 Recycled plastic is cheaper than virgin resin, as long as collecting, sorting and rendering the old plastic can be done economically, Mr. Kirby notes. Another incentive for recycling, he says, is the prospect that companies are going to be held responsible for their old machines.
"It's cost avoidance," he said. "Either you do something with it, or you're going to have to pay to take it away."
Starting next year, computer companies in Germany will be forced to reclaim their old machines when consumers no longer want them. The rule is part of the German "take back" law that applies this year to packaging of all types of products, and next year will cover all electronics products, from hair dryers to mainframe computers.
There are several dozen computer-recycling companies in Germany, but it remains unclear whether there will be an efficient market for the machine dismantling, metals marketing and parts reselling that will result from the new law, according to German computer executives. If not, they say, the effect will be to increase costs to producers, who will then have to pass them along to consumers through higher prices.
"The German system relies on compulsion, while the U.S. is trying to let market forces and innovation do it," said Joachim Tabler, a Munich-based environmental specialist for the Apple Computer Corporation.
 
Giving Them to Others
 Alex Randall is one man who believes that dismantling, recycling and melting down old computers is misguided nonsense. He is president of the East-West Education Development Foundation, a Boston-based charity, that refurbishes second-hand computers and gives them to groups deemed worthy in 130 countries.
The foundation's computers are used for everything from monitoring elections in the Ivory Coast to running municipal governments in Romania. Less than 3 percent of the world's population has ever touched a computer, Mr. Randall notes.
"Ninety-seven percent of the people on the planet would regard an outdated I.B.M. PC as a ride on a rocket ship," he said. "Melting the thing down is not its highest and best use. None of these machines should die. In the right hands, they are mind-enhancing tools."

HEADLINE: Huge Stimulus Package Is Announced by Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, April 14

 BODY:
Japan announced on Tuesday a $116 billion stimulus plan, the biggest in its history, to rescue its faltering economy. The announcement gave a furious boost to the recent rally in the Tokyo stock market as a feeling spread here that an end to the nation's persistent recession, while not around the corner, is at least in view.
The stimulus package, consisting of increases in public works spending and various business incentives, had long been expected, but its size, 13.2 trillion yen, was higher than the 12 trillion yen figure that had been anticipated lately. 
 That helped the stock market's Nikkei index of 225 stocks convincingly smash through the 20,000 level by soaring 858.15 points, or 4.3 percent, to close at 20,740.29 Tuesday -- its highest close in more than a year. At its close today, the market was down 206.91 points, or 1 percent, to 20,533.38.
 
 
Goal for G.N.P.
 Japanese Government officials said the stimulus program would add about 2.6 percent to Japan's nominal gross national product in the year after its enactment, virtually assuring that Japan would meet its 3.3 percent growth goal for inflation-adjusted G.N.P. for the fiscal year that began April 1.
"It's a big, very potent package," said Robert Alan Feldman, director of economic research for Salomon Brothers in Asia. "Its enough to bring fiscal 1993 growth above 3 percent."
But other economists said that company profits and capital spending remained depressed and might not be helped much by the plan. Noboru Kawai, chief economist for Morgan Stanley in Japan, said the increased spending might allow companies to work off their swollen inventories but might not lead to increased production. Others noted that consumer spending is weak and that the Government rejected the idea of an income tax cut, partly because it feared a budget deficit.
 
 
True Stimulus
 Economists estimated that only 5 trillion yen to 9 trillion yen of the 13.2 trillion yen total represented a true stimulus, which in Japan is being called "ma mizu," or pure water.
Some of the money goes for things like purchases of land, which merely transfers an asset from one party to another. In other cases, like in Government-backed housing loans, the Government might merely displace private lending, resulting in no net gain to the economy.
Other economists said that company profits and capital spending remain depressed and might not be helped much by the plan. Noboru Kawai, chief economist for Morgan Stanley in Japan, said the increased spending might allow companies to work off their swollen inventories but might not lead to increased production. Others noted that consumer spending is weak and the Japanese Govermment rejected the idea of an income tax cutpartly because it feared a budget deficit.
Some private-sector economists estimate the package might increase growth by only about 1 percent or so. Moreover, they said, the plan alone would not lead to a full recovery.
"I do think they will be successful in fending off the great depression that was possible in Japan," said Jesper Koll, economist at S. G. Warburg in Tokyo. But he estimated that even with the package, Japan's economy would grow only 1.5 percent in the fiscal year that began this month.
 
 
U.S. Pressure
 Nor is this plan likely to fully satisfy the United States, which wants Japan to stimulate its economy so that its purchases of American products will increase. The stimulus package is perhaps the main plan to reduce Japan's trade surplus that Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa will bring with him Friday when he is scheduled to meet with President Clinton.
But the Clinton Administration has been known to have made known its views to Japan that parts of the previous stimulatory plan were more cosmetic than real. Those same features are in the new plan, making it likely that the new plan, too, will come in for criticism. The United States Government has expressed its belief that Japan, which has a budget surplus, should be willing to use deficit financing to spur its economy.
Moreover, Japan's Government rejected the idea, favored by some American businesses, of setting aside a specific amount of purchases under the stimulus plan for imports, saying only that "due consideration will be given to foreign products."
A senior Administration official said that Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who arrived here Tuesday to attend a Group of Seven ministerial meeting on aid to Russia, told Japan's Foreign Minister, Kabun Muto, that the stimulus package was "a useful first step," but that "Japan needs several years of economic growth for the world economic system to be fully revitalized."
And Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who was also attending the meeting here, said today: "You have to look beyond the headlines and get into some of the detail. What we want to see on the part of Japan is a continuing stimulus to increase demand within the country."
 
U.S. Program
 The Administration has been pushing for a somewhat similar, although much smaller, economic stimulus program for the United States. The $19.5 billion plan is frozen in the Senate by a Republican filibuster.
The Japanese plan will be paid for through construction bonds and through a Government program that draws on consumer savings through the postal system. The United States has complained that this latter source of financing merely diverts money to the public sector that would have otherwise been invested by the private sector and is therefore not a true stimulus.
Last August, Japan announced a stimulus plan worth 10.7 trillion yen, or about $94 billion. That plan does not seem to have had much effect yet. But officials and economists say that because of delays in passage of the necessary legislation, the spending it called for is only now beginning.

HEADLINE: U.N. Appeals for More Funds To Relieve Hunger in Bosnia

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 13

 BODY:
The United Nations issued an emergency appeal for more food for Bosnia and Herzegovina today as five Security Council members raised the flag of revolt against the attempt by the United States and Russia to delay new sanctions against Serbia.
In Geneva, Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, wrote to aid-giving governments expressing "deep alarm" at the shortage of food for the 2.8 million people now dependent on United Nations rations in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
 She told these governments that there had been "no response" to her appeal last month for $817 million to cover relief needs for the rest of the year in the former Yugoslavia.
 
Less Than Half of Needed Food
 Mrs. Ogata, who coordinates the relief efforts there, said she currently had less than half of the food needed for Bosnia and Herzegovina between now and June. As a result she is diverting funds from health, sanitation and shelter programs to meet the more pressing needs of the hungry.
While Mrs. Ogata sought to keep the United Nations relief program alive in Bosnia, five members of the Security Council began planning a revolt they promised on Monday when they strongly attacked the Clinton Administration and Russia for seeking to delay new sanctions against Serbia to help President Boris N. Yeltsin's chances in the April 25 referendum on who rules Russia.
The five are Venezuela, Cape Verde and three Muslim countries -- Pakistan, Morocco and Djibouti.
They are trying to win enough support on the 15-member Council to gain a 9-vote majority. That would enable them to win procedural motions forcing an immediate vote on a new sanctions resolution that has been accepted in principle by all Council members except Russia.
President Yeltsin would then face a difficult choice between angering Russian nationalists at home on the referendum's eve by voting to punish the Serbs, their fellow Orthodox Christians, or coming out publicly in Serbia's defense just after the brutal shelling of Srebrenica and Sarajevo on Monday by vetoing the new sanctions.
 
Shelling Angers Washington
 The shelling of Srebrenica has particularly angered the Clinton Administration, diplomats here say, because Washington thought Moscow had promised to persuade the Serbs not to attack the beleaguered Muslim town as part of an agreement last weekend on delaying the sanctions vote until after the referendum.
Britain, France and Spain, the three European Community members on the Council, have gone along with the Russia and the United States, though only reluctantly.
"We have to do something now," Venezuela's United Nations representative, Diego Arria, said today. "What guarantee do we have Russia and America won't say they want a further delay after the referendum to let Yeltsin consolidate his position?"
Diplomats say the United States and Russia plan to appeal to Serbia later this week to use its influence with Bosnian Serbs to persuade them to sign the peace plan prepared by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, the mediators, and already accepted by the leaders of Bosnia's Croats and Muslims.
But the omens are scarcely encouraging. After visiting President Milosevic of Bosnia last week, Deputy Foreign Minister Vitaly I. Churkin of Russia said he was bringing back new proposals that would make the Vance-Owen plan more acceptable to the Bosnian Serbs. But on Monday Mr. Vance and Lord Owen told the Council that the Russian changes were based on longstanding Serbian territorial demands unacceptable to the other ethnic factions.
Diplomats say Mr. Vance and Lord Owen believe that the only hope of shifting the Serbian position lies in rapidly applying new sanctions, especially those banning shipment of goods through Yugoslavia and the freezing of foreign Yugoslav assets.


GRAPHIC: The NATO force policing the United Nations ban on flights over BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA reported no violators during its first day of operations as about 30 warplanes flew sorties over the former Yugoslav republic, said a spokesman at the operation's command center at VICENZA, ITALY.

In GENEVA, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees appealed to Western governments to donate food for Bosnia, saying current supplies will run out within days for millions of people.
About 650 people arrived in TUZLA aboard United Nations trucks after fleeing SREBRENICA, where Serbian shelling killed more than 50 people on Monday. "Those firing the guns at Srebrenica knew that the town was packed with many thousands of displaced people, mainly women and children," one senior official said.
In PARIS, the French Defense Minister confirmed that Lieut. Gen. Philippe Morillon would soon be replaced as the commander of United Nations forces in Bosnia.
And in WASHINGTON, the United States released its seventh report on war crimes in the former Yugoslavia, again cataloguing a horrifying series of mass murders, rapes and torture mostly attributed to Bosnian Serbs.

HEADLINE: Educators Find a Lot to Like in a Little Increase

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Even though President Clinton has proposed increasing Education Department spending by less than 2 percent for the next fiscal year, his new budget is winning praise from education groups because of its emphasis on those at either end of the public-school ladder: preschool children and high school students who need job training.
The $31 billion Education Department budget for the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1 is up $511 million from this year's $30.5 billion. But it does not tell the whole story. The department's programs would be supplemented by others in the Departments of Commerce and Health and Human Services, in a spirit of cooperation between Federal agencies that analysts and educators say is rare. 
 The Commerce Department's proposed budget, for example, includes $64 million for technological improvements like satellite dishes, wiring for computers and television montoring systems to help schools in isolated areas receive lessons from other schools.
Head Start, the Health and Human Services preschool program for poor 3- and 4-year-olds, would grow by about 46 percent, to $4.1 billion in 1994 from $2.8 billion this year. Head Start has been criticized as ineffective, but it still has a large number of supporters, and the Clinton Administration seems to be backing them.
 
Job Training Gets Push
 The Education and Labor Departments would spend $270 million to develop better job training for students not bound for college. And today and Wednesday, officials of the Education and Labor Departments are meeting with representatives of private industry to devise job programs for young people this summer.
"This is a budget in which there's a very close link among these agencies," said Gordon Ambach, executive director of the Council of Chief State School Officers, an association of state education commissioners and superintendents. "It's the first time in at least 12 years that there has been a very close fit in this kind of way."
The budget also calls for money for the President's campaign, whose details are still to be announced, to develop academic standards and promote structural changes in schools. In addition, Chapter 1, the Federal program to help poor children reach grade level in reading, math and writing, would receive $7.1 billion in 1994, up from $6.7 billion.
"The Bush Administration first put emphasis on early childhood and job-training programs," said William H. Kohlberg, president of the National Alliance of Business, an organization of 3,500 companies concerned about work-force quality. "But the Clinton folks are improving and increasing that emphasis."
Diane Ravitch, a former Assistant Education Secretary in the Bush Administration, said, "It's not as if people didn't care about programs like job training, but attention from the President helps."
Under the proposed 1994 education budget, financing for elementary and secondary programs would increase to nearly $15 billion from $13.6 billion in the 1993 fiscal year, with nearly half of the proposed increase going to the efforts to help poor children under Chapter 1.
Although the program has been lauded for helping a generation of students, in recent months it has been criticized as ineffective; reports by an independent commission and a Congressionally mandated committee both said it needed more money and better teachers.
As part of the Clinton economic stimulus package, now stymied by a Senate filibuster, Chapter 1 would receive $735 million more this fiscal year, $500 million of which would go to summer programs and $235 million to help school districts adjust to a recalculation in the program's financing formula.
Although the specifics of Mr. Clinton's program for structural change are not yet final, the budget proposes spending $420 million to help establish standards on what students should know and when. Some money would also be awarded to school systems to encourage bureaucratic and curriculum changes.
College education financing would decline to $12.6 billion in 1994, from $13.6 billion. But the popular Pell grant program for low-income college students would receive $6.3 billion, up from $6.08 billion.

HEADLINE: Storm Losses At $1.5 Billion

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: OLDWICK, N.J., April 13

 BODY:
The A. M. Best Company said today that the March storm caused insurance companies $1.5 billion in losses in 24 states and the District of Columbia.
The sum is nearly twice the rating agency's initial estimate of $800 million, released last month. It was based on comparison with storms in November and December. 
 Catastrophes have pushed insurance industry losses in 1993 to $2.2 billion, Best officials said. Among the costliest was the World Trade Center bombing, which is estimated to have cost $510 million in damage. Storms in Texas and Kansas last month caused $125 million and $35 million in damage respectively.
"The industry was hoping to return to more normal levels of catastrophes in 1993, but through March, it has yet to happen," said John Snyder, the senior vice president of Best's property-casualty division. "We currently are on track for another costly year, and we have yet to get through the deadly August-through-October months."
Catastrophes and a low interest rate environment resulted in a 2 percent decline last year in the industry's pretax investment income, its first ever, Mr. Synder said. He added that the industry is more vulnerable to catastrophes because of a rate war and the lack of affordable catastrophe reinsurance.
