HEADLINE: Abortion-Rights' Scorned Prophet;
Hated by Both Sides, Bill Baird Raises Hackles, Not Funds

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.

 BODY:
Mention his name on the phone and Betty Friedan's gravelly voice turns into liquid vitriol. Then she hangs up.
Robin Morgan, the feminist author and editor, who is usually attracted to publicity like an iron filing to a magnet, calls him a "chauvinist" and declines interviews if he's the subject. 
 In the peculiar jargon of condemnation, Roman Catholic Church leaders say they pray for his soul. And their lay allies in the anti-abortion movement , who pummel him with fists and Bibles, teach their children that the former choirboy is nothing less than the Devil incarnate.
So who is Bill Baird? And what has he done to become just about the only person who can get both sides of the abortion battle to set aside their symbiotic hatreds and unite in a common cause, even if it's only their mutual antipathy to him?
The vilification of Mr. Baird, whose unapologetic zealotry leads him to criticize even his ideologic allies, provides a glimpse into the passions that have laid waste to the middle ground in the fight over abortion. But Mr. Baird's struggle also is a story of atonement and how he turned his cause into his life, sacrificing even his family on the altar of his beliefs.
"If I were assassinated, I know what the movement would do: They'd say, 'He was a great warrior, a great fighter. He withstood the test of time,' " laments Mr. Baird, whose clinic here was one of the first in the country to openly offer abortion counseling. "But now, while I'm still alive, they won't take my hand or even let me stand by them."
 
The Father of Abortion Rights
 In the eyes of impartial observers, but especially in his own view, Mr. Baird is the father of the abortion rights movement. It wasn't planned. He came to his mission in 1963 when he was at Harlem Hospital and found a woman screaming in the hall, with a coat hanger protruding from her uterus.
"She died in my arms," Mr. Baird recalls. He's told the story thousands, if not tens of thousands, of times and it's almost rote. But it was his epiphany, and tears still well up at the memory.
One of six children in a strict Lutheran family, he grew up devout, but a bully, in Brooklyn's slums. When he earned cookies in school for his posture, he brought them home to his younger sister, Myra. And he willingly, even eagerly, fought to protect his older sister, Louise, who died from a cerebral hemorrhage when he was 9.
After his sister's death, his trust and faith in God was tempered by doubt. Almost 50 years later, when a child suggested praying for Mr. Baird's severely ill grandson, he snapped that only doctors could help.
 
Insult to Injury
 "I told them if there was a God, what kind of God would give a little kid cancer?" he remembers. "An audience member got up and said, 'I know why your grandson got cancer. God's punishing you.'
"It went through me like a knife. Believe it or not, I wake up in the night and think, 'Could I be wrong and everyone else right? Could I be the Devil?' Then psychic perseverance kicks in and I realize it was just an aberration in cell growths. It may sound corny, but sometimes you feel like death is on your shoulder."
Mr. Baird dropped out of New York Medical College in 1963 when he was forced to choose between books and food for his three children. But the Harlem woman's death made him a guerrilla doctor. He bought a dilapidated truck, converted it into a mobile counseling center, the Plan Van, and in his free time began distributing birth control information in New York City's poorest neighborhoods.
That led to a 1965 arrest on charges of violating state laws restricting the dissemination of such information. Ultimately, the charges were dropped. But while the case was instrumental in relaxing New York's restrictive birth control laws, it also led to his dismissal from his job as the clinical director of a pharmaceutical company. The only work he could find was as a security guard in a mental hospital, for $2 an hour.
His setbacks only made him more obstinate. During a 1967 speech at Boston University, he was arrested on charges of giving a female student a condom and a package of contraceptive foam -- a calculated challenge to Massachusetts' "chastity" statute, which barred distribution of such materials to unmarried people.
Planned Parenthood, in the first of several confrontations that Mr. Baird has never forgiven, publicly derided him as an "embarrassment" and said there was "nothing to be gained" by his case. He was convicted and the judge, accusing him of being a "menace to the nation," sentenced him as a felon to three months in jail. He served 36 days until his release pending appeal.
The case was appealed to the Supreme Court of the United States, which initially declined to hear it but succumbed to the persistence of Justice William O. Douglas. "The teachings of Baird and Galileo may be of a different order, but the suppression of either is equally repugnant," Justice Douglas later wrote in his book, "The Douglas Papers."
The Court's decision, handed down in 1972, extended access to contraception to everyone. "If the right of privacy means anything," Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote, "it is the right of the individual, married or single, to be free from unwarranted government intrusion into matters so fundamentally affecting a person as the decision whether to bear or beget a child."
It was more than just a triumph for Mr. Baird. Justice Brennan's phrase "bear or beget" was a precursor to decisions dealing directly with abortion. The following year, in Roe v. Wade, the landmark ruling that made abortion legal, the majority opinion cited the Baird precedent five times.
 
Shot at, Punched, Pummeled
 The tide in favor of abortion rights ebbed in the 1989 decision, Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, that essentially allowed states to impose restrictions on abortion.
Mr. Baird says the ruling, which galvanized supporters of abortion rights, also led to what amounts to his excommunication from the movement. "It organized women," he says. "They circled the wagons." But most men, he contends, were excluded.
After 30 years on the ramparts, the 60-year-old crusader, who describes himself as "the sexually incorrect Joan of Arc," is clearly exhausted, physically and financially spent. He says he lives on $350 a week and has no insurance. His back constantly hurts. He has trouble carrying his suitcase. "I don't know what I'm going to do when my body breaks down," he says.
 
Burned to the Ground
 He has been shot at in his home, punched and pummeled. In 1979, an unemployed drifter carrying a jug of gasoline and a flaming torch walked into his clinic, which was crowded with 35 patients and 15 staff members, and burned it to the ground.
He opened another clinic in a a poor neighborhood here. Last September, chemicals were poured down the elevator shaft, sending noxious fumes through the building and making several people ill. Two months ago, a fire hose was turned on, flooding several floors. The ceiling outside his office still sags.
Where he once rattled on about his plans, Mr. Baird now interrupts himself with reflections, like a man pondering his funeral pyre and his place in history. "I think I've contributed something of significance to the freedom of millions of women," he says. "But now society says it doesn't want to know me."
Above all, he seems to pine for respect, or at least acceptance from groups that advocate women's causes and reproductive rights. "I hope that Gloria Steinem would say, 'He's suffered enough, let's welcome our brother,' " he pleads. But like a rebellious teenager, he can't resist damning himself in the next phrase, saying that Gloria Steinem would even not give him credit for enabling her to use birth control.
Among the attacks on the people whose support he desperately craves, there is a verbal stiletto for Faye Wattleton, the former president of Planned Parenthood.
"It's obscene for anyone to be paid $200,000 a year and to be called a crusader," he says. "Look at what I've done with nothing. Imagine what I could have done with Planned Parenthood's budget. The women's groups think that righteousness is measured by money, by bloated bank accounts. But I measure it by commitment, by dedication, by success."
In her book, "Going Too Far," Ms. Morgan suggested Mr. Baird's mission was an effort to get women to sleep with him, and called him "one of the more male-supremacist men around."
 
Steinem Won't Shake Hand
 Ms. Steinem, like many of her colleagues, has refused to shake his hand. Ms. Friedan, who has suggested he is a Central Intelligence Agency plant, stammered in a 20-second telephone interview that she wouldn't talk about him, called him "irrelevant," and, when questioned, hung up.
Mr. Baird has been estranged from his wife, Evelyn, and their five children since he moved them out of state after receiving death threats in 1971. "They became quite conservative, very religious," he says. "They talk to me about Jesus Christ and tell me he is my savior. I tell them I don't know any saviors. I've lost my children: they talk to me, but they don't want to hear about their father and his wars."
"My life is sad," he says. "I wish I could tell you it's happy."
The story of his life, he says, is that of Don Quixote, with one difference -- in his version, Mr. Baird wins. Nonetheless, he says he wants "The Quest" ("The Impossible Dream") played at his funeral.

HEADLINE: Clinton Finds a Friendlier Chamber of Commerce

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Grabbing for a piece of the Republican coalition, President Clinton went to the United States Chamber of Commerce tonight, stoking a feud between the powerful business group and conservatives in Congress.
The chamber has infuriated many conservatives who contend that the organization has committed ideological treason by cozying up to the new Administration, particularly in informally supporting elements of its economic program. 
 The hostilities have surfaced in letters between the chamber and House Republicans, and a few dozen companies have threatened to resign from the chamber in protest of its position.
Against that backdrop, Mr. Clinton's participation in a satellite television question-and-answer session at the chamber's headquarters tonight to promote his summer jobs program has stuck in the craw of conservative House Republicans, like John A. Boehner of Ohio.
"The fact that the 'kickoff' for the $1 billion summer make-work program the Administration calls its 'summer challenge' is being hosted by the Chamber of Commerce at its Washington headquarters speaks volumes about how far the chamber will go to appease the new occupants of the White House," Mr. Boehner said.
From the chamber's standpoint, there is more to be gained by good relations with the White House than by partisan loyalty.
"There are a handful of Republicans in the House who got exercised because we didn't trash the Clinton economic program," said Richard L. Lesher, the chamber's president. Asked about Mr. Boehner's comments, he replied: "I would tell him to get real and try to understand that our members care about progress. They don't care about perpetuating partisan gridlock."
The budding relationship between Mr. Clinton and the chamber could not be better demonstrated than by tonight's event, which was sponsored by the chamber and the Education Department and was broadcast to audiences at nearly 3,000 sites around the country.
 
Chamber Cites Ties
 The President sat at a table flanked by Education Secretary Richard W. Riley and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich. He answered rather tame questions posed by Mr. Riley and by a caller from New York and one from Texas, both of whom praised the Administration for its education proposals.
And Mr. Clinton had only kind things to say about the chamber. "I want to compliment the chamber on all their efforts at recognizing that without an educated work force, we can grow this economy and remain competitive," he said, "and recognizing that we all have to work together -- business and government, labor and educators -- to make things happen. This satellite town meeting is a good example of that kind of working together."
The chamber held similar events during the previous Administration, but President George Bush never personally went to the chamber to participate. In addition to Mr. Clinton's economic package, the chamber is deeply interested in pushing its positions on the President's plans for education and jobs and health care.
Mr. Lesher said in an interview today that relations with the Clinton White House were at least as strong as those under Republican Administrations.
"The relationship we've built with those folks is quite good," he said. "We didn't agree with Bush on a lot of things, and we don't agree with Clinton on a lot of things. In fact, I don't agree with my wife on many things. But you have to have a decent working relationship to get things done."
Chamber officials make no apologies for courting the White House, and Mr. Clinton has been particularly active in seeking the support of the organization as he seeks to prove that his deficit-reduction proposal and plan to stimulate the economy has appeal to the business community. Mr. Clinton was greeted with warm applause when he made an hourlong appeal at the chamber's annual meeting here in February.
 
Steps to Back President
 The group never officially endorsed the economic plan but has taken other steps to back Mr. Clinton. Last month, the chamber reversed its position and said that all businesses should be required to provide health insurance for their workers.
"I think we've had a real productive relationship with the Chamber of Commerce so far this year," said George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director. "I mean, I think most members of the chamber know that it's time to do something serious about getting the deficit down, and know that we have to get the economy moving."
But conservatives said they felt betrayed by the chamber, and some demanded that members lead a dues strike and demand the ouster of the chamber's top officials. They said tonight's event was the latest example of the chamber's playing up to whomever is in the White House.
Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader; Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, and other Republicans warned in a recent letter to the chamber: "In the interest once again of serving as an alarm bell ringing in the night, we wanted to alert you to a rapidly spreading frustration and anger with the chamber's failure to take an aggressive posture on the Clinton economic program." The letter went on to say that "your current posture is unacceptable."
 
Counter-Campaign by Chamber
 As conservatives mobilize to oppose the chambers' overtures to the Administration, the chamber is also waging a counter campaign to win public support for its position. The chamber is sending packages of letters to news organizations from member chapters that laud its efforts.
Gerald L. Bartels, president of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, wrote to Mr. Lesher: "I wanted to let you know that I think the strategy of trying to work with the Clinton Administration is a good one, even though we probably have fundamental differences with them on almost every score. It's not that we should cave in to their ideas, but rather try to keep a seat at the table, so that we can get the most satisfactory legislation possible for our members."
In another letter to the chamber, Alisa Learner Maher, director of issue analysis for the Chrysler Corporation here, wrote, "You should be proud of the fact that the chamber has tried to take positions which are less ideological and far more pragmatic than other business organizations in town."

HEADLINE: Bond-Accounting Shift Is Approved

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The Financial Accounting Standards Board, on a 5-to-2 vote, approved a new financial standard yesterday that will force banks and other financial institutions to report profits or losses when the market value of many bonds in their portfolios changes.
The board also moved toward issuing another standard, one that would require banks to take losses when they renegotiate loans with troubled borrowers. It is hoped that final action on both rules will be completed by June 30, when the terms of two board members expire. 
 The bond accounting standard was approved when James Leisenring, the board's vice chairman, reversed his position and voted yes. "I really just decided that while it was not my first choice, it was better than the alternative of doing nothing," he said in an interview after the vote. "We had a responsibility of doing something."
Under a two-year-old rule, the F.A.S.B. can issue rules only if at least five of the seven members approve. Thus, the proposal would have died had not Mr. Leisenring changed his vote.
Under the proposal, banks and other financial institutions that own debt securities would have to declare whether they intend to hold a given security until maturity. Unless they do so, they would have to report profits and losses when the market value of the bonds rises or falls.
While there are still formalities, requiring the board to generate a final draft signed by each of the five supporters, yesterday's vote probably ends a long battle on the issue. Some of the board members, including Mr. Leisenring, had hoped for a broader standard, one that would have allowed companies to adjust for the market value of their liabilities as well. But that was dropped when it became clear that it could not win five votes.
Under current accounting, some financial institutions have classified their bonds as investments, thus allowing them to not record changes in market value on their income statements. But some regularly sell such bonds when prices rise, producing reported profits. The new rule is supposed to make that more difficult to do.
 
Opposition to Measure
 The measure was opposed by banking organizations, which expressed disappointment yesterday. "The capital volatility that will occur when interest rates move is the worst thing our bankers will be experiencing," said Marti Sworobuk, a spokeswoman for the Savings and Community Bankers of America.
The board's action won praise from Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the House Telecommunications and Finance Subcommittee, who called it a welcome step to remove bank financial statements "from the world of fantasy."
The proposed loan rule relates to "impaired loans," that is loans on which the borrower is expected to be unable to meet the original terms. Under current rules, many banks do not report losses if they expect to receive all the principal back, even if the interest payments are to be reduced or eliminated.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New Basis For a Rally In Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
With concerns about inflation dampened by restrained price increases in March, a new theme is popping up in the bond market. And if it catches hold, yields on the 30-year bond and other Treasury securities could break the historic lows reached at the beginning of March.
"The next story is going to be that the economy is running out of gas," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers. "There is that body of thought out there and you can't ignore it." 
 Many forecasters agree that the economy is growing at a slower pace than the nearly 5 percent clip at the end of last year. But they are talking about sustained moderate growth, like 3 percent annual growth after adjustment for inflation.
The "out of gas" predictions are for a much sharper deceleration in the rate of growth, perhaps to 2 percent. And some forecasters even think that the economy's pace will slow so much that the Federal Reserve will again have to lower short-term interest rates to prevent the economy's tank from getting close to empty.
 
The Power of a Theme
 Themes can catch on in markets and carry them for some time -- and then turn out to be wrong. When themes grab attention, economic and other data are often interpreted accordingly, causing the market to overreact. The concern about inflation moving higher was the theme that knocked the market off its highs and sent yields up in March.
The surprising 1 percent decline in March retail sales, reported yesterday, played right into the pronouncements of economists who have contended that inflation is an overrated concern because the economy is growing much more slowly than in the consensus outlook.
The fact that February sales, excluding automobiles, were revised downward to an increase of one-tenth of a percentage point, from the original nine-tenths of a point, also supported the new theme that the economy is more sluggish than believed.
The retail sales decline helped push the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.74 percent early in the day, just above the 16-year low of 6.72 percent reached on March 8. But the Treasury auction of seven-year notes, which were sold at an average yield of 5.54 percent, did not go well, leading to a decline in prices in the early afternoon. Enough buyers returned later, however, and the price of the 30-year bond ended up 4/32 with the yield down to 6.78 percent, from 6.79 percent Monday.
 
Rates Down on Bills
 In addition, the discount rate on the three-month Treasury bill was pushed down to 2.83 percent and the rate on the six-month bill to 2.96 percent, showing that there are some investors and traders who are betting that the Federal Reserve will again have to ease short-term interest rates. Both discount rates are below the Fed's 3 percent target for the overnight Federal funds rate.
Stephen Slifer, a financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, is saying that the gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation, grew at an annual rate of 2 percent to 2.5 percent in the first quarter of this year and that the same pace will hold during the next three months. For the second half of the year, he is looking at 3 percent growth because he expects the low level of long-term interest rates to give a boost to the economy by encouraging investment and lowering the debt burden on both consumers and businesses.
"I am slower than the consensus," he said. While he does not feel that the economy is growing slowly enough for the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates, he said the rate decline on short-term Treasury bills shows that there are many others who do. He argued that for the Fed to ease, the economy would have to grow at a rate of less than 2 percent this quarter and next. The retail sales report is making him re-examine his forecast, but he is not sure if he is ready to knock it below 2 percent.
He is concerned, however, that the recent decline in the nation's money supply may mean that his forecast is too strong. Since the fourth quarter of last year, the money supply as measured by M-2, which includes currency in circulation, checking and savings accounts and certificates of deposit, is declining by close to a 2 percent annual rate.
The decline in the money supply may be making others pay some attention to the slow-growth theme. While not all forecasters put as much stock in the ups and downs of the money supply, they acknowledge that the data cannot be ignored.
Mr. Lipsky argues that the "out of gas" forecasts are wrong. "Just as the 'Sky is falling, inflation is here' turned out to be a short-lived phenomenon, the 'run out of gas' phenomenon will also pass," he said.
But he is quick to add that the decline in the money supply and the flattening of credit data are disturbing. "If the money and credit growth does not pick up, we will be in trouble," he said.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of seven-year notes:

HEADLINE: A '72 Report on P.O.W.'s Is a Fake, Vietnam Asserts

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 13

 BODY:
Vietnam's senior diplomat dealing with United States affairs today described as a "clear fabrication" a document suggesting that 1,205 American prisoners of war were in North Vietnamese prisons in 1972, more than double the number eventually released.
The diplomat, Nguyen Xuan Phong, acting director of the Americas Department at the Foreign Ministry, said in a telephone interview from Hanoi that "we have very strong evidence" to prove "this document is not authentic -- a clear fabrication." 
 The document, recently discovered in the archives of the Soviet Communist Party in Moscow, has alarmed former officials in Washington and scholars of the Vietnam War, who say it may prove that hundreds of prisoners were never released, and are now almost certainly dead.
 
Tracing the General
 The document is a Russian translation of what is described as a September 1972 report prepared for the Vietnam Politburo by Gen. Tran Van Quang, who is identified as the deputy chief of staff of the North Vietnamese Army. It describes Hanoi's efforts to keep secret the number of American prisoners.
The report says that in 1972, even as Vietnam was claiming that it held only 368 American prisoners, there were 1,205 Americans in North Vietnamese prisons.
Mr. Phong said the easiest way to prove that the document was a fabrication was to review General Quang's career. In 1972, he said, General Quang was not deputy chief of staff; he was the Army commander in Military Region 4, in central Vietnam, a post he held from 1966 to 1974.
"Gen. Tran Van Quang had nothing to do with the general staff of the Vietnamese People's Army," Mr. Phong said. "There would be no reason for Gen. Tran Van Quang to have prepared this sort of report."
A member of Mr. Phong's staff, Nguyen Ba Hung, said General Quang had never held been deputy chief of staff of the Army. "That's why it sounded very funny when we heard this report," he said. "Those who have knowledge about the war and about the Army would have a better understanding."
 
Diplomatically Awkward
 General Quang, now retired, is the director of an organization of Vietnamese veterans. Foreign Ministry officials said that, while they had not spoken to General Quang about the document, his staff had said the document was a forgery.
The document's release comes at a delicate time: Vietnamese officials are preparing for meetings in Hanoi next week with John W. Vessey Jr., a retired Army general who has been dispatched by President Clinton to discuss the issue of missing servicemen.
When the general's visit was announced this month, the Vietnamese took it as a sign that President Clinton might be prepared to move quickly to relax the 18-year-old United States embargo on trade and loans to Vietnam. Vietnam, one of the world's poorest nations, has abandoned Marxist economics and is eager for foreign investment -- specifically American -- in its newly free markets.
But Hanoi's optimism about the outcome of next week's meetings appears to have faded with the release of the document from the Soviet archives.
 
An Agenda Changes
 Now, it appears, General Vessey's trip will focus largely on the authenticity of the document, and thus on the possibility that hundreds of prisoners were alive at the end of the war but were never freed.
The State Department said Monday that General Vessey, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who has served since 1987 as a Presidential envoy on the issue of missing Americans, will make the document his "first order of business" in Hanoi.
"Obviously this document is not favorable for the course of relations between the two countries," Mr. Phong said. "It will raise suspicions from the American people. But I don't think the document is able to reverse the belief that Vietnam has cooperated very well in this humanitarian issue over the fate of the missing Americans."
Under the 1973 peace settlement between the United States and North Vietnam, 591 American prisoners of war were released from North Vietnam. When the last were freed, in April 1973, Hanoi said no more prisoners were left -- an assertion it has maintained ever since.
Mr. Phong said he was optimistic that United States officials would see the document as a fabrication, and that it should not delay efforts to normalize diplomatic and trade relations.
"I have worked with United States Government representatives for seven years," he said. "I believe that they are careful to distinguish the truth from the fabrications. I hope the American people can distinguish that, too."

HEADLINE: Radio Receivers May Be Catching Echo of Big Bang, Scientist Says

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
A leading astrophysicist reported today that radio receivers in space and on the ground might be recording the passage of cosmic gravity waves, huge perturbations of space that echo the almost instantaneous expansion of the infant universe 15 billion years ago.
The scientist, Dr. George F. Smoot of the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in California, said gravity waves initiated by the "inflationary epoch" of the universe -- a split-second period during which many theorists believe the universe expanded at nearly the speed of light -- might be discernible in data now being collected. If that is correct, scientists would have a powerful new tool for studying the birth of the universe. He reported his findings in a lecture at the Carnegie Institution of Washington. 
 One year ago Dr. Smoot caused a sensation among astrophysicists with his announcement that the haze of microwave radiation reaching the earth from space is somewhat irregular in intensity, depending on the direction from which it comes. Since this microwave radiation is believed to be the afterglow of the Big Bang that is generally thought to have created the universe, irregularities in its intensity apparently reflect the somewhat lumpy distribution of matter in the very early universe.
 
Density and Gravity Waves
 Many astrophysicists now believe this early lumpiness accounts for the later formation of clusters of galaxies and other regions of concentrated matter observed in the present universe.
But Dr. Smoot and a collaborator, Dr. Paul J. Steinhardt of the University of Pennsylvania, now believe that irregularities in the microwave radio background may be only partly the result of irregularities in the density of matter in the early universe.
Another cause, as Dr. Smoot said today, may be gravity waves still reaching the Earth from the inflationary epoch of the early universe. They could account for as much as half of the microwave irregularities, he believes.
By collecting and analyzing background microwave data gathered by several independent teams using different receivers, Dr. Smoot told reporters, it may be possible to distinguish between irregularities caused by the early lumpiness of the universe and those caused by gravity waves still circulating at the speed of light.
Scientists do not know precisely how the universe got its start, although most theorists believe that the genesis mechanism was related to a well-known phenomenon of particle physics, by which elementary particles of matter can spontaneously pop into existence out of nothing at all.
The only thing they need to become "real" rather than "virtual" particles is some source of energy on which to feed. Physicists have determined that in apparently empty space "virtual" particles constantly come into existence and then disappear but can become real under some circumstances.
But how and why the universe evolved from its first beginnings was a major stumbling block in the progress of cosmological theory until the early 1980's, when Dr. Alan H. Guth of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology devised his inflationary theory, various versions of which are widely accepted today. According to this theory, the universe expanded from its microscopic infancy in less than one-trillionth of a second into an object perhaps a hundred yards across. Having reached that size, the universe then expanded at a much slower rate and is still expanding today.
In 1940, Ralph Alpher, George Gamow and Robert Herman predicted that a Big Bang must have left an echo in the microwave part of the spectrum, corresponding to a temperature of about five degrees above the absolute zero on the Kelvin scale. At the time, most astronomers doubted that any such prediction could ever be verified.
 
Accidental Discovery
 But in 1964, Dr. Arno Penzias and Dr. Robert Wilson of Bell Telephone Laboratories accidentally discovered the predicted microwave background while they were investigating a mysterious source of noise that had turned up in Bell antennas. The microwave signal Dr. Penzias and Dr. Wilson discovered had an equivalent temperature of 2.7 degrees Kelvin, astonishingly close to the 1940 prediction.
Another landmark in the exploration of the microwave background came last year, with Dr. Smoot's discovery of directional variations in the temperature of the microwave background. Using data gathered by a satellite launched to measure microwave background, Dr. Smoot and his colleagues produced a map of the heavens showing irregularities that almost certainly reflected irregularities in the distribution of matter in the universe as it was only 300,000 years after the Big Bang, when the super-hot universe cooled to the point at which it became transparent to microwave radiation.
 
Starting Small
 Like the universe itself, Dr. Smoot believes, the cosmic gravity waves now circulating got their start as microscopic events, when the universe was less than one-millionth of one-millionth of a second old. A tiny gravity wave initiated by two elementary particles flying apart at nearly the speed of light would have then been amplified by the universal inflation into a giant gravity wave, something powerful enough to distort the space-time through which it travels, even today.
Such a distortion of space-time would distort any radiation passing through it, including the microwave radiation being measured by the satellite. Thus, the irregularities in the microwave background detected by the satellite may result, in part, to cosmic gravity waves, as well as to variations in the density of matter in different parts of the infant universe.
The challenge now will be to sort out the two types of irregularities.
Dr. Smoot said new data from the satellite might provide clues, as will microwave measurements being collected at two observatories at the South Pole and by two instruments to be sent aloft within a few weeks aboard balloons launched from the National Scientific Balloon Facility in Texas.
The task of separating the effects of gravity waves from the effects of density variations in the early universe will depend largely on matching the observational data with various theories, to determine which theory fits best, Dr. Smoot said.

HEADLINE: Mayor Eases Regulations On Sweeping of Gutters

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration, in a second move in two days to address complaints of small- and medium-sized business owners, said yesterday that it will suspend in some areas of the city a requirement forcing businesses to be responsible for sweeping the street within 18 inches of the curb in front of their stores.
Mayor David N. Dinkins announced the action just one day after he said that his administration would step up its efforts to reduce illegal vending by the city's estimated 10,000 unlicensed vendors, another initiative long sought by business owners. 
 In taking these actions the Mayor appears to be diligently courting the support of owners of the city's 200,000 small- and medium-sized businesses, which make up more than 95 percent of the city's business community. The Mayor, when asked if his announcements in the last few days were intended to gain support for his re-election effort, gave a response he has offered repeatedly in the last few months: "We believe that good government translates into good politics. And if that gets votes, so be it."
Many small-business owners have complained about the gutter-sweeping requirement for some time. They are subject to a $50 fine when Sanitation Department employees determine that the gutter in front of a business has too much trash.
 
A Bid for Votes?
 In easing sanitation requirements that have been in effect since 1979, Mr. Dinkins is responding to vehement criticism from operators of small businesses, who have complained about what they have viewed as excessive ticketing and additional expense of doing business in New York City.
Leah Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Dinkins campaign, said that no campaign strategy had been established to appeal specifically to business owners. "We are not targeting small- and medium-sized business owners, per se," Ms. Johnson said. "But the Mayor is very, very concerned about these businesses as part of his economic growth program."
Norman M. Adler, a campaign consultant not involved in the mayoral race, said that Mr. Dinkins's initiatives this week were consistent with the actions of incumbents seeking re-election. "When you look at past campaigns in New York you see that officials with the power to make things better tend to make things better at a faster pace during campaigns," Mr. Adler said. "The small business people have been complaining about these things like crazy. And, of course, if it is a bid for votes, it would not be surprising."
The Mayor stated in a news conference that the suspension of the 18-inch rule will apply for the moment to only 15 of the city's 59 community boards. The Mayor's Office of Operations, which conducts cleanliness ratings, has found at least 75 percent of their streets in "acceptably clean condition."
Sanitation officials explained that there were initially 18 eligible community board districts but that three had chosen not to participate, apparently believing less stringent enforcement would compromise street cleanliness. The program will go into effect on Monday and other neighborhoods can become eligible by matching the 75 percent level by July 1.
The suspension, which will be conducted on a one-year pilot basis, will result in an estimated 4,450 fewer tickets being written for the remainder of the fiscal year that ends June 30. City officials said that there would be a loss of about $250,000 for the rest of the fiscal year. For the next fiscal year, the estimated 26,000 fewer tickets will translate into a loss in revenue to the city of about $1.3 million, officials said.
Store owners in the eligible districts will still be responsible for sweeping the sidewalk areas in front of their businesses and will still be subject to summonses for violations.
While the suspension of the 18-inch rule will mean a loss of revenue to the city during a period of severe fiscal hardship, Mr. Dinkins and city officials contended that it was more important to adopt policies that would keep streets clean but add expense to operating a business.
"It's obviously a source of revenue," said Emily Lloyd, the city's Sanitation Commissioner, referring to the tickets issued business owners. "But obviously we are willing to forgo that because there is another policy goal that we think is more important."
The Mayor also announced that the city would create six sanitation advisory boards in each borough and in an industrial area that will include of city officials, neighborhood merchants and shoppers. The boards will explore methods of promoting cleanliness and curtailing the number of tickets to business owners.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Income at Westinghouse Dips 1.5% in First Quarter

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 13

 BODY:
The strengthening economy has not done much so far for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which reported today that net income from continuing operations in the first quarter of 1993 was down 1.5 percent from a year ago.
Improvements in Westinghouse's broadcasting, power-plant-construction and nuclear-fuel businesses were insufficient to offset sagging military-electronics orders and weak demand for the company's industrial repair services. 
 Westinghouse, based in Pittsburgh, said it made $64 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with a net loss a year ago of $246 million, or 71 cents a share.
But the 1992 first-quarter figures included special items -- an after-tax charge of $338 million for pension liabilities and $27 million in net income from businesses the company has since sold or put up for sale. The divisions that generated $64 million in the recent quarter earned $65 million, or 19 cents a share, a year ago.
 
Slight Movement in Price
 Westinghouse stock closed yesterday at $15.25, up 12.5 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company said revenue for the quarter had inched up to nearly $1.86 billion from just over $1.85 billion a year ago, but profits from continuing operations fell slightly to $145 million from $148 million and profit margins dipped to 7.8 percent from 8 percent.
"First-quarter results from continuing operations were as expected," said Gary M. Clark, Westinghouse's president and acting chief executive since the ouster in January of Paul Lego by a restive board of directors. "Our objective remains to have improved operating results for the full year compared to 1992, with improvement occurring in the second half of 1993."
The results were close to Wall Street estimates. Analysts noted that Westinghouse has evolved over the years into a company that derives much of its revenue from businesses like military electronics and power systems that do not closely track economic cycles. Westinghouse does not provide details on the quarterly performance of its various groups.
The report did not include any information on the performance of four businesses that the company plans to sell. It has said that it hopes to complete the sale of its electricity-distribution and -control business and its electric-supply business this year, its Knoll office furniture unit next year, and its real estate business in 1995.
In the meantime, revenue and earnings from those operations are excluded from the balance sheet and applied to a reserve fund set up last year to cover the losses of Westinghouse's financial-services businesses, which are also being sold.

HEADLINE: A Small Gain in Faculty Salaries

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
The salaries of college professors increased an average of 2.5 percent in the 1992-93 academic year, the smallest gain since the American Association of University Professors began keeping track in 1971.
The average faculty salary is $46,270 a year, ranging from $80,280 for full professors at private, independent universities with doctoral programs to $18,500 for lecturers at two-year colleges. The findings were based on an association survey whose respondents included 90 percent of the nation's college teachers. 
 Daniel S. Hameresh, an economics professor at Michigan State University who is chairman of the association's Committee on the Economic Status of the Profession, said the average college teacher who was 28 years old in 1971 has seen his or her income increase by 12 percent, while a counterpart in private industry makes 25 percent more than in 1971.
The figures also show that women who are full professors earned on average 88.2 percent of the salaries paid to men who are full professors, and those who are associate professors, 93 percent. Women who are assistant professors were paid 92.3 percent of the salaries for men at the same rank, while female instructors were paid 94.4 percent of male instructors' salaries .
Professor Hamermesh said there had been "essentially no change" in the gap between male and female salaries over the last 10 years.
The association said "real" salaries, adjusted to account for the 2.9 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index, actually lost ground by four-tenths of 1 percent over all.

HEADLINE: Compaq and Microsoft Plan Alliance

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 13

 BODY:
Two powerhouses in the personal computer industry, the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation, today announced an alliance to develop innovations intended to keep their momentum going.
The companies said they would work closely to develop small hand-held machines, easy-to-use technology like wireless communications, pen-based machines, and features for desktop models like compact-disk devices that many analysts regard as important growth areas. 
 William H. Gates, the chairman and chief executive of Microsoft, told reporters in a telephone conference that several products from the collaboration would be available within six months, but he declined to say which ones would be first.
"We are taking the boundary between systems software and hardware, which is the place where a great deal of innovation is taking place, and committing the two companies to working together," Mr. Gates said. "It's the most significant agreement we have done with a PC company in four or five years."
Several analysts said that in some ways the Microsoft-Compaq embrace was forced on them by other companies -- notably Apple Computer Inc., the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, Go Computing, and Motorola Inc. -- that appear to have taken the lead in certain areas, like pen-based computing and the emerging business of hand-held machines.
John McCarthy, who heads technology research at Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass., said that while Microsoft and Compaq have triumphed in the universe of computers powered by chips made by the Intel Corporation, future machines will be very different.
"The big winners and incumbents in the PC-space are scrambling to catch the next train before it leaves the station," Mr. McCarthy said.
Microsoft and Compaq worked closely when Compaq introduced a personal computer in 1987 based on Intel's first 386-series chip, and Microsoft created its best-selling Windows 386 software program around specifications developed by Compaq.
Mr. Gates and Eckhard Pfeiffer, the president and chief executive of Compaq, said they intended to create computing devices that were simple to use, and simple to expand or adapt to new equipment. They said that they hoped to accelerate demand for the devices by setting industry standards.
Mr. Pfeiffer said that in creating new standards, Compaq did not expect to reap huge rewards by accumulating patents or licenses that might discourage other companies from following its lead, and buying related Microsoft software products.
"It is certainly not the intent that we are going to throw rocks in each other's way," Mr. Pfeiffer said. "The goal, as Compaq has stated all along in its history, is to support an open industry standard."
Mr. Gates said it would be more efficient for Microsoft's software and marketing specialists to work with their counterparts at Compaq than for the companies to work on the same projects separately.
"Compaq has great depth in engineering," Mr. Gates said in an interview. "What we're looking for here is somebody who is close enough to the customers to know what things can be improved, what the opportunities are and the willingness to take risks with new types of product features."
Mr. Pfeiffer said that while Compaq had narrowed its product mix and introduced a new line of lower-priced machines, it eventually would have to broaden its products.
"No one has ever been able to stop the process and evolution of technology, not even I.B.M.," he said. "That is going to continue. Those who grab it and move ahead with it will determine the future in this industry. That's why we decided to join forces."
Compaq's stock slipped $1.375, to $50.875.

HEADLINE: State Urged To Rebuild L.I. Beaches

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 13

 BODY:
A task force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called today for the quick restoration at public expense of major Long Island beaches that suffered severe erosion during the winter's bruising storms.
In an interim report released today, the task force began the complicated process of setting limits on the public's responsibility for rebuilding beaches and structures that are vulnerable to routine battering by storms and the constant pounding of the wind and tide. 
 Though the Governor's Coastal Erosion Task Force will not make specific long-term policy recommendations until it releases its final report in June, the interim report provided indications of its direction: toward protecting and rebuilding beaches and structures in more densely settled areas.
For instance, the task force, which was appointed in January, said that major public beaches should be the first to receive state and Federal money.
The task force urged the Federal Army Corps of Engineers to speed up already approved projects to dredge sand from inlets and deposit it on beaches in Long Beach Island and at Robert Moses State Park.
 
Limiting State Responsibility
 But the task force suggested that the public should not be required to pay for beach protection projects on private property in sparsely settled areas, such as in parts of Fire Island. Consequently, the task force recommended that residents of Fair Harbor and Saltaire be allowed to build artificial dunes to prevent beach erosion, provided they pay for them.
The task force also recommended that 275 to 300 property owners, most on Fire Island and in Westhampton, not be allowed to rebuild severely damaged houses because they are likely to be wrecked again in future storms.
The 37-member task force's recommendations would have to be passed as legislation to become binding. But its report is significant, task force members said, because it is the beginning of an effort by the state to say that it should not be responsible for every change to its coastline.
"For a long time, people on the coast have considered themselves entitled to protection by public subsidy," said Thomas C. Jorling, the State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation and co-chairman of the task force. "This task force is starting to change that set of assumptions. We are saying that people who have built on these very dynamic areas, or want to build there in the future, are doing so at their own risk."
The interim report does not call for any major new projects. Instead, it endorses several projects that have been approved, such as a $12 million effort to close two large breaches of the barrier island at Westhampton Beach. Those breaches, which were created by a storm Dec. 11, could cause more erosion on other beaches and serious ecological damage to Moriches Bay. The work, which will be paid for by the state and Federal governments, is expected to begin in the coming weeks.
Citing the need to prepare for the summer vacation and hurricane seasons, the task force also urged the Army Corps of Engineers to speed up several beach restoration projects that have already been approved.
The Corps of Engineers has about $67.5 million in projects along Long Island's South Shore that are under way or about to begin. New York State pays 20 to 40 percent of the cost of those projects.
The Corps could not be reached for comment on whether it could accelerate the timetable for its Long Island projects. But the agency was represented on the task force, and several state officials said they expected the Corps to accept the recommendations.
The task force also endorsed a dredging project that began yesterday near Shinnecock Inlet to help prevent frequent flooding that blocks the road connecting a fisherman's cooperative to the mainland.
But the task force said that dredging is just a short-term solution, and that a permanent solution was necessary. That solution could include raising the road or moving the cooperative, task force members said.
Such specific long-term recommendations will be made in the final report. That report will include cost estimates for projects and recommendations on who should pay. It will also include recommendations for restoring and protecting the shorelines of New York City and Westchester.
The final report is expected to estabish a blueprint for the types of beach-erosion projects that New York State will recommend for Federal money. Task force members said they had sought to balance competing concerns over the environment and the economy. They noted that the barrier islands provide not only pristine beaches but also breeding grounds for wildlife and protection for the mainland.
"You can't do nothing because there is just too much at stake," said Kenneth Robinson, a task force member and an environmental lawyer on Long Island. "At the same time, you don't want to waste money."
Gail F. Shaffer, the Secretary of State and co-chairwoman of the task force, said: "The whole concept is to look at coastal erosion areas in a common sense way and say we aren't going to be able to contravene Mother Nature in everything that occurs. We have to make strategic decisions."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
An auction at a fallen agency is a reminder of the industry's modern perils

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
GEER, DUBOIS died in February, but the funeral, such as it is, is being held this morning. The agency's office in the Flatiron neighborhood of lower Manhattan will reopen a final time to sell its few tangible assets.
A public auction will offer computers, a telephone system and what a newspaper classified advertisement tersely called a "tremendous quantity very fine office furniture and equipment." 
 The sale is expected to raise only a couple hundred thousand dollars toward the estimated $4 million to $5 million in debts left when the agency, known for stylishly creative campaigns for products including Baileys Original Irish Cream liqueur and Jaguar cars, abruptly collapsed two months ago, throwing 55 people out of work.
The shop traced its history to a public relations agency founded by the owner Peter Geer's parents in 1935. But its sudden end more than half a century later offers a cautionary tale at a perilous time in the advertising industry.
"It isn't just another agency that failed to make it," said Doria Steedman, an 18-year employee who left before top executives decided on liquidation. "It was special; we walked taller and were prouder."
What crippled the agency, asserted Ms. Steedman, now an executive vice president at the Partnership for a Drug-Free America in New York, was that it "never moved from the 70's into the 90's" and failed to adapt to advertising's new realities. For instance, as Adweek noted in an article, "Death of an Agency," at a time when most agencies had cut back to staffing levels of one person for each $1 million in billings, Geer, DuBois at one point had 250 employees for its $120 million in billings.
Stephen G. Bowen Jr., who joined the agency in March 1992 as president and chief executive, said that agencies can no longer fool themselves into believing "that if the numbers don't look strong, next year will be better than this year."
"Frankly, the agency business in the last 30 years has been a go-go business," added Mr. Bowen, who is still thinking about what to do next in the wake of Geer, DuBois's closing. Given the industry's current "significant prolonged downturn," he continued, "if you have major account losses, you're dead -- and that's precisely what happened to Geer, DuBois."
Two months before Mr. Bowen arrived at the agency, its second-largest client, Brown & Williamson Tobacco, withdrew its estimated $30 million in billings. And not long after, Jaguar Cars Inc. took its estimated $20 million account to Ogilvy & Mather New York. The final blow was struck by the Paddington Corporation, which markets Baileys and other spirits brands; its decision to consolidate accounts at two other agencies meant Geer, DuBois would lose its largest remaining client and $13 million to $15 million in billings.
"The problems there were worse than I realized," Mr. Bowen said. "To keep the doors open without Paddington, I would have had to risk $2 million of personal money." So Mr. Geer and his lawyers decided to cease operations under a provision of New York State law known as an assignment for the benefit of creditors.
"I never believed it would go under," said Rodney Underwood, chairman and creative director, adding that after he turned down "three separate opportunities" to join other agencies during the final year, a friend told him " 'You're either a saint or an idiot.' "
"I don't think I was either one," Mr. Underwood continued, "but in the end I think I did the right thing." He and about 6 to 12 former Geer, DuBois colleagues are working out of an office at TBWA Advertising, completing work on campaigns for Geer, DuBois's last clients, which include the New York Zoological Society, the Northrop Corporation and Meridien Hotels.
Jerold R. Ruderman, a lawyer in White Plains who was assigned by the New York State Supreme Court to handle the Geer, DuBois liquidation, said that the 750 to 1,000 claims that he expected creditors to file were "massively in excess of the amount of money we will be taking in."
"It's kind of sad when you go down there," he added, referring to his visits to confer with Jackson Hecht Associates, the auctioneers preparing the former agency quarters on the 16th and 17th floors of 114 Fifth Avenue, between 16th and 17th Streets, for today's sale, which begins at 10:30 A.M.
Ms. Steedman said that she was "toying with attending the auction."
"Half of me wants to go and say goodbye," she added. "The other half says 'What the hell for?' "

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Weak Retail Sales Report Causes Decline in the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against most major foreign currencies in worldwide trading yesterday, driven lower by a weak United States retail sales report. But the dollar steadied against the Japanese yen.
Gold edged higher in New York after falling modestly in Europe and Asia. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery gained 70 cents a troy ounce to settle at $337.70. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $336.95 an ounce, up 45 cents from Monday. 
 Activity in the foreign exchange market in New York picked up from the slow pace of the Good Friday holiday. Many markets were closed Friday and Monday.
Dealers sold dollars in response to news that retail sales plunged 1 percent in March. The Commerce Department report raised doubts about the recovery's durability. Continuing economic weakness could cause interest rates to fall further, making the dollar a less attractive investment.
But heavy sales of the dollar in favor of the yen appeared to subside. Traders expect the dollar and yen to trade in a narrow range this week pending news from the meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan in Washington. The leaders are expected to discuss the economic stimulus package introduced in Tokyo, which has elements intended to help Japan trim its huge trade surplus with the United States.
A meeting of major industrialized countries over the weekend is also expected to yield some news on the yen-dollar relationship. The United States and other trading partners of Japan have advocated a stronger yen to combat trade imbalances.
The dollar closed in Tokyo at 113.33 yen, up 0.38 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 113.20 yen. In New York, the dollar finished the day at 113.40 yen, up from 112.80 yen late Monday.
The British pound rose to $1.5591 in London from $1.5251 late Thursday. Later in New York, sterling strengthened to $1.5580 from $1.5460 late Monday.
Late dollar rates in New York compared with Monday's late quotes included: 1.5820 German marks, down from 1.5945; 1.4475 Swiss francs, down from 1.4645

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
General Electric Co. (N)

 BODY:
The General Electric Company said yesterday that profits rose 9.6 percent in the first quarter, led by a strong performance at its financial unit, GE Capital Services. The unit's net income was up 22 percent in the quarter, compared with a year ago.
John F. Welch Jr., G.E.'s chairman, cited double-digit earnings gains in six of the company's 12 businesses -- NBC, appliances, locomotives, motors, power systems and plastics. But pretax profits were sharply lower in the aircraft engines unit. The drop was attributed to product-development costs and a charge for previously announced layoffs as orders dried up from airlines. 
 Analysts said the earnings exceeded estimates. "The productivity gains that G.E. has talked about are surfacing in the numbers," Mark Altman at Paine Webber Securities said. "It was a solid quarter."
G.E. said it continued to squeeze inventories and shorten development time in getting new products to customers. The appliance unit, for example, cut average inventories on hand by $400 million, Bruce Bunche, a spokesman, said.
Strong orders in March helped raise operating margins to 12 percent from 11.5 percent the year before as the American economy picked up, although some European businesses were weak. Lower programming and overhead costs in broadcasting and Super Bowl advertising helped NBC's results.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Fell Sharply In March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Consumers cut spending at retail counters by 1 percent in March, the biggest monthly decline in more than two years, the Commerce Department said today in a report that was considerably weaker than expected.
Although the midmonth blizzard that paralyzed much of the Northeast and South was widely acknowledged to have had an adverse impact, Government and private analysts said there was little doubt that the poor sales results also suggested a further slackening of economic growth. 
 Today's report also included a revision for February sales; a month ago, the department estimated they had risen by three-tenths of 1 percent, but today it said they had declined by that much.
"This is a rather disturbing report," Donald H. Straszheim, a top economist at Merrill Lynch, said, adding that the widespread nature of the declines indicated that the drop could not be entirely attributed to foul weather. Analysts had generally expected retail sales to remain unchanged for March after allowing for the usual seasonal and holiday variations.
The Clinton Administration pounced on the data to argue the urgency of its $16.3 billion economic stimulus package, bogged down in the Senate by Republican opposition.
The sales report, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown contended, "provides compelling evidence that recovery is at risk unless decisive action is taken when Congress returns next week."
Mr. Brown pointed out that retail sales, which account for one-third of economic activity, had not fallen for two straight months in almost two years and that sales, at a seasonally adjusted $166.9 billion in March, have slipped back to the lowest level since September.
Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, responded by accusing the Administration of a "snow job" in seeking to persuade the public that a weather-related sales decline could be dealt with through additional Government spending.
"If anything, consumers are getting more and more worried about being buried under a record-breaking blizzard of new taxes," Senator Dole said.
The retail sales report was the latest in a growing list of disappointing indicators on the economy. For example, income growth has largely disappeared, consumer confidence in the economy has fallen and the job market remains sluggish. Some analysts now think that first-quarter growth of gross domestic product, to be initially estimated by the Commerce Department on April 29, will be less than half the 4.7 percent annual pace recorded for the final three months of 1992.
"There has been a significant slowdown in the pace of recovery -- and that is troubling," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chief economic adviser to President Clinton, whose own G.D.P. estimate is "a little short of 3" percent for the quarter ended in March.
Today's report had scarcely any bright spots, private analysts said. Both long-lasting goods and nondurables posted hefty sales declines, and the 1 percent overall decline would have been even worse -- 1.2 percent -- had the sales decline at automotive dealers, which was four-tenths of 1 percent, been excluded.
Elsewhere in durable-goods sales, which were down nine-tenths of 1 percent, merchants selling furniture and other equipment for the home suffered a 2.3 percent decline while those selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes saw volume shrink 1.7 percent.
 
Drops in Most Nondurables
 Among nondurables sales, which were 1.1 percent lower than in February, there were falls of 1.8 percent for general merchandise stores and for gasoline service stations; falls of 1.6 percent for food stores and apparel outlets, and a six-tenths of 1 percent decline at restaurants and bars.
Drug and proprietary stores, however, posted a gain of five-tenths of 1 percent.
Some, but far from all, of the sales lost to severe weather will likely be recouped, analysts said. Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation, the largest trade group for the industry, noted that last month's sales were still 4.4 percent ahead of the March 1992 level. She said she was confident of improved sales this spring and summer.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Bush Admiral Tells Why He Helped Clinton

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

The Line of Fire
From Washington to the Gulf, the Politics and Battles of the New Military
By Adm. William J. Crowe Jr. with David Chanoff.
Illustrated. 367 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25.
From midshipman to Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the career of Adm. William J. Crowe Jr. spanned the cold war and included a few of the hot ones. Yet after the admiral's 47 years of military service, the present generation probably remembers him best as the retired admiral who served under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush at the Pentagon, then broke ranks and came out for Gov. Bill Clinton in last year's Presidential contest. 
 His autobiography, "The Line of Fire," written with David Chanoff, is not outspoken about the Commanders in Chief he worked for. (By being discreet, he may be making a silent statement of faint praise.) He does, however, call Dan Quayle "a creditable Vice President" but does not say why. By contrast, he is candid on his judgment of Mr. Clinton and why he decided to become his military adviser during the campaign.
"While I had had some occasional disagreements with the Bush Administration on specific national security issues (particularly the plan to abandon sanctions against Iraq and rush to military action before laying out long-term regional objectives)," he writes, "on the whole I was more than satisfied with the direction it had taken."
Once out of uniform, Admiral Crowe, who has a doctorate in politics from Princeton and is professor of geopolitics at the University of Oklahoma, found himself thinking more and more about the nation's economic and social problems. He writes:
"I was dismayed by our lack of a sensible industrial policy, by our educational failings and by the terrible divisiveness isolating so many citizens from the great American community that makes us a people rather than an assortment of factions. I found myself increasingly disturbed by the Republican Party's tendency to exclude certain groups from the mainstream of American life and exploit antagonisms within the society. It seemed to me that our economic and industrial deterioration had replaced superpower confrontation as the greatest threat to our national security."
In this respect, Admiral Crowe's position echoes what the independent Center for Defense Information, founded by Rear Adm. Gene R. La Rocque, retired, has been advocating in its publication, The Defense Monitor, for two decades: strong social, economic, political and military components and a healthy environment all contribute to American security.
Admiral Crowe was the senior adviser to the South Vietnamese Riverine Force in the Vietnam War. In one of the boldest statements in "The Line of Fire," he now writes that Vietnam was "a war in which neither America's survival nor its future was at stake." He deplored what he calls the Republican effort to shift the country's attention away from its pressing problems with "peripheral concerns, such as Bill Clinton's leanings during the Vietnam War some 25 years earlier."
So he decided to get involved in a political race for the first time. He writes that Governor Clinton struck him as the candidate best able to shake off "the inertia of cold war habits" and address the challenges of a vastly different world. During military briefings, he says, he found that Governor Clinton had a powerful and retentive mind and that contrary to some views, he was not antimilitary. As he got to know him more intimately during the campaign, he said, he found Governor Clinton's feeling for people obviously genuine: "I would call him a humanist."
Disappointingly, Admiral Crowe ducks any comment on the current ethnic, religious, political and historical war in the Balkans. He doesn't discuss what role, if any, he and high-ranking Pentagon officers think the United States should play there. His views about the new-old Balkan tinderbox would be valuable. As chairman of President Clinton's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, the author obviously knows a great deal more than he is willing to commit to paper about that volatile situation.
The most revealing sections in "The Line of Fire" concern Admiral Crowe's encounters with his Russian counterpart, Marshall Sergei F. Akhromeyev, who was Chief of Staff of the Soviet armed forces under Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The gruff Soviet World War II commander and the polished American admiral and their wives became good friends. Both men had seen enough of shooting wars and sought treaties to avoid a nuclear conflict.
On his own, Admiral Crowe decided to open a military-to-military dialogue with the Soviets. Ignoring some official opposition, he showed Marshall Akhromeyev the Pentagon's nerve center and the latest American aircraft carrier, followed by a warm visit to Oklahoma, Admiral Crowe's home state. Thereafter, Admiral Crowe inspected Soviet military installations. Later, disillusioned with the state of affairs in the former Soviet Union, Marshall Akhromeyev killed himself. "I admired him," Admiral Crowe writes. "He was a significant figure in creating the breakthrough that ended the cold war. But like Gorbachev himself, he never had in mind the final denouement."
Admiral Crowe rightfully considers the American-Soviet military exchanges that he initiated to be his major contribution to spiking the guns; his inside details make for interesting reading. In "The Line of Fire," he emerges as an admirable diplomat in uniform, a peacetime warrior in the Pentagon.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Plan Is Afoot to Shift OTB Regulation

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
The chairman of the commission looking into the future of racing in New York State said yesterday that the group was concentrating on a plan to put racing in the hands of a corporation, a regulated monopoly that would also run offtrack betting in New York City, but not elsewhere in the state, at least for a while.
"We would hope that the others would eventually come aboard," said Vincent Tese, who heads the nine-member Advisory Commission on Racing in the 21st Century. It was appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last fall to look into a possible restructuring of racing after the year 2000, when the New York Racing Association's franchise to operate the state's three major tracks expires. 
 Since then, the N.Y.R.A., a private, nonprofit group that has been sharply criticized by the Governor, has put forth its own plan to absorb the state's six regional offtrack betting corporations.
 
Report Is Due June 1
 Tese, who also serves as the state's director of economic development, stressed that he was speaking only for himself. The commission's report is due June 1, and Tese suggested that the plan he outlined would meet the key political reality test, acceptance by the Governor and the New York State Legislature.
He said, for example, that the five offtrack betting operations outside New York City would most likely not be included in the plan simply because they had been so outspokenly hostile to a merger and had the political clout to block one.
As outlined by Tese, under the "very, very preliminary plan" being considered by the commission, a publicly owned corporation would eventually take over the operations of the tracks and the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, but only after a transition arrangement of two or three years.
During the transition, a restructured N.Y.R.A. would run both the tracks and the city's offtrack betting operations.
 
Questions Are Raised
 Tese did not say how the N.Y.R.A. would be restructured, and the two-stage plan raises a double-edged question: Why could a revamped association be expected to do any better than the original, and if it could, why would it not simply continue to run the operation?
For one thing, Tese suggested, the combination of racing and offtrack betting, which has wide support, would give the transition group the resources it needs to improve.
Selling the operations to private investors, once the transition management has enhanced racing's value, would mean windfalls for both the state and city.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Uniquely Perilous

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Life over the course of the last half-century has been confusing for those people who manufacture and sell cigarettes. Their product went from being an accepted part of daily life to a suspected carcinogen to the most reviled legal substance in America.
But now their position should be quite clear. Tobacco companies fall into a separate and distinct category of business because they produce and market a product that has no redeeming value and that causes serious illness and death. 
 Five years ago, when the American Bar Association considered -- and rejected -- a proposal that it endorse a ban on all tobacco advertising, one member described cigarettes as "uniquely perilous." Our national policies should reflect that: not just our health policies, but our fiscal policies as well.
One of the most interesting of these is the plan to cut or entirely eliminate the tax deductions tobacco companies receive for the cost of their advertising. Senator Tom Harkin, who wants to cut the deductions and use the revenues for both deficit reduction and counteradvertising, says that taxpayers are unaware that such deductions even exist. But the fact is that cigarette companies spend billions of dollars each year to advertise and promote their products, and take a huge deduction for those costs.
Tobacco company executives insist they use advertising only to get smokers to switch from one brand to another and not to snag new younger consumers to replace those who have died untimely deaths. Of course, these are the same people who not so long ago wanted you to believe that there was no link between lung disease and smoking. Veracity is not their brand name.
But they are savvy, and in the debate about tobacco advertising they push a genuine American hot button, that of free speech. The tobacco companies even have the American Civil Liberties Union on their side. (It should be noted that the A.C.L.U. has accepted contributions from cigarette manufacturers, which the organization insists has no bearing on this issue.)
Ira Glasser, the A.C.L.U.'s executive director, says it's simply wrong to provide business deductions for some businesses but to exempt others because you do not like the product. "You can't pick and choose," he says. "You can't make a distinction based on what is produced."
Sure you can. Government is in the business of making distinctions, between the income taxes paid by those who earn $30,000 a year and those who earn $300,000, between how a company can dispose of garbage and how it can dispose of toxic wastes. By instituting so-called sin taxes on alcohol and tobacco, it surely makes a distinction between products it considers dangerous luxuries and all others.
Mr. Glasser says that this is a slippery slope, that red meat and eggs could be next. But you can argue that those foods have clear benefits if eaten in moderation. No one argues that there is any benefit to tobacco use except to the tobacco companies, who are among the most profitable industries in America.
In recent years members of the Senate have voted down proposals to eliminate tax deductions for cigarette advertising costs, often invoking the free speech argument. But the cause is more likely the millions of dollars tobacco companies give in political contributions. "They have a right to free speech," says Senator Bill Bradley, who has led efforts to eliminate deductions for cigarette advertising. "They do not have a constitutional right to a tax deduction."
So many of our antismoking efforts have focused on the individual consumers, proposing taxes on their single packs while the companies grow ever richer. Restaurant sections, smoke-free offices, sin taxes -- they've all focused on the little guy. That's always easier than taking on the corporations.
Sure, smokers have made personal choices. And they pay for those choices every day, whether sitting through an airline flight dying for a smoke, or dying for a smoke in the oncology wing of a hospital. The tobacco companies have not paid nearly enough for the killing, and that is because we have too often treated them like everyone else. Their product is "uniquely perilous" and should be given unique stature -- or lack of same.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
